fields.headline: Averis sinks soggy Warwickshire
fields.standfirst: Warwickshire 94 Gloucestershire 96-5 Gloucestershire won by 5 wickets
fields.trailText: Warwickshire 94 Gloucestershire 96-5 Gloucestershire won by 5 wickets
fields.body:
It was a good thing the main scoreboard here had leaked water overnight, putting it out of action for the duration. For batsmen of both sides the news it would have broadcast in digital splendour, being mostly of the single-digit persuasion, was scarcely worth publicising.

However, the end amply justified the means for Gloucestershire, who dispatched Warwickshire for their most ignominious total in 28 seasons of B&H endeavour, then overcame a nervy start against Allan Donald and Ed Giddins to prevail with nearly 22 overs to spare.

Having lost to Glamorgan off the penultimate ball on Saturday, the defending champions - if one can so dignify last season's Trades Description Act-defying Super Cup - bounced back spiritedly, aided by a pitch as conducive to strokes as an empty pool.

From the opening over, when Neil Smith was caught behind slashing at his namesake Mike - the first of five scalps for the ageless Jack Russell - it became abundantly clear that only those prepared to graft would prosper for long.

Only Trevor Penney and Dominic Hewson were able to get beyond 20, Hewson scaling the giddy heights of 30 with the decisive boundary.

James Averis, maintaining the form he showed on Gloucestershire's pre-season tour of South Africa and complemented by his fielders' customary gymnastics, was the main tormentor and a deserving man of the match with his tally of four for eight.

Generating movement aplenty from an economical approach, the 24-year-old bowled David Hemp in an opening spell which yielded only five runs in six overs, then returned to nail three more victims as the last four wickets seeped away in 13 balls.

Donald's first contribution was a drive at Averis's slower ball; there was sufficient time for him to have a second bash before his timbers were shivered. Nor did his day improve. He began with a pointless bouncer, donated nine wides in all, and played a distant second fiddle to Giddins, who discomfited all and sundry to pick up three wickets for 22 while his more illustrious partner emerged empty-handed and full of ire.

The most substantial stand came courtesy of Hewson and the debutant Chris Taylor, who made a triple hundred for the second XI last summer and set off here by easing Donald for an off-driven four as classical as it was impudent. Northants, who visit Edgbaston tomorrow, have every reason to fear reprisals.

webTitle: Hussain wants life ban for match fixers

fields.headline: Hussain wants life ban for match fixers
fields.trailText: Nasser Hussain yesterday called for anyone involved in match fixing or taking money for supplying information to bookmakers to be banned from cricket for life.
fields.body:
Nasser Hussain yesterday called for anyone involved in match fixing or taking money for supplying information to bookmakers to be banned from cricket for life.

Hussain's words came on the same day that Chris Lewis, the Leicestershire and former England all-rounder, made claims that an unnamed trio, all of whom have played regularly for England sides in the past four years, have been paid "thousands" to rig matches.

Only last summer Lewis told the England and Wales Cricket Board that he had been promised £300,000 by an Indian sports agent to fix a match against New Zealand by offering the wicketkeeper-batsman Alec Stewart and the pace bowler Alan Mullally similar amounts to drop catches and bowl wide.

Lewis said then that he had refused the deal out of hand, and immediately reported the matter to the ECB, which contacted the police.

The New Zealand captain Stephen Fleming was also approached before the final Test last August, and he reported the incident to the International Cricket Council. A police investigation has since been in progress on both counts.

Lewis says now that the agent had also told him of the involvement of the three players, each of them a household name. "I almost fell off my chair with shock when he told me who they were," Lewis said yesterday.

He also explained why he had failed to disclose this at the time of his original allegations, saying that he feared not only for his career but for his life. "If I had helped to smash a multimillion-dollar betting ring I don't think they would be happy with me, do you?"

The ECB and police must now decide whether there is substance to the fresh allegations or whether the names were given to Lewis as a hook to secure his involvement. Certainly the authorities need the names of the three at the centre of the allegations so that they can be investigated and charged or cleared.

The one certain thing to emerge in the wake of the Hansie Cronje disclosures over the past week has been that no one can afford to take anything for granted any more, no matter how improbable it may seem.

Hussain, the England captain, said that he had been left "dumbfounded" by the allegations but said that he felt there was now a chance for cricket to clear the air and settle the allegations once and for all.

"The whole truth must come out, that's for sure," he said. "This is a good opportunity for cricket to get its house in order. The rules must be absolutely clear and stringent. If anyone takes money from bookmakers, even if it is just a comparatively small amount for what they feel is innocuous information, then they should be gone from the game. Anyone involved in this, and they would have to be pretty stupid to get involved after this affair, has no place in our game."

fields.headline: Nationwide Third Division
fields.trailText: Howard's way
fields.body:
Howard's way

Northampton were the only side in the top five to win, ending Darlington's unbeaten home record with a 1-0 win at Feethams. Steve Howard scored the decisive goal after five minutes to lift Town to three points behind third-placed Darlington.

 Rotherham continue to lead the division but managed only a 1-1 draw at Brighton. The Seagulls, who are now unbeaten in 10 games, took the lead through Paul Watson in the 24th minute. Steve Thompson equalised for the visitors eight minutes later.

 The Millers' advantage at the top of the table actually increased by one point after Swansea were unable to end Plymouth's unbeaten home record. Adam Barrett ensured that Plymouth remain in the frame for the play-offs.

 Cheltenham's play-off hopes were rocked by York, who are unbeaten in the seven games since Terry Dolan took charge.

 Shrewsbury's 4-2 defeat by Rochdale, their 12th match without a win, saw them swap places with Chester at the bottom. "If we don't pick ourselves up I'm afraid it's bye-bye to league football," said Shrewsbury's manager Kevin Ratcliffe. It was no consolation that Gay Meadow's second biggest crowd of the season witnessed the defeat.

 Chester moved off the bottom with victory at Leyton Orient, and Carlisle are not yet safe after their ninth home defeat of the season, 1-0 against Macclesfield.

fields.headline: Nationwide Second Division
fields.trailText: Second Division round-up
fields.body:
Harris heroics

Millwall moved ahead of Bristol Rovers into third place and level on points with second-placed Wigan with a 3-1 win at Brentford. Neil Harris scored his first league hat-trick after Brentford's Italian Lorenzo Pinamonte had given his side the lead in the fourth minute.

Harris's feat made him the first Millwall player since Teddy Sheringham in 1991 to hit 20 goals in a season.

 Gillingham celebrated the opening of their new main stand with a 2-1 victory over Wigan. Goals in each half from Iffy Onuora and Junior Lewis lifted them into sixth place.

 Burnley kept up their hopes of automatic promotion with a 2-1 win at Oxford, Paul Weller scoring the winner in the 90th minute. Matt Murphy gave Oxford a 13th-minute lead only for Steve Davis to equalise five minutes from time.

 Steve McMahon's Blackpool side moved closer to relegation with home defeat by Scunthorpe. "I am deflated, my players are deflated," McMahon said. "Believe it or not we do all work hard in training. I know it doesn't look like that on the pitch."

 Cambridge eased their worries with a 4-0 win at Cardiff. John Taylor, United's striker who had hit only five goals previously in the season, scored a hat-trick.

 Baichung Bhutia became the first Indian to score a goal in the English league by giving Bury the lead against bottom-placed Chesterfield. The visitors equalised 15 minutes from time.

fields.headline: Nationwide First Division
fields.trailText: First Division round-up
fields.body:
Baggies bananas

Gary Megson blamed dreadful defending for relegation-threatened West Brom's failure to win at the Hawthorns despite taking the lead three times in their 4-4 draw with Bolton.

"We cut our own throats," said the Baggies manager. "It's not a lack of players. We are where we are in the table because of utter neglect, and it makes you go bananas."

 The Wolves manager Colin Lee outlined his need for new players after the club's former striker Iwan Roberts gave Norwich a 1-0 home win which dented Wolves' play-off hopes.

"Our strength in depth is not good enough and my job during the summer is to bring in quality players to help build up our squad to cope with the absences of certain players," he said. "If I don't we'll probably stay around the area we are right now."

webTitle: Fun-loving Fergie can afford a smile

fields.headline: Fun-loving Fergie can afford a smile
fields.trailText: Roy Collins has already crowned Manchester United as this year's Champions (really!? we hear you say)
fields.body:
Had Manchester United lost to Sunderland after naming David Beckham, Ryan Giggs, Dwight Yorke and Andy Cole only as substitutes, the FA might have felt compelled to use their rarely invoked rule against clubs deliberately fielding understrength sides. Even having won so handily that the charge would have been ludicrous, United should feel grateful that the FA is unable to prosecute managers for taking the mickey.

It is one thing for Ferguson to bring Ole Gunnar Solskjaer off the bench or, as on Saturday, to give him a starting slot (and be rewarded with a goal in two minutes). But purely to amuse himself Ferguson brought off his £10m centre-half Jaap Stam 11 minutes into the second half and threw on Henning Berg. And what happened? Berg, who had gone two years and 78 games since his only other goal for United, took only 14 minutes to score his side's fourth and final goal.

With the game reduced to about 20 seconds of highlights on the BBC's Match Of The Day, I even thought the United goalkeeper Mark Bosnich had been cheekily replaced at half-time to ensure his fitness to face Real Madrid on Wednesday. But he, at least, was genuinely injured.

Ferguson, whose team have already set a Premiership goals record and may yet eclipse Everton's record title-winning margin of 13 points in 1985 - achieved in a 22-team top division - could be justified in declaring his side the best in United's history. But it is also true that the opposition has been more pathetic than that ranged against Ken Livingstone for London mayor. The rejuvenated Liverpool at least managed to continue their run of consistency by winning at Wimbledon. But even if they beat Everton at Goodison on Friday, it is likely only to delay United's coronation until Easter Monday when, traditionally, the championship should be just coming to the boil.

In the past two seasons, the intensity of the rivalry between Arsenal and Manchester United has seen the title decided only on the season's final day. But despite their brilliant 4-0 win at Leeds yesterday, Arsenal have already lost eight games this season, twice as many as last.

Chelsea, who would be rubbing shoulders with United at the top if they could only speak Premiership English as fluently as Italian and Spanish, lost their seventh league match of the season at Sheffield Wednesday. And poor, sad Leeds were suffering their 11th defeat of the season against Arsenal.

Leeds' young players have simply run themselves into the ground this season and their manager David O'Leary has no one like Solskjaer or Berg to bring in to "freshen up the side" as Ferguson describes replacing one superstar with another. It is more convincing evidence that the Premiership is several small leagues within a league. Liverpool, Arsenal, Chelsea and Leeds strive for a Champions League place while below them are a gaggle of six or seven clubs hoping to get to Europe in steerage class by winning a domestic cup.

Further down the league ladder are clubs like Coventry, Southampton and Wimbledon, who begin every season with the sole ambition of staying in the division. Last of all come the newly promoted clubs who, with a few minor exceptions, accept their role as mere tourists in the Premiership.

This year, it has to be admitted, United have formed a league of their own at the apex of this class structure. If Liverpool fail at Goodison, they could retain their title as early as Saturday at Southampton. And as well as their hosts' manager Glenn Hoddle has done since officially joining the Saints (sic), one cannot see United slipping up, even if Sir Alex sends out a full reserve team in grey shirts.

fields.headline: Barcelona humbled
fields.trailText: Barcelona prepared for their Champions League quarter- final second leg with Chelsea tomorrow in the worst way, suffering their third consecutive 3-0 defeat, at Real Oviedo. Patrick Kluivert was left out in a rift with the Catalan club's manager Louis van Gaal.
fields.body:
Barcelona prepared for their Champions League quarter- final second leg with Chelsea tomorrow in the worst way, suffering their third consecutive 3-0 defeat, at Real Oviedo. Patrick Kluivert was left out in a rift with the Catalan club's manager Louis van Gaal.

Manchester United's midweek opponents Real Madrid beat Real Zaragoza 1-0, and their city rivals Atletico drew 2-2 with Malaga after the former Leeds striker Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink missed a penalty and was sent off.

Galatasaray, who face Leeds on Thursday, were held 1-1 at Besiktas. A 29-year-old fan was stabbed to death after watching the local derby in an Istanbul bar. Arsenal's Uefa Cup opponents Lens lost 4-1 at Paris St-Germain.

Monaco celebrated a seventh French title after drawing at home to Nancy, but in the Netherlands PSV kept the champagne on ice despite a 12-point lead over Heerenveen with four games to play and a goal difference superior by 46.

Darko Kovacevic scored both goals in a 2-1 win over Internazionale to extend Juventus's lead over Lazio, held 3-3 at Fiorentina, to five points at the top of Serie A.

fields.headline: Wright's escape to victory
fields.standfirst: First Division Battle for promotion intensifies as Ipswich put pressure on their big-City rivals
fields.trailText: Stockport 0 - 1 Ipswich
fields.body:
Ipswich can be forgiven for thinking that promotion from the First Division is akin to escaping from Devil's Island. For three years running, the shark-infested waters of the play-offs have proved their undoing.

But with a few more weeks' good conduct, the Ipswich manager George Burley calculates, the parole board must be merciful this time. "We have four games left," he smiled. "Win all four and I believe we will finish in second place."

Whether the frayed nerves of the Ipswich supporters could cope with another tilt at the play-offs is debatable. But it could yet prove to be their only route, such is the intensity of activity among the rival escape committees at Manchester City and Barnsley.

The purists will tell you that the Ipswich style is well suited to the Premiership. Perhaps that was why it was not so well suited to the spartan surroundings of Edgeley Park.

A clinically taken goal by their leading scorer, the much-admired David Johnson, did the damage just before half-time. Yet Burley's boys made heavy weather of it after that, and it was largely thanks to the immaculate Richard Wright in goal that they hung on for the three points.

Wright is now being viewed as the long-term successor to England No1 David Seaman. In the meantime, however, his only target is to make it into the Premiership with his hometown club.

The 22-year-old goalkeeper will almost certainly sign a new deal at Portman Road should Ipswich make it into the top flight.

"I think I can achieve things in the Premiership with Ipswich," he said. "Perhaps it would be nice to be remembered as one of the club's all-time greats."

Wright's second-half reflex save from Ian Lawson's point-blank header was absolutely stunning. "He just came out of nowhere," the County manager Andy Kilner marvelled. "I don't know how he did it."

Johnson's 19th of the season was tucked away with aplomb after a flick-on by James Scowcroft. Stockport rallied after the break but, with Wright in such exceptional form, they were unable to put an end to their miserable record of 18 games without a win.

For Ipswich, the tension continues to mount. As a club with inherent finesse, they long to be part of the big picture once more. All they need now is the Great Escape.

Remaining games: Stockport: Apr 22 Crewe (a); Apr 24 Swindon (h); Apr 29 Huddersfield (a); May 7 Nottingham Forest (h)

Ipswich: Apr 22 QPR (a); Apr 24 Crystal Palace (a); Apr 29 Charlton (a); May 7 Walsall (h)

webTitle: Thorne caps winning tribute to Sir Stan

fields.headline: Thorne caps winning tribute to Sir Stan
fields.trailText: Stoke 2 - 1 Bristol City
fields.body:
A banner showing the smiling features of the late, great Sir Stanley Matthews looked down upon the Stoke players as they received the Auto Windscreens Shield yesterday. It was a reminder of the club's illustrious past and a reminder also that life goes on and that for Stoke it goes forward under the enlightened guidance of Icelander Gudjon Thordarson.

This was the first time a Scandinavian coach had got his hands on a trophy at Wembley. The Premiership has long been the preserve of Scotsmen apart from the lone Gallic intrusion and now even the minor honours in the game are going to managers from outside the country.

It is a sign of the changing face of football though the winning goal, scored eight minutes from time, was the property of Peter Thorne, who hails from Manchester.

It was Bjarni Gudjonsson, the manager's son, who had seized the moment of Bristol City's protest following a foul to take a quick free-kick and set up the chance. With two other Icelanders in the Stoke side the Viking invasion has a secure hold in the Potteries.

For father more than son the victory realised a long held dream. "When I was the national coach in my country I always wanted to bring a team to play at Wembley," said Thordarson. "I used to watch the draws for the World Cup and European Championship and hope we would be paired with England but it never happened. So when I came to Stoke and saw this final was at Wembley I thought this might be my opportunity."

His team made his day because they possessed the knack of scoring just after Bristol City had come desperately close themselves . Their first, on the half-hour, was the result of a vicious drive from Graham Kavanagh, who in recent seasons has been the driving force behind Stoke and who fully deserved his man of the match laurels. He believes this triumph will inspire the red stripes to return here next month in the Second Division play-off.

Kavanagh weaved his way past two defenders - like Matthews someone said, though the Irishman laughed off that suggestion - before drilling a shot inside Billy Mercer's near post. It was where Aaron Brown should have placed his attempt five minutes before when Brian Tinnion sent him racing clear but he chose to go across goal and Gavin Ward was able to block.

The game got off to an event ful start and remained exciting all the way through. Bristol City came on strong in the second half and first Paul Holland and then Scott Murray, who was also unlucky not to earn a penalty when seemingly fouled by Clive Clarke a minute after the restart, demanded the best from the goalkeeper. Both league meetings had ended as draws and the long-promised equaliser arrived in the 74th minute.

Tinnion's corner reached Holland and although his header may not have gone in, a slight deflection off the Bris tol substitute Damien Spencer ensured that it did. Shortly afterwards an accurate centre struck on the run by Tony Thorpe gave the 18-year-old Spencer a glorious opening but, frozen by the responsibility, he miscued badly.

It followed a foul by Louis Carey on Gudjonsson and the Bristol City manager Tony Fawthrop complained bitterly that the referee Kevin Lynch was still ticking off his defender when the free-kick was taken. Yet it seemed more a case of a player's protest than a refereeing lecture and Stoke were clearly given the signal to get on with things. In a flash Gudjonsson had rolled the ball to Kavanagh,who clipped it expertly across the area for Thorne to nudge in and score the most valuable of this season's 22-goal haul which includes 14 in his last 11 appearances.

And that was it. The huge exodus from Stoke gave one more lusty rendition of their anthem Delilah and offered another silent prayer to Sir Stan before heading for home. They have reason to believe their club is also on the move once more.

webTitle: Rovers get the yips as Preston maintain upward pressure

fields.headline: Rovers get the yips as Preston maintain upward pressure
fields.trailText: Bristol Rovers 0 - 2 Preston
fields.byline: Jeremy Alexander  at the Memorial Stadium
fields.body:
This may have been football's first night-day match. It began under floodlights and ended in sun. But the sun shone only for Preston, now eight points clear at the top, with 12 to play for.

Night continues for Rovers, top a month ago but suddenly anxious about the play-offs after two points out of 18. Ian Holloway said: "We're on the crest of a slump but you won't get me criticising the players." He sounded like a manager desperately seeing a prize slip from his grasp, a dream turn to a nightmare. He felt "like I've been mugged".

In fact Rovers are mugging themselves with blown confidence. Holloway sent them off for golf last week to rediscover it. They came back shanking and slicing as Preston stuck to the fairway. "We didn't create enough down the flanks and, when we did, there was not enough in the centre," he said. It hardly mattered what was in the centre. All their crosses were noughts, mainly slewed for goal-kicks. It could have been the rugby XV on parade.

Holloway tried various patterns, as if he was into feng shui, but they came to the same thing, mostly bang and bin, for all David Hillier's attempts to create a passing harmony.

In such conditions the lines that count are led from the back. Michael Jackson was superb for Preston, leading by example, holding the shape four-square on a skidpan, absorbing pressure and rain and judging interceptions with uncanny command - Stonewall Jackson himself. Though they had scored only three goals in six games, Preston have conceded one in seven. They have lost only twice away in 21 games, conceding 12 goals.

David Moyes said "nothing pleases a manager more than seeing his centre-forwards making goals for each other". It was less direct than that. Bjarki Gunnlaugsson set up Paul McKenna, whose shot came back off a post for Jonathan Macken to snap home his 22nd league goal of the season.

Then from Macken's cross the Icelander whipped in his first league goal since arriving in October. Michael Appleton was the inspiration, with a backheel to Macken, then a dummy over the cross. He, Macken and Colin Murdock joined Preston for £1m from Old Trafford. It speaks for itself.

It was tough on Lee Jones. Sometimes a goalkeeper's life is not unlike an anaesthetist's: 98% boredom and 2% panic. Tepi Moilanen's was quieter still as he kept his 21st clean sheet in 37 games. At the final whistle he was not even threatened by Rovers fans.

Remaining games: Bristol Rovers: Apr 22 Bristol City (h); Apr 24 Blackpool (a); Apr 29 Bournemouth (h); May 6 Cardiff (a)

Preston: Apr 22 Scunthorpe (h); Apr 24 Cambridge (a); Apr 29 Millwall (h); May 6 Bristol City (a)

webTitle: Hands-on heartbreak as Barnsley pay the penalty

fields.headline: Hands-on heartbreak as Barnsley pay the penalty
fields.trailText: Port Vale 2 - 2 Barnsley
fields.body:
Imagine the scene. You are a promising defender in a team with a strong chance of reaching the Premiership. You lead 2-1 in the final minute of one of your last matches, on course to move within a point of an automatic promotion spot. You go to close down the opposition's winger as he tees up a cross in what looks like their last attack.

Does anyone, apart from the referee Paul Taylor believe Barnsley's Chris Morgan would deliberately handle the ball in his own area? As he was about six yards from the ball as it was crossed, it is unlikely he would have had time to decide to handle it, even if there were an advantage to be gained from doing so.

But Taylor pointed to the penalty spot, from where Tommy Widdrington scored a goal that may have grave implications for Barnsley's ambitions.

"Chris is devastated," said Barnsley's midfielder Robin van der Laan. "We're all very supportive of him because he just couldn't get out of the way. He's throwing bottles around in the changing room."

Barnsley's manager Dave Bassett said: "Even the Port Vale players looked astonished. Clubs live or die by decisions like that," he said.

Port Vale looked good value when Sagi Burton headed them into a ninth-minute lead but they lost heart after Craig Hignett equalised and set up a second for John Curtis.

The relegation-haunted Vale manager Brian Horton said: "It's a tall order but we're going to keep going until it's mathematically impossible."

fields.headline: Forest continue to haunt Francis
fields.trailText: Birmingham 0 - 1 Nott Forest
fields.body:
Trevor Francis enjoyed some of the sweetest moments of his playing days with Nottingham Forest, not least scoring the goal that won the European Cup in 1979. As Birmingham's manager, however, he must wish that Forest would stop dogging his path.

Having ruined his Christmas by winning at the City Ground in December, Forest have now put the kibosh on his Easter by becoming the first side to complete the double over his side this season. Indeed it was City's 11th defeat in a row by Forest, but it should do them little lasting damage; with Wolves losing at Norwich they have lost no ground in the race for a play-off place.

But what may cost them dear if, as expected, they do make the top six is a failure to accept chances. They were at it again on Saturday: Andrew Johnson, Paul Furlong and Dele Adebola all missed gilt-edged opportunities before Marcelo was pitched into the action in an attempt to salvage a point.

The Brazilian's introduction meant City finished with three strikers on the field but, as Francis agreed, quantity did not equal incisiveness in front of goal. "We had numerous opportunities but just did not cash in," he said. "Most of the forwards had good chances."

It is an all too familiar story which extends back beyond the six matches since the on-loan Isaiah Rankin was the last striker to score for City. The last player to score 25 in a season for them was Steve Claridge in the Second Division in 1994-95; before that it was Francis himself.

A 25-goals-a-season striker would surely represent the difference between another nerve-jangling play-off campaign and automatic promotion. "If we'd had Lee Hughes in our side last season we'd be in the Premiership already," Francis has said of West Brom's prolific goalscorer. "We've been very dependent on players outside of forward areas to score."

Remarkably 17 players have contributed and it was a defender, Gary Rowett, who went closest on Saturday with a header, but Dave Beasant rolled back many of his 41 years to execute a spectacular diving save.

Instead Darren Purse was on target, albeit the wrong one, when an attempt to head clear an inswinging free-kick from Chris Bart-Williams resulted in the own-goal. That also meant that Forest are as good as safe from relegation but it was a win blighted by Colin Calderwood breaking a leg, an injury which at 35 must put his career in jeopardy.

Remaining matches: Birmingham City: Apr 22 Crystal Palace (a); Apr 24 Walsall (h); Apr 29 Manchester City (a); May 7 Grimsby (h).

Nottingham Forest: Apr 22 Sheffield United (h); Apr 24 Fulham (a); Apr 29 Port Vale (h); May 7 Stockport County (a).

fields.headline: City take classic hard route
fields.trailText: Grimsby 1 - 1 Man City
fields.body:
Manchester City secured a place in the play-offs with one of their worst performances of the season and are presumably now hoping to play badly enough in the remaining four games to claim automatic promotion.

They will climb into the Premiership with a second successive promotion under Joe Royle if they win their final matches but, on the evidence of this performance, it could be more complicated, which is the City way.

The centre-back Richard Jobson accepts their fans will have to cope with a few anxiety attacks: "We've missed a chance and we're going to have to do it the hard way; it's going to go to the wire now," he said. "It will go right to the last game but we can't complain, we're a point clear in second place with a home game against Tranmere next.

"We just didn't play well but we're unbeaten in seven and if we stay unbeaten we must have a great chance. If the fans get behind us, we can get another good win under our belts."

Jobson and his partner Spencer Prior held City together - and combined for the goal - in a puzzlingly poor team performance that he could not explain: "It's disappointing. We've scored early and taken our foot off the pedal, as we've done a few times this season. Maybe it's because people raise their game against us. That's been the case a lot and we've got to live with it."

City failed to perform, though they did ride their luck impressively and Royle admitted: "We scored and switched off. I don't know why - it's not an exact science. If it was we'd all be top of the league. It could be the jolt we need."

Grimsby's substitute Steve Livingstone bungled the game's easiest chance and the referee David Laws declined to penalise Danny Tiatto as he brought down Kevin Donovan, which left he home manager Alan Buckley unimpressed: "Donovan was through and he's not going to just fall over, is he? Things like that get us angry. I'm more disappointed with the point than Joe," he said.

Prior gave City a sixth-minute lead but midfielder Alan Pouton ended 627 minutes without a Grimsby goal by equalising to take them almost clear of relegation worries despite not winning in seven matches.

Remaining games: Man City: Apr 22 Tranmere (h); Apr 24 Portsmouth (a); April 28 Birmingham (h); May 7 Blackburn (a).

Grimsby: Apr 22 Blackburn (h); Apr 24 West Brom (a); Apr 29 Tranmere (h); May 7 Birmingham (a).

fields.headline: Police, Permanent regrowth, and Power
fields.trailText: TURKS TO INVESTIGATE POLICE OVER ISTANBUL VIOLENCE
fields.body:
TURKS TO INVESTIGATE POLICE OVER ISTANBUL VIOLENCE

The Turkish government have launched an investigation into the actions of police during clashes in which two British football supporters were fatally stabbed. "The security forces are investigating this event internally. The report will be put on my desk and the necessary will be done to whomever did not do their duty," said Interior Minister Saadettin Tantan earlier today.

But he told the Radikal newspaper that policing such running street battles was difficult. "It is not easy to decide who is guilty or the victim in that chaos," he said. Newspapers have criticised police for failing to prevent the clashes, which had reportedly been brewing for several hours.

Tantam also revealed that Galatasaray will be accompanied by an 11-member anti-terrorist squad when they travel to Leeds later this week. Ercument Yilmaz, Istanbul's deputy police chief, is quoted in the Turkish press as saying: "After being officially assigned, we would protect Galatasaray better than the English - no one should doubt about that."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

IT'S JUST LIKE A LITTLE HARRY HILL!

Enter First Direct's Little Fella Challenge and you could win a VW Beetle or Sony Wega Widescreen TV.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

GINGER-GATE

What the hell is going on with John Hartson's hair? The Fiver's worst player of the year 1999 has been engulfed in controversy this weekend after a high-profile advertising campaign involving his ginger barnet was banned by the Advertising Standards Authority.

According to a complaint from rival company Skolas Reform Clinics, Advanced Hair Studios falsely claimed that their 'ADVANCED laser therapy' had restored Hartson's hair. A Skolas representative had seen John Hartson in the flesh you see (he must work in the Dons' treatment room) and was convinced the Welshman was showing no hairy benefits from his treatment. Hartson's before and after photos, they insisted, must have been fake.

Not so, said the ASA, who ruled the pics were genuine (even the one with Hartson wearing a ginormous metal egg on his head). But further investigation led them to rule against the ad for different reasons, namely the use of the word 'regrow'. "Because the advertisers had not sent clinical evidence that proved their treatments could regrow hair," wrote the ASA in their adjudication, "they were asked to remove the claim".

So what in heck is going on on John's scalp? Amidst fears that Hartson's head is being used as a guinea pig (to which it has always borne a resemblance), the Fiver desperately tried to contact AHS today. But we were told the only man who knows the secret of the treatment is the company chairman, and he's in Australia. Skolas' mysterious Hartson spotter has also disappeared. Wimbledon too are silent on the matter, their only comment being to laugh at the Fiver's promise to "get to the roots of the problem". Which we will.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We are trying to catch up [with United] and the first thing we can try to do is catch up on the field." Cos let's face it, you'll never catch them in traffic. Gerard Houllier, playing the 'umble card.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ALL HAIL FERG THE CONQUEROR

Since the collapse of the Roman Empire, only a handful of leaders have possessed the necessary strength in depth, tactical acumen and puritanical zeal to truly dominate European competition. In the 12th century Genghis Khan made a decent stab at it, as did Napoleon and Hitler. Now in this new millennium we hear of another man, strong of mouth and fierce of temper, who casts his eyes on our fair continent and craves an empire which will last a thousand years.

That man is the Lord Imperial Ferg. "This may be a golden period for Manchester United, so we've got to take advantage because it may never come again" he thundered earlier today. "We've got to set our standards by the big European winners. Then we'll find out where we rank as a great European club." Fergie then bizarrely warned his players what would happen in the bedroom if their determination slackened. "Look at our 1968 team too - marvellous players who were getting old. They won it once, but they couldn't keep it up."

Dave Beckham need only look at Barcelona to see the wisdom of his boss's observation. Barely a fortnight ago Barca were rulers of the universe elect, heading towards inevitable victory in the league and cup, not to mention Big Cup. Four defeats in a row later, and they're on their knees. "I'm sure the fans understand the situation we're in" said Luis Figo unconvincingly last night, denying that arrogance was behind Barca's change in fortunes. Pep Guardiola concurred. "We're going to win and we're going to go through to the semi-finals," the old charmer said. Roll on tomorrow.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Aston Villa have joined the chase for Ruud van Nistelrooy and hope to use his PSV strike partner Luc Nilis as bait. Nilis has already agreed to join Villa on a Bosman in the summer and he told the press: "I'm excited about playing for Villa, and if Ruud were to come too, that would be fantastic."

West Ham's Marc-Vivian Foe may move to Monaco for £5m in the summer. The Cameroon international is supposedly unhappy at Upton Park and wants a move back to France. Midfielder Marc Keller is also set for a summer move to either Lens or Bordeaux, as he is frustrated at the lack of first team opportunities.

Guus Hiddink has dropped a hint that he may still become Celtic's new manager. Hiddink has been offered a new contract at his current club Real Betis, but yesterday he said: "Celtic have a big history, the culture of the club is huge - not just in Glasgow, but all over the world."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Ronaldo has spoken for the first time about the knee injury that will keep him out of the game for about a year. "Some times the scene of the incident returns to me in my mind like an incubus," he said. "For me the accident has been like I died. fields.headline: Markets nervous after record falls
fields.trailText: Dealers and investors are braced for big falls in share prices across Europe today after the huge sell-off on Wall Street on Friday.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  and  Larry Elliott  in Washington and Julia Finch
fields.body:
Dealers and investors are braced for big falls in share prices across Europe today after the huge sell-off on Wall Street on Friday.

The FTSE-100 Index is expected to open up to 200 points lower this morning. But analysts were uncertain whether the fall signalled the start of a global crash or whether US investors would regain their nerve, allowing prices to stabilise when New York reopens this afternoon.

Some stock market watchers believe pension funds and other institutional investors will see the decline merely as a correction - and a buying opportunity. But others believe it is the start of a rout. One said: "This could turn really ugly."

At the weekend, finance ministers and central bankers from the world's leading industrialised nations, attending the G7 meeting in Washington, sought to shore up confidence in the global economy.

The US treasury secretary, Larry Summers, said finance ministers from the Group of Seven leading economies were "satisfied but not complacent" about the prospects for global growth, while the governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, said the environment had not changed, despite the losses shareholders have suffered over the last week.

Technology shares are expected to be hardest hit after the Nasdaq index, the US benchmark for hi-tech shares, fell 10% on Friday and ended the week down 25% - its biggest weekly loss.

The fall has wiped billions off the personal fortunes of some of the world's technology tycoons. Bill Gates's personal stake in Microsoft plummeted by $11bn (£6.7bn) last week, while Jeff Bezos, the amazon.com founder, had $2.4bn wiped off the value of his shares.

The Dow Jones index of leading shares lost more than 616 points on Friday, its biggest one-day points fall, as investors were spooked by US inflation figures that showed core prices rising by 0.4% last month. The data raised fears that US interest rates will have to rise sharply.

Jeremy Batstone, head of research at NatWest Stockbrokers, said: "The technology sector had been spoiling for a correction for a long time ... We believe that around 75% of tech shares could end up going to the wall and there will definitely be more losers than winners."

fields.headline: This Vivaldi is vibrant
fields.standfirst:
Cecilia Bartoli/ Les Arts Florissants
Barbican Hall, London
Rating: * * * * *
fields.trailText: It would easy for Cecilia Bartoli to rely upon her stellar reputation and captivating stage presence to bring in an adoring audience. But she is a far more interesting musician than that, always keen to expand her repertory.
fields.body:
It would easy for Cecilia Bartoli to rely upon her stellar reputation and captivating stage presence to bring in an adoring audience. But she is a far more interesting musician than that, always keen to expand her repertory.

Her current enthusiasm is Vivaldi, so it was no surprise that the first half of her appearance with William Christie and Les Arts Florissants on Friday should have been given over to that composer. A motet, and two arias from his only oratorio, Juditha Triumphans, were sandwiched between two sprightly concertos, one for strings alone from L'Estro Armonico, the other for sopranino recorder, in which Sébastien Marq was the dazzling soloist. Bartoli was dazzling too: not just in her technique, which even in the most exacting coloratura passages never failed her - some of her trills were more even precise than those of the instrumentalists - but in the sheer emotional energy that she put into everything.

There was equal theatricality in the Handel after the interval - a sequence of three numbers from The Triumph of Time and Truth, including a honeyed, heart-stopping account of "Lascia la Spina", which the composer famously recycled in his opera Rinaldo, a concerto grosso (Op 6 no 6) for Christie and his band, and the opening, declamatory aria from La Resurrezione, where Bartoli's stamina and sheer control were breathtaking.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Wartime revisited
fields.standfirst:
Birmingham Royal Ballet
Birmingham Rep Theatre
Rating: * * *
fields.trailText:
Birmingham Royal Ballet
Birmingham Rep Theatre
Rating: * * *
fields.body:
When Sir Frederick Ashton choreographed Dante Sonata in 1940, Britain had been at war for five months and Sadler's Wells Ballet had been turfed out of its home theatre. This was the company's first war ballet but rather than creating a jingoistic crowd pleaser, Ashton staged a highly personal view of catastrophe, his work anticipating an arena of destruction in which there could be no victory.

The ballet hasn't been seen in 50 years and BRB's revival is a generous effort of archaeology. The backdrop is stunning and BRB's dancers honour Ashton's choreography sufficiently for us to see that for wartime audiences, its images of torment would have been harrowing. For modern audiences though, Dante Sonata is a period piece, fascinating but unlikely to re-enter the regular repertory.

Aspects of Ashton's vision still connect: the visual and musical rhythms which animate the group dances create powerful contrasts between the rarefied anguish of The Children of Light and the hard-edged, hysterical aggression of The Children of Darkness. His sculpting of the dancers' tableaux achieves a luminous intensity of line and imagery, their religious iconography overlaid with an erotic frisson.

Yet Ashton's heavy reliance on hectoring gestures and frenzied runs to generate emotion now appears clumsily artless. This kind of raw physical expression was being handled with far greater sophistication by modern dance choreographers in the US and central Europe. And Ashton knew this. As the two later ballets in the programme prove - Scenes de Ballet (1948) and Enigma Variations (1968) - Ashton's genius flourished in classical soil.

 Until April 20. Box office: 0121 236 4458

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The role of office manager is one of those vague jobs that can encompass everything from ordering the stationery to organising an office move. "It is a very wide-ranging role," says Sue Kimpton-Brown, who combines her responsibilities as office manager for Roc Recruitment with working as PA to the chairman. "I tend to be the first point of contact for staff and suppliers - which makes for an extremely busy life!"
fields.body:
The role of office manager is one of those vague jobs that can encompass everything from ordering the stationery to organising an office move. "It is a very wide-ranging role," says Sue Kimpton-Brown, who combines her responsibilities as office manager for Roc Recruitment with working as PA to the chairman. "I tend to be the first point of contact for staff and suppliers - which makes for an extremely busy life!"

Kimpton-Brown's aim is to keep the office running smoothly, and she believes the best way to do this is to keep one step ahead. "I'm responsible for ordering all office equipment and stationery. With things such as toner for the fax and printer, I always ensure we have two in stock so we never run out. I do a complete stocktake once a month and keep a permanent list of what is in the building."

Not all her responsibilities are so straightforward. "We have three offices and I recently had to organise one office move and the refurbishment of another - from getting quotes from contractors right through to deciding where to store everything in the new office. At present I'm trying to sort out a disaster recovery plan, whereby everything on our systems is backed up and stored on a different site, so that if anything happened to this office we'd still be able to function."

She tries to work as independently as possible, using her judgment as to when to consult her boss. "I can decide which contractors to employ and authorise their invoices. I am constantly on the look out for systems or companies that offer better value for money. If a phone system offered lower charges, I would consider changing and that would be my decision, although I do consult my boss when large sums of money are involved."

On top of all the administration, she is responsible for keeping staff updated on any changes to the office. "I send memos about anything the staff need to know about. They may be about anything from phone systems to fire drills to holiday requirements. I also manage the holiday and sick leave system which takes quite a bit of updating."

Kimpton-Brown's key to successful office management is always to have a back-up plan. "I have a separate file for every aspect of my job - cleaners, computer systems, staff holidays - and I also store it all on computer. That way I can always lay my hand on the details I need, and if the computer goes down, I know the office isn't going to grind to a halt."

To help the job run smoothly, Kimpton-Brown advises:

* Use an action plan for each task. Draw up a table detailing everything that needs to be done on a project, what meetings are scheduled when and who is responsible for what. Ensure it is constantly updated.

* Try to look ahead. If a fax machine is playing up, get someone in to fix it - don't wait until it breaks down completely.

* Put as much as possible in writing: this way if anything goes wrong, you have written proof of what action you took and when.

* Be approachable - people are far more likely to do their best work and keep you updated if you are easy to deal with.

fields.headline: Desktop icons No 15: Scissors
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Don't you just hate those people who are good at everything? Not content with painting the Mona Lisa, designing helicopters and sketching the idealised figure of man, Leonardo Da Vinci somehow found the time to apply himself to sticky workplace problems. How to snip the pages of his legendary sketchbooks? Leo locked himself in his studio, not emerging until he had come up with the first pair of modern scissors.
fields.body:
Don't you just hate those people who are good at everything? Not content with painting the Mona Lisa, designing helicopters and sketching the idealised figure of man, Leonardo Da Vinci somehow found the time to apply himself to sticky workplace problems. How to snip the pages of his legendary sketchbooks? Leo locked himself in his studio, not emerging until he had come up with the first pair of modern scissors.

If the usefulness of an office implement is directly proportional to how quickly it disappears from one's desk, scissors must be very handy indeed (apart from those curly ones you are meant to use on your toes, which are absolutely no use to anyone). But enthusiasts should beware confusing their scissors with their shears. The bows of scissors (the holes for your your fingers) are the same shape and size, while shears are normally longer and have one bow for the thumb and a larger one for two or more fingers.

But scissors are far more important than their provenance or shape implies: as any child will tell you, they play an important part of our cultural history. What would one do on long car drives without the game scissors, paper, stone? Scissors, of course, were a particular childhood favourite because it almost looked like you were swearing.

They have even been honoured by Hollywood in the 1990 film Edward Scissorhands, starring Johnny Depp. No one has made a movie about a gothic freak with wooden spoons for hands, which only goes to prove the star quality of scissors.

But the most important thing is to remember never, ever to run with scissors. Even if you are dashing across the office to bury them in your boss's back.

If the usefulness of an office implement is directly proportional to how quickly it disappears from one's desk, scissors must be very handy indeed (apart from those curly ones you are meant to use on your toes, which are absolutely no use to anyone). But enthusiasts should beware confusing their scissors with their shears. The bows of scissors (the holes for your your fingers) are the same shape and size, while shears are normally longer and have one bow for the thumb and a larger one for two or more fingers. But scissors are far more important than their provenance or shape implies: as any child will tell you, they play an important part of our cultural history. What would one do on long car drives without the game scissors, paper, stone? Scissors, of course, were a particular childhood favourite because it almost looked like you were swearing. They have even been honoured by Hollywood in the 1990 film Edward Scissorhands, starring Johnny Depp. No one has made a movie about a gothic freak with wooden spoons for hands, which only goes to prove the star quality of scissors. But the most important thing is to remember never, ever to run with scissors. Even if you are dashing across the office to bury them in your boss's back.

webTitle: My company is higher than yours

fields.headline: My company is higher than yours
fields.standfirst:
It's no longer enough for companies to be big. Now they have to be high up as well. Claire Phipps on the race for space in the new skyscrapers
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: It's no longer enough for companies to be big. Now they have to be high up as well. Claire Phipps on the race for space in the new skyscrapers
fields.body:
There is a legitimate way to get higher up in the office - join the increasing number of workers taking the multistorey option. Every day, 27,000 of them pour into Canary Wharf in London's Docklands, a number that will rise to 100,000 by 2006 with the completion of two office blocks alongside the flagship tower. And entrepreneur Irvine Sellar this week launched his own riposte to these ambitious schemes, unveiling plans for an even higher skyscraper.

The proposed 1,200ft-high London Bridge tower would look down on the Wharf (a mere 777ft) and could house another 10,000 employees in its 87 storeys. PricewaterhouseCoopers, whose current home on the site would be swept away for the new neck-stretcher, is said to be keen to grab top floors if the project goes ahead. Employees would be advised to stake their claims now for a window-side desk.

"It's amazing, I love being so high up," says Lee McCormack, a financial adviser at City financial partners on the 25th floor of the Centrepoint tower block in central London. "I can see every building in London from here. You have to stop yourself having more than just a quick stare out of the window now and then."

But what if a step up the career ladder also means taking 40-odd flights of steps when the lifts are out of order? "It does happen," admits McCormack, "but fire alarms are the real nightmare. You have to walk all the way down, which is not too good for the ankles."

Even for those with a head for heights and a stout pair of walking boots, high-rise working has its problems. Security in these often high-profile buildings has to be tight, and occasions such as last June's march against capitalism can turn landmark buildings into targets, leaving workers stranded inside - though they do have the perfect vantage point.

It's not difficult to see why companies are keen to secure towering locations. Barclays bank is not the only company to be preoccupied with all things big at the moment: an extra floor or two can put you, literally, a few important feet above the competition. The Bank of New York, for example, occupies the 49th floor of Canary Wharf (currently the highest floor in use). Prestige, so the logic goes, increases with every ping of the lift indicator.

An unmissable office HQ not only provides instant recognition with built-in cachet, but also ensures a ready supply of curious visitors: "Our clients love it," says McCormack. "Most of them have never been up so high in London. They come in and can't believe the views."

Ah, yes, the views. While the London Bridge Tower - a thrusting corkscrew, according to the artist's impression - would, if it goes ahead, be the tallest in Europe and an instant landmark on the London skyline, the residents of Southwark might be less pleased at losing their vista of St Paul's cathedral to a rather phallic piece of competitive showmanship.

Which may have been the argument of the London planning advisory council two years ago. It concluded that future high-rise developments should be restricted to height-accustomed areas such as Docklands. Birmingham has also risen to the challenge with a 50-storey skyscraper given government go-ahead earlier this year.

It seems that office workers are heading skywards, and in true competitive spirit, London Bridge Tower wants to take them highest of all. Much has been made of the fact that the London Bridge venture would be only the sixth tallest structure in the world, lagging behind such old timers as the Empire State Building. But that's not to say that the announcement won't start a race that will take Britain's workers to the clouds. As Fred Manson, director of regeneration at Southwark council, said this week: "If we don't do it, Croydon will." Croydon, it's over to you.

fields.headline: Secretaries with skills in sabotage
fields.standfirst:
City of London police are warning companies to be on their guard against workers out to destroy their systems. And the most likely suspects? Admin staff. Kate Hilpern reports
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: City of London police are warning companies to be on their guard against workers out to destroy their systems. And the most likely suspects? Admin staff. Kate Hilpern reports
fields.body:
Take heed: saboteur secretaries are on the loose. You could be sitting next to one right now. Dressed smartly, hair neatly glossed, fantastic typing speed - saboteur secs sport the uniform of any office worker. But as you get on with your daily routine, the quiet revolutionary next door could be rapidly destroying part of your company's computer system - all without a trace of evidence.

Sound over the top? Police in the City of London don't think so. Still stinging after the violence of last June's anti-capitalist riots in the City, police are taking seriously the threat of sabotage from anarchists who may try to infiltrate big companies to coincide with this year's protests, planned for May 1. Last week, they issued a warning to companies in the country's financial heart to be on their guard against temporary workers who may come to work with a hidden agenda.

"We are aware that a number of events are being planned for the May bank holiday weekend," admits a spokesperson from the Metropolitan Police, adding that they are merely taking precautionary measures to avoid a repeat of last year's protest, in which rioters brought terror to the financial district and caused £2m of damage.

Whether or not the police are being over-cautious, their concern highlights the ease with which determined saboteurs could access the vulnerable and vastly expensive systems of a major corporation. Posing as temps, they would target jobs only in the Square Mile in firms with which they had an axe to grind. Once past security - who, like everyone else, believe the temp is there to do some extra filing - he or she could place a tiny file on a computer system, finish the temporary job, and vanish. At a specified time, hackers would then be able to dial in from anywhere in the world and use the file to open the system to attacks. Alternatively, the saboteur could leave programmes that would go into action automatically, crashing the system at a specific time and date.

Secretarial posts are a better option than IT roles, the anarchists believe, because they cause less suspicion and have a higher turnover of staff. It may also make it easier to win the trust of sympathetic permanent staff, who may offer to give them a helping hand. Alternatively, determined infiltrators could help rioting associates outside by leaving doors open, allowing them to storm company headquarters.

One of the main problems for law-enforcers is that few individual members of anti-capitalist groups are known to them. It is almost excusable when you consider that even the City of London commissioner claimed last year that "they reveal a level of sophistication and planning not seen before". Some of those posing as temps even carry the FT with them at all times to ensure they look the part. The fact that some on-line recruitment companies supply temporary workers without having conducted personal interviews is also making the path for saboteur support staff more tempting than it might otherwise have been. You simply send a CV into cyberspace and hey presto, you've got the City post you're after.

But the recruitment establishment is far from toothless in confronting the threat from people who are not who they claim to be. Recruitment consultants specialising in City appointments and employers themselves are beginning to recognise their vulnerability to a determined criminal, and have introduced tighter selection methods. Step into Jonathan Wren, for instance, and you'll find your references may be checked for up to 10 years. "If there's a gap in employment, we'll want to know why and we'll check it out," says Philip Ayling, associate director.

Some employers have even resorted to lie-detecting methods - though not yet using electrodes strapped to the body. Instead, increasingly numbers of employers use psychologists and psychometric testing to wean out individuals who may be suspect. According to Dr Richard Wiseman, a specialist in lie-detection at Hertfordshire University, observing leg and arm movements is particularly effective. When movement is exaggerated, there's a good chance the candidate is fibbing. "Another giveaway is the extent to which hands are used to touch body and face," he says. "We tend to touch ourselves more when we are lying. It's almost as if we are trying to appear sincere by pointing to ourselves more and saying, 'Would I lie to you?'"

Of course, it is not only anti-capitalist and anarchist elements that employers are on their guard against. The risk of industrial sabotage and fraud is increasing, and computer systems need to be made ever more complex to beat talented computer fraudsters. These people can steal millions of pounds, destroy the evidence by vandalising the computer system, and then hand in their notice and disappear.

In addition, what has been dubbed "work rage" drives many to plant "computer bombs" that can cripple an employer's entire IT network. A recent study published by the American society of industrial security found that vengeful employees are now the biggest security worry for 90% of US bosses. And while less research has been carried out in the UK, anecdotal evidence confirms we're catching up fast.

Increased short-term contracts, job insecurity and a feeling of being undervalued are largely to blame, believes organisational psychologist, Andrew Ellis. "At best, this will mean staff are not prepared to give their job their all, or work overtime when needed. At worst, it could mean demolishing computer systems."

After all, says Professor Cary Cooper, organisational psychologist at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, sabotaging IT systems is the easiest and most anonymous way of getting back at an employer. "A single person can create enormous amounts of damage by removing material from a computer system or infecting documents with a virus."

A spokesperson from the investigatory division of Capital Group, one of the UK's largest security specialists explains, "People think of cyber attackers as nerdy teenagers but most is done against business by junior employees and sub-contractors."

That's why, he believes, employer surveillance reminiscent of Big Brother is becoming a normal part of working life. Not only are passwords, restricted access and back-up systems becoming common, but you are more likely than ever to spot a camera lens on the wall. You may also find that you're subjected to "cyber snooping". A recent survey by NOP has indicated that more than 59% of UK employees suspect that their bosses monitors their emails.

According to Anthony Benson, who calls himself an "intelligence operative", fast increasing numbers of companies are hiring people such as him to pin down today's computer crooks. You could be forgiven for thinking this private eye's life resembles a James Bond film - he admits to using phone-tapping, hidden cameras, computer keyboards that monitor the activity of the person operating them, and thermal imaging equipment. "Sometimes I have to have a crash course on a particular company and job, then pretend to be a new employee. I befriend the suspect and find out if they're up to anything. If they are, I get proof."

The irony is that anyone can set up shop as a private investigator. Even a someone who has been convicted of, say, anti-capitalist activity can walk out of jail and place an ad offering such services. But maybe that's just being paranoid...

fields.headline: Giving good ear
fields.standfirst: Do you listen? Or do you think you know it all?
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: Are you a great listener? Probably not. Few of us are, and yet listening is the most important communication skill in the workplace.
fields.body:
Are you a great listener? Probably not. Few of us are, and yet listening is the most important communication skill in the workplace. Real listening, that is: tuning in and grasping the meaning of what is being said, rather than hearing, which is just registering sounds in the same way that a parrot does.

Good listening requires practise and patience. If you find you're missing the plot on a regular and very tragic basis it could be because your listening skills are suffering from any or all of the following conditions:

The know it all

You stopped listening to colleagues years ago when you realised you had already learnt everything in the world that is worth knowing. Listening is therefore a futile exercise for you and a patent waste of your valuable time. The only communication skill you practise is talking, in the hope that you can share some of this rich store of information with others less gifted.

Verdict: You will wonder why colleagues are reluctant to wait on pins the moment you open your mouth at meetings. You probably suspect you are speaking on a higher intellectual level than they can easily understand, but the fact is they hate you and are willing you to shut up and die. They probably wish horrible accidents or plagues of toads on you on a regular daily basis. You have two ears and one mouth and you should remember to use them in that ratio.

The interrupter

You don't mean to be rude but you just can't help jumping in when others are speaking. Either you are too keen to get your points across to wait, or you feel you are helping out your more verbally-challenged colleagues, who seem to spend a long time stammering, umm-ing and pausing.

Sometimes you realise you might be seen as ill-mannered, so switch to indulging in a series of quick head nods instead, which is the body language version of communicatus interruptus.

Verdict: What you fail to realise is that it is you who is causing your colleagues' diffident speech patterns. By telling them to hurry up or you'll jump in and take over you are converting them into babbling mutes. Be strict with yourself before they give up trying and leave you out of everything. Make yourself allow a pause of five seconds after each of your colleagues has finished speaking. It may be painful for you but boy, do you deserve to suffer.

The distracted child You have the attention span of a baby newt and not even the most fascinating speaker can hold your interest. While someone is talking to you will alternately: fidget, try to carry on working, perform and impromptu manicure or gaze around the room. You will also change the subject at the drop of a hat, without even remotely recognising that a conversation will only flow when there is a two-way exchange of ideas and views. An average chat for you would run something like: "...no, I'm afraid I had a lousy Easter break, actually. I ran over my mother-in-law as she was rushing out from her blazing bungalow, hence the black armband which my wife insisted I wear even though she packed her bags and left as a result of the tragedy..." "Really. Did you get that memo about the restructuring of the IT department?"

Verdict: You annoy the hell out of your colleagues, not to mention your family, who probably stopped trying to talk to you ages ago. You are selfish in the extreme, and should learn to focus on the concerns, values and experiences of other people for a change. Or perhaps you were not even aware they were there.

The aerobic listener

You work really hard at your listening skills but the point is you take it all a little too far. You lean forward while your colleagues are speaking with a look of concentration puckering your face up as though you had just sucked a very sour lemon. Your eye contact is constant and intimidating and your nods are slow and measured. You give it all the right verbals: "I seeee...." "Absolutely....." "Fascinating....." and you tend to make loud listening noises, like a cow mooing, to register agreement and empathy.

Verdict: You are probably giving people the creeps. Ignoring them is one thing but intensity can be off-putting too, especially when you put all that energy into a conversation over the filling of the coffee machine. Calm it down a bit. No one believes this nice guy act for one minute.

Good listening tips


 Show you are listening. Use eye contact and nodding but don't overdo it.
 Never queue up your own ideas and comments in your head. Plan to ask a question about the speaker's point, instead.
 Never try to top the speaker's story. Reflect back the major points, instead.
 Never make the assumption that you know what the speaker is going to say before he/she has finished speaking.
 Mirror his/her body language to create empathy

webTitle: Brown calls for clamp on tax dodgers

fields.headline: Brown calls for clamp on tax dodgers
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, will call on the European Union today to take concerted action against tax evasion after the G7 meeting of finance ministers and central bank governors backed Britain's approach to tackling illegal avoidance.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott and Jane Martinson in Washington
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, will call on the European Union today to take concerted action against tax evasion after the G7 meeting of finance ministers and central bank governors backed Britain's approach to tackling illegal avoidance.

The G7 supported using exchange of information by tax authorities to track down those moving money offshore to avoid tax - the argument Britain has been using in its long-running fight with some EU countries over the proposed witholding tax.

Britain believes that the proposed levy would not only harm the City's lucrative eurobond market but would be a less effective way of collecting unpaid tax than comprehensive exchange of information.

Treasury sources said yesterday that over recent months, pressure had eased on Britain to back the withholding tax and was instead being put on countries such as Luxembourg to support exchange of information.

Mr Brown will say in New York today: "We are making progress." The chancellor will add that the recent Helsinki summit agreed that all EU citizens should pay the tax due on all their savings.

"This weekend's G7 statement agreed to call on all countries to work rapidly towards the position where they can permit access to and exchange bank information for all tax administration purposes. I believe the onus is on Europe to show how at the European Council in June we can collectively deliver on the commitment, meet the Helsinki principle and so effectively tackle tax evasion."

The G7 communique gave strong backing to exchange of information and is also supporting moves by the Financial Stability Forum group on offshore centres - chaired by Howard Davies, chairman of Britain's Financial Services Authority, to "name and shame" financial centres with inadequate systems of regulation.

The G7 said: "We support the identification of priority jurisdictions and the focus on improvements in transparency and international co-operation."

It added: "We welcome the report by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development's committee on fiscal affairs on access to bank information for tax purposes, and call on all countries...to work rapidly towards a position where they can permit access to and exchange bank information for all tax administration purposes."

Larry Summers, the US treasury secretary, said: "I believe there is an emerging consensus on the need to move forward in more forceful ways to combat these growing threats."

Mr Summers said that the G7 had called for a crackdown on offshore tax havens and their potential to disguise money-launderers and other fraudsters.

webTitle: Wait a minute as Abbey speeds up mortgage deals

fields.headline: Wait a minute as Abbey speeds up mortgage deals
fields.trailText: Abbey National plans to revolutionise the way mortgage brokers sell its home loans with an internet system that could allow approvals within 60 seconds.
fields.body:
Abbey National plans to revolutionise the way mortgage brokers sell its home loans with an internet system that could allow approvals within 60 seconds.

The new Abbey service will involve 10,000 mortgage brokers gaining access to its new, "intelligent" mortgage introducer internet service at a cost of £5m.

Ambrose McGinn, director of retail e-commerce at Abbey, said that by using the system a mortgage intermediary should be able to speed up the process of arranging mortgage.

He admitted that if it proved successful it had implications for "low value" jobs which are connected to processing and filling in mortgage application forms.

The system will also be a model for the bank's push into the stakeholder pension market later in the year, where direct sales and on-site marketing, whether in the workplace or in the home, is considered important.

"We'll have an e-commerce facility for that too," Mr McGinn said. He claimed that the bank already had guarantees of £3bn of mortgage business from "key introducers" over the new online service.

"With 50% of our mortgage business supplied by intermediaries, the new introducer internet services will respond to all improvements that our contacts have been crying out for, namely speed of service, flexibility regarding time availability and up to the minute tracking of customers' cases," he said.

Abbey said that while the new system could mean a "decision in principle" would be made in a minute, it calculates it could take 10 minutes from "start to decision", still an improvement on the three hours that is the norm at present.

The service will provide real time tracking of cases throughout the process between 8am and 10pm, seven days a week, and aims to scrap any unnecessarily filling-in of forms.

John Malone, the national mortgage manager at Scottish Amicable, added: "It's an impressive online service. Buying a home or moving is one of the biggest events in anyone's life so we encourage anything that makes that process easier."

fields.headline: Markets braced for shares turmoil
fields.standfirst:
Investors told not to panic but hi-tech stocks bubble is expected to burst
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The spin and hype which has sent hi-tech stocks to incredible highs in recent months is expected to come to an abrupt end today. Around the world, markets and dealers are braced for a plunge in share values, prompted by the huge falls on Wall Street on Friday night, which could see some of the old economy stocks recently spurned by investors return to favour.
fields.body:
The spin and hype which has sent hi-tech stocks to incredible highs in recent months is expected to come to an abrupt end today. Around the world, markets and dealers are braced for a plunge in share values, prompted by the huge falls on Wall Street on Friday night, which could see some of the old economy stocks recently spurned by investors return to favour.

It also likely to leave many of the speculators, often small investors who have been playing the market on borrowed money, nursing severe losses.

One of the first high profile casualties of the market shake-out is likely to be T-Online, a subsidiary of Deutsche Telekom and Europe's biggest internet provider. The company is to be listed on Frankfurt's Neuer Markt this morning and Deutsche Telekom was yesterday forced to slash its offer price to €27 - the very lowest that had been forecast, in an effort to reassure small investors. In Britain, the video-on-demand company Yes Television is reviewing its flotation plans this morning, also as a result of the market turbulence

"The corner has turned, definitely," said Andrew Look, regional director at Prudential Portfolio Managers in Hong Kong. "People will still pay a premium for growth, they will still pay for dreams, but they will be more selective."

Mark Dampier, of stockbrokers Hargreaves Lansdown, said: "London and most other European markets could suffer falls of up to 5%, in line with Wall street's drop on Friday. But the market was due for a correction. It was definitely becoming overheated and we are now seeing the reaction to that overheating. It's likely to be a pretty bumpy ride for the next few days, if not weeks."

But he he did not advise private investors to engage in any panic selling. "For those investors prepared to take a long term view this market correction could be seen as a useful buying opportunity."

The share buying boom, fuelled by the arrival of online stock trading, has meant that there are now 100 private buyers for every 90 sellers. Angela Knight of the Association of Private Client Investment Managers and Stockbrokers, said: "Investors should take advice about what to do and certainly not be panicked into selling in a rush. They should remember that money invested in stocks and shares has historically performed better than any other type of investment over the long term."

The first indications of the scale of today's expected sell-off came last night from Tel Aviv. Israeli stocks, led by technology shares, tumbled, but no one stock or sector was spared the bloodbath, as all 25 blue-chip shares and virtually every one of the Tel Aviv 100 stocks posted steep declines.

Technology stocks were battered most, with the Teltech index down 17%. Traditional industries and banks posted relatively small losses compared to the huge drops of more than 20% for many tech stocks.

"It is a reaction to the panic on Wall Street from Friday's freefall," said Richard Gussow, equities analyst at Lehman Brothers in Tel Aviv. "There's a lot of uncertainty."

fields.headline: Archie Shepp/ Andrew Hill
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.body:
Some may tear their hair out over Archie Shepp's unorthodox style, but his performance with pianist Andrew Hill at the QEH explored musicality in its broadest sense.

Shepp, the 62-year-old saxophonist, composer and campaigner, has an unusual sax embouchure, as though he were licking an oversized ice-cream. His playing veers between romanticism and free-jazz wails. Yet his characteristic sound and singing was immensely expressive, especially in musical conversation with the endlessly inventive Hill.

In the 60s, Shepp was a Coltrane-generation iconoclast and a political activist, but he has always had a deep feeling for the blues. He has brought many more pre-bebop elements into his work in the past two decades. The result, on tenor sax particularly, can be fascinating. On Charlie Parker's Mohawk he blended swing-era opulence with the sinister crackle at the edges of notes that gives his work its signature. Mohawk edged into Thelonious Monk territory at the persuasion of Hill, eventually turning into a stride-piano walk over which Shepp unleashed eerie warbles and trills.

He sang a bizarrely wonderful version of Good Morning Heartache in the style of a rich-toned 1940s crooner. It followed a tenor solo that began with him settling briefly on the melody, then abstracting it until it almost evaporated. Hill's piano solo on the same piece preserved the sense of the song but reshaped its choruses into a miniature concerto. It was close to being the improvisation moment of the night. The audience cheered long and loud through the evening, recognising that such a grasp of the jazz tradition cannot simply be absorbed from a college course and a record collection.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: PC plod
fields.trailText: The police do not have a problem attracting potential recruits (News, last week). Their problem is that they are turning down too many able candidates at final selection.
fields.body:
The police do not have a problem attracting potential recruits (News, last week). Their problem is that they are turning down too many able candidates at final selection.

In Hampshire - which has a chronic shortage of officers - candidates must have successfully completed a gruelling physical examination, written tests and an interview before they attend for final selection. However, the vast majority are turned away, on the basis of perceived performance during personality-based exercises such as group talks.

It should also be of concern that many of those turned down are (unpaid) special constables. Surely they are either good enough to be members of the police force or they are not?
Eleanor Scott
Portsmouth
