fields.headline: French slip?
fields.trailText: I have long admired Philip French's trenchant writing on film. It was a shock, therefore, to read his attack on Sam Mendes (Review, last week) who did not say in his Oscar acceptance speech that he wasn't thinking of making another film in the foreseeable future.
fields.body:
I have long admired Philip French's trenchant writing on film. It was a shock, therefore, to read his attack on Sam Mendes (Review, last week) who did not say in his Oscar acceptance speech that he wasn't thinking of making another film in the foreseeable future. Indeed he has announced the formation of Donmar Films, for which he has managed to secure significant development funding from Dreamworks. That strikes me as pretty smart and potentially good news for British film-making.
Genista McIntosh
London NW3

fields.headline: Steiner's mistake
fields.trailText: In George Steiner's gracious review of my book  New Horizons  (Books, 2 April), there is an inaccurate statement that raises issues that perhaps merit comment.
fields.body:
In George Steiner's gracious review of my book New Horizons (Books, 2 April), there is an inaccurate statement that raises issues that perhaps merit comment.

Steiner writes that I deem 'the right of freedom of expression to be an absolute', and have 'prefaced and defended a tract denying the Holocaust'. I do not regard that right as absolute, though any infringement must bear a heavy burden of justification. The 'tract' was the defendant's response to the charge of falsifying history, for which he was brought to court, and condemned - not for denying the Holocaust, according to the excerpts from the Court judgment published in Le Monde , but for such crimes as allowing others to use his writings in nefarious ways. I did not 'defend the tract', nor preface it. I did not even know that it existed until apprised that a statement of mine on the right of freedom of expression had been appended as an ' avis ' (opinion) - stressing the distinction between defending the right to speak and defending what is said; the merest truism, as I pointed out. There is more to say about these matters, but I will keep here to the specific issues raised.
Noam Chomsky
Washington DC

fields.headline: Blunkett's wrong on Summerhill
fields.trailText: I write in response to David Blunkett (Letters, last week) compounding the lies already put out by his press office about Summerhill School. This issue is now becoming more than about Summerhill. The Secretary of State is clearly trying to undermine the decisions of an independent tribunal that did not go his way.
fields.body:
I write in response to David Blunkett (Letters, last week) compounding the lies already put out by his press office about Summerhill School. This issue is now becoming more than about Summerhill. The Secretary of State is clearly trying to undermine the decisions of an independent tribunal that did not go his way. His arrogance in attempting to back-track is a threat to justice as well as to Summerhill School.

I was present at the Independent Schools Tribunal that heard the Summerhill case. I also chaired a team that carried out an independent inquiry into the school and we urged David Blunkett voluntarily to do precisely what he had to concede at the tribunal. I'm saddened that he does not have the good grace to accept his defeat and let Summerhill School get on with its work. The facts are as Nick Cohen presented them in his article.

What David Blunkett appears to be doing is trying to create a situation where he can, at will, renege on legal agreements to suit his own purposes. Lord Haskins (chairman of the Government's better regulation task force) was quoted recently as saying that the DfEE 'is the most Stalinist department I have ever come across'. How right he is - and how dangerous for all of us.
Professor Ian Cunningham
Brighton

 David Blunkett's letter taking Nick Cohen to task is not about Summerhill School at all - it is about governmental power and a refusal to recognise when it is in the wrong.

Mr Cohen was absolutely spot on when he said that Summerhill had not agreed to 'encourage children to attend lessons', as it did no such thing. The agreement allows the school to follow the system and philosophy of A.S. Neill, whose writing makes it perfectly clear that he was against any form of direction or suggestion to his pupils.

It is very disturbing to see the DfEE - supposedly in charge of the moral welfare of our children - behaving like this.
Zoe Readhead
Principal, Summerhill School
Leiston, Suffolk

fields.headline: Can 'date rape' carry convictions?
fields.trailText: It was refreshing to see a well-argued and thoughtful article about rape (Comment, last week). Unfortunately Carol Sarler's arguments are undermined by a fundamental error.
fields.body:
It was refreshing to see a well-argued and thoughtful article about rape (Comment, last week). Unfortunately Carol Sarler's arguments are undermined by a fundamental error. She refers to conviction rates dropping from 24 to 6 per cent and suggests the answer is to introduce a new 'date rape' charge to persuade juries to convict. These figures, as I understand them, however, refer to conviction rates of those charged, not of those who stand trial - not the same thing at all. Many cases do not get as far as the courtroom, for a variety of reasons including the Crown Prosecution Service dropping the case and the complainant withdrawing her allegations. A perceived unwillingness of juries to convict may have an impact on a case stalling at an early stage, but there is no evidence to suggest the conviction rate for rape following a trial is any lower than for any other offence - currently 55-60 per cent.

There have been two high-profile rape cases in the last two weeks, one where the defendant subjected the complainant to a gruelling cross-examination and another where a man spent years in prison as a consequence of a false allegation. Unfortunately, as ever, these are used as justification for the two extreme positions of the argument about rape trials. We must not be misled by the use of such cases, as they tend to represent the bizarre and uncommon rather than the reality, which is that rape trials based on the prosecution's needing to prove their case are unpleasant affairs, but vital in a democracy subject to the rule of law. Rape trials are distressing for complainants, and of course we must do all we can to alleviate their distress, while paying heed to the rights of suspects.

With the removal of the rights of suspects to cross-examine in rape cases we have struck the right balance. We do not need a 'date rape' charge, which would lower recognition of a terrible wrong in the eyes of a complainant. Equally, to reverse the burden of proof would go too far, and result in more miscarriages of justice.
J M Schone
Lecturer, Centre for Comparative Criminology & Criminal Justice
University of Wales, Bangor

 Carol Sarler's perceptive and even-handed article shows why the conviction rate for rape is so low: because nobody can decide what on earth 'consent' is supposed to mean. Replacing one lawyers' fiction with another - 'free agreement' - will only make the law more uncertain, for alleged victims and alleged perpetrators alike.

We should go further than the Canadians and abolish the element of sex altogether. A court is simply not the place to decide whether a particular form of behaviour, accepted as normal in most circumstances, was or was not a criminal assault.

In the case of a physical assault, if someone hits you over the head with a mallet no one argues about whether you consented. You have bumps and bruises to show a crime was committed, and fingerprints on the mallet to prove who did it. No accused person should have their liberty put at risk if their alleged victim didn't make a complaint promptly, can't provide physical evidence that a crime was committed, and can offer no corroboration.
Michael Reeves
Gravesend, Kent

 I think a new charge of date rape will result in even less convictions because juries would be even less willing to send a 'foolish young chap' to jail. At the moment everyone is more interested saving these 'chaps' from false imprisonment but being attacked and raped by someone you know and trusted is the ultimate betrayal and the ultimate crime.
A. Davidson
London

You have bumps and bruises to show a crime was committed, and fingerprints on the mallet to prove who did it. No accused person should have their liberty put at risk if their alleged victim didn't make a complaint promptly, can't provide physical evidence that a crime was committed, and can offer no corroboration. At the moment everyone is more interested saving these 'chaps' from false imprisonment but being attacked and raped by someone you know and trusted is the ultimate betrayal and the ultimate crime. A. Davidson London

fields.headline: Grave robbery
fields.trailText: In promoting the collection of prehistoric stone tools, John Windsor (Cash, last week) demonstrates ignorance of London's role as a centre for the sale of illegally-acquired archaeological artefacts.
fields.body:
In promoting the collection of prehistoric stone tools, John Windsor (Cash, last week) demonstrates ignorance of London's role as a centre for the sale of illegally-acquired archaeological artefacts, often by so-called 'ancient art' dealers including major auction houses. Nor does he show any knowledge of the way in which treating ancient artefacts as art or investments encourages looting, the destruction of archaeological sites, and the multi-million-dollar trade in such 'acquisitions', itself often associated with organised crime and corruption.
Dr Mark Pluciennik
Dept of Archaeology, University of Wales
Lampeter
Dr Sarah Tarlow
School of Archaeological Studies, Leicester University

webTitle: Our aid is good, but not enough

fields.headline: Our aid is good, but not enough
fields.trailText: Your front page article and leader on Ethiopia last week were misleading. The Government has committed £5 million in humanitarian aid to Ethiopia and £45m to Mozambique so far this year to meet emergency and rehabilitation needs.
fields.body:
Your front page article and leader on Ethiopia last week were misleading. The Government has committed £5 million in humanitarian aid to Ethiopia and £45m to Mozambique so far this year to meet emergency and rehabilitation needs. The Government has also increased its overseas aid budget by £1.6 billion in the last three years, a real-terms increase of 28 per cent.

That said, of course more still needs to be done. We will continue to press the Government for faster and deeper debt relief and for improved terms of trade for developing countries. Much more could, and should, be done to tackle the causes and consequences of poverty.
Mike Aaronson, Director General, Save the Children
David Bryer, Director, Oxfam
Julian Filochowski, Director, CAFOD
Daleep Mukarji, Director, Christian Aid
Salil Shetty, Chief Executive ActionAid

webTitle: This ugliest side of New Britain shames us all

fields.headline: This ugliest side of New Britain shames us all
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: There is an odious mood abroad concerning asylum seekers. Radio talk shows reveal prejudice bordering on hatred. Those shocked by the vocabulary and attitudes are characterised as part of a politically-correct, race-relations industry. An essentially liberal and tolerant country is losing touch with its own values.
fields.body:
There is an odious mood abroad concerning asylum seekers. Radio talk shows reveal prejudice bordering on hatred. Those shocked by the vocabulary and attitudes are characterised as part of a politically-correct, race-relations industry. An essentially liberal and tolerant country is losing touch with its own values.

The only relief in an increasingly poisonous climate was Mr Justice Gray's verdict last week on David Irving, who had sued Deborah Lipstadt for saying that he had systematically and deliberately misrepresented historical evidence to justify his pro-Hitler, anti-Semitic views. It was a reminder of what Britain once was, of a tradition that is dissolving before the daily xenophobic and racist parade of prejudice that informs much of our media and political debate. Enoch Powell was dismissed from the Conservative front bench for expressing attitudes that today would seem little more than normal. We have fallen a long way and judging by the approach of William Hague, we have further still to fall.

What Mr Justice Gray's verdict highlighted was the rarity with which any public figure is prepared to risk the wrath of the tabloid and right-wing press and offer leadership over race. We can expect little better from the cornered, shrivelled Conservative Party, obviously looking for electoral advantage by making the basest appeal it can to racial prejudice. But we should expect better from New Labour, both because of its philosophy and because of the obligations of power. If it will not lead, who will?

But New Labour is not a natural leader. Thus Mike O'Brien, Deputy Home Secretary, jeered that the Tories are soft on immigration; Barbara Roche, Home Office Minister, criticised Romanian beggars; Baroness Jay sought to decry Bill Morris, Transport and General Workers' Union leader, in his attack on Government asylum policies, saying that he was defending lorry-driving members who bring in illegal immigrants.

And there is Home Secretary Jack Straw, architect of the Asylum Act which became law on 1 April, who has consistently tried to draw the teeth of right-wing criticism by steering Labour policy into more illiberal territory. The balance of policy is wholly wrong. Mr Straw should not be criticised for trying to ensure that illegal entry into Britain is as difficult as possible; the up-to-£2,000 fine for a driver carrying illegal immigrants is not unreasonable. But there is no compensating generosity for asylum seekers pending their application; no explanation of why numbers have risen; no explanation that immigration can be beneficial for the host country. We may be surrounded by sea, but Britain cannot shut itself off or drop its efforts to be the custodian of the principles by which a civilised society should live.

Paying asylum seekers their benefit in 'asylos' - pitched some 30 per cent below already low income-support levels - and letting supermarkets not give change is spiteful. Indeed, the whole penny-pinching approach is one of the origins of the crisis, especially unjustifiable now that the Treasury is so rich. We should have invested in a fast means of processing asylum seekers; we should have dispersed them around the country in special centres pending that rapid processing. The Government should have offered proper funding to over-stretched authorities so that they did not have to cut general budgets when meeting the needs of asylum seekers, but none of this was advanced for fear of right-wing criticism and Treasury meanness.

Conditions in Eastern Europe, the home of many asylum seekers and economic migrants, are not going to improve rapidly unless the European Union makes brave and generous efforts to help restore their economies. The economic migrants mingling with those fleeing from tyranny are victims of the unequal manner in which the West runs the world economy. If we want to stem the flow from the poorer countries, we have to make greater efforts to ensure that there is better governance, better economic management and a fairer share of world GDP.

But nothing will happen until we choose to be more careful in our vocabulary and more vigilant in the defence of first principles. The lazy columnist who repeats populist lies; the union official who blames foreigners' sub-human habits for the loss of jobs; Tory election planners picking up marginals through racist campaign literature; the Labour Minister who goes with the flow of right-wing bigotry - they all help maintain Britain as a host to racism. We need a reaffirmation of our traditions of fairness and tolerance and for that we need leadership and equitable policies.

fields.headline: The tyranny of numbers
fields.standfirst:
New Labour's obsession with the Gradgrind culture of accountancy is killing off creativity and reason

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: New Labour's obsession with the Gradgrind culture of accountancy is killing off creativity and reason
fields.body:
Some of the most eloquent moments in politics are the silences, those single-beat hesitations when a powerful person is struck by the possibility that he's wrong; when you can hear a mind turning. One such came at about 8.15am on Wednesday on Radio 4's Today programme. After hearing the father of a seven-year-old boy protest about the stress caused to young children by national testing, David Blunkett ... paused. Then, sounding troubled he said that if it was really a national problem, 'I would very seriously consider changing it.'

I don't want to make too much of this. In the end, nothing will be changed. Education bureaucrats will pile in with statistics to prove there is no problem and that small children who think they feel upset are mistaken. In fact, they feel fine.

But the boy's father, Ian Anderson, struck a chord that will have thrummed through the nation. Tests and targets have become a fetish. In politics, all good ideas are eventually pressed too far. Inspiring innovations, introduced into bureaucracies, become oppressive systems. Original insights are followed to their logical conclusion, where they die gasping for want of commonsense. And now this has happened with targets.

It was John Major with his Citizen's Charter, not New Labour, who began the audit revolution. As he says in his memoirs, 'publishing the performances of different schools, hospitals, local authorities or transport services would act as a kind of surrogate competition to raise standards.' And it was a good idea. He was right. The National Audit Office has been trying to measure outputs, in a rough way, since the time of Pepys but the great difference has been to use it as a external political weapon, not simply an internal system of housekeeping.

Even as Tony Blair and Gordon Brown were mocking it all to death across the Commons chamber, they were watching and learning. New Labour took Major's audit culture and then turned it against a host of enemies. First, in 1996-7 it was used against Major himself: by offering pledge cards and reams of targets by which they should be judged, Blair and Brown challenged the voters to take them seriously as leaders committed to modernity, efficiency and delivering the goods. 'We will raise this; we will double that, and halve this ...' From class sizes to waiting lists, it was their response to the charge that Labour was fuzzy. And it worked.

Next, in government, public auditing became the core weapon of Treasury control over other departments - the comprehensive spending review is basically a mass of management and output targets. On a wider front, it has been increasingly used to fill the hole left by ideology, as an ultimate self-justification beyond ordinary politics. 'Don't judge us by left or right ideas, judge us by results. You think we are wrong? But we have cut waiting lists for heart operations by X per cent. How can that be "wrong"?' In this way, cleverly set targets, well-promoted, become a kind of irrefutable political language in themselves.

I am not trying to suggest that this hollows out everything else; if you work through the mass of targets set by New Labour, its values shine through very clearly - a government of the right would never make as much of targets on child poverty, class sizes or racial harassment. Nor is this kind of auditing bad in itself; there certainly was an idle and sod-the-public mentality through much of the state bureaucracy. Short of fiery swords and flails of scorpions, I don't know what else would work.

But we are now at a stage in this Government's life when the target-frenzy needs to be cooled, shaken and reassessed. When I typed the words 'health' and 'target' into one government computer search engine, it offered me a choice of 25,998 different documents. Every government department offers you lists of self-flagellating targets with the pathetic zeal of revisionist bourgeois undergoing Maoist self-criticism. Targets on courts, car crashes, gall-bladders, atmospheric particles, the numeracy of small children, telephone answering times, computer services, you name it.

This means Sir Humphrey has adapted already. Set up any system of measurement which is attached to a funding mechanism and you will imme diately create a set of new skills with which it can be twisted, subverted or otherwise neutralised. One trick is to ensure that the target is easier than it looks. These days, every government target comes with the swaggering adjective 'tough', like lanky students in bikers' jackets - and just as convincing.

Another is to adjust the timescale so that, with luck, no civil servant or Minister involved will be anywhere nearby when the measuring-rod is applied. New targets for police Best Value Performance Plans, government online services and Britain's share of the global higher education market (all 'tough') don't bite until 2005. The - yes, tough - targets on reducing children's road deaths are for 2010; the same goes for cuts in greenhouse gas emissions and the percentage of electricity from renewable resources.

Outside Whitehall, there are already a fantastic range of dodges used by hospitals and consultants to achieve the Government's waiting-list and other targets and schools. The same goes for the chivvied, target-bound local authorities. When John Prescott announced his (excellent) new package on reviving council estates on Thursday, it came with a raft of new monitoring including explicit performance targets - 'tough ones', reporters noted with amazement - and 'national efficiency guidelines' run by government statisticians, for refuse collection, road maintenance and so on. In the days since, no doubt, council staff have been working with frantic enthusiasm to ensure that these targets are met with the minimum of bother.

In schools, quite clearly, literacy and numeracy targets have worked to raise standards. But don't imagine that teachers haven't found ways of confounding the inspectors and twisting the children's working weeks to get the best results. Tell people they'll be judged by jumping through hoops, rather than making pupils gasp at the beauty of a Shakespeare lyric; and hoop-jumping is what they'll get up to. The protesting Radio 4 father spoke for many others when he said: 'It seems a lot of time is being used in school, because there is so much pressure on the teachers to get good scores in the tests, simply preparing children for the tests, and that this is time that could be better used in other ways.'

The danger of the audit culture is that it leaves too few other ways, too little room for inspiration. In the political arena, it shrivels debate to a dry, impenetrable conflict about numbers which will turn voters off. The recent party political broadcasts by Labour and the Tories for the local elections were overwhelmingly statistical, each of them convincing in isolation, but incomprehensible when placed against one another. We don't believe either side's measurements, quite; and we won't be driven to the polling-booth because of them.

In hospital wards, classrooms and local authorities, the audit culture also tends to leave too little room and therefore too little leadership. It is the big stick of the central state, the new prime system of control in a state which already too centralised. No doubt a healthy state needs auditing but it needs a modern constitution too; at the very least, Whitehall's stick should be used in a discriminating and humble way. And 'humble' is not Sir Humph's natural condition.

Finally, in human terms, we can only make an audit culture successful if we remember that life is lived between the numbers, not through them. It is not likely that Thomas Gradgrind was able to listen to the Today programme last week, first because he dates from April 1854, not April 2000 and second, because he is a fictitious schoolmaster dreamt up by Charles Dickens. But many of us, hearing that debate, will have thought of him - 'a kind of cannon loaded to the muzzle with facts, and prepared to blow [the children] clean out of the regions of childhood with one discharge.' Gradgrind, who wanted nothing but Facts, 'With a rule and a pair of scales, and the multiplication table always in his pocket, Sir, ready to weigh and measure any parcel of human nature, and tell you exactly what it comes to. It is a mere question of figures, a case of simple arithmetic.'

The point being, of course, that even in politics, it never was. I do hope David Blunkett's pause was a pregnant one.

fields.headline: Radio: the full northern breakfast
fields.trailText: The Breakfast Show (R1)
fields.body:
The Breakfast Show (R1)

Night Waves (R3)

WHERE, demanded thousands of Radio 1 listeners (well, one actually), was my intelligent, unbiased appraisal of the new Breakfast Show presenter, Sara Cox, last week? Seven-and-a- half-million kids listened to her predecessor, Zoë Ball; the inheritor of such a fortune must surely merit mention. Exactly so, but two factors persuaded me to bide my whisht, as they say only slightly north of Bolton, from whence Miss Cox hails.

First, I thought it only fair to give her a week to settle into her new job, stage fright and all that. Second, I wanted to report on the arrival of the most important thing in her life by her own admission, after her fella and her career, namely her nine-week-old puppy called _ Ah, that's the point. He didn't have a name, Miss Cox told listeners on her second Monday in the Radio 1 hot seat. She was relying on them to choose one for her.

In years to come, when Sara Cox is as much a part of the media furniture as Sue Lawley and Jenni Murray, critics writing intelligent appraisals of her career will compare the role of that puppy to Flaubert's parrot or Postman Pat's cat.

The word most often used to describe Sara Cox is 'ladette'. Zoë Ball, for all her references to booze and knickers, was essentially feminine, sometimes disarmingly so. With that deliciously husky laugh, she couldn't be anything else. Sara Cox's laugh comes from her belly, her beer belly by the sound of it. She's basic, earthy; she's from up north and proud of it.

She talks about the pool of drool you find under your chin when you know you've had a good night's sleep and how she's shaved her armpits that morning. She d steamrollered through her first show with the confidence of Stormin' Norman. As a role-model, she will inspire shy guys with acne to come out of their shell and sock it to them but I fear for her influence on sweet, fluffy, impressionable little girls, yeah right.

And then, miraculously, we saw the other side of Sara Cox, the sentimental, puppy-owning side. Was it a Rottweiler? A pit bull? No, it was a basset hound, all floppy ears, soppy eyes and drool pools. She noticeably softened after that. 'Eee, I love that Travis track so much,' she whispered, 'it makes me feel sick.' Then she played another one especially for a young lad on his paper round. I like Sara Cox. She's scary but she's real. Her dog is called Snoop, by the way.

Wednesday's Night Waves was a special post- David Irving edition which proved yet again that nothing can touch a good radio discussion. Sarah Dunant led her panel of historians, journalists and Holocaust spokespersons with skill, but through it all I could feel the ghost of that most articulate of all Moral Maze participants, Rabbi Hugo Gryn, looking on. I know he would have commended Sanchia Berg's pre-verdict interview with Irving on the Today programme which, for all its cool control, still gave us the measure of the man.

She d steamrollered through her first show with the confidence of Stormin' Norman. As a role-model, she will inspire shy guys with acne to come out of their shell and sock it to them but I fear for her influence on sweet, fluffy, impressionable little girls, yeah right. And then, miraculously, we saw the other side of Sara Cox, the sentimental, puppy-owning side. Was it a Rottweiler? A pit bull? No, it was a basset hound, all floppy ears, soppy eyes and drool pools. She noticeably softened after that. 'Eee, I love that Travis track so much,' she whispered, 'it makes me feel sick.' Then she played another one especially for a young lad on his paper round. I like Sara Cox. She's scary but she's real. Her dog is called Snoop, by the way. Wednesday's Night Waves was a special post- David Irving edition which proved yet again that nothing can touch a good radio discussion. Sarah Dunant led her panel of historians, journalists and Holocaust spokespersons with skill, but through it all I could feel the ghost of that most articulate of all Moral Maze participants, Rabbi Hugo Gryn, looking on. I know he would have commended Sanchia Berg's pre-verdict interview with Irving on the Today programme which, for all its cool control, still gave us the measure of the man.

webTitle: Huge cash bid to end road chaos

fields.headline: Huge cash bid to end road chaos
fields.trailText: A multi-billion pound package of measures to tackle Britain's crippling transport crisis will be unveiled in July, as the Government attempts to head off public anger about its failed election promises.
fields.body:
A multi-billion pound package of measures to tackle Britain's crippling transport crisis will be unveiled in July, as the Government attempts to head off public anger about its failed election promises.

Treasury officials have been told to open their coffers to fund 'revolutionary' plans to unblock the roads, overhaul rail services and improve public transport.

Chancellor Gordon Brown and Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott have ordered officials to produce plans for the strategy, which will cost up to £10 billion. Details will be released in a spending review this summer.

Projects that will be given top priority include:

 double-decker trains for commuters, with every traveller guaranteed a seat.

 more money for the West Coast mainline to speed up journey times between London, Manchester and Glasgow.

 new high-speed routes into cities, with buses and trams being given dedicated lanes.

 light rail schemes to take pressure off congested roads.

 a task force to tackle traffic jam hotspots, such as the M25 orbital route round London and M6 Midlands corridor.

 new bypasses around traffic-hit towns.

 national concession scheme, so pensioners get cheap public transport.

 'super interchanges' where people can move easily from motorways to rail and buses.

The Government spends less on transport than any other country in Europe. But Ministers know that continuing snarl-ups on roads, delayed trains and poor bus services could cost votes.

Businesses have also complained bitterly that traffic jams and the rail failure has left them with billions of pounds of unnecessary costs.

Although many initiatives have been announced, polling evidence reveals that the public and the business community are not convinced by the Government's efforts.

Government sources said the new money would be tied to results, with every plan given an inflexible deadline.

Figures prepared for Prescott's Transport Department reveal that two-thirds of Londoners travel to work by public transport, but outside London two-thirds of people use their cars. Officials refused to be drawn on how much money would be spent, but there is speculation it could be as much as £10bn of extra funding in the first three years.

Further big increases will also be agreed as part of the Government's 10-year strat egy on transport. Ministers were delighted with the reaction to the £2bn a year lifeline Brown threw to the NHS in last month's Budget. They want a similar 'big bang' for transport. Such a large amount of money will allow the Government to demand results from rail companies and local authorities on transport as they now do from the health service.

Discussions on the 'transport revolution' started last year when the Treasury put forward a position paper on the need for more funding.

Civil servants at the Department of Transport produced a manifesto for change. Lord Macdonald, the Transport Minister, is working on the details and will show them to the Prime Minister, Chancellor and Deputy Prime Minister after Easter.

News of the cash injection comes as the latest damning report reveals the chronic state of Britain's roads. The annual local authority road maintenance survey (the Alarm report) reveals that more than three-quarters of councils believe that the under-funding of road maintenance is a threat to safety.

More than £50 million has been paid out in compensation to people injured in road accidents or who have had their vehicles damaged.

Many councils say they can only afford to resurface roads every 78 years rather than the 20 years safety campaigners suggest.

webTitle: IRA offered new 'war is over' deal

fields.headline: IRA offered new 'war is over' deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland"
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson will lift the suspension of the Northern Ireland power-sharing executive if the IRA states publicly that its war is over for good,  The Observer has learned.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson will lift the suspension of the Northern Ireland power-sharing executive if the IRA states publicly that its war is over for good, The Observer has learned.

The proposed move by the Secretary of State is part of a series of steps contained in a new initiative drawn up in London and Dublin aimed at restoring devolution.

The broad outline of the two governments' position paper includes the following:

 the IRA to state that its war is finished forever;

 the British government then to end the suspension of devolution.

If the Ulster Unionists agree, the Irish and British governments will seek confirmation from the IRA that decommissioning will hap pen within a longer timeframe.

The British will give some concessions to David Trimble's party on the Patten report, particularly the retention of the Harp and Crown badge on new police uniforms.

A spokesman for the Northern Ireland Office said the key issue was to get 'clarity' from the IRA on decommissioning - securing answers to two questions posed by SDLP deputy leader Seamus Mallon last year: 'Will you decommission, and when will you do it?'

British and Irish officials have been working frantically to draw up a common position paper. Jonathan Powell, Downing Street's chief-of-staff, is understood to have been in Dublin last weekend discussing the way forward with officials from the Republic.

However, there are still areas of disagreement on the final shape of the package. Nor is there any guarantee that the IRA will make a definitive statement that their campaign is over for good.

Republicans gather next week for the 84th anniversary of the Easter Rising. The IRA leadership normally uses the event to announce shifts in strategy.

Both governments accept that the deadline for decommissioning written into the Good Friday Agreement, 22 May, will have to be passed. The assurances they are seeking from republicans envisage decommissioning happening in the long term. They also believe they have to make the first move.

webTitle: Positive thinking can kill cancer cells, say psychologists

fields.headline: Positive thinking can kill cancer cells, say psychologists
fields.trailText: The power of positive thought can help cancer patients live longer by boosting their immune systems, according to new research.
fields.body:
The power of positive thought can help cancer patients live longer by boosting their immune systems, according to new research.

The research, presented at a British Psychological Society conference yesterday, described how women diagnosed with cancer and trained in 'relaxation' techniques developed more cells equipped to fight the disease. Professor Leslie Walker of Hull University worked with 80 women who had just been diagnosed with breast cancer. All received normal treatment, including chemotherapy, radiotherapy, hormone therapy and surgery.

But half were also trained in relaxation techniques and guided imagery, where they visualised their bodies' own defences fighting and overcoming cancer cells.

By the end of the 37-week trial, the second group all showed strengthened immune systems. Levels of the white cells that play a vital role in fighting disease increased and the 'killer cells' which scout out and destroy infected or cancerous cells also became more active. Certain types of stress suppress the immune system. Walker said: 'Some of the muscle-relaxing exercises were specifically developed to help people "switch off" their natural "fight/flight" response to high levels of stress. This results in real changes in internal organs, and also affects white blood cells.'

Throughout the usually distressing post-diagnosis and treatment period, the 40 women doing relaxation and visualisation therapy reported real improvements in their quality of life.

Walker said 'Treatments for cancer are often invasive and very upsetting. Developing straightforward techniques that nurses can teach to patients throughout the NHS means that the benefits can be widespread.'

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText:
Vera Duckworth to become Lady Mayoress of Leeds
Coronation Street star Liz Dawn, who plays Vera Duckworth, is to become Lady Mayoress of her home city of Leeds at the invitation of Councillor Bernard Atha, the next Lord Mayor, in recognition of her work for cancer charities.

Vera Duckworth to become Lady Mayoress of Leeds
Coronation Street star Liz Dawn, who plays Vera Duckworth, is to become Lady Mayoress of her home city of Leeds at the invitation of Councillor Bernard Atha, the next Lord Mayor, in recognition of her work for cancer charities.

Hillsborough remembered
Hundreds of relatives and friends of the 96 people killed in the Hillsborough football ground disaster attended a memorial service on its eleventh anniversary.

Boy, 16, on murder charge
A boy aged 16 charged with murdering a four-month-old girl and stealing a car was remanded in custody at Cambridge until 19 April.

Holiday chaos as Tenerife baggage handlers strike
Hundreds of holidaymakers faced massive disruption today at the start of the schools Easter break after baggage handlers went on strike in Tenerife, leaving passengers stranded on the island without luggage.

Climber's body recovered
The body of Craig Heimstra from Essex, who disappeared with an American companion while climbing Mount Shasta in California, was recovered by rescuers.

Crabs menace fish stocks
Chinese mitten crabs, which can grow as big as dinner plates, are threatening fish stocks off the south and east coasts of England by attacking fish and their eggs.

Hollyoaks stampede
More than 20,000 hopefuls aged 16 to 23 queued in London to be auditioned for parts in Channel 4's youth soap Hollyoaks.

Stamped out
A 75p Jersey stamp commemorating Prince William's eighteenth birthday has been withdrawn because its background mistakenly shows Beaumaris instead of Caernarfon Castle.

Brontë letter for auction
A letter written by Charlotte Brontë to her friend John White in 1851 is expected to fetch £10,000 when auctioned next month.

Donkeys saved
Thirty donkeys that were abandoned on Montseratt when the Soufriere Hills volcano became active in 1995 have been rescued by an animal charity. They will be found a new home in St Lucia.

webTitle: Straw set to block 'racist' visitors' bonds

fields.headline: Straw set to block 'racist' visitors' bonds
fields.trailText: The government is set to abandon its controversial bond scheme for people visiting Britain after ministers agreed that it was likely to be unworkable.
fields.body:
The government is set to abandon its controversial bond scheme for people visiting Britain after ministers agreed that it was likely to be unworkable.

Senior government sources said the idea would be 'kicked into the long grass', as a clear message that Labour would not persecute legitimate visitors to Britain. Although pilot schemes will be launched in Casablanca, Manila and the Ukraine, the scheme will not be rolled out worldwide as originally planned.

The Home Office decided to look at the idea of a bond scheme as a way of controlling the numbers of people visiting Britain. The plans were heavily criticised by anti-racist groups. Bill Morris, the black union leader whose stinging attack on the Government on Friday put race at the top of the political agenda, said that it was one of the reasons why he believed that the Government was racist.

In a rearguard action, sources made it clear that Home Secretary Jack Straw was unconvinced that the plans would work. He is concerned that the scheme would be impossible to administer and that £10,000 was not enough money to deter those trying to enter Britain illegally.

The moves will come as a blow to the Immigration Minister, Barbara Roche, who is thought to be a firm supporter of the plans. Straw has also got the backing of the Foreign Office.

The Government was meanwhile facing fresh embarrassment over the issue of race last night, after figures obtained by The Observer revealed that average salaries among black and Asian staff in the civil service are up to £3,500 less than their white counterparts.

New figures from the Cabinet Office show that black and Asian civil servants are more likely to resign than white staff and that in many ranks the proportion of ethnic minority staff has fallen despite policies aimed at redressing racist employment practices in government.

The Commission for Racial Equality has also launched an investigation into practices at the Department for Environment, Transport and the Regions after evidence that promotion policies disadvantage black and Asian staff.

At the highest levels of the Government, there are actually a lower proportion of ethnic minority staff than there were more than 10 years ago. Only 1.7 per cent of staff in the most powerful positions are from ethnic minorities, down from 1.8 per cent in 1989. More than 5.5 per cent of the working population are black or Asian. In the past year only one more person from an ethnic minority background has joined the senior ranks, taking the figure to 55 compared with 3,176 white staff.

But it is in the area of salaries that most concern has been raised. Such is the bias among ethnic minority staff towards lower paid jobs in the civil service that the average earnings of black and Asian men is £16,820. For white men that figure rises to £20,130.

The service's fast-track method for rapidly promoting bright, younger candidates has also been criticised for failing to pick ethnic minority candidates. In one year during the 1990s the scheme, which takes on approximately 100 candidates a year, failed to employ any black or Asian people.

The Government also found itself under fresh attack yesterday from one of Britain's most senior black members of the Church of England. The Rt Rev Wilfred Wood, the Bishop of Croydon, said that talk of 'bogus asylum-seekers' was the 'evocative kind of language that stirs people up' and was similar in tone to Enoch Powell's infamous Rivers of Blood speech.

'We have moved on and are now more populist in the kind of language but the sentiments are the same,' he told Radio 4's Today programme.

Mike Best, editor of the black newspaper, the Voice , warned the Government that it could no longer rely on unswerving ethnic minority support.

fields.headline: Dumb ... and it's getting dumber
fields.trailText: Television really is 'dumbing down'. An  Observer survey has confirmed what discerning TV viewers have long suspected: current affairs, documentaries and drama are being replaced by chat shows, quizzes and docusoaps.
fields.body:
Television really is 'dumbing down'. An Observer survey has confirmed what discerning TV viewers have long suspected: current affairs, documentaries and drama are being replaced by chat shows, quizzes and docusoaps.

Despite claims by BBC and ITV bosses that 'dumbing down' is a myth dreamt up by ageing, out-of-touch broadcasters, the study shows the main channels are serving up more and more trivia.

BBC1 is the worst offender. Greg Dyke, the BBC director-general, who is thought to acknowledge the criticisms, is expected to introduce new 'quality' programming later this year.

The Observer analysed television schedules for 1980, 1990 and this year. The study found the amount of 'light' TV has almost doubled from 17 per cent to 33 per cent over the past 20 years while 'serious' programmes have slumped from 44 per cent to 29 per cent. In 1980 the top 10 programmes on BBC1 included education, drama and current affairs. A decade later current affairs had disappeared from the list, morning television had overtaken drama and educational viewing only just sneaked in. Although news tops the BBC1 list in 2000 - largely because of the decision to screen the digital service News24 throughout the night on BBC1 - current affairs, documentaries and educational programmes have been replaced by docusoaps, quiz shows, chat shows and DIY. Drama, once considered the jewel in the crown of BBC1, is relegated to ninth position.

BBC2 has fared slightly better. Education was in second position in 1980 and made it up to first in 1990 and 2000, largely because of the decision to screen Open University programmes throughout the morning. Current affairs is fifth today and documentaries have held fast in sixth position. New entries in 2000 include fashion and travel.

Although viewers and commentators often complain there is nothing to watch but cookery and gardening programmes, both categories failed to make it into the top 10 for 2000. Gardening's only appearance was bottom of the BBC2 list in 1980.

The changes on commercial television have also been dramatic. Drama topped the schedules on ITV in 1980 but by 1990 and 2000 it had been replaced by morning television. Current affairs programming failed to make it into the top 10 in any year.

Despite scrapping News at Ten , news bulletins made it into second place this year - up from sixth position a decade ago. As with BBC1, quiz shows come seventh. Soap operas are surprisingly low in eighth position, compared with sixth on BBC1.

Educational programmes disappeared from ITV's top 10 between 1980 and 1990 and documentaries do not feature after 1980. Chat shows, which did not appear in previous decades, are now third.

Channel 4, which started broadcasting in 1982, has changed the least. Film topped the schedules in 1990 and 2000, and children's programming has remained in third place. Unlike BBC1, documentaries still make it into the top 10.

The only casualty is news, which has fallen from second position 18 years ago to drop out of the top 10 this year.

Channel 5's aim to produce a schedule of 'films, football and f******' has been realised. Films and sport take first and second positions, followed by programmes about sex or relationships.

Taking all five terrestrial channels together, film, news and education remain in the top 10 but new types of programme, barely screened 20 years ago, are now among the most popular, including quizzes, chat shows, morning television, and docusoaps.

Despite the findings the BBC and ITV, the two largest broadcasters, dismiss claims they have dumbed down.

A BBC spokeswoman told The Observer : 'We broadcast a variety of genres in peak time - more, in fact, than other channels. On BBC1 we have high-quality programmes in peak time on science and medical matters which other channels do not. The audience in 2000 is very different to the audience in 1980 and we have to be mindful of that.

'When you look at the range of programming in tone, style and genre, there is phenomenal quality on the BBC, whichever way you define quality.'

An ITV spokeswoman said: 'As the world and audiences change, schedules are changing but we do not accept that we are dumbing down. In the past two years we have increased the range and diversity of programmes. We have introduced a new flagship current affairs programme - Tonight with Trevor McDonald - and we have doubled our factual output in peak time. This year we are commissioning 20 per cent more 90-minute and two-hour single dramas.

'We are very proud of our record in producing quality television that engages large audiences.'

 Research by Rosalind Ryan and Ellen Bennett

Channel 5's aim to produce a schedule of 'films, football and f******' has been realised. Films and sport take first and second positions, followed by programmes about sex or relationships. Taking all five terrestrial channels together, film, news and education remain in the top 10 but new types of programme, barely screened 20 years ago, are now among the most popular, including quizzes, chat shows, morning television, and docusoaps. Despite the findings the BBC and ITV, the two largest broadcasters, dismiss claims they have dumbed down. A BBC spokeswoman told The Observer : 'We broadcast a variety of genres in peak time - more, in fact, than other channels. On BBC1 we have high-quality programmes in peak time on science and medical matters which other channels do not. The audience in 2000 is very different to the audience in 1980 and we have to be mindful of that. 'When you look at the range of programming in tone, style and genre, there is phenomenal quality on the BBC, whichever way you define quality.' An ITV spokeswoman said: 'As the world and audiences change, schedules are changing but we do not accept that we are dumbing down. In the past two years we have increased the range and diversity of programmes. We have introduced a new flagship current affairs programme - Tonight with Trevor McDonald - and we have doubled our factual output in peak time. This year we are commissioning 20 per cent more 90-minute and two-hour single dramas. 'We are very proud of our record in producing quality television that engages large audiences.'  Research by Rosalind Ryan and Ellen Bennett john.arlidge@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Labour wants Sinn Fein's US backers named

fields.headline: Labour wants Sinn Fein's US backers named
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Personal details of Irish-Americans who send cash to Sinn Fein may be published in an Irish Government register after the next general election in the Republic.
fields.body:
Personal details of Irish-Americans who send cash to Sinn Fein may be published in an Irish Government register after the next general election in the Republic.

Ruari Quinn, the Labour leader, has warned that one of the preconditions for his party entering a new coalition will be a register of foreigners who donate money to Irish parties.

It would include names, addresses and details of private individuals sending money from the US.

Quinn's move is a response to growing concern in the Dail over the amount of money raised, in particular by Sinn Fein in the US. Recent figures show that the republican party gained $700,000 there last year - seven times more than the largest Irish party, Fianna Fail.

The Labour leader said individuals had a right to send money to political causes in Ireland, but all contributions must be made public in future. Quinn said Labour was publishing a policy document in the autumn, which would also call for the outlawing of corporate donations to parties in the state.

In an interview with The Observer last week, Quinn said: 'We would outlaw corporate donations from whatever source and we would require two categories of declaration, one from citizens entitled to vote, that is European Union citizens, and those who are not entitled to vote in the EU.

'I don't think you can stop somebody giving money to a cause they wish to support but I think it's important to know who they are. I am reconciling two rights here: the right of someone to support a cause and the transparency of donations. That isn't the case at the minute. There should be transparency because the business of the public should be done in public.

'The origin of that money should be known. We are not talking about someone donating a five-dollar bill in the Bronx - we are talking about big, big money. Money received above a certain threshold should be declared with the identity of the donors, then the electorate can draw their own conclusions. If the money is not declared, sanctions should kick in. Either they get fined, or if a candidate fails to declare money received they can run the ultimate sanction of being barred from office.'

Quinn said he defended the principle of people raising funds for Irish parties abroad, but added: 'You can't say somebody cannot make a contribution, because they can turn around and say, "You are free to hustle for cash in Brooklyn". But we want to know is it Mafioso people in Brooklyn or straightforward lads from Donegal? The first step in any democracy is openness and transparency. After that an informed public can make informed choices.'

He confirmed that a foreign donors' register would be a condition of Labour's participation in government.

Quinn accepted, however, that partition could create a loophole in the law on funding for parties such as Sinn Fein, which organise in both Ulster and the Republic.

'If you take parties that operate in two jurisdictions it depends where they are registered. If they were registered they would have to comply with a statement of accounts. But I think we could make a case for aligning the funding regulations in both north and south as part of cross-border arrangements through the Good Friday Agreement.

'Perhaps the rules regarding transparency and accountability could even be brought under a European wide directive to cover parties in all the EU states,' he said.

The bar on corporate donations would also affect Irish-Americans who send company funds to parties such as Fianna Fail and Sinn Fein.

Quinn's stance reflects the fact that Labour wants to sever the umbilical connection between big business and Fianna Fail. This relationship has been at the heart of allegations of corruption and political favouritism in the Flood Tribunal.

fields.headline: 'Sell' panic to hit home
fields.standfirst: Focus: the coming crash
fields.trailText: Stockbroking systems face gridlock tomorow morning as thousands of investors, scared by Friday's record-breaking losses on the US markets, try to sell their shares,  write Jamie Doward and Faisal Islam . Following frantic scenes on Wall Street on Friday afternoon, brokers believe the action will move to the living rooms of private investors when world stock markets reopen tomorrow.
fields.body:
Stockbroking systems face gridlock tomorow morning as thousands of investors, scared by Friday's record-breaking losses on the US markets, try to sell their shares, write Jamie Doward and Faisal Islam . Following frantic scenes on Wall Street on Friday afternoon, brokers believe the action will move to the living rooms of private investors when world stock markets reopen tomorrow.

'There's a real fear around,' says a trader. 'I'll be looking at selling on Monday - assuming I can get through to my broker - systems do freeze.'

All three main US stock markets recorded their heaviest drops ever last week as City analysts worried that the US Federal Reserve Board would hike interest rates.

webTitle: Irish soldier aided IRA, says ex-Provo

fields.headline: Irish soldier aided IRA, says ex-Provo
fields.standfirst:
Probe into Garda collusion may need to be extended to Defence Forces

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The investigation into IRA agents working inside the Garda may have to be extended to cover alleged Provisional moles in the Irish army.
fields.body:
The investigation into IRA agents working inside the Garda may have to be extended to cover alleged Provisional moles in the Irish army.

A former Provisional IRA fire-bomber has told The Observer that an intelligence officer in the Irish defence forces helped the IRA in the Monaghan-Armagh border region during the 1980s.

The officer passed information and helped to clear roads for the IRA commander Jim Lynagh, who was shot dead by the SAS at Loughgall in 1987, according to the former Provo.

Vincent McKenna, who has turned his back on republican violence, said Lynagh told him that he had an agent working inside the Defence Forces' barracks in Monaghan town.

The claims are bound to dismay many Irish soldiers, who tend to be hostile to republican terrorism.

McKenna said that Lynagh used the officer to clear roads leading to Northern Ireland during an IRA attack on an RUC border station in the late Eighties.

'My job in the run-up to that operation was to gather intelligence on the base. I had to measure the distance from the base to the Monaghan side of the border in order that the mortar rounds were fired accurately.

'After the attack took place I remember talking to Jim Lynagh about it. He told me he got someone from the barracks to clear the road for his unit, and when I asked who, he just said "an officer in intelligence who had been in the army for 15 years".

'It was around this time that our policy towards the Army and the Garda in Monaghan changed. In the early 1980s the IRA and the Fianna [the IRA's junior wing] beat up Free State soldiers every time we saw them in pubs and clubs. The same went for the Gardai. Then Lynagh said the aggro had to stop. I can only assume the reason was because he had an agent working for him in the bar racks and there was no point antagonising the Free Staters in the base,' McKenna said.

The ex-IRA man said he was prepared to pass on his information to the investigation team established by the Irish government into alleged collusion between individual Gardai and the IRA.

'I have no faith in any inquiry, because if it really looked at what was going on _ there would be an international outcry. In places like Monaghan we had supporters in mainstream political parties like Fianna Fail, who helped local IRA volunteers and backed the republican cause,' he said.

The Republic's Justice Minister, John O'Donoghue, said that the investigation into claims of IRA moles in the Garda were of the 'utmost seriousness'. But he questioned whether there was enough 'tangible evidence' to convict any police officer serving or retired, of offences connected to aiding the IRA.

The claims that individual Garda and now Irish soldiers secretly worked for the IRA during the height of the Troubles have fuelled demands from unionists for the Irish government to hold inquiries into collusion.

Until recently the Irish government backed northern nationalist demands for inquiries into alleged collusion between British security forces and loyalist terrorists.

The family and colleagues of nationalist solicitor Rosemary Nelson, who was murdered in a loyalist bomb attack last year, claim that prior to her murder she was threatened by RUC officers.

webTitle: Computers rot our children's brains: expert

fields.headline: Computers rot our children's brains: expert
fields.trailText: Computers can rot young children's brains, a parenting expert warned yesterday. The warning is set to alarm parents who believe they must introduce their children to computers at ever younger ages.
fields.body:
Computers can rot young children's brains, a parenting expert warned yesterday. The warning is set to alarm parents who believe they must introduce their children to computers at ever younger ages.

Dr Jane Healy, an educational psychologist from America, told a conference in London that instead of helping to advance a child's knowledge, computers can stunt the healthy development of a child's mind, reducing attention span and hampering language skills. Parents who feel guilty about not buying their child a computer and expensive 'learning software' will be relieved.

Healy told the Parent Child 2000 conference that parents should limit the time youngsters spend using computers and watching television. Rather than living in an 'unchallenging, two-dimensional world', they should interact with others around them.

Demolishing the hype of what she calls the 'technology-pushers', Healy condemned the conventional wisdom that declares every child must have a computer at home and in school. Studies have shown that children under the age of seven are likely to be better off without them.

Dr Healy told the conference: 'It is playing with the parental hormone, guilt, to make them believe that if a child doesn't have a computer by the age of three it's not going to get a job.

'But quite to the contrary, it is limiting children's physical development and taking too much time away from what they should be doing. They are, in fact, damaging the brain development in the sense that it's going to make it harder for them to learn at school.'

In the US, schools spent more than $4 billion on computers last year, and the market for 'edutainment' software is growing at about 30 per cent a year. Tony Blair has promised to connect every UK school to the Internet.

Rye College in Watford runs lessons for 18-month-old infants, using software aimed at the very young. They learn about shapes, colours and simple words. At two and a half, children begin programming and basic word processing.

But Healy said: 'Most of this software ... is doing more harm than good.'

webTitle: BMW to study new bid to save Rover jobs

fields.headline: BMW to study new bid to save Rover jobs
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: BMW has pledged to examine an eleventh-hour bid for Rover put together by the company's former chief executive John Towers. Towers says it could save thousands of jobs at the Longbridge car plant in the West Midlands.
fields.body:
BMW has pledged to examine an eleventh-hour bid for Rover put together by the company's former chief executive John Towers. Towers says it could save thousands of jobs at the Longbridge car plant in the West Midlands.

Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers said yesterday the German car giant had promised to consider plans put forward by the Phoenix consortium, which has emerged as a rival bidder to Alchemy Partners, a venture capital group that wants to concentrate on building sports cars at Longbridge, a move leading to thousands of job losses.

Alchemy, which would concentrate on building MG cars, cutting back production of the Rover 25, 45 and 75 models, dismissed the Phoenix bid as 'unrealistic'. 'We think the way we are going gives an opportunity for a growing viable MG car company,' Alchemy's chief Jon Moulton said.

The news that the BMW board was to study Phoenix's proposals was welcomed by Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union.

webTitle: E-mail shoppers find it's quicker to phone

fields.headline: E-mail shoppers find it's quicker to phone
fields.standfirst: Britain's top 30 companies rapped for taking days to react to their websites
fields.trailText: British Airways, once proud to call itself the world's favourite airline, has come last in an investigation of customer service standards.
fields.body:
British Airways, once proud to call itself the world's favourite airline, has come last in an investigation of customer service standards.

A second national institution, BT, comes joint last in the report by the consumer watchdog Which? even though it has spent millions expanding communication via the Internet.

Although most of the 30 top businesses reacted promptly to telephone calls, they were much slower to answer via e-mail. Half, including banks and supermarkets, failed to reply within 48 hours to customer queries via websites.

The findings are bad news for companies pushing customers to use new technology in order to cut costs at call centres and high street branches. 'Consumers are increasingly reliant on electronic methods of communicating,' said Which? Online head Paul Kitchen. 'We were really surprised to find that a significant number of companies were providing such a poor e-mail response service. Online customer services should at least match and not fall short of traditional meth ods of enquiry. It seems that it's good to talk but slow to e-mail.'

British Airways, however, was quick to respond when told of the report and launched an immediate inquiry. A spokeswoman flatly denied that the airline had failed three times to answer e-mailed questions within 72 hours, the time limit set by Which? 'I have tracked down the computer records for two of these three questions and both were answered well within 24 hours,' she said. 'There is no question in my mind that these messages were replied to. This is a serious allegation and it is not fair that BA should be in the bottom four. We have had no other complaints about this and we receive 1,300 e-mails each week.'

Which? Online stands by its criticism. Head of market research Leslie Sopp insisted: 'They received automated acknowledgments of their questions to their e-mail addresses but not the answers. If British Airways can show us that responses were actually sent to the e-mail addresses of our investigators then we would have to look at this again.'

The watchdog's findings were accepted by BT, which admitted that responses from its flagship website 'have not been good enough'.

'We have a target of responding within 24 hours and we have not met this,' said a spokesman. 'As a company in the business of communications we should be doing better and we are going to improve our systems and increase the number of people answering e-mail inquiries.'

webTitle: Dyke axe to fall on 1,000 at BBC

fields.headline: Dyke axe to fall on 1,000 at BBC
fields.standfirst: Special report: future of the BBC
fields.trailText: Up to 50 journalists, news producers and researchers will be told this week they will lose their jobs when Greg Dyke, the BBC's new Director-General, launches his long-awaited crackdown on waste and inefficiency.
fields.body:
Up to 50 journalists, news producers and researchers will be told this week they will lose their jobs when Greg Dyke, the BBC's new Director-General, launches his long-awaited crackdown on waste and inefficiency.

Dozens of newsroom posts will be axed as flagship BBC1 news programmes are merged with the troubled rolling news channel, News 24. The first cuts will be announced this week, when news chiefs scrap BBC1's Breakfast News and News 24's Breakfast programme and replace them with a single bulletin.

Dyke's move, which will save £1 million, is the first in a series of cuts that will see up to 1,000 jobs go. Insiders say he is prepared to become the first BBC boss to drive through compulsory redundancies in the newsroom.

The decision to merge BBC1 and News 24 bulletins is the first step toward creating the streamlined corporation 'with no duplication' that Dyke said he wanted when he first addressed the BBC's 22,000 staff two weeks ago.

It is also designed to answer criticism of News 24 which costs more than £50m a year to run but attracts fewer viewers than Rupert Murdoch's Sky News .

Roger Mosey, director of television news, will argue that producing two early morning news programmes wastes resources.

Up to 50 posts will be axed. Although news chiefs say they are 'pretty sure' most staff will find other BBC jobs, insiders who have seen the plans for the merged programme say some will be laid off. 'The figure is around 30,' one said.

The combined breakfast news programme, which will go out on air this autumn, will be renamed and is likely to be presented by current Middle East correspondent Jeremy Bowen.

webTitle: My escape from hellhole cell in the 'Bangkok Hilton'

fields.headline: My escape from hellhole cell in the 'Bangkok Hilton'
fields.standfirst: EXCLUSIVE  Judith Payne faced 10 years in jail after Thai police found drugs in her room. Here she tells the story of her trek to freedom through the jungle to Tracy McVeigh
fields.trailText: A young British woman spoke yesterday for the first time about her ordeal after she fled a Thai jail and escaped through the jungles of Malaysia before making it home safely to Britain last week.
fields.body:
A young British woman spoke yesterday for the first time about her ordeal after she fled a Thai jail and escaped through the jungles of Malaysia before making it home safely to Britain last week.

More than a stone lighter and with her hair falling out in clumps because of stress, 21-year-old Judith Payne told how she walked for two weeks through Malaysian rainforest in plastic flip-flops after spending weeks locked in a fetid prison cell, where she was being held for drug offences.

In an exclusive interview with The Observer, the dental nurse from Yorkshire described how she dodged armed police and border patrols while navigating with a compass as she made her desperate attempt to get home.

The nightmare began after Payne left home in Castleford four months ago for a backpacking trip to Thailand and Australia. She wanted to travel after splitting up with her fiancé and reading The Beach, the bestselling novel by Alex Garland - now a film - about backpacking adventures in Thailand.

She used the money saved for her wedding to fund the trip. But instead of lazing on exotic beaches, she found herself crammed into a cell with 24 other prisoners in the notorious 'Bangkok Hilton', the rat-infested women's jail in the Thai capital where violence among inmates is rife and suicides are commonplace.

It had all started so promisingly last December. 'It was all I'd dreamt it would be,' she said yesterday. 'I missed my mum, but it was incredible to be in this beautiful place.'

A graphic designer, Gilligan was also taking time out to travel.

'He was going to an island the next day to find his friends, so he went off to arrange things and I went and booked my ticket,' said Payne. She waited for friends downstairs, but they did not turn up. Gilligan and Payne both turned in for the night.

That night she cried herself to sleep while the other women, mostly drug addicts and thieves, laughed at her distress.

'They would talk about me among themselves and point at how red my nose got when I cried. One woman spoke English, but as soon as I refused to give her money she would pretend not to hear me when I talked to her.'

She had no idea how the routine worked or how to get food or water. Then we had to sit under an open-sided building until it was time to go to back to the cells. I thought I'd rot away there.

The guards gave them sticks to beat their fellow prisoners and many would also abuse inmates sexually. 'There was a lot of pressure on the women from the lesbian warders. It was very frightening.

'But the worst was the beatings. Old women and the mentally ill were all shoved in together and often beaten. I saw a pregnant woman being battered by sticks. It was terrible to watch. In England, the Payne and Gilligan families were told by the Foreign Office what had happened. A Bangkok lawyer was hired and, after three weeks, the pair were released on bail of £5,000 each, raised by their families.

Gilligan was waiting for Payne when she was released. 'It was such a foolish thing I had done, but I knew the women's prison was worse than the men's and all I could think about was if she was OK,' he said yesterday. Then they boarded a train heading for the border with Malaysia.

'I couldn't believe we were doing it, but I was just driven by the fear of going back to jail,' Payne said. 'We just thought to get as far south as possible where the border crossings to Malaysia are less guarded.'

The 26-hour train journey put nearly 500 miles between the terrified pair and Bangkok. 'Armed police were on the train. One came and stood at my elbow so I picked up the Lonely Planet and pretended to read it as if we were any other tourists. I couldn't even focus on the words, I was just waiting for him to grab my shoulder.'

At the end of the line James and Judith walked to the border, fearful of every car and every footfall behind them. They bribed their way past a border post with $10 and were in Malaysia. But their ordeal was not over. The alarm had been raised in Bangkok and the fugitives knew Thailand had an extradition agreement with Malaysia.

They decided not to risk walking along the main road to Kuala Lumpur, which was lined with police and army checkpoints, and instead walked through the jungle towards the capital.

'We had to avoid people; we had no papers, so if we were caught we would be sent straight back to Thailand. The jungle was just buzzing with noise. In a different context it would have been fascinating, but we were so scared.' The rainforests are dangerous places for the most experienced adventurer, and it was a terrifying environment for the two runaways. Insects the size of teacups, giant spiders, lynx and Asian tigers, poisonous cobras and bone-crushing pythons inhabit it.

At night they hung their hammocks from trees, wrapped themselves in mosquito nets and fell into fitful sleep. 'We argued all the time, our feet were sore and the tension was unbearable. At one point we came to a river and had to swim across and walk on in wet clothes,' she said.

Their hunger overcame their fear of poisoning, and they ate exotic-looking fruits they found on the forest floor. Eventually, the forest cover petered out, and they hitched a lift to Kuala Lumpur.

'It was incredible to reach the city but even then we were not out of trouble. We went straight to the British Embassy to get temporary passports so we could fly out. We had to wait a week and that was pretty nerve-racking, wondering if the Thais would catch up with us,' said Gilligan.

During the ordeal, the pair became close and are now romantically involved. 'We have stuck together; until now we haven't spoken to anyone about what happened, not even our families, so we needed to support each other,' said Gilligan.

Safely back at home, Payne nodded in agreement: 'I am only now starting to take it all in, I can't believe we managed to get out and I know I'm lucky to be alive.' Gazing out over Yorkshire on a rainy spring day, past the smoking towers of the power station, she added: 'I guess one day we'll put it down to experience but it hasn't put me off travelling. There are still a lot of beautiful places out there we want to see.'

webTitle: Revealed: GM firm faked test figures

fields.headline: Revealed: GM firm faked test figures
fields.standfirst:
Poor crop results were replaced by a forgery, Ministry's internal paper shows

Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Results from vital Government-backed crop trials to assess genetically-modified seeds have been falsified, The Observer can reveal.
fields.byline: by Antony Barnett Public Affairs Editor
fields.body:
Results from vital Government-backed crop trials to assess genetically-modified seeds have been falsified, The Observer can reveal.

Internal minutes from the Ministry of Agriculture, obtained by this newspaper, show that an employee at a Suffolk-based firm, Grainseed, manipulated scientific data to make certain seeds in the trials appear to perform better than they really did.

This will cast a shadow over the Government's programme of GM trials, and further undermine public confidence in the controversial crop technology. MPs and environmentalists want the trials suspended.

Crucially, the trials involving Grainseed are being relied on by the Government to enable the first GM crop in Britain to be made commercially available to farmers.

Earlier this month, the Government proposed that a GM maize known as Chardon LL, which will be used as an animal feed, should be put on the National List of Seeds which farmers may buy.

MPs and environmentalists have already objected to this listing on the grounds that its potential environmental impact has not been properly assessed, and it could cross-pollinate with other crops. They say it has not been tested for food safety on cattle.

Labour's Alan Simpson said: 'This is confirmation of all our worst fears that the Government's GM policy is being driven by bad or fraudulent science. They are reliant on the industry that wants to sell these seeds to monitor the trials. This is insane, and criminally irresponsible. If data from one company has been falsified how do we know others have not been up to the same.'

The minutes give precise details of how the Grainseed employee manipulated his data. When the harvest showed that some crops were not doing as well as was hoped, he simply forged the results. It was only after an investigation by firm's managing director that the full extent of the fraud came to light.

The employee boosted the amount of the crop's 'dry matter' - a crucial measurement which shows how effective the maize would be in animal feed: the more dry matter, the better the crop.

The Ministry documents - taken from a meeting on 11 February, said: 'An employee of Grainseed altered the data from the... trials at Crewe so that they appeared to be within protocol for dry matter content at harvest.

'It appears that he then went on to manipulate the data on individual varieties which had the effect of increasing the dry matter yields of some and decreasing those of others.'

While the company's data from the 1999 trials have now been excluded, environmentalists are concerned that Grainseed's 1998 GM trial results are still being relied on by the Government.

Friends of the Earth believes all the data involving the GM maize should now be discarded. Pete Riley, the group's food campaigner, said: 'The whole process must be suspended and the trials declared null and void.

'How can the public have any confidence in a Government decision which is based on scientific data from a company which has been shown to produce fake data.'

An official at the Cabinet Office, which runs the Government's GM policy, said: 'We have a robust system in place to ensure we base decisions on sound science. This includes routine tests to double-check all data.

'Irregularities were identified in the data supplied by Grainseed. All of the affected data from this year was discounted... and had no bearing on the proposed list[ing] of Chardon LL.'

In the trials Grainseed was acting as an agent for the British Plant Breeders Society. This body is run by Roger Turner, who is a senior figure in SCIMAC, the key organisation responsible for commercialising GM technology and for finding trial sites.

Nobody at Grainseed was prepared to comment.
