fields.headline: Dentists ruin teeth for profit
fields.standfirst:
Dentists accused of inflicting £200m of extra scaling, X-rays and fillings on patients to boost earnings
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's dentists are inflicting at least £200 million of unnecessary and even harmful treatment on patients each year, according to one of the UK's most respected dental experts.
fields.body:
Britain's dentists are inflicting at least £200 million of unnecessary and even harmful treatment on patients each year, according to one of the UK's most respected dental experts.

A damning report, to be presented to the Dental Practice Board conference in Eastbourne tomorrow, will say that dentists are boosting their incomes by insisting on too many check-ups, taking too many X-rays, doing unnecessary scaling and polishing, and replacing fillings too frequently.

Aubrey Sheiham, professor of public health at University College London, says: 'Numerous dental procedures are ineffective at best and harmful in many cases.'

The study is a dramatic demonstration of recent concern that dentists - who earn on average £50,000 a year - are being financially motivated to do treatments that are based on tradition rather than medical evidence. Last month the National Institute of Clinical Excellence ruled that dentists should stop taking wisdom teeth out as a precautionary measure. It said there was no evidence that there is any medical benefit from extracting wisdom teeth unless they are diseased.

Sheiham claims there is no medical evidence to support dentists' insistence that people need a check-up every six months. The twice-yearly check-up was first mentioned in The Toothache, a storybook for children published in 1849, that quickly entered dental mythology. 'Recall intervals can safely be extended to 18 months for most age groups. For those over 20 years old, longer intervals of three to five years are recommended,' says the study. Overall, adults endure between 6 million and 10 million unnecessary dental check-ups each year, wasting up to £120m.

More than 13 million scalings and polishings are done every year, at a cost to the NHS of more than £100m, and yet there is no evidence of any medical benefit. Within 72 hours they are as dirty as they were before the cleaning. There is also no benefit from having X-rays every year. Dental decay is so slow that X-rays are only required every five years. Replacing missing molars with false teeth may have a cosmetic benefit but there is no health gain. Modern foods are so tender they can easily be chewed without the full set of molars.

Studies show that dentists replace fillings far more than necessary, and that if they suffer a drop in income, they will replace their patients' fillings more frequently. The less someone visits a dentist, the longer their fillings last, because it gives their dentist fewer opportunities to replace them prematurely.

Fillings should last at least 15 years, and Sheiham claims that if a filling needs replacing within five years, it is professional incompetence and should be replaced free. The reason that women lose their teeth earlier than men, he says, is because they visit their dentist more often.

Compared with other doctors, dentists have almost total clinical freedom to do whatever they want, and are paid for each piece of work they do. A year after having his wisdom teeth out, Theo Howe was told by his dentist that he needed 13 fillings. He sought a second opinion from another dentist who told him he needed only one. 'It was clear the dentist was just trying to boost her work. I find it gutting that I went through all the pain and expense of having my wisdom teeth out when it was completely unnecessary,' he said. 'But there is little you can do but trust your dentist.'

Dentists are only likely to face discipline in extreme cases, but can then be barred from practising. Earlier this year Stuart Molloy, who claimed to be one of Britain's best dental surgeons, was struck off after giving 18 unnecessary root fillings to a man who had visited him with a cracked tooth and sore tongue. Another patient, Sheila Muggleston, visited Molloy's practice complaining of pain in her upper jaw, and ended up spending £2,000 on dental treatment that left her with broken facial bones. Molloy told another patient she needed all her top teeth taken out, although a second opinion revealed she only had one problem tooth. Molloy claimed he was trying to nip problems in the bud.

Another dentist, Melvyn Megitt, earned £600,000 in a single year by seeing 150 patients a day. Megitt was eventually found guilty on five charges of misconduct after deliberately snapping braces to ensure they needed further treatment.

Sheiham claims that the amount of unnecessary dental work will increase unless the number of dentists is cut back sharply. Improving dental health - the result of better diet and toothpaste not better dental treatment - means there is less and less work for dentists to do. He says that idle dentists will find new markets: 'A hungry dentist is a dangerous dentist. Dentists will look for new work to do. They'll tell patients to have their teeth whitened or straightened; they'll tell them to replace coloured fillings with white ones. They will start offering treatments to stop snoring, although there's no evidence that it works.'

Replacing missing molars with false teeth may have a cosmetic benefit but there is no health gain. Modern foods are so tender they can easily be chewed without the full set of molars. Studies show that dentists replace fillings far more than necessary, and that if they suffer a drop in income, they will replace their patients' fillings more frequently. The less someone visits a dentist, the longer their fillings last, because it gives their dentist fewer opportunities to replace them prematurely. Fillings should last at least 15 years, and Sheiham claims that if a filling needs replacing within five years, it is professional incompetence and should be replaced free. The reason that women lose their teeth earlier than men, he says, is because they visit their dentist more often. Compared with other doctors, dentists have almost total clinical freedom to do whatever they want, and are paid for each piece of work they do. A year after having his wisdom teeth out, Theo Howe was told by his dentist that he needed 13 fillings. He sought a second opinion from another dentist who told him he needed only one. 'It was clear the dentist was just trying to boost her work. I find it gutting that I went through all the pain and expense of having my wisdom teeth out when it was completely unnecessary,' he said. 'But there is little you can do but trust your dentist.' Dentists are only likely to face discipline in extreme cases, but can then be barred from practising. Earlier this year Stuart Molloy, who claimed to be one of Britain's best dental surgeons, was struck off after giving 18 unnecessary root fillings to a man who had visited him with a cracked tooth and sore tongue. Another patient, Sheila Muggleston, visited Molloy's practice complaining of pain in her upper jaw, and ended up spending £2,000 on dental treatment that left her with broken facial bones. Molloy told another patient she needed all her top teeth taken out, although a second opinion revealed she only had one problem tooth. Molloy claimed he was trying to nip problems in the bud. Another dentist, Melvyn Megitt, earned £600,000 in a single year by seeing 150 patients a day. Megitt was eventually found guilty on five charges of misconduct after deliberately snapping braces to ensure they needed further treatment. Sheiham claims that the amount of unnecessary dental work will increase unless the number of dentists is cut back sharply. Improving dental health - the result of better diet and toothpaste not better dental treatment - means there is less and less work for dentists to do. He says that idle dentists will find new markets: 'A hungry dentist is a dangerous dentist. Dentists will look for new work to do. They'll tell patients to have their teeth whitened or straightened; they'll tell them to replace coloured fillings with white ones. They will start offering treatments to stop snoring, although there's no evidence that it works.' anthony.browne@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Noye linked to more killings
fields.standfirst: The M25 road rage murderer could have ordered at least three gangland deaths while on the run.  Tony Thompson  reports on a brutal life of crime which began at the age of three
fields.trailText: The M25 road rage murderer could have ordered at least three gangland deaths while on the run.  Tony Thompson  reports on a brutal life of crime which began at the age of three.
fields.body:
Kenneth Noye, sentenced to life imprisonment for the M25 road rage murder of Stephen Cameron last week, is believed to have ordered at least three gangland killings in the time between Cameron's death and his own extradition to Britain, The Observer can reveal.

Detectives now believe that south London car dealer John Marshall - found shot dead in his Range Rover a few days after Noye had fled the country in May 1996 - was murdered in cold blood to prevent a link being made between Noye and the car he was driving at the time he stabbed Cameron.

Marshall had supplied Noye with false papers and number plates showing that the killer's Land Rover Discovery was owned by an Anthony Francis. Marshall was about to be visited by police trying to track down the vehicle. Underworld sources say that Noye, fearing his true identity would be revealed, ordered him to be silenced. Marshall's murder is still unsolved.

Noye has also been linked to the November 1996 murder of Keith Hedley, shot dead on his yacht in Corfu. Hedley and Noye had once been close friends, but fell out over money. Noye is believed to have visited Corfu during his time on the run.

Noye's name has also surfaced in connection with the killing of Daniel Roff, shot dead behind the wheel of his Mercedes outside his home in Bromley, south London, in March 1997. Roff, suspected of being the look-out in the murder of Great Train Robber Charlie Wilson in 1990, was confined to a wheelchair following an assassination attempt 18 months earlier. Like Hedley, he is believed to have crossed Noye.

Until last week, Noye was widely regarded as one of the most powerful and clever criminals of his generation. His downfall came not through his numerous criminal enterprises, but because of his short temper. This flared when he was cut up by a van being driven by Danielle Cable and her fiancé, Stephen Cameron, on a roundabout linking the M25 and M20.

Both vehicles stopped at a red traffic light and Noye leapt out of his car to confront Cameron. A brawl started but Cameron gained the upper hand, so Noye went to his car and returned to plunge the knife he always carried twice into Stephen's chest. Cameron died in the arms of his girlfriend, while Noye coolly drove off.

The following day, a briefcase full of cash in hand, Noye was flown by private helicopter from the Bristol area to northern France. He took a train to Paris, then journeyed south by private jet to Madrid. He flew on to the Canary Islands, then to North Africa before settling in southern Spain.

His idyll lasted only a few months before Noye was publicly named as the chief suspect in the Cameron murder, to the annoyance of Kent police, who had suspected him from the start but wanted to keep his involvement secret until they knew where he was. It was not the first time he had hit the headlines.

Kenneth James Noye was born on 24 May, 1947, at Maternity House, Lavernock Road, Bexleyheath, Kent, since bulldozed.

He was the apple of his mother Edith's eye, her only son, but Noye's criminal activity started when he was just three. He fell from a tree in a neighbour's garden while pinching apples. He broke his nose, giving it a dent that still gives him the look of a boxer. Aged five, his mother caught him stealing money from a till in Woolworths while she chatted to a shop assistant.

At 11, bored by lessons at Bexleyheath Secondary Modern School, he got his kicks at break times by picking on smaller pupils and making money from a dinner money protection racket.

A fellow pupil, Mick Marshall, now 51, said: 'He was vile. He didn't give a damn who he hurt. You never knew who he was going to pick on next. And that Kenny had a knack of getting away with blue murder.

'I will never forget being about 14 and sitting in the playground with my lunch when Noye grabbed my sandwiches out of my hands and smashed them into my face, breaking my nose. There was no reason for him to do it, and when he saw me covered in blood he laughed. He got a kick out of physical violence.'

While still at school Noye began his first truly profitable crime, receiving stolen bikes, stripping them down and selling them on. He quickly moved on to selling stolen car parts and jewellery, and acting as a fence for burglars. These crimes led to a year in Borstal. Ironically, it was while he was waiting to see a barrister about some of the accusations that he began chatting to a legal secretary, Brenda Tremain, who would soon become his wife.

By his early twenties, Noye was no longer happy being a small-time criminal. He hung around the Hilltop Hotel, a few hundred yards from his home in West Kingsdown, Kent, which was a haunt of notorious gangland figures such as the Richardsons and associates of the Krays. He began building up contacts throughout the underworld.

Noye played from both ends of the court. He used his contacts to get more work as a fixer and fence, but stayed ahead of the game by signing up as a police informer. He even joined the Freemasons to cement his police contacts.

As his profits and family grew, a new home became Noye's next priority. He bought a 20-acre site in School Lane, West Kingsdown, but was refused permission to pull down the existing bunga low and rebuild it. A few weeks later it was the victim of a freak electrical fault and was burnt to the ground. Noye built his dream home.

Noye was careful to ensure he had the guise of a successful, legitimate businessman. He ran a haulage company and traded gold bullion, an area of speciality that made him an obvious choice for the villains attempting to dispose of the £23 million of bullion stolen during the 1983 Brink's-Mat robbery.

By 1986, Noye was believed by police to have access to regular supplies of Brink's-Mat gold. On Saturday, 26 January, 1985, surveillance officer John Fordham was cornered by Noye's three rottweilers as he watched the gangster's £1m home. Noye believed, he said later, that he was being targeted by an underworld assassin. In a frenzy of supposed self-defence, he stabbed Fordham 11 times. Noye was cleared of murder when the jury accepted his story.

Helen Barnett, a police cadet who helped search Noye's house after the stabbing, recalls finding several secret compartments, where 11 gold bars would eventually be found, and the fact that his sound system was hooked up to play the title track from the James Bond movie, Goldfinger , each time someone walked into his room.

'I also remember that officers discovered that the electricity used to heat his swimming pool had been wired up to a supply for an adjacent old people's home.'

Although cleared of murder, Noye was kept in jail, and later sentenced to 14 years, for handling the Brink's-Mat gold. As he was sent down, he screamed at the jury: 'I hope you all die of cancer.'

Even today, Noye is known to have access to vast quantities of cash. He is said to have placed a £300,000 contract on the life of Danielle Cable - living under a new identity through the police witness protection programme - and offered cronies up to £5m to help bust him out of jail.

fields.headline: Gridlock Britain's last chance
fields.standfirst: Labour promises a transport revolution - but if it fails to deliver, it will pay a heavy costTransport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: New Labour has been making transport promises ever since it took office - but three years on, all the weary public gets is jams.
fields.byline: Kamal Ahmed, Louise Tickle and Joanna Walters
fields.body:
If Mair Evans's alarm clock lets her down tomorrow morning, she won't be getting her bus to work, because there isn't one that gets her there on time. Instead, she will have to walk the three miles from her village on Anglesey to her job as office administrator for the RSPB in its Bangor office, and hope it isn't raining.

'Every trip, whether to work, going shopping or even a day out at a weekend, ends up as a planning marathon,' she says. Starting at 5am is not unknown. A journey to Cardiff last month saw her take a cab to Bangor station, wait on a cold platform for the 6am train that took her on a four-hour detour into England, before dropping her at the Cardiff platform 20 stations later at just after 10 o'clock. Five hours to cover just over 200 miles.

And then there's Sophie Tranchell, managing director of the Day Chocolate Company in London. She became so frustrated with five months of delays, missed connections and non-appearing buses that she moved the office so it was closer to where she lived.

'It can be a truly miserable experience travelling at rush hour from my station, Lewisham, into central London,' she says. 'Even now, I get on to the platform in the morning and sigh when the train turns up, literally stuffed full of very unhappy, stressed people, because there aren't enough carriages. At the old office, when I finally got into London, I ended up waiting for ridiculous amounts of time on tube platforms for the phantom Circle line.'

And then there's Heather Smith, a support worker for adults with learning disabilities, who has to co-ordinate shift work on different sites around Brighton with caring for a young baby. After struggling for a year, Heather has given up on relying on buses and trains and bought a car.

'In the year since I had Conlan, trying to make everything work by using public transport has been exhausting and finally impossible,' she says. 'Going shopping by bus with a baby sounds so mundane, but everyone has to shop for food, and it's made difficult for anyone who isn't young, fit and babyless.'

The car has made an enormous difference to Smith. "We whizz to my current work in 10 minutes rather than it taking an hour and a half. I don't like the idea that I'm contributing to the awful traffic in Brighton when we go into town but, after a year of struggling, I just can't fight with buses and trains any more.'

These are the everyday stories of people trying to make the best of Britain's creaking transport system. The impossibly complex arrangements, the lack of connections, the standing around for trains that never arrive, buses that are cancelled or, if they do set off, are doomed to sit in traffic jams because someone is digging up the road.

Evans, Tranchell and Smith are important, because people like them are starting to blame the Government - and the Government knows it.

New Labour has been making transport promises ever since it took office - but three years on, all the weary public gets is jams.

At last, however, the Government has said it will act decisively. There will be big plans and 'multi-billions' of pounds, according to the Treasury. Just as health received a huge boost in the Budget, Ministers are now planning a similar injection of cash for transport in July.

The ambition is huge: a transport revolution that will change the face of Britain. Look 10 years into the future and this is what the Government wants to see: double-decker trains whisking commuters into the cities; high-speed bus and tram routes; stations at major motorway junctions so that people can leave their cars and jump on to frequent, high-speed train links to the city.

And more. The congested, creeping river of traffic that is the M6 at Birmingham will be tackled with road building and rapid public transport systems. The M25 will be the target of a taskforce that will work at plans to encourage people out of their cars and on to public transport. London will have its own tram network. A national scheme for cheaper travel for pensioners will reduce pressure on the roads. We will live in a country where the travel from A to B will not be the nightmare it too often is at present. Bus routes will be integrated with trains which will be integrated with roads.

Sources told The Observer last week that the government would crack chronic congestion with new taxes on traffic that, in a policy triumph for transport over Treasury tight-fistedness, would be spent on gleaming new trains, trams, buses and cycle lanes. The private sector would bankroll the best projects and, with the biggest investment since Victorian times, Britain would be on the move again.

The Observer first exposed the transport crisis last summer. Inertia, indecision, underfunding and Cabinet splits stifled the policies of Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott, who admitted it would take up to 10 years to solve. One year on and the good ideas have not gone away. And neither have the problems. The Prime Minister, Tony Blair, and Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, want to lift transport out of the morass and, as with health, make the providers of the services - rail companies, bus firms and local authorities - take the strain. It will be the big summer message.

The past year has been a disaster for railways and roads and a tangle of indecision for government. A report to be published tomorrow reveals that three-quarters of local authorities in England believe that underfunding of essential road maintenance is now putting safety at risk.

Tomorrow's announcement of the results of the Annual Local Authority Road Maintenance (Alarm) survey will show that councils paid out £34 million last year to road users for accidents caused by crumbling and potholed streets, a 50 per cent increase on 1998.

Some authorities said their road maintenance budgets were the lowest in real terms since 1974, and if funding did not increase they could only afford to resurface roads once every 78 years instead of the recommended 20 years.

Britain spends less per head on transport than Germany, France, Finland, Portugal, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland and, according to the Automobile Association, has the worst road congestion in Europe. If the measures to reduce congestion in the Transport Bill, at present grinding its way through Parliament, are not rigorously implemented, the Government's own forecasts show there will be 35 per cent more traffic in 10 years' time than there was in 1996 and 65 per cent more congestion.

Meanwhile, about 3,600 people are killed in road accidents every year and 43,000 are seriously injured. Almost 25,000 people die prematurely each year because of air pollution, much of which can be attributed to road vehicles.

Railtrack, which is responsible for the condition of Britain's tracks and signals, has been attacked for its patchy investment record and poor stewardship of the network. The Government has also been criticised for failing to commit funds to automatic signalling and for being slow to get a grip on reshaping the railways to improve performance and investment.

And all the while, as papers and clever documents are passed backwards and forwards between Ministers, the great British public struggles to overcome gridlock and shambles. Evans battling her way to and from her Anglesey home; Tranchell stuffed into another miserable commuter train in London, and Smith sitting in traffic jams around Brighton because local public transport isn't good enough. The Government knows these three are not alone.

webTitle: Age need not weary the marathon runner

fields.headline: Age need not weary the marathon runner
fields.trailText: A record number of pensioners have entered today's London marathon, amid growing speculation that in the next few years the world will see the first 100-year-old finish the 26.2-mile run.
fields.body:
A record number of pensioners have entered today's London marathon, amid growing speculation that in the next few years the world will see the first 100-year-old finish the 26.2-mile run. Geriatric marathon running is one of the fastest growing areas of sport, as people in their eighties and nineties exchange zimmer frames for jogging shoes. New training methods allow most old people to double their strength.

More than 1,300 people over 60 have entered this year's London marathon, an increase of over 30 per cent since 1995. However, it is among the oldest runners that the rise has been most dramatic. There are 185 entrants over 70, two thirds more than five years ago, and 31 over 80, three times the 1995 figure.

New age records are expected this year for both men and women, with the American Abraham Weintraub - born four years before the First World War - becoming the first nonagenarian to enter.

The oldest female runner is the Scotswoman Jenny Wood-Allen, who is aged 88 and began running marathons against her doctor's advice at 71 after 20 years of doing no exercise. She has since run 30 marathons, with a best time of 4 hours 21 minutes.

Wood-Allen says she is not surprised that marathon running is popular among octagenarians. 'The longer mileage is more amenable to the older person than the short runs. As we get older, our speed decreases, but our stamina increases,' she said.

In recent years, geriatric marathon running has become more competitive, with the World Association of Veteran Athletes compiling record times for each age-group. The world record for a 79-year-old is 3 hours 49 minutes, and for a 90-year-old it is 7 hours 53 minutes.

According to the Guinness Book of Records, the age record is held Dimitrion Yordanidis, a Greek man who managed to complete a marathon in 1976 aged 98. However, experts say it will not be long before we have 100-year-old marathon runners.

'We're going to get centenarian runners - someday someone over 100 will run the marathon. It will be quite soon,' said Craig Sharp, professor of sports science at Brunel University, who studies old-age sports. 'You are literally never too old to run.'

Sharp claims most of the decline in physical strength as people get older is due to less activity, not the ageing process. 'Half the deterioration of ageing is detraining. As you get older you travel more by car and so on, and you do less activity.'

Over the last few years, several studies have shown that it is easy to train people over 65 who have previously done little exercise. One American coach specialises in nonagenarians, and claims to be able to more than double the strength of their legs within eight weeks.

Sharp puts much of the popularity of old-age marathon running down to the rise of veteran competitions encouraging people not to hang up their shoes. 'It's largely a sociological and organisational phenomenon,' he said.

Jack Fitzgerald of the British Veteran Athletics Federation says that the rise in old-age marathons is because runners just don't want to stop.

'I started in 1950, and have run more than 200 marathons,' he said. 'Age is no bar. Many people who run marathons just don't want to pack up ever. A lot of jogging clubs are also bringing in more peo ple late in life.'

Fitzgerald has entered today's marathon, but says he plans not to push himself too hard. 'I'm saving myself for the Comrades double marathon in South Africa later in the year,' he said.

Wood-Allen also reckons that there will soon be hundred-year old marathon runners, but she said she was unlikely to be one of them.

'I don't think I'll do it when I'm 100. The training takes up too much time, and there's other things I want to do.'

webTitle: Orange march in Dublin is first step across divide

fields.headline: Orange march in Dublin is first step across divide
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: For more than 30 years the Rev Brian Kennaway has had a dream. As a student at Trinity College, Dublin, in the 1960s, walking the streets of the city, he was disappointed at the lack of any memorial commemorating the long tradition of the Orange Order in the Irish capital.
fields.body:
For more than 30 years the Rev Brian Kennaway has had a dream. As a student at Trinity College, Dublin, in the 1960s, walking the streets of the city, he was disappointed at the lack of any memorial commemorating the long tradition of the Orange Order in the Irish capital.

Kennaway, who is now the education officer of the order, was dismayed to find that there was nothing to mark the house in Dawson Street where the first meeting of the Grand Orange Lodge of Ireland was held in April l798.

Next month that omission will be remedied when the Labour Lord Mayor of Dublin, Mary Frehill, unveils a plaque at No 59, Dawson Street. It will be a significant step towards realising Kennaway's hope that one day society in the Irish Republic would be generous enough to recognise the part that the Orange tradition has played in the history of the whole island.

The ceremony will be followed by an Orange parade, complete with drums and flute bands, down Dawson Street. It will be the first time that the order has marched in the Irish capital since l937. It is expected that several hundred Orange men and women will come from Northern Ireland and from Scotland.

The Irish police have given permission for the parade and the Dublin Corporation has allowed the Mansion House, the official residence of the Lord Mayor, to be used for a religious service after the march.

Already the event has provoked conflicting reactions. Many people in the Republic have welcomed it as a timely gesture, marking the new relationship between the two parts of Ireland that is integral to the peace process. They want to demonstrate to Northern Unionists that they are ready and willing to recognise the cultural and religious diversity of the whole island. That includes the Orange Order. Already steps have been made in that direction.

Irish President Mary McAleese, herself a Northern Catholic, has invited leaders of the Orange Order to her official residence in the Phoenix Park. The government has recently allocated funds to restore the site of the Battle of the Boyne, the Protestant victory that is remembered annually on 12 July.

Others are much less enthusiastic. They point to the sectarian violence that surrounds the Orange marching season in Northern Ireland and argue that to allow a parade in Dublin is a betrayal of those Northern nationalists who live in areas like the Garvaghy Road. Sinn Fein has compared the decision to welcome the order to Dublin to 'allowing the Ku Klux Klan to march in Portadown'.

That is to be expected. What is more surprising is the fact that Protestants living in the Republic have also expressed reservations about the march. In recent years the Church of Ireland, which has congregations on both sides of the border, has been deeply divided about the Orange parades. Protestants living in the Republic have been appalled by the sectarian hostility that regularly erupts in areas like Portadown around 12 July. They disapprove of the fact that the small parish church at Drumcree features in scenes of violence. The impression has been given, they argue, that the Church of Ireland is the Orange Order at prayer.

But there are others living in the Republic who feel it is time for the Protestant community to celebrate its distinct history and traditions. Since Irish independence, they say, the Protestant community south of the border has been marginalised. This is demonstrated by its lack of representation in the Dail. The bitter violence in the North over the past 30 years has made Protestants more timid about expressing controversial views, for fear of being branded as 'sectarian'. The instinct has been to keep the collective head down and say nothing.

Ian Cox, the 25-year-old Dubliner organising the parade, believes it is time for the Republic's Protestant minority to celebrate its identity as an integral part of a pluralist Ireland. He says the march will be primarily a cultural event. He hopes it will present a more positive image of the Orange Order and thus, perhaps, take some of the sting out of the marching season in the North.

The peace process is in a fragile state, but the silence of the guns has brought about a thaw in relations between the two parts of the island. There is a genuine desire to try to bridge the old sectarian divide by greater understanding of the other person's point of view. Next month's Orange celebrations in Dublin will be another step along that road.

webTitle: Bible belt fury as Queer as Folk heads for US

fields.headline: Bible belt fury as Queer as Folk heads for US
fields.trailText: Queer As Folk, the Channel 4 series that provoked complaints from the British Broadcasting Standards Commission, is to be remade in America - and Christian  groups across the country's Bible Belt are not relishing the prospect.
fields.body:
Queer As Folk, the Channel 4 series that provoked complaints from the British Broadcasting Standards Commission, is to be remade in America - and Christian groups across the country's Bible Belt are not relishing the prospect.

The drama about young gay Mancunians will be reshot in New Jersey with a new cast and script.

Fundamentalist and evangelical groups are already lobbying for the show's explicit sexual content to be toned down.

Executives of Channel Four International met this weekend in New York's Russian Tea Rooms restaurant to seal the deal with Los Angeles-based Showtime television network.

'The Showtime slogan is "No Limits",' said Nicola Shindler, producer of the British show, which was made by Red Productions. 'So we are very hopeful that the new show will remain true to the original.'

The American version will, however, have a much bigger budget. 'They were talking about as much as £1million an episode, but that is much more common over there,' said Shindler.

The new series will be cast with unknown actors and made by the Batman director Joel Schumacher who has assured the show's British creator, Russell T. Davies, that every attempt to stick to the original storylines will be made.

He has repeatedly argued that the sex scenes were not necessarily what shocked audiences anyway. He said: 'There are no naked sex scenes in the second series, but I think it's more shocking when the two central characters go to bed after 16 years and don't have sex.

'Some people may also be shocked to see a boy of 15 having tea with his boyfriend, his mum and his sister.'

But the American production team in-waiting has said it is prepared to face anti-gay lobbyists.

'The show will not be watered down,' Schumacher told the LA Times.

On a US religious website, the evangelist pastor Connor Crawford called for Showtime to leave the show in Britain. Fans who have seen original episodes on satellite or cable channels called for tolerance. One of the series' biggest Internet defenders, a man who describes Manchester as 'a notoriously gay area just outside London', says Americans would be lucky to have their own version.

The British series, starring Aidan Gillen, Craig Kelly and Denise Black, has already been sold to 13 other countries and is Channel 4's biggest selling video ever. No more shows will be made in this country because Davies was eager not to milk the format.

'I wouldn't mind going back to the characters in another 20 years or so,' he said, 'but I'll probably be dead by then.'

News of the American deal is further evidence of the increasing interest in British television. US versions of formats developed here are topping ratings. Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? leads this charge, but an NBC version of Granada's Cold Feet is airing and there are commitments to a second American series of Whose Line is it Anyway? hosted by Drew Carey on ABC and to develop scripts for both The Royle Family and Only Fools and Horses. Rock Scissors Paper is a version of Andrew Davies' sitcom Game On under consideration by Fox, re-written by Bill and Sheri Steinkiller, the husband-and-wife team who created Cheers.

This change of name highlights one looming problem for Showtime. What will they call Queer As Folk? While the term 'queer' is used in some quarters, the saying 'There's nowt as queer as folk' has no currency at all.

webTitle: Mobiles threaten to close West End

fields.headline: Mobiles threaten to close West End
fields.trailText: Mobile phones annoying theatregoers by bleeping incessantly in the middle of  Hamlet are one thing, but now the ubiquitous devices are threatening to close London's West End completely.
fields.body:
Mobile phones annoying theatregoers by bleeping incessantly in the middle of Hamlet are one thing, but now the ubiquitous devices are threatening to close London's West End completely.

While the Chancellor Gordon Brown rubs his hands at the prospect of a £20 billion-plus windfall from the imminent sell-off of five new mobile phone licences, the nation's impresarios are facing a catastrophe of epic proportions. The problem? Too many competing uses for the radio spectrum.

The country's leading theatres are dependent on wireless microphones to let audiences hear the performers no matter where they are on stage - even if they are moving around. The devices operate at between 1785 megahertz and 1800 megahertz.

Unfortunately for the theatres, the new mobile phones, which allow wireless access to the Internet, will operate at similar frequencies. Experts say this will prevent wireless microphones from working because it creates 'dirty spectrum' - a clash of signals caused by two sets of frequencies overlapping.

'It's getting to the stage where the radio spectrum is now chock full of telephones,' said Brian Copsey, secretary of the Association of Service Providers, the trade group which looks after the interests of wireless manufacturers. 'The Government is mesmerised by the money it is going to make, but it is not looking at the effects on an industry that is going to be disenfranchised.

'If the West End shuts down, how many people are going to lose their jobs?'

The news will be a huge concern for composer and impresario Andrew Lloyd-Webber, whose Really Useful Group owns many of theatreland's top venues, including the Garrick, the London Palladium and the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane. Lord Lloyd-Webber's productions rely heavily on wireless microphones, often using 40 channels at any one time.

In addition to causing havoc for theatres, circus acts that use the same frequencies will be hit and the clash of competing uses for the radio spectrum will cause headaches for broadcast journalists whose video links are also at risk.

fields.headline: David Irving v The Observer
fields.standfirst: The David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: David Irving is continuing to pursue his intention to bring a libel action against  The Observer and the writer Gitta Sereny, for words in an article entitled 'Spin Time For Hitler' which appeared on 21 April, 1996.
fields.body:
David Irving is continuing to pursue his intention to bring a libel action against The Observer and the writer Gitta Sereny, for words in an article entitled 'Spin Time For Hitler' which appeared on 21 April, 1996.

In his Statement of Claim, Irving lists 13 points he considers defamatory. The article, in his view, accuses him, among other things, of inflating the death toll in the Allied air raid on Dresden tenfold, of obtaining the microfiche plates of the Goebbels diaries in Moscow by subterfuge, and of using 'the means of invention, omission or distortion to express an obsession, thereby demonstrating a lack of the detachment, rationality and judgment'. Irving also claims aggravated damages on the grounds that The Observer failed to publish a timely reply by him to the article and that Sereny had pursued a campaign of defamation against him for nearly 20 years. The Observer will apply to have his action struck out on the grounds that these matters have already been litigated in the libel case against Penguin Books and Deborah Lipstadt that concluded last week.

webTitle: Are you a snob or a pleb?

fields.headline: Are you a snob or a pleb?
fields.standfirst: New money rules - and old money doesn't like it.  John Arlidge and  Burhan Wazir report on the ongoing class war
fields.trailText: New money rules - and old money doesn't like it.  John Arlidge and  Burhan Wazir report on the ongoing class war.
fields.body:
In their Donna Karan frocks and Armani dinner suits, the bubbliest stars of British film filed into the Odeon Leicester Square in London's West End to honour one of Britain's longest-serving and most admired actors. Michael Caine, his bow tie barely unknotted since he won his second Oscar a fortnight ago, walked slowly to the stage.

Accepting lifetime awards is a tricky business. An actor cannot be too saccharine, too gushing, too controversial, or too smug. In Los Angeles two weeks ago Warren Beatty, who won a special achievement award, showed how to do it. He won a standing ovation for his modest, witty speech.

Last week in London Caine started well enough. The former meat market porter turned Hollywood star acknowledged the honour and thanked the British Academy. But the vast auditorium soon fell silent as his voice dipped and he began to turn on his profession.

As a south Londoner with a 'duff accent', he said he felt unloved - 'a stranger in my own country and profession.' It was, he whimpered, 'cold out there'.

The next day commentators were quick to condemn the Cider House Rules star as an ungrateful, grouchy multi-millionaire. Like Anthony Hopkins, who deserted his Welsh homeland and became an American citizen last week, he was a 'top-class whinger'.

Caine was infuriated but kept quiet. Not so his fellow actors. Jane Horrocks, who played along side him in Little Voice, said there was 'a lot of snobbery' in the film industry. Middle-class actors like Maggie Smith, Judi Dench and Juliet Stevenson won most of the awards while 'a lot of people in the lower classes are ignored'.

Bob Hoskins soon added his cockney vowels. British film and theatre was full of 'lunatics' who judged actors on background and their accent rather than talent. 'There is still a class aspect in this country which is scandalous,' he sniffed. Corin Redgrave said there was 'sadly a lot of truth in what they say'. It was harder today, he said, for working-class actors than when Caine first trod the boards.

It is only a few years since John Major and Tony Blair proclaimed Britain a classless society. Even John Prescott, a former cruise liner steward, now insists he, like most of us, is 'middle class'. So what are Britain's showbiz elite on about? Is snobbery alive and well in cool Britannia? Social commentators insist it is.

The British love looking down on those they consider beneath them, says Countess Jennifer Guerrini-Maraldi, society commentator and fashion writer. 'Snobs are as alive and well in this country as they have ever been. Being a snob is part of the British character. It is about being aspirational and, of course, when you get to where you want to go, you can look down on other people you have left behind. Without snobbery we would have no-one to laugh at.'

For some, snobbery is the aristocratic sneer of the past. As the summer frolics at Glyndebourne, Henley and Cowes approach, blue-bloods are complaining that the Tia Maria-and-Coke-drinking classes are ruining 'the Season'. Clive Aslet, editor of Country Life , says merchant bankers, corporate sponsors, fashion victims, It girls and C-list celebrities are edging the well-bred out of Ascot's Royal Enclosure and off the banks of the Thames at Henley.

'The old formula of "see you at the tree next to the Royal Box, darling" no longer works,' Aslet complains. 'There are too many other darlings there already. The Season used to be about title and breeding. You had to be "introduced" before you could join in. But these days you can barely move for the nouveau-riche showing off and trying to get themselves on the front page of the Telegraph.'

The patrician elite's fight to retain the old order, is backed by some of Britain's oldest institutions. Hotels like The Savoy in London enforce strict dress and behaviour codes as a buttress against the shifting social mores. With an almost unstoppable tide of middle-American tourists, pop stars and trendy new-money types arriving, hotels like The Savoy struggle to hold on to anachronistic leanings. 'We prefer our clients to be dressed in a suitable man ner,' says Lucas Johansson, a duty manager who closely watches over his guests' attire.

'After six in the evening, we'd rather that our clients be smartly turned out - smart jacket, pressed trousers, that sort of thing. We do have certain standards.'

Even department stores maintain strong Etonian-style habits - Harrods' dress code, introduced in 1989, is vigorously policed. The code bans visitors wearing rucksacks and torn denims. Former pop stars Jason Donovan and Luke Goss have both been refused entry over their trendy torn jeans.

'We'd like people to remember that they are walking into the most famous store in the world,' says a Harrods spokesman. 'Our dress code is not about trying to force an identity on people; we'd like them to consider our reputation as a world brand.'

As they cling on to the nineteenth-century, the old elite is being joined by a new class of snob. Instead of worrying about birth and breeding, they fret about their bank balance, the cut of their coat, and coloured glass tiles in their Philippe Starck bathrooms.

The 'new' snobbery begins and ends with money. Those that have it can buy the labels and gadgets which enable them to look down on those who don't.

And where do you find these style fascisti? In the fast-growing after-hours members clubs. 'The club says something about what kind of person I am - that I'm better than many of my contemporaries. Call that snobbishness? Maybe that's true - I'd prefer to view it as an achievement. 'So they throw the money, and shout out, 'Home, Jeeves!' I don't know where they live. And if you take a wrong turning, just imagine the kind of raw abuse I get. webTitle: The battle may be over - but the war goes on

fields.headline: The battle may be over - but the war goes on
fields.standfirst: Neal Ascherson explains why a disgraced David Irving has surprising sympathy from serious historiansThe David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: Neal Ascherson explains why a disgraced David Irving has surprising sympathy from serious historians.
fields.body:
The egg has been sponged off David Irving's best suit, splattered by High Court demonstrators last Tuesday. The defence lawyers are seeking an archive nerd who wants 92 lever-arch binders of Holocaust documents, each in seven copies. And yet the great three-month libel trial refuses to go away.

Five days after Mr Justice Gray's judgment against Irving, the smoke is clearing. But the view, depressingly, is much the same as before.

The good news is that Irving lost his action against Penguin Books and Deborah Lipstadt. The bad news is that he still apparently intends to bring another one - against The Observer. Irving has still not had enough.

One of the reasons is that there were two trials going on, not one. The formal trial ended with one of the most crushing judgments ever dumped over an English plaintiff. The judge accepted almost every single point of the defence case: Irving was - among other things - a liar, a distorter of historical evidence, an anti-Semitic racist and a 'Holocaust-denier'.

But Irving was also suing before 'the court of world opinion'. He kept one eye firmly on the journalists packing the front row (we were daily ticked off or praised, and fed with interesting papers).

He lost that trial, too. But not nearly so completely. Incredible as it seems, a minority of people clearly think it was Irving who was on trial, being sued for his opinions by Penguin Books. He might as well have been fighting the charge of 'Holocaust denial' waiting for him at Mannheim in Germany, where it is a criminal offence. In consequence, there is now a tendency to see the trial outcome as a form of censorship, a clamp on the limits of historical inquiry.

Professor D.C. Watt, in Tuesday's London Evening Standard, asserted that historians were uneasy about the trial, that Penguin had been 'out for blood' and that 'the truth needs an Irving's challenges to keep it alive'. Watt overlooks the fact that it was Irving who was out for blood; he, after all, sued Penguin and Lipstadt. John Keegan, another historian of war, wrote after the judgment that Irving 'has many of the qualities of the most creative historians ... if he will only learn from this case, [he] still has much to tell us'. Keegan dismissed Lipstadt, whose remarks about Irving were the pretext for the trial, as 'dull as only the self-righteously politically correct can be'.

Both men are scrupulous scholars; neither could possibly be suspected of fascist sympathies. Yet both see Irving as still somehow 'one of us' - wrong but romantic. But Lipstadt is a respectable historian too, more honest in her use of documents than Irving, and the trial vindicated what she said about him. So why is she being slighted as somehow not quite one of us?

On the day after the verdict, the headlines unanimously pronounced Irving dead and buried. Unquiet grave! People like that always bounce back. And Irving's reputation has always been a double one: as a writer of his tory, but also a hunter of un-known, sensational documents. The first part - his reputation as an interpreter of those documents - lies in ruins. The second survives.

This is a shadowy underworld, hidden beneath the clean, bright places where scholars write books. Down in the cellar of Third Reich studies, con men and SS veterans, obsessive journalists and forgers and real historians stumble about in echoes of fantastic rumour. And here Irving is a dark prince.

His special gift is finding papers which others don't even know how to look for. Gitta Sereny, another famous researcher in this field, acknowledges : 'He's so good at cross-searching. Take the Kommissarbefehl [the order to kill captured Soviet party cadres]. He would go in 12 different directions; he would check through what everyone was doing on the day it was issued, on who Hitler saw or phoned that day and where.'

Has the trial changed anything? Very little. The judgment does not advance historical research into Hitler's murder of the Jews. It merely repeats what was known. Neither is it likely to deter 'Holocaust-deniers'.

But Mr Justice Gray's judgment will be useful as a sort of quality guarantee. As the Pinochet case showed, an English court still has clout and international credibility.

Irving lost his case last Tuesday. Does that mean Lipstadt and her supporters won on the same scale? As a lawyer explained to me, it's not that simple. She won a battle, but not necessarily the war. She is the author of Denying The Holocaust - the book in which she accused Irving of being a racist, a right-wing extremist, an anti-Semite, a twister of evidence and a Holocaust-denier - and the judge endorsed almost every allegation she made. And yet, in the wider sense, her victory may not have done much to help her cause.

Lipstadt sat in court for three months and said nothing. This annoyed Irving, who plainly longed to have her at his mercy in the witness-box, and it did not endear her to the public. It may be that she was simply afraid of what Irving could do to her. More probably, she was sticking to her own precept: never debate with deniers. Never act as if there were two sides to this question. There is only one. The Holocaust did happen. End, Schluss , no argument.

This has proved an unpopular view. The Jewish Chronicle took the Lipstadt line: 'Merely to suggest the fact of the Holocaust... is somehow open to debate is obscene'. So did David Cesarani, Professor of Modern Jewish History at Southampton. He reproached the media for continuing to talk to Irving and ask him for his opinions. Most British commentators found this repugnant. They had no doubt the Holocaust happened. But in the old liberal way, they felt like fighting for a man's right to express views they found loathsome.

They were also worried that the judgment could deter 'genuine' historical argument about the details of the Holocaust. The total of the victims, some of the methods and the genesis of the plan itself are all uncertain. But the judgment stated that such research did not amount to 'denial' (which is no offence in this country), and Lipstadt's writings make the same point.

How about Lipstadt's even more passionate belief that the Jewish Holocaust was unique - that to set it in the context of other great atrocities is blasphemous? Again, Irving's defeat did nothing to support her. But the reporting of the trial seemed to some to imply an exclusiveness about Jewish victimhood. This disturbed both historians (such as Mark Mazower, author of Dark Continent: Europe in the Twentieth Century) and minorities who have themselves been subjected to genocide, like the Armenians. As Mazower said last week, more data have come to light in recent years which multiply the scale of great atrocities in the past. These include the death toll in King Leopold's Congo Free State, which may have reached 10 million, and the famine deaths caused by Mao's Great Leap Forward in China, now thought to number more than 20 million.

The Irving trial again brought out the unique features of the Holocaust. The more Irving blustered about how unplanned the 'Final Solution' was, the more his own documents reminded an appalled court of its deliberate, industrialised character, its intention to eradicate an entire race.

But an English libel court is for justice, not for history. Mr Justice Gray did not say whether the Holocaust should or should not be placed in a wider context of war and genocide. He left that to Irving and Lipstadt, who will go on contesting it for the rest of their lives.

webTitle: US unions flex muscles in uneasy alliance with greens

fields.headline: US unions flex muscles in uneasy alliance with greens
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of truck drivers, steelworkers, railroad engineers and autoworkers came to join thousands of protesters airing their grievances against globalisation and the world financial talks in Washington.
fields.body:
They converged on what they call 'Our Nation's Capital', from across the prairies and the grim factories of the rust belt. Tens of thousands of truck drivers, steelworkers, railroad engineers and autoworkers, to join thousands of protesters airing their grievances against globalisation and the world financial talks in Washington.

Their bomber jackets proclaim their loyalties: 'Iron Workers of America Local 914 Ohio'; 'International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 302. Labor Omnia Vincit'. And all bear the American flag.

The first round of Washington's battle of wits went to the police when they closed down the protesters' headquarters after fire officials declared the old warehouse unsafe.

But protesters promise to disrupt weekend meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

Don Peterson came from Cleveland to shout 'Motherfuckers!' at Congress and the IMF, but then walked the length of the Mall to pay tribute at the Lincoln Memorial. 'Greatest American ever lived,' he affirms, almost choking with emotion. Many carry the Star-Spangled Banner as well as insurrectionary placards; Martin Leach from Chicago took time out from the demo so his family could see the Vietnam memorial, 'because that's where Uncle Barry lost his arm'.

And while the anarchists and whale-savers adjourn for crystal therapy, peppermint tea and civil-disobedience class, these folk hit the Big Hunt bar for ribs and some well-deserved neck-oil, after which the single lads check out peepshows along Capitol Street in DC's no-go downtown, where angels and deep greens fear to tread.

There is a severity to the gatherings in Washington that was missing from the disruptions at the World Trade Organisation meeting in Seattle. This time, as Todd Gitlin, the veteran who organised anti-Vietnam rallies in the 1960s, observes: 'The demonstrators are undertaking the time-honoured, indispensable mission of democratic crowds: to crack a wrong-headed consensus and to precipitate public debates.'

This is a time of sudden and unexpected resurgence for US labour. Union membership rose faster last year than at any time for 20 years. A legacy of corruption scandals was laid to rest, especially in the Teamsters union, cleaned up by none other than the son of corrupt Jimmy Hoffa, Jimmy Junior.

There have also been successful strikes, won with widespread public support, against American Airlines, the United Parcel Service and General Motors. And there are moves to begin organising in the blue-chip industries, even at Microsoft.

The call to arms in Washington arose first over Congress's imminent vote on a trade deal with China, against a backdrop of the IMF-World Bank gathering. 'They bailed out one communist disaster in Russia, now they wanna do it all over,' observed Rick Dooley of Younstown, Ohio.

The voice of narrow-minded union muscle is also here: 'We're for an America where no working mom or dad every lays awake at night worrying what's going to happen to their family because their paycheck was ripped off and shipped away to a factory in China,' said David Bonior, one of the movement's friends in Congress. 'Or Taiwan!' they shouted back. 'Or Indonesia.'

But, as every union leader knows, the high wire isn't simple. John Sweeney, leader of the states-wide trade union federation AFL-CIO, told the placard-waving crowds on the Mall: 'This is part of a long-term campaign to make the global economy work for working families.'

But Sweeney was later on another podium, at the demonstration against the debt owed by the world's poorest countries. Backed by a huge red-and-white sign read ing 'Cancel the Debt', he thundered: 'In Ethiopia more than 100,000 children die every year from diarrhoea while its government spends four times as much on debt payments as it does on health care.'

This is the new face of the US union movement. The demonstrators must confront a deep dilemma: jobs at home, and concern for the worldwide effects of globalisation - poverty, human rights and the environment. Can organised labour embrace the global economy and yet combat the consequences for workers of free trade?

Jerry Shea, assistant to the general secretary of the AFL-CIO, said: 'There is no turning back the clock. But we don't see any reason why you can't create a rules-based global economy.

'To say that we are in solidarity with workers around the world is not enough,' says Shea. 'We have to do something about it.'

The US trade union federation is not just talking. It has sent teams of activists into the Third World to work alongside the International Labour Organisation and local unions to remove underage children from sweatshop factories, mines and coffee plantations.

Shea sees this spurt of activity, now focused on Washington, as coming in the spirit of the support the US unions gave the Solidarity movement in Poland. 'We have often had the right policy positions,' he says 'but we haven't worked hard enough on them. If we get our unions to put their shoulders to the wheel on some of this stuff, it could make a big difference.'

Labour's critics insist that they remain on the wrong side of trade. 'As long as they are opposed to free trade,' says Frank Coleman, spokesman at the US Chamber of Commerce, 'it kind of stretches credulity for them to talk about freedom.'

webTitle: Nurse tells court how troops killed her patients

fields.headline: Nurse tells court how troops killed her patients
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian government is being taken to the European Court of Human Rights by a Chechen nurse who saw five of her patients killed in front of her, and says 61 others have vanished.
fields.body:
The Russian government is being taken to the European Court of Human Rights by a Chechen nurse who saw five of her patients killed in front of her, and says 61 others have vanished. The case of Sasita Khasuyeva, 45, has been raised by London solicitor Gareth Peirce. The nurse claims that on 2 February a hospital convoy of three buses carrying white flags was attacked by Russian troops.

'The wounded were thrown from the buses and beaten on the spot,' Khasuyeva says. Then the medical team were forced out and beaten.

The medics and patients were taken to Tolstoy Yurt, and dumped into a hole in the ground with no heating, no light and snow on the floor and kept there for six days without treatment. The wounded were repeatedly beaten and tortured. Five , including a paralysed boy, Mowladi Idrisov, 16, were killed in front of her.

On the sixth day the medics were transferred to a 'filtration camp' at Chernokozovo, where five female nurses, including Khasuyeva, were separated from the men. The women were stripped and forced to dance in front of the Russian soldiers, who were constantly drunk.

Khasuyeva has compiled a list of the 61 wounded who were arrested with the medical team. All have disappeared.

The case before the Strasbourg court comes at a bad time for President Putin, Tony Blair's guest. Buckingham Palace declined to say whether the Queen would raise the question of the torture and killings with Putin when he visits her tomorrow.

john.sweeney@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Thousands flee anarchy in Zimbabwe
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The leader of Zimbabwe's land grab campaign yesterday rejected a court order for the eviction of farm squatters and said he would not order his followers off the white-owned farms they have seized.
fields.body:
The leader of Zimbabwe's land grab campaign yesterday rejected a court order for the eviction of farm squatters and said he would not order his followers off the white-owned farms they have seized.

Chenjerai 'Hitler' Hunzvi told 1,000 cheering liberation war veterans in the grounds of the ruling Zanu-PF headquarters: 'Dr Hunzvi has no power to withdraw the war veterans from their motherland.

'Even if I had the power, it would be against my conscience. I didn't send them there and I cannot and I will not withdraw them.'

Hunzvi, a doctor trained in Poland during the 1970s guerrilla war against white rule, has commanded the invasion over the past two months of at least 500 white-owned farms in a campaign to reverse Zimbabwe's colonial legacy.

President Robert Mugabe, 76, in power for 20 years, has backed the invasions, saying they are a morally just response to the white domination of the country's prime farmlands. On Friday, police said they would appeal to the Supreme Court against court orders requiring them to evict the squatters.

Hopes that a more moderate tone was emerging from the regime are diminishing, and fears for the future are affecting all sections of the community. A crowd of about 500 turned up recently at a seminar on emigration to Australia and it is a measure of the severity of Zimbabwe's crisis that only 40 per cent were white, with 30 per cent black and 30 per cent Asian.

The crowd sighed when pictures of Australian beaches were shown and groaned at the news that those over 45 could not qualify as skilled immigrants. They laughed when informed that they cannot expect servants.

Zimbabweans of all races and walks of life are seeking new places to live. Emigration 'experts' give similar seminars for Canada. Other Zimbabweans are looking to start new lives in Britain, the United States and South Africa.

In 1996, a total of 1,629 Zimbabweans officially emigrated from the country, according to the government's Central Statistical Office. In 1997, 1,821 left, and in 1998, when the economy deteriorated sharply, the number jumped to 6,135. Those who are leaving are the educated and the skilled and their departure is a significant loss.

At the lower end of the economic scale, thousands of poor blacks try to smuggle themselves across the border to South Africa every month. They risk the crocodiles in the waters of the 'great grey-green, greasy Limpopo River' for the chance of getting a job. 'We black Africans who are young and educated would rather be somewhere where the economic opportunities are better,' says Tazvitya Mukonombindo, 23. 'I'm optimistic that elections will bring change and things will get better soon. But if things don't work out, then we must be prepared to look for a better place to live.'

A black architect, trained in Britain, is forthright in saying why he wants to leave. 'Things are not going well in Zimbabwe. The medical situation is bad; the state of the hospitals is terrible,' he says. 'I am looking at the future for my three children. At the rate we are going, only the toughest can survive here. I could do it, but I don't want that for my children.'

webTitle: Putin aims to bridge the gap

fields.headline: Putin aims to bridge the gap
fields.standfirst: Russia's leader flies into London tonight. Critics are furious that a warm welcome at No 10 will bolster his ruthless policies at homeRussia: special report
fields.trailText: Russia's leader flies into London tonight. Critics are furious that a warm welcome at No 10 will bolster his ruthless policies at home.
fields.body:
He has been accused of presiding over horrific war crimes and earned the nickname 'Butcher of Grozny', and yet there is something in Russian President Vladimir Putin's character that Tony Blair finds attractive.

Blair and Putin developed a 'very friendly' personal relationship during informal meetings in St Petersburg last month, senior diplomatic sources said yesterday. And despite global concern at the savage war still raging in Chechnya, the British Prime Minister is ready to do everything he can to nurture these seeds of friendship.

When he arrives in London this evening, Putin will find his debut on the stage of international diplomacy soured by controversy. Some have hailed his choice to make Britain his first port of call as a coup for the Foreign Office. Others say his visit is scandalous.

Blair's government has been bitterly criticised by human rights groups and politicians across the spectrum for hosting Putin's visit - which has a primarily business-led agenda - at a time when new details of atrocities committed by the Russian military in Chechnya are emerging daily.

Putin's swiftly-organised trip comes before he has even been inaugurated as president - just weeks after an election victory firmly tied to the popular brutality of the military campaign in Chechnya. International recognition of the human rights abuses committed by the federal army is such that Russia is on notice of suspension from the Council of Europe for its conduct in Chechnya.

Under Putin's presidency, Russia's bid to crush Chechen rebels has led to the wholesale destruction of a city once home to 400,000 people and the displacement of more than 300,000 Chechens. Because access to the war zone has been severely restricted, no firm casualty figures exist, but local aid workers estimate that as many as 5,000 civilians may have died in the course of the six-month war; Chechen sources claim the final figure could be twice as high.

There was intense concern that the decision to welcome Putin - particularly with a symbolic trip to Buckingham Palace for tea with the Queen - would be seen as an endorsement of Russia's ruthlessness in the region. But diplomatic sources insisted that any unease about Chechnya should be secondary to the need to forge a strong new bond between Russia and Britain; the opportunity to maximise on the personal chemistry between Blair and Putin must not be missed, they said.

Putin, who in a recent book of interviews said his KGB training helped make him a specialist in dealing with people, has charmed a series of Western leaders in the months since he took over from Boris Yeltsin.

Blair and Putin met in Putin's home town, St Petersburg, just before last month's presidential elections, when they found time to make a friendly trip to the opera together with their wives. 'They clearly formed a good personal relationship during the time they spent together,' a senior diplomat said. 'You could see it developing over the hours spent in informal meetings that day. These are men of the same generation.'

It was crucial to make overtures to Putin at this 'early, formative stage' in his career and this personal closeness would have a significant impact on Russian-British relations, he said. 'It will be much easier for them now to pick up the phone and talk to each other.'

The official British line is a positive one. Putin is 'young, energetic, intelligent and appears to be interested in developing his understanding of how the West works', one diplomat said.

'His vision of the future is one that we would feel comfortable with,' Blair said in an interview last week. 'Putin has a very clear agenda of modernising Russia. When he talks of a strong Russia, he means strength not in a threatening way but in a way that means the country economically and politically is capable of standing up for itself, which is a perfectly good aim to have.'

Putin said yesterday that Blair had demonstrated 'a willingness to co-operate with Russia' during his visit to St Petersburg and this was why he had chosen to make a return visit. 'We should respond likewise, therefore my first visit to Western Europe should be to Great Britain,' he said.

The value to Putin of a warm welcome in Britain is obvious. After Chechnya, he needs an ally in the West. He sees Blair as a crucial bridge to Europe and the US.

Russian presidential advisers said Putin chose Britain for his first trip because he believes Blair to be the sympathetic on Chechnya. 'Britain - which has had its own bad experiences in Ulster - understands possibly better than any other western country all the difficulties connected with separatism and terrorism,' a Kremlin source explained. But what does Britain gain by courting Putin?

Andrei Piontkovsky, director of Moscow's Centre for Strategic Studies, said there was no value for Britain holding such a meeting at this time. 'Blair is making himself into Putin's pet poodle,' he said. 'Putin has a small white poodle which he is extremely fond of and Blair is happily taking on the role of his poodle in the international arena.'

Blair had already helped Putin by his visit to Russia in the last days of the election campaign, Piontkovsky added. 'After the revolution when he was trying to make overtures to the international community, Lenin used to say: "We need some useful bourgeois idiots." I think this is exactly how Putin views his relationship with Blair. [It] shows Britain is prepared to overlook...Chechnya.'

When Putin and Blair meet tomorrow morning, Chechnya will be on the agenda, and British diplomats argue that only through dialogue at the highest level can Russia be persuaded to seek a political solution to the conflict.

Human rights groups said yesterday that abuses in the region would not be a prominent enough part of the talks.

webTitle: Drugs and death in Sin City

fields.headline: Drugs and death in Sin City
fields.standfirst: Did the 'Irish Venus' and her lover smother the casino boss to dig up his buried treasure, asks  Christopher Reed in Las Vegas
fields.trailText: Corporations have turned Las Vegas into a Disney world of family entertainment. But anyone nostalgic for the old Sin City can visit Room Six at the county court for a murder trial involving gangsters, dope, buried treasure, greed, lust and unintentional Runyanesque low humour.
fields.body:
Corporations have turned Las Vegas into a Disney world of family entertainment. But anyone nostalgic for the old Sin City can visit Room Six at the county court for a murder trial involving gangsters, dope, buried treasure, greed, lust and unintentional Runyanesque low humour.

The two accused, the victim, and many witnesses seem superficially normal, only to reveal an underside. And almost every day the court is jolted by remarks tossed out as inconsequential: 'He never closed the curtains after the drive-by shooting' and 'The box contained letters my father regarded sentimentally because they were written by my grandfather from the penitentiary.'

One witness, a manicurist who testified that one of the accused outlined the murder plot a week before the victim died, was castigated by the defence for fabricating evidence to help her father, who was serving life imprisonment without parole. Three other prosecution witnesses acknowledged they had prison records for drug dealing.

On trial for murder are former stripper Sandy Murphy, 28, known as the Irish Venus, and her clandestine boyfriend, building contractor and tough guy Rick Tabish, 35. Their alleged victim was Horseshoe Casino boss and multi-millionaire Lonnie 'Ted' Binion, 55, found in September 1998 sprawled on the floor of the Las Vegas mansion he shared with Murphy, and dead from an apparent heroin overdose.

Two days later, Tabish was arrested at 3am in the Nevada brothel town of Pahrump while digging up Binion's secret vault containing 23 tons of silver ingots worth $7 million (£4.4m). Tabish, as the vault's original builder, said Binion had asked him to remove the treasure 'if anything happened' to him. When police examined the underground chamber it contained one silver dollar. Earlier this year 100lb of the bullion were found near Tabish's home in Montana.

Yet police waited months before charging Murphy and Tabish with murdering Binion, a drug addict, by forcing heroin and a tranquilliser down his throat and smothering him when he didn't die. Prosecutors say the couple wanted to free Murphy from Binion, a beloved figure around Vegas, who beat her during their three-year affair. The cuckolding couple allegedly stole his millions to help Tabish out of financial trouble and because Binion was disinheriting Murphy.

The two, who face life imprisonment, insist Binion's death was either suicide or an accidental overdose. For months they denied any romance, but in a pre-trial hearing the court camera caught them in a glance of such heated lust it would have peeled the varnish off the judge's bench. In the trial's opening statement the defence admitted the romance but failed to mention Tabish's wife and two children in Montana.

The trial typifies the free-for-all state where brothels and gambling have been lawful for decades. Murphy has one of its top lawyers, John Momot, whose fees are paid by a mysterious 'Irish busi nessman' who also financed a defence opinion poll advertised on Las Vegas TV during jury breaks. The responses were intended for planning defence strategy. Viewers are split 50-50 over the verdict, not expected for weeks. The judge ordered future polls to be kept confidential.

The case originates in Las Vegas's genesis in the late 1940s, when Irish-American mobster Benny Binion left Dallas just ahead of a murder allegation. He arrived with young Ted - and a suitcase with $2m - in Vegas, where gangster Bugsy Siegel had launched the Flamingo Casino. Benny killed at least two men in Vegas, but was never convicted.

Ted loved gambling and was adept at running the Horseshoe, where no bet was refused. At 14 he was almost kidnapped and Benny's home had hidden corridors and a 'bomb-proof' barn.

Ted inherited Benny's caution. His former wife Doris told the court Ted propped twin shotguns either side of the marital bed, 'one for each of us'. Their daughter Bonnie said Ted kept mountains of cash around the house, stashed in a boat, in the fridge, in bathroom cupboards and the rafters, amounting to up to $100,000. Everywhere in the mansion were guns. Binion also had a collection of gold coins, jewellery and diamonds, with an estimated value of $1m. After his death, the house was ransacked, allegedly by Murphy and Tabish.

Murphy went into hysterics when she 'found' Binion dead and was taken to hospital. Yet 24 hours later she directed a videotape 'inventory' of the house, claiming Binion's family and lawyers had stripped it.

Binion had fought Nevada's Gaming Board since 1987 when it removed his casino licence first for drugs, and later for consorting with 'undesirables' - mostly gangster Herbie 'Fat Herb' Blitzstein, who died of a bullet in the head in 1997. But, although Binion's sister took over his casino, half a dozen witnesses said he was optimistic and showed no suicidal tendencies.

They said Binion was suspicious of Murphy and Tabish, who were 'tighter than a cheap suit'. Before he died he phoned his lawyer Jim Brown and told him: 'Take Sandy out of the will if she doesn't kill me tonight. If I'm dead you'll know what happened.' Earlier, Brown had appended a codicil adding the mansion to a legacy that included her Mercedes-Benz sports car and $300,000, yet when Brown heard of his old friend's death the next day he did not tell police about the call.

In the world of Ted Binion and old Las Vegas that is not something one does.
