fields.headline: It never rains...
fields.standfirst: All Tim Adams wanted was a new shower, but then his builder won the Lottery
fields.trailText: All Tim Adams wanted was a new shower, but then his builder won the Lottery.
fields.body:
As an ice-breaker the sentence, 'My builders have just won the Lottery' has, I've discovered, much to recommend it. I've used it to barmen polishing glasses at opening time; I've employed it to distract taxi drivers from their 'I've got nothing against coloureds personally, but' stories; I've shared it with tired voices on the end of the line in call centres and heard them saying 'Have a nice day' with feeling.

It is the hint of outrageous fortune that sets it apart from most tales of construction woe. That and the fact that it carries with it a series of obvious supplementaries: How much did they win? (£900,000); Have they retired? (Yes); Did they finish the work on your flat? (No). It's a sentence that might make a decent opening to a short story by Raymond Carver. Unfortunately, in my case, it's also a sentence which is true - and, as with Raymond Carver, when things begin badly, they only get worse.

It all seemed to start innocently enough. There was a small, second bathroom on a half landing in our north London flat, and we wanted to convert it to a shower room. We bought some Starck-esque fixtures and a dozen boxes of mosaic tiles and, with a torn page from an old Elle Decoration in my back pocket, I called some builders to come in and quote. (Get Federation blokes, the bathroom people had said, you can't go wrong with Federation.)

Most of the builders, Federation blokes or not, took a quick look around our eight by six room and decided they had more important lives to make miseries of. But eventually a Federation father and a Federation son, Steve and Kevin, agreed to do the work with an iron handshake; we settled on a start date, 6 December. 'It'll take about 10 days,' Steve said confidently. 'We'll be long gone by Christmas.'

On Christmas Eve, I was standing on a joist in the dark catching water in a baby's plastic bath and trying to raise Steve on his mobile. Before knocking off for the holiday fortnight and after having ripped the old bathroom out (but before putting the new one in), Steve and Kevin had discovered a leak in the roof. Still, they had, of course, patched it up 'safe as houses' for the festive season. (The millennium dawned to the sound of baling.)

In January, Steve and Kevin returned with grim talk of mansards and gutters, and with the promise of scaffolding and roofers. A week later, the scaffolding arrived. After leaving it a couple of weeks to settle in, the roofers followed it, ordering mugs of tea: 'Two with four sugars, one with five,' said one; 'Which is the one with five?' said another. Steve and Kevin couldn't wait around for the roofers to finish their tea forever, though, so by now they were on other jobs. (It is, of course, a golden rule of the Federation that once a builder has started a job, he can't morally tear himself away from it. The only exception to this rule is if it's your job he's started.)

A new series of arrival dates thus came and went, and then one Sunday evening in February, Steve, with whom I was now enjoying a daily conversation, rang to share his good news: 'We won't be coming in tomorrow, I'm afraid, Tim, you see we have to go and collect this cheque' I held the phone away from my ear. When I put it back, Steve was talking in Oxymoron: 'reliable subcontractors,' he said, and 'quality workmanship'.

I'm not sure if anyone has ever investigated the possibility of a Quantity Theory of Good Fortune, the proposition that for every windfall there is equal but opposite storm damage in the near vicinity, but perhaps it's worth looking into. For most of the rest of the month, a series of reliable sub-contractors arrived with the express purpose of 'inspecting the job', all six square yards of it.

At the beginning of March a sub-contracted carpenter broke with the pack and turned up to replace a joist that had been water damaged from the leak. The next day, a sub-contracted plumber arrived, stood on the new joist and brought down the entire ceiling, somewhat to the consternation of my wife and baby, who had just passed underneath. For a few seconds the plumber apparently occupied two floors of the flat; his legs whirling above the stairs, his torso still in the bathroom covered in dust and mouthing obscenities, like a character in a Samuel Beckett play.

In some ways this seemed like an omen, because from then on the progress of the bathroom took on the character of the Irishman's prose. 'It can't go on,' I thought. 'It must go on. It won't go on.' It went on. For a while, in place of a new bathroom we had a new hole in the ceiling to add to the new pile of rubble and assorted debris outside the (absent) bathroom door. The hole was at the top of the stairs and as we walked up, our six-month-old baby would stare up into the void wide-eyed, as if assailed with Chicken Licken visions, and then she'd look at us, alarmed, as if to say, 'I think I preferred it as it was'

Towards the end of March, Steve and Kevin came by with pictures of their new Jags and talk of Caribbean holidays, and a couple of days later, the plasterers arrived; or at least the sub-sub-contracted plasterers arrived (the sub-sub-contracted plasterer had, I was told, fittingly, admitted himself to a drying-out clinic the previous week). My suspicions should, of course, have been alerted by their entrance carrying bicycle wheels and their opening greeting: 'Have you got a hammer, mate?'

But by now a wild desperation to move things forward had overtaken any real sense of discrimination. I thought I'd leave them to it for a couple of hours. I returned to discover that they had made a start at plastering the stair carpet without yet getting to the walls. 'Someone took our dust sheets,' they said, by way of explanation. And: 'We always do it this way, we just pour loads of water on the carpet afterwards.'

The sub-contractors and the sub-sub- contractors were 'marshalled' by a man called Les. When you needed him most, when your ceiling had fallen in, say, Les was always 'on site', and the sites he was on invariably inhibited the reception of mobile-phone signals. Not on site was Michelle, who came armed with a stubborn catchphrase: 'There's no point in yelling at me,' she would say. 'I'm only the messenger.'

Over the next few weeks the messages Michelle delivered were of two kinds: there was the promise of immediate action: 'You've been messed around; we'll be done by Friday, no question'; and there was the subsequent extraordinary explanation of inaction: the plumber who fell down the stairs; the sub-sub-sub-contracted plasterer whose girlfriend contracted malaria.

There are only a limited number of ways of making builders build. We'd tried the obvious ones: threats, pleading. I'd lain half awake in the early hours envisaging myself singing my builder's tale into a hand-held shower on a vintage episode of That's Life, searching for a rhyme for 'outrageous stunts'. We'd explored impromptu good cop, bad cop. On the few days when a builder was in the vicinity of the bathroom, I would talk encouragingly of slotted wastes and flexible hoses, and my wife would unexpectedly burst in to offer a startling stream of consciousness of insults, before departing behind a slammed door.

(This induced a change in behaviour of sorts. Thereafter, in our daily phone conversations, the litany of excuses and promises to be there 'at 8.30 sharp' would close with the words 'and send our apologies and best wishes to your wife, too'.) We could, at any time, of course, have fired them all, but each successive promise seemed more genuine than the one just broken.

By default, then, at the beginning of this month, we found ourselves maturing into a Zen position towards our builders (a state of mind perhaps necessary for anyone contemplating construction work in London). We have come to respect the existence of the grout containers under the stairs and the wisdom of the plumber being here, there and everywhere; and, as a result, we have become more in tune to the almost imperceptible I-can-hear-the-grass-grow pace at which the bathroom is taking shape. Apparently, by Friday it will be finished, and if it's not this Friday, then no doubt it will be one Friday soon. And this way we will know it tile by tile.

webTitle: Curse of the locust hits rain-saturated Australia

fields.headline: Curse of the locust hits rain-saturated Australia
fields.trailText: Not much frightens tough Australian farmers. But after a summer of torrential rain, many are watching the skies nervously. Locusts are swarming in vast numbers, carrying the potential to wipe out thousands of square miles of valuable cereal crops and vines.
fields.body:
Not much frightens tough Australian farmers. But after a summer of torrential rain, many are watching the skies nervously.

Locusts are swarming in vast numbers, carrying the potential to wipe out thousands of square miles of valuable cereal crops and vines. Most locust eggs hatch in the spring months of September and October, so these autumn swarms are particularly worrying, because any eggs laid now will significantly boost the spring hatch. A female can lay three batches of up to 40 eggs each during her brief, four-week life.

The swarms are already on the move, according to Peter Walker, an entomologist and forecaster for the Australian Plague Locust Commission. 'Current infestations are in north-west New South Wales, near White Cliffs, and on the eastern and northern sides of the Flinders ranges in South Australia,' said Walker. More have been reported in the south of New South Wales.

'Winds from the north carry them south, and we have already had reports of locusts turning up on some farms around the Mallee region in Victoria. That is a fair way south.' In fact, it is about 350 miles, a reminder that locusts can travel more than 600 miles in a few nights.

Western Australia is enduring its worst locust infestation for a decade, covering roughly 400 square miles. The last one cost A$4.5 million (£1.8m) to control, and entomologist Kevin Walden recalls that the population that preceded that one was smaller than the one now threatening the state.

'If we get significant spring rainfalls, we could be in big trouble. Then it's a race between the crops and the locusts to see who matures first. If the crops lose, it can cost millions,' said Walden. 'We are re-vegetating out here, planting a lot of trees, and the locusts can destroy them in a matter of hours.'

Such biblical infestations are created by the weather. Australia has suffered one of its most severe rainy seasons ('big wets') for 100 years. Record rains have turned deserts of red earth into lush green carpets of grass and flowers, a locust feast. So much rain fell on Uluru (formerly Ayers Rock) in the Northern Territory that it changed colour as water ran down its slopes.

February was the wettest that Alice Springs can remember. More than 9.4in of rain fell in one month, more than for the whole of 1999. Such saturation has left ideal conditions for locusts - wet and warm with an abundance of vegetation. And the rain is still falling, hampering attempts to control the swarms as they migrate closer to rich agricultural lands. Field officers from the Australian Plague Locust Commission in Broken Hill, New South Wales, had to postpone spraying last week as storms broke over the area.

Walker said: 'The hoppers (the new-born stage) are now matured into adults and have started to aggregate into swarms. We had just started controlling them, but we have had more rain and that has delayed things.'

Farmers can do little but wait, watch the skies and pray for no more rain.

fields.headline: WORLD IN BRIEF
fields.trailText: Kinshasa blasts
fields.body:
Kinshasa blasts

Up to 40 people were killed in a series of explosions at Kinshasa Airport. Congolese authorities said the blasts had been caused by a warehouse fire but witnesses said they were triggered by a short circuit in an ammunition dump. A hospital was said to have been overwhelmed by the numbers of injured and by distraught relatives.

Anwar riots

Riot police fired tear gas and water cannon and stormed a mosque as hundreds of demonstrators protested in Kuala Lumpur in support of Malaysia's jailed former Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim on the first anniversary of his conviction and six-year prison sentence on corruption charges.

Open all hours

Italy's state-run museums, archaeological sites and monuments are to open in the evenings on Sundays and bank holidays.

Party marine shot

A marine guard working at the US consulate in the Russian Pacific coast city of Vladivostok was shot and seriously wounded as he left a night club. A suspect was arrested.

Disaster area

South Korean President Kim Dae-jung has declared a disaster area in parts of the east coast where forest fires have killed two, destroyed more than 600 buildings and left more than 800 homeless.

Double tragedy

A boy aged 13 shot a friend, 16, with a rifle he didn't know was loaded and then, after calling police at Petersburg, Pennsylvania, used the gun to kill himself.

Burroughs' vultures

Internet auctioneer eBay is removing from its site personal items stolen from the Kansas home of writer William Burroughs, author of The Naked Lunch , who died in 1997. The items included identification cards, credit cards and prescriptions forms.

fields.headline: Exit, Passion play's racism
fields.standfirst: Oberammergau is split over changes that purge its Easter play of anti-Semitism and paint Pilate in darker colours, reports Elisabeth Ribbans
fields.trailText: You can tell which men in Oberammergau are taking part in this year's Passion Play. They're the ones with overgrown hair and beards of biblical proportions. But you wouldn't know by looking which one has just stood centuries of tradition on its head in this conservative Bavarian town. He turns out to be the cuddly fellow with a ciggie in his hand: Otto Huber, the local schoolmaster.
fields.body:
You can tell which men in Oberammergau are taking part in this year's Passion Play. They're the ones with overgrown hair and beards of biblical proportions. But you wouldn't know by looking which one has just stood centuries of tradition on its head in this conservative Bavarian town. He turns out to be the cuddly fellow with a ciggie in his hand: Otto Huber, the local schoolmaster.

Huber, 53, is deputy director of the Oberammergau Passion Play 2000 and the man responsible for the biggest reworking of the script in the past 140 years. His aim has been to drag the Easter play from its medieval roots and replant it in the light of modern thinking. To add drama, more relevance but, above all, to excise its anti-Semitic content. 'His blood shall not come upon them,' says Huber, in reference to Pilate's malediction that has, after fierce resistance, been axed from the play.

Since 1965, when Vatican II decreed Jews should not bear collective guilt for the death of Christ, Jewish organisations, particularly in the US, have been lobbying for changes to the world's most famous Passion play. They have won modifications along the way but nothing compared to Huber's text.

Out goes all reference to Jewish cupidity and culpability. Out, too, goes Pontius Pilate as heavy-hearted judge. Huber, who reckons the Gospels give the Roman procurator far too good a press, has recast him as craven villain: cue new Old Testament tableau that makes unflattering comparisons with Pharaoh.

Out goes the word 'Pharisee' which in German has the secondary meaning of 'hypocrite'. Also deleted are the curses poured on Judas, and in their place a prayer for all traitors. In comes Jesus the rabbi, firmly a Jew among Jews. When he arrives at the Last Supper he will find it infused with Hebrew Passover rituals. Figures who spoke up for Jesus have been given more dialogue, and a new character, Gamaliel, has been borrowed from Acts Chapter 5 to defend Jesus before the High Council.

The final week of Christ's life on earth has thus become a story of good people and bad people who just happen to be Jews. An internecine, rather than an interfaith, dispute. If anything, it's become a parable for German misdeeds. 'We do not want to make any judgment about Judaism,' says Huber. 'As Germans, we are in no position to.'

The changes may seem overdue, but in Oberammergau traditions die hard. The Passion play, a descendant of the part religious, part popular mystery plays, has been performed roughly every 10 years since 1634, in fulfilment of a vow made when the Alpine town was spared from the plague. Throughout wars and in defiance of Enlightenment edicts, it has hardly broken stride. This year around half a million visitors, 60 per cent from America, will attend its 20-week run from May to October.

Until German law caught up with Oberammergau in 1990, married women and women over 35 were banned from taking part in the play. Now the only rule is that all 1,900 cast and crew must have been born in the town or resident for 20 years. For the first time, there will be around 20 Muslims among the players.

Getting the town, which 'owns' the play, to accept a re-write of Joseph Daisenberger's 1860 script has been a slow process. In 1980, a referendum rejected an alternative version. Ten years later, director Christian Stückl - then just 28 - was again forced down the old route.

But it seems the progressive postwar faction have finally come of age. Stückl and Huber narrowly won a mandate to produce the millennium Passion play in the renovated Passionspielhaus. There are fresh set designs and new music.

The traditionalists will not be drawn to comment openly until they have seen the play, but one citizen cautioned darkly that 'Man should not put new wine in old bottles'.

Huber, whose family, like Stückl's, has been involved with the play since the seventeenth century, blames Passion plays 'whose gospel messages were perverted' for nourishing anti-Semitism. Adolf Hitler attended the 1934 performance and praised it as a 'precious tool' in the fight against Jews.

'We can no longer ignore the fact that we don't have Jewish neighbours in Oberammergau,' says Huber.

The new version seeks to build bridges between the faiths. Before the Last Supper there is a new tableau depicting the Passover of the Israelites before they leave Egypt. 'It is an allegory for the coming salvation of Jesus by the same God,' says Huber.

But in Huber's head the allegories work forward as well as back. He sees parallels between the closed systems of power in Jerusalem and those in the Third Reich. 'When Jesus stands before Pilate and Caiaphas, he is like one of the wonderful men who was brought before Judge Roland Freisler [president of the Volksgerichtshofs in the Nazi period] and found a 100 per cent deficit of justice. The play is much more a mirror of our own experiences in the twentieth century than a reflection of Jewish guilt.'

His only regret is the removal from a song of the word 'Yahweh' (a name for God that Jews consider too sacred to pronounce). 'I think it's a beautiful word, but we took it away to keep the peace.'

How far would he go to expunge all trace of prejudice? 'I can't go further, but maybe a genius will come after me who will find a way,' says an exhausted Huber. 'To my mind, if you try to tell this tale as a neutral observer, it is one depressing story. The story of a loser. You must tell it like a believer to see the hope.'

The new drafts have been scrutinised by the town's council, its Catholic and Lutheran priests, and Jewish groups such as the US-based Anti-Defamation League (ADL). Bavaria's Cardinal Wetter sent what Huber describes as a 'charming inquisitor', Ludwig Mödl, professor of theology from Munich University, to check on the changes. Mödl says the council's debates were long and robust but feels the new version is the 'best compromise' between the faiths.

Rabbi Leon Klenicki, director of interfaith affairs at the ADL, will be among those at the premiere on 21 May. He 'commends' the team on its editorial efforts but a month before curtain-up is still urging changes to the script. 'I am very unhappy that the Jewish leadership continue to be portrayed as unconditional allies of Roman power - as Quislings,' he says. 'You can't do that when Dachau is just up the road.'

Whether Oberammergau goes the extra step will be for the first-night audience to discover. But it seems unlikely: 'If you took away every bad element from the Jewish priests, it would not work,' says Huber. 'You know, Jesus did not die of influenza.'

The changes may seem overdue, but in Oberammergau traditions die hard. The Passion play, a descendant of the part religious, part popular mystery plays, has been performed roughly every 10 years since 1634, in fulfilment of a vow made when the Alpine town was spared from the plague. Throughout wars and in defiance of Enlightenment edicts, it has hardly broken stride. This year around half a million visitors, 60 per cent from America, will attend its 20-week run from May to October. Until German law caught up with Oberammergau in 1990, married women and women over 35 were banned from taking part in the play. Now the only rule is that all 1,900 cast and crew must have been born in the town or resident for 20 years. For the first time, there will be around 20 Muslims among the players. Getting the town, which 'owns' the play, to accept a re-write of Joseph Daisenberger's 1860 script has been a slow process. In 1980, a referendum rejected an alternative version. Ten years later, director Christian Stückl - then just 28 - was again forced down the old route. But it seems the progressive postwar faction have finally come of age. Stückl and Huber narrowly won a mandate to produce the millennium Passion play in the renovated Passionspielhaus. There are fresh set designs and new music. The traditionalists will not be drawn to comment openly until they have seen the play, but one citizen cautioned darkly that 'Man should not put new wine in old bottles'. Huber, whose family, like Stückl's, has been involved with the play since the seventeenth century, blames Passion plays 'whose gospel messages were perverted' for nourishing anti-Semitism. Adolf Hitler attended the 1934 performance and praised it as a 'precious tool' in the fight against Jews. 'We can no longer ignore the fact that we don't have Jewish neighbours in Oberammergau,' says Huber. The new version seeks to build bridges between the faiths. Before the Last Supper there is a new tableau depicting the Passover of the Israelites before they leave Egypt. 'It is an allegory for the coming salvation of Jesus by the same God,' says Huber. But in Huber's head the allegories work forward as well as back. He sees parallels between the closed systems of power in Jerusalem and those in the Third Reich. 'When Jesus stands before Pilate and Caiaphas, he is like one of the wonderful men who was brought before Judge Roland Freisler [president of the Volksgerichtshofs in the Nazi period] and found a 100 per cent deficit of justice. The play is much more a mirror of our own experiences in the twentieth century than a reflection of Jewish guilt.' His only regret is the removal from a song of the word 'Yahweh' (a name for God that Jews consider too sacred to pronounce). 'I think it's a beautiful word, but we took it away to keep the peace.' How far would he go to expunge all trace of prejudice? 'I can't go further, but maybe a genius will come after me who will find a way,' says an exhausted Huber. 'To my mind, if you try to tell this tale as a neutral observer, it is one depressing story. The story of a loser. You must tell it like a believer to see the hope.' The new drafts have been scrutinised by the town's council, its Catholic and Lutheran priests, and Jewish groups such as the US-based Anti-Defamation League (ADL). Bavaria's Cardinal Wetter sent what Huber describes as a 'charming inquisitor', Ludwig Mödl, professor of theology from Munich University, to check on the changes. Mödl says the council's debates were long and robust but feels the new version is the 'best compromise' between the faiths. Rabbi Leon Klenicki, director of interfaith affairs at the ADL, will be among those at the premiere on 21 May. He 'commends' the team on its editorial efforts but a month before curtain-up is still urging changes to the script. 'I am very unhappy that the Jewish leadership continue to be portrayed as unconditional allies of Roman power - as Quislings,' he says. 'You can't do that when Dachau is just up the road.' Whether Oberammergau goes the extra step will be for the first-night audience to discover. But it seems unlikely: 'If you took away every bad element from the Jewish priests, it would not work,' says Huber. 'You know, Jesus did not die of influenza.'

fields.headline: Young and gifted
fields.standfirst: Michael Young seems to get his inspiration from outer space. First, there was the pod cushion, the Smarty, then the sci-fi tray on legs, and now his latest venture, Astro, a nightclub in Iceland's Reykjavik. But whatever happened to puffin soup? By Tamsin Blanchard
fields.trailText: Michael Young seems to get his inspiration from outer space. First, there was the pod cushion, the Smarty, then the sci-fi tray on legs, and now his latest venture, Astro, a nightclub in Iceland's Reykjavik. But whatever happened to puffin soup?
fields.body:
Five minutes to 11, and Michael Young and his Icelandic wife, Katrin Petursdottir, are leaving the Rex, Reykjavik's sleekest and shiniest restaurant. They step out into the cold night, past a typical Friday night drunken brawl, and walk briskly a few doors up the hill to the Astro bar. It is the opening of a new Reykjavik night-time landmark. Young walks through the door, trying to ignore the queue gathering outside. He is a little nervous. Some of the furniture is still held in customs, the toilets are barely finished and - he sniffs the fumes in the air - the paint isn't dry yet.

But what a glorious shade of green it is: the kind of souped-up, pistachio green you associate with 50s ice-cream parlours. And just to set the teeth on edge is a stripe of bright, beefy red, a motif that outlines the club's doorways and cloakroom, as though Young has drawn them with a giant red marker. You know how these designers are - they don't like things to be too tasteful. They like things to jar a little. A single, bold red stripe marks the floor, a few yards short of the bar. 'It's the thin red line,' he says. 'There's no going back once you've crossed it.'

The moulded, loopy bar itself has Michael Young's fingerprints all over it. Not literally, of course. That would be enough to send him right over the edge. The furniture designer has a permanent hang-dog look at the best of times. As he himself admits, he worries too much. But he agrees, the sticky paint surfaces will have to do.

Time up. It's 11 o'clock, and the moment is here to unveil the world's first total Michael Young experience. This is his space, from the light fittings, his brand new prototype armchair, and the vibrating colour scheme to the Star Trek-modern uniforms of the bar staff (designed by Katrin, along with the graphics for the invite). If you had asked someone 30 years ago to describe an interior for the year 2020, it would have looked something like Astro. 'This is my playground - my dream project,' he says. 'Most bars are dreary places. There aren't many bars designed purposefully for entertainment. I wanted to create an environment for people to escape to and forget their week.'

It is a little like entering a spaceship - there are these strange white spiky-looking lights suspended from the ceiling; the surface of the bar feels as though it is made from some material from another planet; and slap-bang in the middle is a hollow crater, with five round red pods arranged within it, like huge buttons waiting for some giant alien to come and push them. The 'sticklights' are, in fact, Young's latest design for the West London-based company Eurolounge. They are made from the same plastic that is used for motorway cones. The bar is made from Corian, a man-made stone composite that has been carved by hand until it is perfectly smooth and rounded, just the way he likes it. And the strange pods in the crater are Young's celebrated Smarty cushions, which he says are like toys. The sunken structure was engineered by the same people who built Reykjavik's recently revamped Blue Lagoon, the hyper-real, turquoise-blue steaming volcanic waters that have become Iceland's star tourist attraction. The idea was to create a dry version of a hot tub. In Iceland, they are something of a national institution. Young says he takes to the hot tub when he gets bored or disillusioned, or when he needs time to think. During the week, friends meet in their local tub for a soak and a gossip, much as the Brits might meet up for a few pints in the pub after work. This is a combination of the two.

Upstairs, there is another bar, with lots of space for dancing and a floor that lights up in multi-colours, specially designed by lighting innovator Jeremy Lord. There's a VIP room, too, that basks in the glow of red light, which has a heat sensor and intensifies the more people there are in the room. The furniture is all white, just as Young likes it, so you can see the design in all its purity.

In the chaos of Astro's opening night, however, Young seems rooted to his Smarty for much of the night as the crowds sweep around the place, stampeding over the furniture, hanging off the lights, spilling their drinks and stubbing out their cigarettes. He seems a little bemused and out of place in his own environment, partly, perhaps, because he is not used to seeing his work used quite so brutally. But this is a nightclub, and the Icelanders know how to party. Friday night in Reykjavik is not a place for the faint-hearted. It's like New Year's Eve, Valentine's Night, 10 hen parties, and Arsenal winning the double all at the same time. The first time he was left on his own in his newly adopted town, Young recalls wandering out for a drink and being set upon by a gang of drunken teenagers, who beat him up just for the sheer, lager-sodden fun of it. And he's a tall bloke. From Sunderland.

Young and Petursdottir live and work in the centre of town, and run around in a Jeep with a mini Union Jack propped on the dashboard. It appeals to Young's innocent sense of humour. It would be impossible for Iceland not to have an effect on Young's work. 'I moved here for the obscurity of it,' he says. He likes the isolation and the purity of the place, the fact that wherever you look you can see snow-capped mountains. He also loves the Icelandic horses, which look as though they have been speeded up on film because their legs are too short for their bodies, and the vast factory down at the docks, where fishing nets are made by hand in hundreds of bright and cheery colours. The docks themselves, with their huge, brightly painted trawlers and disused whaler, are a favourite hunting ground for Young. It is places like this where great ideas are born. 'I've never been inspired by looking at design,' he insists.

Like Björk, who recently moved back to her home town, and Blur's Damon Albarn, who has an apartment and a part-share in Reykjavik's most talked-about drinking den, Young lives in the centre of town. He's lived there for more than 18 months, after marrying Petursdottir on a tiny, windswept island off the mainland. She's a designer, too. They met in London while Young was becoming known for the child-like simplicity of his designs - the MY16 (the Smarty) or MY03, (the magazine sofa that doubles as a magazine rack).

Since being in Iceland, Young has set up another branch of his company, in partnership with his wife. It's called Young & Beautiful, and one of their first ventures was the comical-sounding puffin soup (he is fascinated by the creatures, which in Iceland are something of a delicacy. The meat, apparently, tastes like a cross between chicken and fish.) Production had to be curtailed; the responsibility of running a slaughterhouse suddenly didn't have quite the same appeal for the couple. Typically, the operation was always more about packaging than content anyway.

Another Young & Beautiful venture is a small selection of jewellery made by the Icelandic silversmith, Snorri Sigurdsson, under the label s.m.a.k. The silver ring is based on the couple's wedding ring, which in turn is based on the curvy rectangular shape of his magazine sofa. There are six collections by other designers in progress, including a necklace by the British furniture maestro Michael Marriott. Eventually, Young says he would like his ring to be made in plastic, 'in hundreds of different colours'.

Like most product designers, Young dreams of a world in which his furniture, jewellery, lights and glasses are widely available and accessibly priced. This week, he is at the Milan Furniture Fair, presenting his new products for the Italian manufacturer Magis. There's a tray on legs - the sort of bed tray you might imagine the Jetsons using to serve up sci-fi food at the Jetson Hospital. There's a flat, square floor light, with a mini volcano of light erupting from a crater within it. And two tables - one that's just simple moulded plastic, and another with globular trestle legs and a glass top. 'They're going to be cheap,' he enthuses. And if they are, then surely no self-respecting modern home should be without at least one of them.

Young was born in Sunderland in 1966, and confesses that he was a bit of an academic failure. 'I was crap at school,' he says. 'The teachers told my parents there was no hope for me. That just drove me to prove I could do something.' So he got himself on to the furniture and product design degree course at Kingston University, and found work at Tom Dixon's Space studio in London's Notting Hill.

By day he worked, and then after hours he would play to his heart's content, using up Dixon's scraps for his own experiments. 'I had really just started learning about shapes,' he writes in the design source book We Like This! Michael Young, published by Black Dog last year. 'The way the Smarty was born was through my getting a huge block of foam... I put this massive metal bolt through the centre of it and attached it to the end of a lathe - the whole machine would be shaking up and down. I then cut at it with a circular saw blade, which was about 1ft in diameter. I wrapped a cardboard box around my stomach, taped it to myself and cut into the foam with this really dangerous blade. Of course, I didn't know what it was going to be exactly... but it turned out to be one of the greatest accidents in my life.'

The Smarty became the basis for Young's expansion as a designer in his own right. It was eventually put into production in 1998 by the Italian manufacturer Cappellini, and has become an international design classic. In the world of furniture, the designer is paid a percentage on every piece sold. 'If you've got 40 products on the market then you can retire,' he says. Or you do as Philippe Starck does - take more risks and get richer.

Starck once turned up at the young designer's London studio. There had been a call beforehand to say he was coming, but Young didn't realise it would be the man himself. The eccentric Frenchman arrived - on a moped - inspected Young's work and then left again, as suddenly as he arrived. For a designer, this was like having the Queen pop in for an impromptu tea. 'I guess Starck has broken down all the traditional design values,' says Young. 'He's made a mockery of them, and that's fantastic. He's paved the way for people like me.' Young still has a way to go, but there seems little doubt that he will get there. 'I have curiosity and determination,' he says. 'I do my things, and I will do them till I die.' He is like an icebreaker at full steam.

The day after the launch party, Young is back at Astro assessing the damage. He had sneaked off early the night before. Now the place looks like it needs a new lick of paint. You can see the imprints of people's bottoms where they sat on the paintwork. But Young's perma-frown just sets a little deeper. As he hands out instructions for work to be done, he is already on to the next project. There's talk of bringing the Astro concept to London.

But now that he has completed his first nightclub, following in the foot-steps of Marc Newson (Tokyo) and Philippe Starck (Paris) before him, Young's next interior promises to be something altogether wilder. It's a virtual world, in conjunction with other Icelandic artists, scheduled to come alive at the end of May. @ is a world without the confines of straight walls, fixed floors and paint that doesn't dry. 'It'll be a colourful grid, with any shape that comes out of the ground,' says Young. And you won't have to leave the comfort of your Smarty cushion to go there. n

 To order a copy of We Like This! Michael Young by Alexander Payne for £7.99 (rrp £9.99), plus 99p UK p&p, freephone 0800 3168 171 or send your order with a UK cheque payable to The Observer CultureShop, to 250 Western Avenue, London W3 6EE. For more information and news on up-and-coming MY products, go to www.michael-young.com. For a closer look at Astro, go to www.astro.is. For information on @world, go to www.OZ.com.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: The job of religious leader can be very lonely, says Chief Rabbi Jonathan Sacks. But meeting up with Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz, his friend of more than 30 years, lifts his spirits and lets him laugh at his problems.
fields.trailText: The job of religious leader can be very lonely, says Chief Rabbi Jonathan Sacks. But meeting up with Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz, his friend of more than 30 years, lifts his spirits and lets him laugh at his problems.
fields.body:
Chief Rabbi Professor Jonathan Sacks We met a long time ago when I was a student at Jews' College in London, and Rabbi Steinsaltz came to give a talk in the 70s. Everyone who begins studying the Talmud meets Rabbi Steinsaltz, because one of his great works has been to make the Talmud accessible to students. So I knew of him long before I met him because he was my gateway to the world of rabbinic learning.

Rabbi Steinsaltz always stays with me when he's in London, which is two or three times a year, and he always says something that lifts my spirits. When we meet up, we tell each other stories - we learn to laugh at our problems. And so we live from encounter to encounter, as Adin is one of those people who perhaps despite, or perhaps because, he is part of another very complicated Jewish community in Israel. He sees very far and very deeply into the problems of this community, and so always manages to say something that I needed to hear in order to have the strength to write the next chapter or fight the next battle.

The relationship is very simple. The story's told of a great Hasidic master, Rabbi Nachman of Bratslav, who one year foresaw that the harvest would be infected and whoever would eat it would go mad, and Rabbi Nachman said to his disciple, 'What shall we do? If we eat it, we'll go mad, but if we don't eat it, we will fail to share in the suffering of our community.' So they decided they would eat of the grain but each one would put a mark on the forehead of the other so that while everyone else was mad, at least the two of them would know they were mad. And that is the relationship between Rabbi Steinsaltz and myself; knowing we're both mad keeps us sane.

It was the encounter with another remarkable person, Rabbi Lubavitcher, who set me on this journey to becoming a rabbi. I met him when I was an undergraduate at Cambridge, and I travelled to New York, and immediately he started encouraging me to be a leader. I realised that here was someone who believed in me more than I believed in myself. And as the years went by, I sensed a challenge that I had to respond to.

Sometimes you discover that religious leadership can be a very lonely job, and the knowledge that there is someone else somewhere else who understands, that in itself is a source of enormous strength.

We are a people of very strong individuals, and therefore it is very difficult to be a leader because, quite rightly, every Jew sees himself or herself as a leader, and that means it can sometimes be a difficult and fraught life, but all you really need is a friend who understands and sympathises and lifts the burden, and that's what Rabbi Steinsaltz is for me. He's also a role model of how one can be very much in the heart of Jewish life and Jewish study, and yet preserve your integrity intellectually and ethically.

The word adin is the nearest Hebrew gets to a particular kind of gentleness, which is Adin's very great characteristic. Adin is both a mystical and a poetical person, and poetic spirits are relatively rare in contemporary Judaism. And to hear Rabbi Steinsaltz speak is to hear a poetic stream of consciousness. It is always a wonderfully ethereal vision, which he always brings down to earth by analogies and stories which are so unexpected that one realises one is in the presence of a very vast intelligence indeed, and a very benign one.

Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz I met Jonathan about 30 years ago, which is a sizeable part of both of our lives. The age difference between us is only 10 years, he's 51, and as far as I remember he was a student at Jews' College when we met. I was a different, slightly older person trying to do the same thing Jonathan dreamt of doing. When I first saw him, I realised he was intellectually and otherwise, clearly above the others.

We became very friendly. We have an affinity in so many ways. I have very few friends like this, where you can be friends without needing to send cards between visits. Rabbi Sacks visits Jerusalem three or four times a year, and he has such a busy timetable that it is easier for us to spend time together in London.

The thing that was most important was that he cared. He cares about God and he cares about Jews and the religion. My real question at the time was will he have the stamina to go through with the job of being a rabbi. And it is an immense job being chief rabbi - the chief rabbi has lots of titles but very little clout. People have lots of expectations that he cannot fulfil and you just get tired of the whole thing. In one way, nobody is strong enough to ignore all the politics, whether it is government politics or internal Jewish politics. A position like this needs stamina.

When people asked my opinion about him being chief rabbi, I said I saw him as the only likely candidate - from all over the world. It was obvious to me from the beginning that he would go far. He has an unusual capacity for understanding, not only the Jewish religious world, but also the outside world.

The book aims to put complex philosophical ideas into simple words. Just imagine I gave you a cookie loaded with LSD, you would swallow it and then you would jump up. The book, likewise, is deceptively simple, so you might read it and think, 'There's nothing new in it. I've always thought like this', but afterwards you find your perception has changed.

Rabbi Sacks and I talk about philosophy, and we sometimes compare wounds and talk about what makes people like us tick. We have similar missions in many ways.

fields.headline: Trailer flash
fields.standfirst: They have no running water, rarely exceed 30mph and are done up with customised marble fireplaces. For the Carters, of Royal Berkshire Steam Fair fame, their antiquemobile homes are thier castles
fields.trailText: They have no running water, rarely exceed 30mph and are done up with customised marble fireplaces. For the Carters, of Royal Berkshire Steam Fair fame, their antiquemobile homes are thier castles
fields.body:
Fairground showman 'Big John' Carter is not one to mince words. He's a get-this-straight, don't-argue sort of bloke. And when talking about his passion (the world of vintage funfairs), he's a stickler for the correct use of terminology. It certainly didn't go down too well when I referred to his 1890s steam 'galloper' as a carousel. 'Call it a merry-go-round, if you must, or even a roundabout,' he boomed. 'But never, never a bloody carousel.'

Fortunately, I wasn't even tempted to call his mobile 'living van' a caravan.The traditional showman's wagon - a fairground essential during the first half of the 20th century - is too fine and beautiful a thing to be lumped together with a run-of-the-mill Caravan Club tourer. John Carter and his travelling entourage (wife Anna, children Seth, Zed, Joby, Amber and Rose, numerous dogs, grandchildren and extended family) have a whole fleet of heavy-goods, engine-hauled living vans. Like most of what they own, they are museum-quality classics; they are also real, working, all-season homes and a vital part of the Carters's way of life.

John and Anna used to be 'flatties' (people who live in proper houses) before founding the now-famous Carters Royal Berkshire Steam Fair more than 25 years ago. They started small, with the steam galloper, bought on a whim from a retired showman and painstakingly restored. Once committed to the life, they gradually built up an extensive collection of fairground 'machines', including 1870s Overboats, a 1948 Electric Rotor, 20s 'white-knuckle' Steam Yachts and a 60s Octopus ride which once belonged to Gerry Cottle.

The Carters have no time for what John describes as 'the sea of plastic signs which passes for the modern funfair, or the dismal kitsch of theme parks'. Every link in the long chain of Carter rides, trailers and haulage vehicles (including a 1932 Ford Model AA which is pulled laboriously from one Thames Valley venue to another) represents a chapter in English fairground history. Living in original wagons is part of their devotion to the past, and thus they are one of the last remaining families in Showland to resist upgrading to modern caravans.

For 14-year-old Rose, the youngest of the Carter children, a van of one kind or another is the only home she's ever known. Touchingly, she keeps a whimsical collection of miniature cottages in her wagon bedroom. Every bit the pragmatic traveller, however, she has Blu-Tacked them into a glazed cupboard so they don't jiggle about when the wagon is rattling down the motorway (literally rattling, that is; the Carters rarely travel faster than 30mph).

Last month, they were preparing to leave their winter premises in suburban Maidenhead - with its mains water and electricity - for seven months on the road. The yard was a chaos of machinery; the air thick with the smell of paint, varnish, engine grease and diesel. Nobody had time for idle chitchat but I managed a series of living-van tours before they were 'packed down' for the big pull.

'They'll start to look the same after you've seen a few,' warned Anna, but while it's true that they are all vaguely reminiscent of Victorian railway saloon cars (cream, gold and Crimson Lake coach paint, polished hardwood interiors, cut and bevelled glasswork, etc), no two vans are exactly the same. They all have a traditional 'Mollycroft' roof (a strip of glazed vents under a raised canopy) and a decorated 'belly box' (a lock-up storage unit slung below the chassis), but each has been produced to order by one of a number of specialist makers. An educated wagon enthusiast can easily tell a classic Brayshaw (made by William Brayshaw & Sons) from a Vosper, a Southern and North or an Orton and Spooner. The Carters, of course, have had examples of them all.

John and Anna's home life is shared between a 1948 Vosper, a rare 1927 Brayshaw, and a relatively modern trailer converted into a family kitchen van (with attached bathroom and outdoor chemical toilet). The Vosper - 30ft of 'late utility Art Deco style' with a half-ton marble fireplace and a tiny bedroom at either end of the living room - is ostensibly John's domain (his name, at least, is on the door). But the van also accommodates Rose's typically teenage bedroom (all boy bands, soft toys and cute pictures of Rottweilers) and, in the summer months, when Anna's Brayshaw is left behind, it becomes Mum and Dad Carter's main living space.

Anna's Brayshaw, her 'Palace on Wheels', is far too precious to travel, she explains. And I see what she means when I remove my shoes and step inside. This is the Sistine Chapel of living vans: wall-to-wall mahogany joinery, curved-glass cabinets, etched mirrors, brass fittings, glass lamps and ornately painted ceiling panels featuring gilded scrolls, a trellis of roses and the odd butterfly against a pale blue sky. In common with much of the Carter collection, it didn't always look this good.

The ceiling, for a start, was badly damaged. The whole surface was covered in sticky brown toffee which, according to Anna, was caused by a former owner, who had stockpiled candy-floss sugar during a shortage and then had an accident with a heater. After five weeks of scrubbing the panels clean with paper and meths, Anna used her artistic talent (she is the Carters resident fairground artist) to restore some of the decorative paintwork and reinstate the melted shellac varnish.

Meticulous attention to detail is clearly a family trait and, in all, the restoration of the Carter vans must amount to years of hard labour. Indeed, I was unable to see the inside of Zed's gleaming Vosper because he was in the midst of repairing its leaded bay windows. And Joby, who has already spent three years doing up his one-bed Brayshaw, still works hard to keep it up to the standards of its previous owner, showlady Priscilla Shaw, who is said to have employed a maid.

'You have to keep it clean and tidy, because if you don't, it really gets to you,' says Joby, 24, who not only insisted that I remove my footwear before entering but also supplied a coaster for my tea cup so as not to mark his immaculate woodwork. It's not what you'd expect of a young man in oil-stained overalls, but his living van, he explains, is his private refuge - an escape from the world of whirling Chair-o-planes, hooplahs and shooters, of organ music, engines and Carter family business. 'When I step outside, I'm at work,' he says. 'In here, I can be me.'

That said, he is still, effectively, living at home - dependent on big brothers or parents for baths and hot food. 'I've got a sink,' he says proudly. 'And I've just invested in a camping stove so I can make tea and toast.'

The sink, however, is not connected to mains water, and the stove takes about an hour to do toast. 'The other disadvantage of this wagon is that it's like a corridor,' adds Joby. 'If you've got two people in here, it's full up. Four people, and it's almost a party.' When he first moved in, he invited 18 people to a 'wagon warming' - it was a case of packing them in like rush-hour commuters on a Bakerloo line tube.

'What I wouldn't do for two sofas opposite each other,' sighs Joby. 'But apart from more room, there's nothing that other people have got that I haven't got or could have. If I was prepared to mess up the originality of the van, I could have a tap and a cooker, but I believe in respecting the history of what you're living in. And as the owner of this van, I carry quite a lot of responsibility.'

That responsibility, however, becomes less of a pressing issue when sharing a van with young children. If Joby is short of room, imagine what it's like for Seth and Tania, squeezed into a 30ft Southern with their toddlers, Ashley and Ben. 'It is hard,' admits Tania, whose fairground life started when, at the age of 16, she met Seth on Carters's 60s 'Kings of Rock and Roll' Dodgems (their eyes met over the roar of chrome supercars) and they fell in love. 'The lack of space can be very stressful,' Tania says. 'It puts a great strain on a relationship.'

According to 'Little John' Todd (one of a number of permanent Carter Fair tenants) who lives with wife Shelley and two young children in a 50s Proctor, there are compensations. 'We love the outdoor life, the constant change of scenery and the atmosphere of the funfair. It's what we always wanted to do,' he says. But though they all share those sentiments, there's not one of the Carter clan who can say they don't miss flushing toilets and - during the months on the road - running hot water.

Even Big John, the seasoned traveller, bemoans the inconvenience of relying on generated electricity, chemical toilets and, in 28 cases out of 30, the fairground sites that don't provide mains water ('in the old days, it would have been considered a form of persecution'). As an ex-flattie, he adds, it is hard to refine his life down to the barest minimum. But there is sparkle in his eye when he talks about his role as chief preservationist of a dying tradition. 'There's not many English families these days who can say they run a small business which provides its members with both a living and a home,' he says. n

 Carters Royal Berkshire Steam Fair appears at 30 venues in the Thames Valley area (including central London, Hemel Hempstead and Guildford) between April and October. For details of dates and places, call 01628 822 221.

webTitle: Britain backs ugly war for oil

fields.headline: Britain backs ugly war for oil
fields.standfirst: As Sudan's fundamentalist regime kills and tortures civilians in the rebel South,  Julie Flint in Pagerau reveals UK involvement with the exploiters of the region's oil
fields.trailText: As British involvement in Sudan's oil war deepens, the fundamentalist generals ruling the country have launched an offensive of unprecedented brutality against civilians living around the disputed Bentiu oilfields, just below the divide between the country's Arab-Islamic north and long-neglected African south.
fields.body:
As British involvement in Sudan's oil war deepens, the fundamentalist generals ruling the country have launched an offensive of unprecedented brutality against civilians living around the disputed Bentiu oilfields, just below the divide between the country's Arab-Islamic north and long-neglected African south.

Fugitives from the offensive trickling into Yirol county, 200 miles south of the main oil-producing area, say troops backed by tanks, helicopter gunships and aerial bombardments are torturing, slaughtering and burning men, women and children in a drive to evict all 'non-Arabs' from oil-producing areas.

'All the villages are being burned,' said Peter Magany, a southerner who spent a week in hiding before trekking 17 days through the bush to Pagerau.

The New Sudan Council of Churches accused Khartoum of 'genocide' and called for international action to halt the flow of oil.

'The government is using the roads and airstrips of the multinational companies engaged in the production of oil in the Sudan for military purposes,' the NSCC said. It urged creation of a no-fly zone over all war-affected areas.

Government officials admit oil revenue is financing their war against the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), which took up arms in 1983 to fight for a secular democracy and a fairer distribution of wealth.

After years of non-production caused by insecurity, a 1,000-mile pipeline was opened eight months ago to carry oil from the Heglig and Unity fields to Port Sudan on the Red Sea coast. In February, as reports piled up of government atrocities around the pipeline, the United States Treasury imposed sanctions on the Greater Nile Oil Project, the consortium set up to exploit the oil.

In the same month, BP Amoco acquired a large investment in a company linked to a member of the consortium which unites Sudan's state-owned oil company with three foreign firms led by Canada's Talisman Energy, formerly British Petroleum Canada. The China National Petroleum Corporation or CNPC, BP's connection to the oil war, has the largest slice of the project - 40 per cent.

The Observer has learnt that Khartoum is planning a second pipeline that will bypass eastern regions, where the first pipeline is under attack from opposition forces. The new pipeline will more than double Sudan's production, spreading the oil war far beyond its present borders.

Industry sources say Weir Pumps of Glasgow, which provided the pumping stations for the first pipeline, is constructing the pumps for the second, using engines manufactured by Allen Power Engineering of Bedford. A third British firm, Angus Fire of Oxfordshire, is providing integral fire-extinguishing systems.

'Pumps are the heartbeat of the pipeline,' Peter Verney, author of Oil and Conflict in Sudan, said yesterday. 'Without them, the oil can't be pumped. The British government has called on Premier Oil to pull out of Burma, saying "constructive engagement" doesn't work. Yet in Sudan we are still plugging away at constructive engagement, getting by with warm words of concern about the turmoil in the South.'

According to the wretched, ragged survivors reaching Pagerau, that turmoil has plumbed new depths of depravity in the last month, following the return to armed struggle of Riek Machar - until this year one of Khartoum's most important southern allies. In a letter tendering his resignation as assistant to President Omar al-Bashir, he said the government was interested only in divide and rule - not in peace. Machar's defection prompted a new government push to depopulate the oil-producing areas, inhabited largely by Machar's own Nuer tribespeople.

Meding Yieth, a Nuer from Rik village near the Heglig oilfield north of Bentiu, witnessed a government attack that razed Rik last month. 'They burned the entire village and shot all males older than 15 or 16,' he said. 'Women and children fled towards Bentiu. Some were caught and taken in cars to Bentiu. Others drowned while being chased across the Bahr el Ghazal river [on Bentiu's northern edge].'

Yieth escaped across Bentiu and reached the village of Guk a day's walk south. Here, he said, he hid in a luac - a thatched byre - belonging to a friend called Chol Riak. Then the army reached Guk.

'I saw soldiers questioning Chol Riak,' he said. 'They nailed his wife and three young children to a tree and hit the children with sticks to make him talk. They they cut their throats. They sliced off Chol's ears and hammered nails into his temples. He was a trader; he knew nothing of the SPLA.'

Yieth said the family of a second friend, Chol Bol, was similarly slaughtered. The husband was killed with nails, his wife was shot dead and their seven children had their throats cut. Old people who were unable to flee were herded into a cattle pen and burned alive with their animals. Another southerner who made it to Pagerau, Kolang Yar, said his sister and brother-in-law had been killed in an attack on Roub Nyagai, near the Unity oilfield. Khartoum seven months ago imposed a ban on all UN relief flights into the region. Paul Savage, Christian Aid's senior field officer in southern Sudan, said: 'Foreign investors and foreign workers are being invited into the oil fields, but relief is being denied to people forced from their homes to secure that oil.'

David Rice, director of BP's Policy Unit, admitted oil was responsible for human rights abuses in Sudan and was financing the war against the South. But the BP delegation said the company was committed to increasing its stake in PetroChina to $1 billion.

fields.headline: Flannelled fools
fields.trailText: For those who cling to the quaint notion that cricket should provide a whiter than lilywhite role model for young people, it has not been a vintage week. Hansie Cronje, the erstwhile South African cricket captain, was the first dream-breaker. The republic, where Godliness is next to the scoreboard, is still in denial over allegations that the devout Christian took money to fix matches against India. A survey on Friday showed 94 per cent of South Africans think Cronje should be allowed to play for his country again, even though he admitted he had not been 'entirely honest' in his initial response to the claims from India last week. Thereafter, he dissembled with Nixonian aplomb.

Thereafter, he dissembled with Nixonian aplomb.

Cricket exposure of a different kind hit the headlines later in the week. An anorak delving through the 1,600 pages of the latest Wisden Almanack suggested that in the Leicestershire team photo, the left-arm spinner Matthew Brimson was fiddling with what London's Evening Standard called his 'middle stump'.

Brimson's 'crime' proves nothing more than that at the age of 30, he has not shed his schoolboyish tendencies. The charges against him can be laughed off. The charges against Cronje are altogether more serious. Only one of these players is truly guilty of bringing the great game into disrepute.

webTitle: Raise the scarlet standard high again

fields.headline: Raise the scarlet standard high again
fields.standfirst:
By alienating his party activists, Tony Blair is imperilling both his majority at the next election and his mandate for change

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: By alienating his party activists, Tony Blair is imperilling both his majority at the next election and his mandate for change
fields.body:
A senior minister said to me recently that the Government has a major problem with presentation. This was a little ironic given the immense amount of effort which the present Government has put into presentation.

The very fact that a senior Minister should say such a thing does not, at first look, fit easily with polling returns that show record popularity for a government at this stage in the political cycle. To understand the Minister's concerns, it is necessary to recognise that politicians do not address one audience, but a whole series of them, most of which have differing expectations of the government of the day. Not for nothing is politics defined as the art of the possible.

What the Minister was perhaps unconsciously saying was that there is a problem for the Government in addressing its core vote and its own party activists. Recent reports suggest that Millbank is anticipating major losses in the forthcoming local elections, although there have been immediate rebuttals of the leaked information. Nevertheless, given the high point in local election success in 1996, it would be astonishing if Labour did not lose seats this time around, regardless of the Government's poll standing.

Yet there are other signs that all is not well within the Labour family. Apparently, about a third of Labour constituency parties have not bothered to nominate a delegate to the annual jamboree known as the Labour Party conference. Traditionally, this has been a high point in the calendar for Labour Party activists, often with fierce competition for delegate places. Indifference to it is sure sign of trouble at t'mill.

The anecdotal evidence within the Parliamentary Labour Party is of a disjunction between activists and the Government. The reasons for this remain clouded in mystery for many MPs, who are rightly focused on government successes. Is the aforementioned Minister right? Is it merely a presentational problem with one of a number of target audiences?

We have to first look at that audience, a wide spectrum of people, both geographically and socially. Their common link is the Labour Party and its values, particularly its commitment to social justice. The link between them was reinforced by 18 long years in opposition, fighting the repugnant tenets of Thatcherism. Their high hopes in May 1997 were based upon a profound sense of optimism, hence, the resonance of 'Things Can Only Get Better' as a campaign song.

While a minority still hankered for 'The Internationale' or 'Jerusalem', the modernity of the campaign tune reflected the acceptance of the need for modernisation - of the Labour Party, the constitution, the Government, the country. The huge enthusiasm of that spring paralleled that of Prague in 1968. Why, then, is there now, three short years later, a sense of unease among many Labour supporters?

Part of the answer lies with people's own experience on the ground. They tend to judge a government's performance not by inputs, no matter how impressive, but by outcomes. Their experience is reflected in the findings of the Office of National Statistics, which reports an increasing gap between rich and poor. In many parts of the country, they recognise the conclusion last week of the economic consultancy, Business Strategies, that the North-South divide is getting worse.

An issue for Labour Party activists is a feeling of irrelevance in the overall scheme of things. It is this sense of alienation which has led to the less than enthusiastic take-up of conference seats. It emanates in part from a perception of an increasingly centralised party structure, a suspicion of an emasculated conference and a belief that we are heading towards a happy-clappy, American-style form of politics. This is anathema to activists although it may be attractive to some newer members who see 1997 as Year Zero.

It is a perplexing situation. It may be that current party strategists are right, believing this to be a period of metamorphosis into an as yet ideologically undefined new political entity. For a governing party, however, it is a particularly dangerous conundrum.

For those same strategists have a very simple strategy. They have adopted clothes and language consonant with those whose votes gave us the Thatcher-Major years. They have asserted repeatedly that our core supporters would stay with the Labour Government simply because they had no other political home to go to. They argue in party councils that the result in 1997 confirmed their thesis. They had based their original views on Clinton's break from traditional party parameters in the presidential campaign of 1992.

However, time has moved on in America and the United Kingdom. There is also another polity closer to ours whose experience merits examination. In the early Nineties, the Australian Labour Party started to suffer from the attrition of their core supporters. Where did they go? They stayed at home. A conversation last week with Australian politician Wayne Swan indicated that 'things have moved on'. Many stay-at-homes now do turn out to vote - for the xenophobic extremism of Pauline Hanson.

For both party and governmental reasons, it is essential that such a tendency should not develop here. A government at odds with its party activists is in danger of denying itself the many thousands of personal networks which those activists represent and use at election periods. A sensible approach is to ensure - in word and deed - that both activists and core voters feel wanted by the Government. The worst of all worlds is for these lay audiences to believe that they are being taken for granted.

It is not as if the Government is imperilled at the next election. It is the longer term effect on morale in the party and support on the street. Right now, Members of Parliament with relatively low majorities raise their eyes fearfully to the looming general election. They were given a salutary reminder of the swings and roundabouts of representative politics by the Prime Minister's recent comment on his anticipation of lost seats at the next general election. More than any others, such MPs in marginal seats will examine their local election results like an ancient diviner rummaging through the entrails of a chicken.

The real challenge for the Government is already being recognised as the general election after next. There will be no credibility in blaming previous Tory governments for difficulties. There will have been a referendum on the euro. There will, barring miracles, be a decreased majority with more Labour members fearing a twist of the electoral cycle against them. And, of course, in Harold Macmillan's words, there will be 'events, dear boy, events'.

It will require a hugely co-ordinated and disciplined effort to take the Labour Government through its second term. It will require committed activists and a resolute core support in the country. These not only provide the spine of campaigning, and a platform for electoral success, but give resolution to MPs who might waver under pressure.

I suspect it will take more than presentational changes to keep them reassured - and they need reassuring now.

 Peter Kilfoyle is Labour MP for Liverpool, Walton, and was Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Defence until his resignation from the Government in January this year to rally the party's traditional voters. Andrew Rawnsley is on holiday

fields.headline: Why breast is best
fields.standfirst: Why is a woman making life so hard for breast-feeding MPs?  Pamela Armstrong argues they should be encouraged, not told to stop
fields.trailText: Why is a woman making life so hard for breast-feeding MPs?  Pamela Armstrong argues they should be encouraged, not told to stop
fields.body:
We don't know if Betty Boothroyd has ever breast-fed a child. Public record would have us assume she has not. But you can't be too careful. As Commons Speaker we do know that she has just banned breast-feeding from committee rooms and the public gallery in the Houses of Parliament. The Commons chamber itself is already a no-go zone. Maybe such an anti-baby measure can only come from someone who has had nothing to do with them.

Breast-feeding is such a touchy subject. Just as paternity leave is an issue with a bit more bite within those hallowed walls at the moment, so now is breast-feeding. Boothroyd is wrong to ban nursing mothers. A number of MPs, some of them women, have new-born babies to deal with. Some of those nursing MPs are on committees and need to be present in committee rooms. But as Swindon MP Julia Down, who had a baby five months ago, says: 'No one wants people to be disturbed, but babies are quiet when they are being breast-fed. The general rule should be, if it does not disturb anyone it should be allowed.'

Most women in this country don't breast-feed. Even if they do it is for a very short time compared to those in other countries. Those of us who do breast-feed our kids don't need bans in the working place to make it even harder than it already is.

I've written the phrase 'those of us who breast-feed our kids' literally. I breast-fed my kid for four and a half years. Though, of course, when they get that big you don't admit it at the time for fear the Social will have them off you. Especially as in my case it was a boy.

There are hazards. When he developed teeth he did bite. It was only the once because much to my amazed surprise an entirely involuntary left hook caught him on the chin as soon as his savage molars closed around my ripped flesh. Before I knew it, the blow travelled at huge speed in one flowing motion from my shoulder through my arm and down to my fist. He never did it again.

Don't be fooled into thinking breast-feeding is easy or fun. If it were it would be illegal. Mother and child are not enrapt in a continuously glorious and blissfully sensuous haze of mum and babe exclusivity. Long-term breast-feeding with an older child is a mixed bag. Sometimes they nuzzle. Other times it's a 'hit and run', a quick snack in transit as they dash past. It's a bit like standing close to the edge of the platform at Crewe train station when the InterCities fly through. Twenty seconds a breast max. Bah, boom and off.

There is a lot about breast-feeding that is a drag. Not least the fact that it is an issue which divides women against themselves. When I first outed myself as a long-term breast-feeder my post-bag exploded with the velocity of a storm in a D-cup.

'Weird!' they said. 'Completely bizarre.' 'Psychologically disturbed.' And those were the compliments.

The hallowed image of the Madonna feeding her new-born is OK. But there is a line that is crossed as the child gets older. It was a divide I never really got a handle on. For most people it seems to be when a toddler walks up to its mum, heaves up her T-shirt and latches on without concern for decorum or convention. I'm small and my boy is tall. I think we started seriously raising eyebrows when, still breast-feeding, he grew high enough to reach my rib cage.

There were times when keeping the breast-feeding going was tough. I'm a freelance with an erratic schedule. I travel all over the country. An average day might see me catching the 6.40am flight from Heathrow to Glasgow. So dawn would find me marching on to the plane overnight bag over one shoulder, suit-holder over the other and baby strapped on front.

I was cavalier about who I left him with. (Psychiatrists who complain about over attachment and an inability to separate out might like to explore that.) I would often be working in hotel complexes and would simply book one of their babysitters over the phone, never knowing who they were in advance.

After I'd dumped him I'd go off and do my filming or give my speech or chair a conference or whatever. When I had a break, I'd race back down the hotel's corridors to our room, ripping open my blouse as I went and whacking him on for a top-up. After a quick zap I'd race back down the corridors doing up the buttons as I ran.

It was chaotic and muddled. When he got too big to travel I started breast pumping. That's when you develop a more intimate relationship with your pump that you do with your partner. Which brings us to the milk itself. People find it kind of yucky. I would go off to work leaving precious plastic bags full of the stuff. They're cute little see through sachets full of pale liquid with all the cream risen to the top a bit like gold top.

But we also kept bought baby formula in the house for emergencies. Curiously these would always be used rather than my carefully harvested milk. I never pushed it. It's one of the most benign body secretions, but it is still a secretion. People, other people, can't seem to handle it. In the end I had a freezer full of the stuff. It got chucked.

I heard of one new mum who went back to work soon after the birth. She sensed unease about her breast-pumping. But she kept going by carefully storing her milk in an anonymous looking closed box in the office fridge. Someone stole it.

The challenge when you are away from a baby is to stimulate the breasts so that the milk keeps flowing. In the end I got tired of carting the machine around so I pumped and squeezed my breasts by hand. It is much like milking a cow and it nails penis envy on the head. I could shoot my milk a good five feet. It had the arc of a diver: Five glorious spurting feet of unadulterated pure honeyed nectar.

The issue in Parliament has been finessed. What they have actually banned is all 'refreshments'. Of course they would turn their noses up at someone dripping hot greasy cheeseburgers on the carpet while they're chowing down on the chips. But to conflate breast-feeding with the above is disingenuous. A discreet shawl is all you need. I inadvertently breast-fed on live television once. I didn't know they were about to cut to me. Nobody took a blind bit of notice because nobody saw anything except a mum with heavily swaddled babe.

It is a painful irony that it is a woman who is making life harder for breast-feeding women in Parliament. That pain is compounded by the fact that Boothroyd is bearing down so heavily on one of the most female of human activities. Is it really necessary for someone to have had a child and breast-fed before they themselves are prepared to create a welcoming environment for other mothers of new-born babes. Do we have to wait till such a woman is made a Commons Speaker perhaps sometime in the twenty-second century?

Breast-feeding is novel in this country and carries much negative social freight, but Parliament can withstand the supposed affront to its august authority. It is big enough to take it.
