Just as paternity leave is an issue with a bit more bite within those hallowed walls at the moment, so now is breast-feeding. Boothroyd is wrong to ban nursing mothers. A number of MPs, some of them women, have new-born babies to deal with. Some of those nursing MPs are on committees and need to be present in committee rooms. But as Swindon MP Julia Down, who had a baby five months ago, says: 'No one wants people to be disturbed, but babies are quiet when they are being breast-fed. The general rule should be, if it does not disturb anyone it should be allowed.' Most women in this country don't breast-feed. Even if they do it is for a very short time compared to those in other countries. Those of us who do breast-feed our kids don't need bans in the working place to make it even harder than it already is. I've written the phrase 'those of us who breast-feed our kids' literally. I breast-fed my kid for four and a half years. Though, of course, when they get that big you don't admit it at the time for fear the Social will have them off you. Especially as in my case it was a boy. There are hazards. When he developed teeth he did bite. It was only the once because much to my amazed surprise an entirely involuntary left hook caught him on the chin as soon as his savage molars closed around my ripped flesh. Before I knew it, the blow travelled at huge speed in one flowing motion from my shoulder through my arm and down to my fist. He never did it again. Don't be fooled into thinking breast-feeding is easy or fun. If it were it would be illegal. Mother and child are not enrapt in a continuously glorious and blissfully sensuous haze of mum and babe exclusivity. Long-term breast-feeding with an older child is a mixed bag. Sometimes they nuzzle. Other times it's a 'hit and run', a quick snack in transit as they dash past. It's a bit like standing close to the edge of the platform at Crewe train station when the InterCities fly through. Twenty seconds a breast max. Bah, boom and off. There is a lot about breast-feeding that is a drag. Not least the fact that it is an issue which divides women against themselves. When I first outed myself as a long-term breast-feeder my post-bag exploded with the velocity of a storm in a D-cup. 'Weird!' they said. 'Completely bizarre.' 'Psychologically disturbed.' And those were the compliments. The hallowed image of the Madonna feeding her new-born is OK. But there is a line that is crossed as the child gets older. It was a divide I never really got a handle on. For most people it seems to be when a toddler walks up to its mum, heaves up her T-shirt and latches on without concern for decorum or convention. I'm small and my boy is tall. I think we started seriously raising eyebrows when, still breast-feeding, he grew high enough to reach my rib cage. There were times when keeping the breast-feeding going was tough. I'm a freelance with an erratic schedule. I travel all over the country. An average day might see me catching the 6.40am flight from Heathrow to Glasgow. So dawn would find me marching on to the plane overnight bag over one shoulder, suit-holder over the other and baby strapped on front. I was cavalier about who I left him with. (Psychiatrists who complain about over attachment and an inability to separate out might like to explore that.) I would often be working in hotel complexes and would simply book one of their babysitters over the phone, never knowing who they were in advance. After I'd dumped him I'd go off and do my filming or give my speech or chair a conference or whatever. When I had a break, I'd race back down the hotel's corridors to our room, ripping open my blouse as I went and whacking him on for a top-up. After a quick zap I'd race back down the corridors doing up the buttons as I ran. It was chaotic and muddled. When he got too big to travel I started breast pumping. That's when you develop a more intimate relationship with your pump that you do with your partner. Which brings us to the milk itself. People find it kind of yucky. I would go off to work leaving precious plastic bags full of the stuff. They're cute little see through sachets full of pale liquid with all the cream risen to the top a bit like gold top. But we also kept bought baby formula in the house for emergencies. Curiously these would always be used rather than my carefully harvested milk. I never pushed it. It's one of the most benign body secretions, but it is still a secretion. People, other people, can't seem to handle it. In the end I had a freezer full of the stuff. It got chucked. I heard of one new mum who went back to work soon after the birth. She sensed unease about her breast-pumping. But she kept going by carefully storing her milk in an anonymous looking closed box in the office fridge. Someone stole it. The challenge when you are away from a baby is to stimulate the breasts so that the milk keeps flowing. In the end I got tired of carting the machine around so I pumped and squeezed my breasts by hand. It is much like milking a cow and it nails penis envy on the head. I could shoot my milk a good five feet. It had the arc of a diver: Five glorious spurting feet of unadulterated pure honeyed nectar. The issue in Parliament has been finessed. What they have actually banned is all 'refreshments'. Of course they would turn their noses up at someone dripping hot greasy cheeseburgers on the carpet while they're chowing down on the chips. But to conflate breast-feeding with the above is disingenuous. A discreet shawl is all you need. I inadvertently breast-fed on live television once. I didn't know they were about to cut to me. Nobody took a blind bit of notice because nobody saw anything except a mum with heavily swaddled babe. It is a painful irony that it is a woman who is making life harder for breast-feeding women in Parliament. That pain is compounded by the fact that Boothroyd is bearing down so heavily on one of the most female of human activities. Is it really necessary for someone to have had a child and breast-fed before they themselves are prepared to create a welcoming environment for other mothers of new-born babes. Do we have to wait till such a woman is made a Commons Speaker perhaps sometime in the twenty-second century? Breast-feeding is novel in this country and carries much negative social freight, but Parliament can withstand the supposed affront to its august authority. It is big enough to take it.

fields.headline: The lying game
fields.standfirst:
Don't write off David Irving just yet - he's seen this all before
The David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: Don't write off David Irving just yet - he's seen this all before
fields.body:
After a lengthy High Court libel action culminating in a massive five-figure award of damages, the judge made a devastating attack on the historian David Irving, whom he described as 'a slippery and fly character'. In spite of everything, Irving announced his intention of lodging an appeal.

That was 30 years ago when Irving was found to have libelled Captain John Broome RN in his book The Destruction of Convoy PQ 17 . Anyone like myself who remembers not only that action but other similar episodes - such as that surrounding General Sikorski (when Irving helped to promote the absurd idea that Winston Churchill had ordered the murder of the Polish wartime leader), or the Hitler diaries (revealed by Irving in quick succession to be fake and then genuine) - must find it strange that Irving is still considered to be a man with a reputation to lose.

'Journalists are supposed to be slapdash,' wrote the late A.J.P. Taylor, 'academics to be cautious scholars. I do not think this distinction has any validation.' Even in these degenerate days I doubt very much with a record like his whether any newspaper editor would touch David Irving with a bargepole. For a start, the risk of expensive libel damages would deter them.

Fellow historians, however, are even now, after all that has happened, still prepared to put in a good word for him. Sir John Keegan, the Daily Telegraph 's military historian, seemed to value Irving higher than his victorious opponent in the recent libel action, Professor Deborah Lipstadt. Lipstadt was boring but Irving, he wrote, 'has many of the qualities of the most creative historians'. He 'still has much that is interesting to tell us'. Professor D.C. Watt seemed to think Irving had somehow done us all a good turn by questioning the reality of the Holocaust. 'The truth,' he concluded mysteriously, 'needs an Irving's challenges to keep it alive.'

In the light of such tributes, anyone who naively thinks that David Irving has somehow been finished off by last week's libel verdict should think again. Journalists may damn him but the professors, the so called 'experts', will help to keep the flame burning. We need a liar, it seems, to help to lead us to the truth.

Greedy bankers

Along with most business operators, the Government has discovered how much money you can save by paying or charging people directly via their bank accounts.

I predict that sooner or later we will be told that we have to pay more for, say, our annual TV licence, if we refuse to pay by direct debit and insist on sending an old-fashioned cheque.

Meanwhile, small post offices are in a state of crisis because the Government want to stop them paying out cash benefits to pensioners and others because, they say, it will be easier and cheaper to pay them directly into their bank accounts.

The trouble with this argument is that it coincides with the news that Barclays Bank, for one, is busy closing down its branches all over the country, leaving people, espe cially in rural areas, without any kind of banking facility. So the real possibility exists that many of these people will eventually be left with neither post office nor bank.

It is pointless for critics to rail against Barclays Bank for their anti-social behaviour, as if bankers had some kind of obligation to the community as a whole. The object of banks is to enrich themselves by whatever means possible - and to hell with the well-being of the punters.

In the old days when greedy capitalists failed to provide for the needs of the public, the Government would be urged to step in and do something about it by, for example, providing its own bank or at least allowing the Post Office to expand its operation to include banking. Such a solution, however, would smack of socialism - and we don't want anything like that again, do we?

Funny old world

When I had to launch the Oldie magazine some years ago, I remember being interviewed by Canadian television about my attitude to old people and what we termed the youth culture. Afterwards the interviewer told me that I wouldn't be able to talk gaily, as I had done, about oldies if I had been in Canada. Old was now considered to be a dirty word there, like blind or fat. The old folks were nowadays referred to in public as 'mature Canadians'.

It is a general rule that any ludicrous idea thought up by Americans (or Canadians for that matter) sooner or later will be adopted on this side of the Atlantic.

We are not yet faced with a Fattist Rights movement but that may only be because we don't have anything like the number of serious fatties that they have in America.

With oldies, however, changes are already afoot. Mr Alistair Darling is about to be appointed by Mr Blair as a Minister for the over-50s and it has simultaneously been reported that civil servants are even now trying to 'rebrand' the old with a new name that will appeal to younger people. Outsiders too have been invited to come up with suggestions.

But the Government, of all people, ought to know that you cannot alter the public's perceptions just by changing a name. If the youth despise the oldies they will go on despising them even if they are taught to call them senior citizens or 'mature English persons.'

Some time ago, faced with the bad image of Windscale, the nuclear re-processing plant in Cumbria, they changed its name to Sellafield and hoped that no-one would notice. But now Sellafield is just as dirty a word as Windscale ever was.

webTitle: I've seen the light - and it's global interactive TV

fields.headline: I've seen the light - and it's global interactive TV
fields.standfirst: Richard Li wants to turn couch potatoes into Net heads. But will they agree to play?
fields.trailText: Richard Li wants to turn couch potatoes into Net heads. But will they agree to play?
fields.body:
In the middle of a business park near Chiswick, west London, amid a welter of construction work, an idea is taking shape.

The idea is based on a plan to force a head-on collision between the worlds of television and the Internet: combining the wide appeal of the former and the interactive draw of the latter. Employees at the firm behind the plan, a little known company called Network of the World (NOW), believe the impact will change the way the media works, transforming the way the media tells its 'stories'.

At the heart of the idea is the belief that the mass media is dying: new technology is allowing individuals to personalise what they watch and how they access it. And, as individuals become empowered, they want to control their media rather than digest it passively. The consequence is that audiences start to splinter into groups around shared interests.

This is the theory promoted by Pacific Century CyberWorks (PCCW), the new media business run by Richard Li, which intends to turn its NOW subsidiary into a global media player. A few months ago not that many people outside the Pacific Rim knew much about Li, other than that he was the son of Li Ka-shing, Hong Kong's richest man.

But since the start of the year PCCW has burst on to the global stage, pulling off an audacious coup which should see it acquire Cable & Wireless's 54 per cent stake in Hong Kong Telecom. Alliances with the likes of Internet investment fund CMGi and last week's deal with Australian telecoms carrier, Telstra, reinforce the impression that Li is in no mood to slow down.

Li is refocusing PCCW from being a telecoms equipment firm into a pure Internet player. The company's re-orientation, not to mention its unique plans for reformatting television, are Li's personal vision. 'The Internet is a world that Richard totally understands and is part of. He has a different focus from his father,' said Michael Johnson, Li's senior adviser charged with getting the project up and running by June.

This will be no small feat. The company wants to recruit 1,500 people. It is also rushing to finish the construction of its HQ, complete with a state-of-the art broadcasting studio, digital library and production suites. NOW's real challenge is technological. It needs to ensure its Internet arm meshes with its television offering. The plan is to start with a single television channel, which will later split into several channels. But each programme will have its own Internet links.

So a viewer will be watching a television programme and will then be able to click on a link and, say, discuss what they had seen or download information. NOW has a team of 200 producers who will generate four hours of live online content seven days a week. It seems this integrated idea was partially inspired by the situation in the US where Internet users often surf on their PCs while watching television.

NOW wants to go further than creating an integrated television/Internet offering. Users who access the Network of the World will be able to build their own web-sites so that every TV programme spawns fans who create their own content.

'Up until the 1980s, TV was so powerful that it had to be controlled by government. The idea of allowing people to generate and become a part of the mass media is principally taking place in the web. This is the democratisation of the mass media realm, you should be able to create content no matter who you are. It's all about engaging people in the stories,' Johnson said.

As telecom networks develop and become able to carry heavier traffic, including video data, users will be able to make their own broadcasts which can be linked to NOW's broadcasts, thus expanding its reach ever further. And, because content on the web is never destroyed, users will be able to pick it up and re-package it, becoming their own producers.

'As you increase the bandwidth you're changing the story. When you make that story bi-directional that's a big change. We used to need presenters to explain things to us, today people want to do things for themselves,' Johnson said.

'It reflects people's desire to find their niche. It's about lining up smaller and smaller communities,' he said.

And, of course, the more audiences are segmented the easier they are to profile - vital for advertisers who are looking to reach specific audiences and are becoming increasingly lost in the infinite mass of the Internet. It is an old approach - copying the way the magazine market segments readers around interests - albeit using some very clever technology.

Such innovation does not come cheap. PCCW, which has a market value of more than $30 billion, declines to say how much money is being invested in the project, but Johnson admits it amounts to 'hundreds of millions of dollars'. The initial plan is to focus on the Asian market where NOW will be broadcast to 63 countries with a combined potential audience of 135 million households. Europe will be targeted later.

But despite NOW's attempts at technological innovation and its claims about the death of the mass market, the company is not reluctant to rely on a decidedly old fashioned, not to say populist way of introducing itself to the world. In the same way that BSkyB used sport to draw in the viewers, NOW is keen to buy up rights to live events. It has the broadcasting rights to Indian cricket matches and is rumoured to be looking at Internet rights to the Wimbledon tennis tournament and considering a similar deal with football's Premier League clubs.

The fact that PCCW's main partner in NOW is the world's largest sports marketing firm suggests its plans have substance. PCCW's partnership with TWI, the broadcasting arm of International Management Group, gives it access to more than 130,000 hours of sports programming. IMG is also a leading adviser on Internet rights to many of the world's top teams which means its insights will be invaluable if PCCW goes shopping for content. In addition to its sports arm, NOW will also roll out channels devoted to technology, money and lifestyle.

As new technology improves online broadcasting over the next five years, PCCW's self-confessed attempts to become the 'largest broadband Internet business in the world' become more understandable. Such grandiose claims help explain why the fledgling company is valued so highly: they also raise concerns about what would happen if the recent slide in Internet stocks turned into a slump.

Given Li's financial fire-power (backers include chip giant Intel) - not to mention his family contacts in Asian and Far Eastern business communities - other media firms which had ignored PCCW now have to start taking it seriously. Rupert Murdoch realised this earlier this year when he backed a rival bid for Hong Kong Telecom, in an attempt to thwart Li's expansion plans.

Li realised the cash to create PCCW by selling Star TV, the first pan-Asian satellite television network, to Murdoch's News Corp in 1993. Just how much Murdoch comes to regret the sale depends on how powerfully Li's interpretation for the future of broadcasting pans out.

Whether viewers of the future will want to play such an active role in the way they consume their media is a big question. After all, couch potatoes may not be so amenable to two-way telly.

webTitle: When the magic starts to wear off

fields.headline: When the magic starts to wear off
fields.standfirst: As expansionist euphoria falters, the IMF and US Treasury sound alarm bells, writes  William Keegan
fields.trailText: As expansionist euphoria falters, the IMF and US Treasury sound alarm bells, writes William Keegan
fields.body:
Gordon Brown may have declined the opportunity to become managing director of the International Monetary Fund, but today, with the markets in turmoil, he is due to chair its policy-making committee, the International Monetary and Financial Committee (IMFC).

As the IMF's acting managing director, Stanley Fischer, joked this month: 'This is the successor to the Interim Committee, which managed to be an interim committee for 25 years but finally expired last September'.

Some Whitehall insiders think it was somewhat unsporting of the Chancellor not to nominate another Briton for the managing directorship - we backed the German official Horst Kohler instead - but the chairmanship of the heavily political committee we now know as the IMFC, once held by rotation on an annual basis, has itself acquired an 'interim' character. 'Who knows,' said one IMF official, 'Gordon could be the IMFC chairman indefinitely. He may get the best of both worlds.'

The run-up to today's meeting has been awkward for Brown, partly because as a champion of debt relief for the Third World, he finds it unfortunate that there are so many demonstrators who have moved on from Seattle to the streets of Washington to continue their protests against bodies such as the World Trade Organisation (WTO), World Bank and IMF.

But there has also been the little local difficulty that the latest issue of the IMF's World Economic Outlook has taken the Chancellor to task over his recent Budget. Referring to UK interest rates last week, the IMF said: 'Further upward adjustments may be needed to contain inflationary pressures. It is important for fiscal policy not to add to these pressures. In this regard, the recently announced Budget for 2000/2001 appears to be regrettably pro-cyclical.'

By pro-cyclical the IMF means the Budget is adding to upward pressures on demand in the economy, and making the task of the Bank of England's monetary policy comittee (MPC) that much more difficult.

This is an embarrassment to Gordon Brown, because the Treasury has gone out of its way to try to deflect City criticism that the Budget was unnecessarily expansionary, and marks a return, via higher public spending, to the 'bad old days' of Old Labour.

From having been eager to highlight previous IMF comments on the UK, the Treasury has been reduced, rather unconvincingly, to maintaining that this is only - well, the vogue word is an 'interim' judgment. But the IMF has had plenty of time to digest the Budget. This is its considered view.

One might have thought, from some of the headlines last week, that it was the IMF's only view. In fact, its World Economic Outlook (WEO) contains disturbing analysis of how things could go badly wrong in a world economy officially expanding nicely, with growth forecast to accelerate this year in most industrial nations.

The IMF stresses how difficult it is to forecast turning points. However, one for the world economy could be that outlined by the WEO in its 'alternative scenario' to the continuation, indeed acceleration, of growth rates in the US and Europe. Under this scenario, the US euphoric boom continues for the first half of this year, then there is an explosion: suddenly there is panic about inflation, Wall Street falls by 25 per cent, capital flows out of the US, and the dollar falls by 20 per cent.This already looks less 'alternative'.

'The main concern about the outlook,' says the Fund, 'stems from a series of economic and financial imbalances that have been building up for several years, including the lopsided pattern of growth among the principal currency areas and the resulting increase in external imbalances, with the US [balance of payments] current account in record deficit.'

The growth of consumer demand in the US has been even more formidable than the record expansion of output; the US is borrowing some $1bn a day from the rest of the world to finance its insatiable appetite for imports.

Thus, the US has been acting as a locomotive for the rest of the world economy. This has not only assisted the recovery of East Asia from the 1997-98 financial crisis; it has also, along with the decline in the value of the euro, contributed handsomely to the recent European economic recovery, via higher exports by Germany and others to the US.

A rise in the euro, caused either by the above scenario of a Wall Street collapse and a decline in the dollar, or by a change in forex market sentiment, could slow down the eurozone economic recovery. Output is still rising at less than potential in the key continental economies. And a recent report by the IMF executive board stated that there was 'no pressing need for an increase in interest rates in the near future, in the light of the remaining slack in labour and product markets'.

This is a far cry from the usual declarations that the high unemployment in Europe is 'structural'. The WEO warns the European Central Bank that 'it is important currently to avoid holding back the ongoing recovery through a rapid tightening of policy'. A senior IMF official, Jacques Artus, has complained that 'the recent increase in [ECB] interest rates came a little bit early'. This contrasts with the IMF's advice in favour of higher interest rates in the UK, and 'a more significant tightening of monetary con ditions in the US' (that is, over and above rises of up to 0.75 per cent already expected in the market).

US Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers makes no bones about the unsustainability of the US boom and the implications for a Europe that may be a little too complacent at present.

Last week he said: 'While it accounts for less than half of the G7's total GDP in the past three years, the US has accounted for more than three-quarters of the growth in the G7's real demand. On current forecasts, the US will still account for about two-thirds of real demand growth within the G7 this year.'

Summers described global imbalances as 'a matter of concern' and urged European leaders to make contingency plans. 'The right kind of macro-economic environ ment will be crucial if growth is to come through rapid investment rather than export growth, as has too often been the case in the past,' he said. Again, parting from the conventional view that Europe's problems are largely structural, he warned: 'Macro-economic policy will need to promote a domestic-demand-led expansion and to accommodate the increased potential for growth that more decisive structural reforms would promote.'

Behind the warnings being made by the IMF and US Treasury lie fears of a renewed outbreak of protectionism in the US if the boom turns sour. Even at the peak of this record burst of US economic expansion, protectionist fears are never far below the surface - witness some of the Seattle-Washington anti-globalisation demonstrators.

While putting in the usual plug for the wonders of globalisation, the IMF acknowledges that the process claims victims, but puts this down to 'policy shortcomings' in the afflicted countries.

As if to warn the protesters, the IMF declares that, despite the disruption caused by highly mobile international capital flows, 'retreat from globalisation is no solution, as shown by inter-war experience, which led to a prolonged disruption in international trade, capital movements and technology diffusion,with detrimental effects for output growth in poor and rich countries alike'.

Just to ram the message home, it reminds us that between January 1929 and February 1933, the imports of 75 countries 'contracted by 69 per cent'. The spectre of the Great Depression still looms.

webTitle: A fashion reshuffle that already looks threadbare are

fields.headline: A fashion reshuffle that already looks threadbare are
fields.trailText: Had your fill of the technology rollercoaster? Then why not take your seats for a round of BrandMAX - as Arcadia's latest review is called. The rules are straightforward. You simply take a deck of high-street shops, shuffle them thoroughly, drop about a quarter of them on the floor, then spread the rest out wherever they look as if they might fit. Oh and don't expect to win: if BrandMAX is anything like all the variations which have been played out on Britain's high streets over the last decade, there will be only losers.
fields.body:
Had your fill of the technology rollercoaster? Then why not take your seats for a round of BrandMAX - as Arcadia's latest review is called. The rules are straightforward. You simply take a deck of high-street shops, shuffle them thoroughly, drop about a quarter of them on the floor, then spread the rest out wherever they look as if they might fit. Oh and don't expect to win: if BrandMAX is anything like all the variations which have been played out on Britain's high streets over the last decade, there will be only losers.

Arcadia, the BrandMAX croupier, is an old hand at such games, having entertained the City with them regularly, both before and after its divorce from the Debenhams department store.

This time round, however, the stakes are much higher as it has spent £151 million adding the three suits in the Sears pack - Wallis, Warehouse and Miss Selfridge - to its hand.

Those without the right spirit of adventure questioned the wisdom of this, given Arcadia's difficulty in making sure that all its suits - including such fashion essentials as Top Shop, Dorothy Perkins and Evans - were playing the same game.

It looked particularly brave when even players with a consistently good record like Marks & Spencer were failing to come up with a winning strategy. The result is en-tirely according to form. It has found itself with too many shops, most of them in the wrong place, and too few shoppers. The complicated matrix of openings, closings and relocations which BrandMAX involves will be all too familiar to anyone with shares in Arcadia.

In summary, 654 of its 2,187 stores will be closed, including all of its Principles men's and womenswear chains, and 300 will be opened. It is not as simple as that, of course. Among the rest, some brands will be moved into different stores, some brands will be combined in one outlet and some will be reopened as concessions in someone else's stores.

The reshuffling is costing £90 million, including £30 million in cash to be spent on things like sacking 3,500 people and paying rents on shops it no longer wants. That is high for a company which has already had to beg its bankers for more time to pay off its debts. Those bankers can only hope that its estimates are accurate and that the £160 million annual savings promised by August 2002 do actually materialise.

Finding new tenants for that number of stores would be challenging, even in a buoyant high street. Even if it succeeds, there must be a question mark over how much of those cost-savings will be passed back into profits, given the relentless pressure on high-street prices. Just look at the collapse in Arcadia's operating margin from 3.8 to 0.1 per cent in the six months to 26 February.

The fact is that the high street is crowded with clothing stores offering things no one wants to buy. Arcadia is at least addressing that problem, but the risk is that its action will be too little, too late. Leave the shares on the shelf along with the clothes.

Gizmo wizards

We all know that the likes of Vodafone and Nokia are benefiting from our obsession with talking to each other while on the bus, the street or at the local restaurant. A less publicised beneficiary is Pressac, a small electronics company which is transferring its skills in producing switches and other electronic bits from car dashboards into making keypads for those irritating little handsets.

It has become an instant success. Two years ago it was just looking at the market. Now, the big three handset suppliers - Nokia, Ericsson and Motorola - are among its customers and it estimates it has about 10 per cent of the market.

Demand for mobile phones is rising by 35 per cent a year and - the industry hopes - WAP technology and other such gizmos mean that rate of growth will continue for a few more years.

Pressac's order book has almost doubled from £30 million to £55m in six months, and chief executive Geoff White thinks its superior technology means it should win more market share. It is investing £20m over three years to build a dedicated manufacturing base for the keypads. Despite its early stage of development, and the investment needed to grow the business, it is already making profits: £2.9m in the six months to end-January, double that achieved last time, on sales up 40 per cent to £20.3m.

Pressac's automotive business is also doing well, benefiting from the growing use of electronic components in cars which is cushioning it from the effects of over-capacity and sluggish demand.

Overall, pre-tax profits from continuing businesses, before exceptionals, rose almost 30 per cent and analysts expect a strong second half too. Yet the shares trade on around 15 times earnings - cheap for a company with such good growth prospects. Buy.

Okay to indulge

The team of young managers sent off on Unilever's foresight programme to find out what its customers want apparently came up with a rather odd finding: we want to get thinner and fitter but we want to indulge ourselves as well.

Ever responsive to our needs, Unilever is to help us do just that with the acquisition of Slim-Fast, America's largest maker of replacement meals and 'slimming' bars, and Ben & Jerry's, the ultimate in indulgence ice creams.

Both are rather unusual moves for a company which has managed to create brands like Magnum, I Can't Believe it's not Butter or Chicken Tonight using only a laboratory and a multi-million marketing budget. Both, however, also make perfect strategic sense.

Slimming products have existed for years in Europe but largely in a niche market of chemist's shops and slimming-clubs.

Backed by Unilever's marketing muscle, there must be at least a fair chance that they can get to the kind of $1.3 billion (£810 million) sales achieved in the US, where the 20 per cent annual sales increases make them one of the fastest-growing food categories.

Ben & Jerry's, too, could benefit from a bit more focused promotion - that should more than make up for losing its socially responsible tag. These deals demonstrate that the pace of change at Unilever is not slowing. Its shares have been weak on investor fears that it had retreated into its conservative shell. That is misguided. Buy.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Tune into Securicor, the doyen of the security sector now making big moves into wireless communications both here and in the US.
fields.body:
Tune into Securicor, the doyen of the security sector now making big moves into wireless communications both here and in the US.

At 126.5p, the shares have slumped sharply of late, hit by a series of earnings downgrades from a number of brokers. Still, they are well ahead of the 106p they were worth after last year's distribution of proceeds from the sale of its Cellnet stake.

And even after the latest reassessment of Securicor's potential, the group is still capable of 30 per cent compound earnings growth, according to the latest research note from broker Charles Stanley.

The firm's basic business - guarding cash in transit - still offers opportunities for expansion by acquisition. Omega, the distribution operation, has been hit by integration costs following the sale of a half stake to Deutsche Post, but should now perform better.

The communications division, meanwhile, is still loss-making, but should turn a profit next year and become the main driver for growth.

Buy on fundamentals and takeover potential.

Predators in the stack

TBI, the regional airport operator, is hardly a recommendation we can crow about. If you bought the shares at 96p when we last looked at them at the end of 1998, you'll be nursing losses of nearly 50 per cent following last month's profit warning.

But hang on in there. Irish entrepreneur Dermot Desmond has snapped up a 3.7 per cent stake - and he may not be the only predator circling the group.

Operating profits this year are now expected to come in at around £22 million, a full 20 per cent less than analysts had been expecting. Poor trading at Luton, Stockholm and Orlando airports has caused the blip, but the firm expects to be back on track next year. Well, of course, it would, wouldn't it. But even for sceptics, at 54p, the shares are trading at below asset value and offer a reasonable yield. Hold on.

Mind the gap

All eyes in the European insurance market may now be on Allianz, the dominant German player and prime loser from the collapse of Deutsche and Dresdner Bank's grand merger. That embarrassing failure notwithstanding, however, at some 20 times earnings, Allianz' shares are still trading on nearly twice the rating of Allied Zurich, its closest European peer within the FTSE-100 index.

That valuation gap is, says broker Salomon Smith Barney, simply too wide. Formed from the merger of BAT's old insurance arm with a Swiss rival, shares in the group have already recovered strongly this year. But the undervaluation gives scope for strong recovery over the next 12 to 18 months, Salomon's sector analysts believe.

Salomon's team calculates that Allied Zurich is worth 956p on a sum-of-the-parts basis. Accordingly, it has set a 900p price target over the next year, against the 682p the shares trade at now.

Fixed asset

Prpoperty looks to be one sector which has barely benefited from the switch away from Internet and high-technology stocks to good, old-fashioned firms.

True, there has been a rally in property shares since mid-February. But the sector index is still trading below the level of the beginning of the year. At an average discount to net asset value (NAV) of a third, indeed, property shares can now be bought at prices reminiscent of the recessionary days of the early 1990s.

One quality play surely to watch for recovery is British Land. At 397p, the shares are now changing hands at a whopping 40 per cent discount to NAV, one of the widest variations around.

webTitle: Europe's spinners hit their own wicket

fields.headline: Europe's spinners hit their own wicket
fields.trailText: What would happen if a 'tired and dispirited' Tony Blair, surrounded by Cabinet critics, was said to be 'ready to resign'? Especially if the tale, on examination, was all bunk? Alastair Campbell would get kicked, that's what. So who is Romano Prodi kicking this morning (apart possibly from himself)?
fields.body:
What would happen if a 'tired and dispirited' Tony Blair, surrounded by Cabinet critics, was said to be 'ready to resign'? Especially if the tale, on examination, was all bunk? Alastair Campbell would get kicked, that's what. So who is Romano Prodi kicking this morning (apart possibly from himself)?

British newspaper readers know a great deal about the horrors of Brussels life. Our sceptical press keeps them commodiously informed. And European officialdom is, of course, glumly resentful of such treatment. Geoffrey Martin, the European Commission's representative in London, took time out last week to lash the 'bias, paranoia and jingoistic rubbish' which he thinks habitually disgraces our breakfast tables.

But do the commissioners and spin doctors of the Union ever pause to think how they could help themselves? The dismal fact - seldom reported, let alone analysed - is that today's EU is at least 20 years off the spinning pace. As mighty press machines go, it goes almost nowhere.

President Prodi, more than most, should realise that. He, these past few days, has been your actual Mr Tired and Dispirited in a Der Spiegel story, given extra credibility by Frankfurter Allgemeine . He's had a lousy, chaotic time (gleefully recycled here). Commissioners Kinnock and Patten have, allegedly, been sharpening their knives behind the arras. 'Embattled Prodi may be tempted to quit top job,' said the Times .

In reality, I can unexclusively reveal, Prodi will serve out his full term: and Neil and Chris couldn't be happier. This is a crisis that never was, greatly fanned by inept press relations - particularly a melodramatic emergency meeting of the Commission to express 'full confidence' in its President which even Ron Atkinson would have counselled against.

You can (and probably should) blame Prodi's old Rome amanuensis and current spokesman, Ricardo Levi, for that. He's a personable Italian ex-editor - but he finds the cross-cultures of the job damnably difficult. The posher Italian papers (such as his own L'Independente ) are still natural charters of policy debates, not personality clashes. Levi, after the debacle of the Santer Commission, hasn't caught up with the new personality-centred jour nalism the Germans, Belgians and Brits want - just as Prodi himself, no natural communicator, couldn't coin a soundbite to save his neck.

Yet Levi and Prodi cannot carry every can, as a fascinating editorial in the spring edition of specialist magazine Spokesman makes clear. They at least recognised that something was structurally wrong and aimed to fix it, within weeks of taking office last year, with their '3 June Announcement' - a plan high on 'streamlining and reorganisation'. The President wanted a co-ordinated system with his own chaps at the centre, and the ability to control the previously uncontrollable flow of news.

Some hope! His chosen Commissioners vetoed the plan by 19 votes to one. They, essentially, wanted to keep their individual spokesmen under local (nationally focused) control. They also helped preserve the batty arrangement which makes a distinction between 'news' - which is what the Commission wants you to put on the front page - and 'information', which has its own directorate and Commissioner.

There is, as Spokesman says, no rhyme or reason to this. 'What a journalist, especially a specialist, decides is interesting to his public is seldom what officials think ought to be interesting.' Meanwhile, Commission websites - 70 or more of them - grow like Topsy, seemingly without reference to each other, and all the crucial relationships are misty, going on totally befogged.

How does Information Commissioner Reding from Luxembourg relate to Levi and Jonathan Faul, the British lawyer who's in putative charge of the news operation? Where do the EU representation offices in the 15 member countries fit in? When there's a nasty question from the Daily Telegraph , who clears his throat? How do you cope if a member in Whitehall loses its voice?

Their replacements are young and often bemused by the Byzantine organisation they must interpret. The Commissioners themselves are spread in different buildings across Brussels and meet too rarely. Expect things to get even worse, insiders say, before they get better.

fields.headline: Biotech's gene blueprint
fields.standfirst: Genome science could spell an end to most diseases but only if it's a money spinner.  Oliver Morgan reports
fields.trailText: Genome science could spell an end to most diseases but only if it's a money spinner. Oliver Morgan reports
fields.body:
If you had the misfortune to fall ill in seventeenth-century England, the last thing you would have wanted was a visit from the doctor.

The human body was a mystery as deep as the universe. The suffering patient had to face the quack, who would discern which of four 'humours' was out of balance, before cutting a specific vein, pouring off blood and stitching up the wound.

The great philosopher Thomas Hobbes said he would 'rather have the advice or take physic from an experienced old woman'. Much has changed in the intervening 200 years - from advances in public health to the discovery of penicillin. But in one respect things have stayed the same - medicine works backwards from diagnosis into the still-mysterious human body. The process has been still little more than trial and error.

Now, however, a genuine revolution is under way. The human body is literally being turned inside out. The blueprint of life - made up of pairs of spiral 'barcodes' of DNA 3 billion characters long - is just months if not weeks away from being decoded.

The effect on pharmaceutical development will be revolutionary. Paul Triniman of biotechnology firm Oxford Glycosciences says: 'Until now medicine has been geared to working from the symptoms of diseases and treating these. Now it can make cures from causes.'

Genes create proteins which instruct cells in the body how to act. Most diseases are caused by too many, too few, or malformed proteins being created by cells. Medicines are developed by isolating these cells and 'targeting' them for treatment.

In the 50 years in which modern pharmaceutical research has developed, some 500 'targets' have been painstakingly identified. The unravelled DNA blueprint, or genome, will reveal up to 10,000 new ones.

The hope is that terrible diseases from cancers to heart disease, diabetes, schizophrenia and osteoporosis will be curable by altering genes instead of just suppressing symptoms.

But for the real benefits of the genome to be realised, the promise of science has to meet commercial demands. At one level, the picture seems bright. Big drugs companies which have invested in genomic technology have seen their research efforts accelerate. With the completion of the genome they can effectively go supersonic. SmithKline Beecham (SB) says before it began genomic research in 1993 it would explore six to eight drug targets a year. With genomic research it examines 200.

Drug development is lengthy and costly. It takes some 15 years and $500 million to get an idea to market. Only 10 per cent make it. Genomics can weed out the chaff early, and will also be able to screen patients to detect who will be able to benefit from particular drugs.

Research by Andersen Consulting indicates that new technology will increase the success rate to 30 per cent by 2008, and firms will be able to concentrate on high-revenue treatments. Andersen partner Nick Edwards says: 'The number of treatments coming out of research will increase. In addition, companies will be able to run smaller, more focused clinical trials programmes, and lower their costs dramatically.'

But there are big problems with the relationship between genome science and business. The first is ethical. The race to unravel the genome has caused controversy. Celera, a Maryland-based private company, has vied with the publicly funded European-American collaboration called the Human Genome Project (HGP) to churn through the 3 billion characters and publish the sequence first, for profit.

Some firms have attempted to 'patent' genes, preventing competitors from using them. Tim Hubbard of the Wellcome Trust's Sanger Centre - which is collaborating with the HGP, says: 'It's like fishing with dynamite. You catch a lot of fish, but you destroy the environment for everyone else.'

But the reality is that although patenting actual genes may not be allowed by law, patenting applications derived from them must be. Uncertainty over what can be patented is a problem for the biotech companies.

The genome itself is, after all, only the start. It must be exploited by firms using IT systems to screen information, identify targets and develop medicines.

Oxford Glycosciences, for example, searches for genes which create protein imbalances and cause disease, inserting its own proteins to cure the problem.

But this leads to a second problem. Can the commercial world sustain the level of investment in biotech companies which will make many of the discoveries crucial to delivering the brave new world that science predicts?

At one level, the answer is yes. Nick Woolf, pharmaceuticals analyst at ABN Amro, says: 'The genome project is opening up areas of understanding which have never been explained before. It shows investors that the unravelling of the human genome would produce incredible opportunities for drug discoveries. They can see big value in some of these companies.'

But the effect of genome discovery on biotech companies is difficult to gauge. Many are years from producing products, let alone profits, so calculating their real value is hard.

Instead of assessing a firm's share price by expressing it as a multiple of its profits (price/earnings ratio), other methods are used. For example, potential markets for all of a firm's proposed products are assessed, adjusted by the probability of them making it to market.

But, as Warburg Dillon Reed analyst Karl Keegan comments, for many companies, 'valuation is an impossibly subjective task'.

The hype surrounding the genome has contributed to a major biotech boom this year. The value of the US Nasdaq Biotech Index rose by nearly four times in the year to March, and Europe followed, its biotech companies rise by three times. Valuation confusion added to the surge.

Analysts are comparing this year's biotech boom to dot.coms last year. 'The sector has been driven by the US and the position of biotech in the new economy, as investors have moved out of dot.coms looking for other high-growth sectors,' says Woolf. Triniman adds: 'Internet stock performance in 1999 woke the world up to the fact that traditional valuation models were not applicable to the new economy.'

These may seem academic points for investment theorists. But while in 20 years time the demise of many dot.com companies will be of little interest to those who did not lose their shirts, widespread market failure by biotech companies would have serious consequences for useful healthcare.

So what is the danger of biotech facing a bust like that in the dot.com sector? History is not encouraging.

Booms at the end of the Eighties and the mid Nineties ended in tears. One firm, British Biotech, has seen its share price fall 90 per cent to 27p after hopes that its Marimastat treatment would soon provide a cure for a range of cancers proved unfounded.

Even the recent surge turned down on a single news item in the middle of March - when Bill Clinton and Tony Blair declared that all raw genome data should be freely available, not locked in patents.

Far from indicating an appreciation of new economy company valuation, this showed that lemming-like investors did not understand biotech companies and were spooked into dumping them.

Of course, because many Biotech companies are at the very early stages of the 15-year development cycle, it is easy to say they are in a worse position than a dot.com, which is likely to develop to a possible flotation in three to five years.

But significant differences could underpin the recent increases in value.

Woolf says biotech is a tried-and- tested part of the new economy. The proof lies in the US. Some 20 of the 350 quoted US biotech companies made profits last year; a further 10 are expected to this year. Five potential blockbuster drugs have been created with gene technology in the past five years.

These companies can increasingly be analysed with traditional price/earnings valuation models, and as a result, their values soar. Amgen, for example, is the US's biggest biotech company and at $50 billion market capitalisation is worth as much as many pharmaceuticals giants.

As with dot.coms, we must not be blinded by science. Biotechnology covers a wide range of technologies (see glossary, below right). But the question is how close companies are to launching products, and therefore to profits. Europe is following the US, says Woolf, with a select group of companies - such as UK-based Celltech and Scotia - reaching product launch and profitability. In the US, Celltech is expected this year to launch its first antibody treatment for leukaemia, with estimated annual sales of $250 million .

ABN Amro expects the firm to move from a £37.7m loss in 1999 to a £102m profit in 2002. Shares have jumped from 500p to 1200p since January.

Celltech financial director Peter Allen says this time biotech is for real: 'In the Eighties biotech was a new sector which nobody understood. In the Nineties, a series of setbacks in clinical trials - we had some, too - saw values collapse. Now we are getting products to market, and there is more understanding of what it all means through the genome.'

In other words, a clear link between causes of disease and patients with disease helps scientists understand who to treat, and how. It also allows investors to see exactly what companies are doing.

If the biotech pioneers are right, finance and medicine incentives should work together to reap the biotech harvest.

If not, the missed opportunity will make the dot.com bust look like a tea party. And our collective health will be much, much poorer.

Glossary

Biotechnology 'splices genes' to cut and paste DNA from one organism into another. Powerful computers screen genetic material for problem genes and aim treatments at them.

Biotech uses natural processes; the traditional pharmaceutical technique is to use manufactured chemicals.

Biotech firms generate intellectual property (IP), which they protect with patents, in various ways. These include:

Genomics
This involves interpreting the DNA code to identify gene targets for treatments. US company Millennium and French firm Genset do this. Big drugs companies such as SmithKline Beecham work in genomics.

Combinational Chemistry
Libraries of millions of molecular combinations are put on computers to make a databank which can be matched to gene targets to provide treatments. Oxford Asymmetry works in this area.

Proteomics
Proteins themselves can make better targets than genes because genetic activity does not fully explain protein imbalances. Oxford GlycoSciences checks proteins to identify targets for drugs.

Antibodies
These proteins attack disease-carrying organisms. Cambridge Antibody Technology links this work with screening to identify drug targets.

webTitle: Technology by the bucket, but no brass neck

fields.headline: Technology by the bucket, but no brass neck
fields.trailText: At a point when we still thought that there was a future for the telecoms and technology sector - around about 2pm on Friday - perusal of the new organogram for BT prompted one thought: it's good, but is it good enough?
fields.body:
At a point when we still thought that there was a future for the telecoms and technology sector - around about 2pm on Friday - perusal of the new organogram for BT prompted one thought: it's good, but is it good enough?

Sir Peter Bonfield's assertion that 'the business has changed, so we have got to change to stay ahead of the game', sounded more like the echo of a stable door banging in the wind than a call to arms. The problem is that BT should have been 'staying ahead of the game' four years ago instead of sitting down, caught like a hippo in the headlights, as the less regulated more pro-active companies raced past it.

BT has slipped to being Britain's second-largest telecoms company behind Vodafone. And while its new structure, with four separate divisions under a flatter management hierarchy, ticks all the boxes on the consultants' charts, will it actually alter the culture of BT?

This seems the single most important problem for the telecom company to address. Many years ago I remember going on a charabanc to the BTR Labs in Martlesham to be appraised of the most fantastic fibre-optic-driven technology - all those applications which now seem so laughably misplaced, like 'high-definition television'. We were left in no doubt that BT would soon be delivering all sorts down our spanking new fibre network: as soon as those bastards at Oftel let it off the leash there would be everything-on-demand. Of course there wasn't. And still isn't. Even though BT will by this time next year be allowed to carry media on its network, our great expectations of what this might deliver have scaled down into little more than a vague hope.

In fact, the only on-demand service BT seemed to generate was a press conference every time it wanted to rattle a sabre in the direction of the cable industry. Despite the strenuous efforts of Oftel to ensure that BT's might was restrained from trouncing its fixed-line opposition, the behemoth made only languid progress in the exciting new markets which were open to it.

The strategy was lazy and simple; leverage your consumer inertia into maintaining high charges on services which were slow to arrive. For BT customers the arrival of any meaningful Internet product was a repeat performance of its video-on-demand fiasco. Much was promised, often advertised; little was delivered. ISDN - which was, it has to be said, an interim technology - largely passed the UK by because BT was in no hurry to reduce the crippling consumer expense of the product.

From what one hears of the new, new thing - DSL, which can deliver extremely fast service to the home - there has been a very similar reluctance to waft the possibility of it anywhere near the consumer.

When big-hitting companies such as BSkyB adopt a new friendship with tiny Kingston Telecom to develop these new technologies - rather than keeping up a longstanding relationship with BT, one suspects that it is the same old story. BT seems always to be reacting rather than acting.

But the emergence of new technologies has given BT a second chance to get it right. The four new divisions created to grasp the opportunities of the weightless economy glory in preposterously go-ahead brand names such as 'Ignite' and 'Yell' and 'Openworld' alongside the more prosaic 'Wireless'.

These will, one hopes, pursue the 'destroy your own business' model so favoured by GE's Jack Welch. The problem of making a denationalised company entrepreneurial is a tough one to crack. BT has had more time than most in which to smash the state mould, yet it has failed at nearly every major opportunity.

It is not, however, too late. Whether Bonfield, an engineer by background, has the mettle to follow up his restructuring with the necessary vision, marketing oomph and inspiration is very much an open question. BT, as they said in the Six Million Dollar Man, has the technology.

Whether it has the brass neck to go with its fibre optics is perhaps more pertinent to the company's future.

Despite the strenuous efforts of Oftel to ensure that BT's might was restrained from trouncing its fixed-line opposition, the behemoth made only languid progress in the exciting new markets which were open to it. The strategy was lazy and simple; leverage your consumer inertia into maintaining high charges on services which were slow to arrive. For BT customers the arrival of any meaningful Internet product was a repeat performance of its video-on-demand fiasco. Much was promised, often advertised; little was delivered. ISDN - which was, it has to be said, an interim technology - largely passed the UK by because BT was in no hurry to reduce the crippling consumer expense of the product. From what one hears of the new, new thing - DSL, which can deliver extremely fast service to the home - there has been a very similar reluctance to waft the possibility of it anywhere near the consumer. When big-hitting companies such as BSkyB adopt a new friendship with tiny Kingston Telecom to develop these new technologies - rather than keeping up a longstanding relationship with BT, one suspects that it is the same old story. BT seems always to be reacting rather than acting. But the emergence of new technologies has given BT a second chance to get it right. The four new divisions created to grasp the opportunities of the weightless economy glory in preposterously go-ahead brand names such as 'Ignite' and 'Yell' and 'Openworld' alongside the more prosaic 'Wireless'. These will, one hopes, pursue the 'destroy your own business' model so favoured by GE's Jack Welch. The problem of making a denationalised company entrepreneurial is a tough one to crack. BT has had more time than most in which to smash the state mould, yet it has failed at nearly every major opportunity. It is not, however, too late. Whether Bonfield, an engineer by background, has the mettle to follow up his restructuring with the necessary vision, marketing oomph and inspiration is very much an open question. BT, as they said in the Six Million Dollar Man, has the technology. Whether it has the brass neck to go with its fibre optics is perhaps more pertinent to the company's future.

webTitle: Jack Straw wants the keys to your office. Don't let him in ...

fields.headline: Jack Straw wants the keys to your office. Don't let him in ...
fields.trailText: The scene: an office in a high-tech start-up of the kind beloved of Iron Chancellor Brown. Let us call it UK-plc.com. The time: early next year; the Regulation of Investigatory Powers (RIP) Bill has been on the statute book for nearly six months. Alice, UK-plc's star programmer, has been receiving encrypted emails from an old flame, Bob, who (unknown to her) has a dodgy past.
fields.body:
The scene: an office in a high-tech start-up of the kind beloved of Iron Chancellor Brown. Let us call it UK-plc.com. The time: early next year; the Regulation of Investigatory Powers (RIP) Bill has been on the statute book for nearly six months. Alice, UK-plc's star programmer, has been receiving encrypted emails from an old flame, Bob, who (unknown to her) has a dodgy past.

Enter Inspector Knacker, armed with a Section 46 Notice requiring Alice to provide the keys necessary to decrypt her correspondence. Section 50 of the RIP Bill requires Alice not to disclose to anyone the existence of the Notice, nor the actions taken pursuant to it.

Being a law-abiding subject, Alice gives Knacker the keys. Under Section 50, she may not tell Bob, which is right and proper. But now here's the interesting bit - Alice may not tell her other correspondents that their privacy has been compromised, even though they are entirely innocent and the Inspector is now able to decrypt all their messages as well.

She can't tell her boss either, even though his business is suddenly at the mercy of Knacker and his boys. The boss, not surprisingly, is annoyed and demands to know what the hell is going on. But since Alice could go to jail for telling him, she refuses - and is promptly sacked. There is more.

Section 50 forbids Alice to tell an industrial tribunal or even a court of law that she has surrendered the keys to Knacker. Nor is she permitted to explain to the court why she is unable to answer the question: 'Have you revealed the keys to any person?' Stressed out, Alice consults her psychiatrist. But if she tells him what is bothering her she can go to jail for that too.

This scenario is just one of several envisaged by Dr. Charles Lindsey of Manchester University in a fascinating commentary on the legal farrago which is currently being railroaded through the Commons by the Interior Ministry (prop. J. Straw). The RIP Bill is such a crazed piece of legislation that one wonders if the Government hasn't taken leave of its senses. Bemused MPs say they don't understand this encryption stuff and hide behind the assumption that the Home Office must know what it's doing.

Big mistake. It's becoming clear that Straw & Co have no idea of the nightmare they are creating. Their screwball Bill is the product of a shambles in Whitehall over online regulation.

The original e-commerce Bill was the responsibility of the DTI: when it became clear that its fatuous proposals over encryption were going to bring the Bill down, they were summarily dropped. Responsibility for encryption policy passed to the Home Office, which is obsessed with official secrecy, buttressing police powers and doing whatever GCHQ requires. The RIP disaster is the result.

Does this matter to anyone other than us civil liberties fanatics? Answer: you bet. Many companies are deeply worried about the RIP Bill's provisions. And they are looking westward, to where Section 26 of the Irish E-Commerce Bill declares that 'nothing in this Act shall be construed as requiring the disclosure of unique data, such as codes, passwords, algorithms, private cryptographic keys, or other data, that may be necessary to render information or an electronic communication intelligible'.

To get this protection from snooping, however, it won't be enough to host your e-commerce site on an Irish server while running the business from Britain, because Straw's Bill will cover every communication you send from your base. You will have to move the business to Ireland. Which of course is exactly what the Irish government is banking on. And they give whopping tax breaks too.

fields.headline: Briefcase
fields.trailText:
Company futures
Back to basics for Blue Circle
On 4 May, there is an exceptional line-up of six planets in earthy, practical Taurus, including the New Moon. With old economies sliding back into favour after the gentle hissing of the dot.com bubble, sensible money is likely to flow back to traditional businesses, especially construction. Nothing fits the bill better than the cement operation of Blue Circle Industries. Its horoscope (incorporated 10/7/1900) is stacked with earth, with Taurus rising and a powerful Saturn in chalky Capricorn. Blue Circle is also a home-loving Cancerian, perhaps indicative of the local nature of cement production, necessitated by high transport costs. Its globe-trotting Sagittarian Moon gives it a strong global presence, but Lafarge's Bertrand Collomb, mounting a hostile bid, reckons BCI lost its way during the Eighties. Does astrology agree?

Back to basics for Blue Circle
On 4 May, there is an exceptional line-up of six planets in earthy, practical Taurus, including the New Moon. With old economies sliding back into favour after the gentle hissing of the dot.com bubble, sensible money is likely to flow back to traditional businesses, especially construction. Nothing fits the bill better than the cement operation of Blue Circle Industries. Its horoscope (incorporated 10/7/1900) is stacked with earth, with Taurus rising and a powerful Saturn in chalky Capricorn. Blue Circle is also a home-loving Cancerian, perhaps indicative of the local nature of cement production, necessitated by high transport costs. Its globe-trotting Sagittarian Moon gives it a strong global presence, but Lafarge's Bertrand Collomb, mounting a hostile bid, reckons BCI lost its way during the Eighties. Does astrology agree?

Blue Circle's renaming and new logo in 1978 marked the start of diversification when confusing Neptune led it to meander away from its core business into Armitage washbasins, Potterton boilers, New World cookers and Bluewater shopping. Last September, back-to-basics Saturn returned it to the cement track and with good contacts to Venus now, Lafarge's bid seems unlikely to suffice unless it substantially increases its offer. Expect a rise in stocks around 4 May but further uncertainty when deconstructive Pluto moves across its Moon next January. It may not be until this influence is over in November 2001 that BCI squares the circle of a global reach for its core traditional business.

This week in Business
Monday
FINALS: Henry Boot
INTERIMS: Bank of America Corp, Microplanet Systems
ECONOMICS: UK CBI pay databank survey, US Fed's Parry speech on economic outlook
Tuesday
FINALS: Reed Executive, Rugby Estates, Solitaire, S&U, Time Products, Walker Greenbank
INTERIMS: AB Foods, St Ives, WH Smith
ECONOMICS: UK March Consumer Price Index, EEF March pay settlements, US March housing starts, API weekly oil data

Wednesday
INTERIMS: Air Partner, Ferraris Group, News Comms & Media
ECONOMICS: Minutes of BoE MPC's April meeting, UK March labour market report, US Feb trade deficit

Thursday
FINALS: Jumbo International
INTERIMS: Glaxo Wellcome (Q1), SmithKline Beecham (Q1)
ECONOMICS: UK March retail sales, public sector finances, prov M4, M4 lending, BBA analysis of bank lending, BSA building society lending, CML mortgage lending, car production

Friday BANK HOLIDAY - UK markets closed

Watch out for:
Associated British Foods
Food manufacturer Associated British Foods, maker of Kingsmill bread, Silver Spoon sugar, and Twinings tea, is set to report a fall in half-yearly pre-tax profits of around 10 per cent on Tuesday, say analysts.

The strength of sterling and the payment of a £448 million special dividend in May were cited as reasons for expected profits of around £165m, compared with £185m in the same period last year.

Prospects for the second half look more robust, with a good sugar crop countering the impact of sterling's strength on the profits of the processor British Sugar.

The management is currently on the prowl for acquisitions in Europe and North America. Earlier this month ABF sold its underperforming ice cream business to Richmond foods for £18.8m.

Trading floor

Buy...
Primark, ABF's discount clothing retailer, is vastly undervalued according to some analysts. Williams de Broe suggest that the growing unit could be valued as high as £2.5 billion despite contributing only 13 per cent to group profits. Pfizer, manufacturer of Viagra. Sales of the anti-impotence drug are soaring, and now it is on the threshold of finding a potentially even larger secondary market as, of all things, a conservation tool. This week, Chinese zoological officials announced that endangered male pandas have been put on the drug in the hope of fostering a population boom. 'The male panda can only mate for ten to 20 seconds,' an expert told the Chinese press this week. 'And hence the chances of getting the female pregnant are very low.' With Viagra, the male could mate for up to 20 minutes.' If the experiment is a success, there will be demand from a huge range of endangered species including, in the UK, many species of birds and, incidentally of bees which, in another development this week, were said by the Bee Conservancy Council to be on the verge of extinction.

Sell...
Centennial Publishing, owner of Feng Shui for Modern Living magazine. The End of Trend is Nigh. Christian fundamentalist hot-house nurserymen employed by an Isle of Wight tomato producer walked off the job this week after the owner employed a Feng Shui consultant to boost productivity. The two men, both Baptists, said that the ancient Chinese art of energy channelling and lengthy hand-wringing over the positioning of fish-tanks was, basically, the work of the devil. Management science gurus have long wondered when the backlash against the growing use of pagan and, indeed, satanic rituals in modern business would begin.

T'Share-Hi-Ping, the ancient Manchurian art of money-channelling, is reportedly causing unease among the faithful in the City. There is concern too, among the holy, about the increasing popularity of Oriental metaphysical disciplines such as Sp'Red Bhet-'Ting and Ly-Ing, which are both thought to have immense appeal to City types and are known to be psychologically addictive. This sort of New Age mystical nonsense has no place in a modern economy. They'll be telling us they can predict the future next! (On other pages: share tips, economic forecasts, analysts' reports, lucky lottery numbers, astrology _)

fields.headline: One for the road
fields.standfirst: The Corvette V8 is fast, thirsty and totally impractical. But you don't end up being a motoring legend by being politically correct. By Andrew Smith
fields.trailText: The Corvette V8 is fast, thirsty and totally impractical. But you don't end up being a motoring legend by being politically correct.
fields.body:
Being an icon is hard work. My Collins dictionary defines the word as pertaining to 'a representation of Christ or a saint', before blathering vaguely about 'images' and 'symbols', all of which merely hints at the tyranny of its present usage. In the modern world, an icon is something whose physical presence has become secondary to the space it occupies in our imagination. The problem is that, once it's there, it is fixed, frozen in a particular time and stage of evolution. In the American Century, most of the universal examples were either pop stars or actors or cars, such as the Corvette. How are they going to negotiate the tricky passage into this century?

Prior to trying the Corvette, another (the other) American motoring icon, the Cadillac, demonstrated how hard it can be to straddle eras without spilling iconic aura. In terms of toys, this car has everything. Put your key in the ignition and the steering wheel and electric seat come alive, the latter groping around to suit your posture. As you reverse, gentle chimes, exactly like the ones that sound on planes when it's okay to undo your seat belt after take off, grow more urgent the nearer you get to the car behind. Once you've learnt not to yell 'Oi, ger orf, you perv!' at the seat, or get up to ask the stewardess for a Bloody Mary as you pull out into traffic - something the writers of the Highway Code neglected to specifically forbid, by the way - this is all rather pleasant. Unfortunately, thanks to the Americanised suspension, driving the Cadillac feels a lot like driving a bouncy castle, and, more crucial yet, the thing looks disappointing. Where are the fins? The two-one paint job? The grille you could roast an ox on? Not here. Friends grew excited when offered a ride over the phone, but when they saw it, their faces dropped. This was not the Cadillac of their imaginations. For the money, it was an average to dull executive car.

The fate of the Caddy is not inevitable, however. American motoring iconography holds nothing more dear than the Corvette. In the 50s, they were naming rock'n'roll guitars after it: 30 years later, Prince was still singing about a Little Red one. It was the first sports car General Motors built, supposedly in response to US troops coming home after the Second World War with a taste for MGs. A company-wide competition yielded its name, after a class of rapid-chase ship in the British navy. More splendid still, the distinctively cheesy badge looks as though it was cobbled together at the last minute, because it was. The emblem on the first model, introduced to the public at a New York motor show in 1953, was to incorporate a chequered racing flag and an image of the Stars and Stripes, something which is forbidden by law. The production team learnt of this hitch the day before the show and scoured the city for a jeweller to fashion a new badge overnight. They kept the chequered flag, but replaced the Stars and Stripes with the Chevrolet company flag - which made sense - and a fleur-de-lis, the symbol of French royalty, which patently did not. No one knows why. All of which is by way of pointing out that the Corvette is no focus-group kid.

A large chrome rendering of the Corvette emblem plunges between the driver's and passenger's seats, with all the subtlety of a Jayne Mansfield neckline. Subtlety is not this machine's forte, even though it is unquestionably beautiful; sleek and stretched as long as a Jag XJ6 and broad enough to cause trepidation in negotiating the gates to my apartment block. Constructed from fibreglass, with a chunky, raised rear end, it so clearly echoes the Corvettes of the past as to seem at once classic and notionally modern. With a 5.7-litre, V8 engine, you can watch the petrol gauge march downward even while idling, but you can also do 175mph. The automatic gearbox seems incongruous at first, but still manages 0-60 in five seconds. If you waggle your arms about really fast in the direction of the gearstick, people will think you're an expert shifter anyway. Schlepping around Brighton on a sunny winter's day, passers-by looked at the Corvette in the same way that they would have gazed at Bianca Jagger marching down the pavement. It has an air of the exotic and unexpected about it.

People smiled a lot, in a way that they don't when confronted by a growling Porsche. I'll be honest. Sports cars aren't my bag. I long ago vowed never to own a car that couldn't reasonably be driven in carpet slippers while smoking a pipe. Nevertheless, this one is so out of step with every principle of fashion and practicality and common sense as to be quite irresistible. It harkens back to an innocent past, before petrol crises and environmental awareness and Aids, and I found myself warming to it in the same way that I've always warmed to John Prescott - though he, of course, while weighing the same as one Corvette, would need to own two. In the end, its iconic status lives on into the next century through the simple trick of failing to notice that the old one has ended. The Nobel winning poet Seamus Heaney summed this up best when he enthused that, through the Corvette 'I glimpsed an elsewhere of potential that seemed at the same time to be a somewhere being remembered'. Or was he talking about Beowulf? Either way, he was right.
