fields.headline: Prudence could be dear indeed
fields.trailText: It would be a terrible thing if a Labour government with a majority of 180 went down in history as having squandered its inheritance.
fields.body:
It would be a terrible thing if a Labour government with a majority of 180 went down in history as having squandered its inheritance.

During a week when it was officially announced that social inequality, as measured by the distribution of income, had actually increased since 1 May 1997, the Prime Minister seemed to be reduced to pleading that a Conservative government would be even more right- wing than this one.

The first, and possibly last, 'New' Labour government in history is widely criticised for its arrogance and its addiction to 'control freakery'. But many of its problems stem from a sense of inner weakness, not to say terror.

The fact is that New Labour has done extraordinarily badly since May 1997 in any contest when voters have been required to turn out, as opposed to answer an opinion pollster. The sign that Tony Blair was becoming really worried was when he used a recent interview to disinter the idea of a deal with the Liberal Democrats.

The Lib Dems are unlikely to fall into such a trap. They know that disaffected Labour voters who would never dream of voting Conservative have a place to go now. And in some respects such disaffected voters regard the LibDems as vaguely left wing.

This is not to say that this Government is doing nothing about social inequality. It intervenes in the social security system and the labour market with myriad schemes. Having almost got the message that attacks on lone parents and the disabled were not primarily what people voted for in 1997, the Government is highlighting what it is now doing for the poor and the disadvantaged. Unfortunately, as with extra spending on health and education, it is all happening late. The overall impression is one of panic rather than strategy.

Which brings us to the macro-economic strategy on which so much else depends, and which, until recently, was winning the Government plaudits from all sides.

I accept that the general aims of the Chancellor's strategy are noble. He has not forgotten his old Labour roots, but he has had to learn the lessons of successive Labour defeats. He has therefore been 'prudent with a purpose'.

But the Government now faces criticisms from industry, the City and the International Monetary Fund that the Budget is in fact somewhat imprudent. This is the last thing my good friend Gordon Brown wanted to hear. New Labour has assiduously cultivated all these once alien (for Labour) constituencies. The Parliamentary Treasury Committee has sprung to his defence, and he has vigorously hit back at his critics. But the criticism hurts. So much investment in the goodwill of business, the City and the IMF cannot be written off just like that, surely?

We live in a world of assets and liabilities. In attempting to build up the prudence 'asset', the Government risked the 'liability' that a public spending freeze would cause in the health, education and infrastructure spheres it was elected to tackle.

Now that panic has set in, we have a policy of 'education, education, education' and 'health, health, health'. There are growing suspicions that the new public spending plans leave little scope for sorting out the transport and other infrastructure prob lems that are a source of frustration in an otherwise prosperous country.

The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) was supposed to be a prize asset. I respect it. But, as in the case of Chairman Mao's views on the French revolution, it is too early to judge whether it has been a success.

Economists at the independent National Institute of Economic and Social Research, whose model of the economy is similar to the Treasury's, point out that inflation has been close to target since two years before the election, and that a visitor from outer space looking at what statisticians call the 'time series' would be unable to pinpoint the introduction of the MPC in mid-1997. Its influence does not appear on the radar screen.

But the interesting strategic problem now is of course the pound and its short- and medium-term relationship with the euro. Even the most hardened proponent of the pound's entry into the single currency knows that a substantial devaluation of the pound is one of the necessary conditions attached to taking such a step. The MPC 'takes account' of the pound in reaching interest rate decisions. But its brief is to achieve the inflation target, not to devalue the pound.

Eddie George has hinted several times recently that the MPC could contrive a devaluation by lowering interest rates but, in the absence of vast tax increases to cool an increase in consumer demand, that would unleash forces that would cause 'overheating' and severe risks of 'overshooting' the inflation target.

I do not see the Government deliberately devaluing this side of the election. The relationship between the words 'devaluation' and 'Labour governments' is a skeleton in the cupboard.

I hope my fears are misplaced. But it could be that this Government is embarking on a year-long election campaign during which the industrial consequences of the strong pound could make the Rover affair look like a vicarage tea party.

fields.headline: The outing of insider dealing
fields.standfirst: UK regulators can learn from their no-nonsense cousins in the US, reports Paul Farrelly
fields.trailText: UK regulators can learn from their no-nonsense cousins in the US, reports Paul Farrell
fields.body:
It is the insider-dealing affair tabloids dream of - a steamy mix of sex, adultery, high finance and betrayal. Last week in New York one of Wall Street's highest-flyers stood trial on charges of passing inside information to a glamorous porn star who made a killing on the US stock market.

James McDermott, former president of US investment bank Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, faces seven charges of insider trading and conspiracy after allegedly passing on share tips about a string of bank mergers. If convicted, he faces fines of $1.25 million and a total of 65 years in jail.

The woman he was having an affair with - euphemistically called a 'dancer and model' in the Manhattan court - has fled to Vancouver, Canada, where she faces extradition proceedings. Kathryn Gannon - a 28-year-old veteran of 100 blue movies under the name Marylin Star - has threatened to blow New York apart with revelations about further senior figures on the Street.

Her alleged associate, secretive New Jersey businessman Anthony Pompino, with whom she was also having an affair, has turned state's evidence following a two-year probe by the FBI and the powerful Securities & Exchange Commission (SEC). Nonetheless, US prosecutors have put him on trial too.

But the case has more than mere titillation value. As the powers of Britain's new watchdog, the Financial Services Authority (FSA), come under concerted attack by vested interests in the City, it demonstrates the wide gulf between the two sides of the Atlantic in matters of market abuse - and how effectively the regulators get their man, or woman.

'We've got very workable laws, and the powers we need to obtain evidence from people who don't want to give it,' said Thomas Newkirk, associate enforcement director at the SEC. 'The federal courts in Manhattan are very savvy about the market and what it's all about. We have stiff penalties that can really make people hurt. It's all a very great deterrent.'

Ten days ago, the UK mounted its first prosecution for insider dealing since 1996. Lawrence Champion, a tax official, admitted 13 charges of using sensitive Inland Revenue information to go on a 15-month share-dealing spree.

Last November, when The Observer last looked at the parliamentary progress of the new Financial Services and Markets Bill, we established that the Crown Prosecution Service had not pursued one insider-dealing case since Labour came to power. This was despite an increasing number of referrals of suspicious dealings by the Stock Exchange and a growing number of investigations by the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI), responsible for current legislation.

When asked, the DTI denied there had been a deliberate switch in policy following the patchy success and frequent embarrassments in prosecuting City fraud. 'There has been no policy change,' a DTI spokeswoman said. 'In all the cases, there has been insufficient evidence to prosecute.'

However, The Observer has since learned that a Govern ment Minister told top UK regulators that there would be no high-profile prosecutions until the new Bill, with its extra powers, became law. The minister, Lord Falconer, a close friend of the Prime Minister, was in 1997 Solicitor General, a senior law officer in the Lord Chancellor's department. He is now in the Cabinet Office and in charge of the Millennium Dome.

This weekend, senior regulatory sources said there had been no outright ban. 'He [Falconer] may have said there will be no high-profile cases, and therefore no high profile failures,' one regulatory source said. 'But it is something we are working away hard at. It's not that black and white.'

However, despite DTI protestations this weekend, the Champion prosecution does not contradict evidence of a policy change. His was an open-and-shut case: he admitted the charges. So since the election, there has still been no prosecution mounted in a case where the suspects contested the charges.

Champion now faces a maximum seven years in prison but, if history is a guide, he has little to fear. The biggest fine ever levied in the UK has been £25,000. And in the past 20 years, only one person has been jailed, serving just nine months.

The contrast with the US can hardly be greater. There, the SEC has forced insider dealers to pay over billions of dollars in ill-gotten gains. Junk-bond king Michael Milken was fined $600m and jailed for 10 years. Arch insider dealer Ivan Boesky, whose information to the SEC led to Milken and the Guinness share-dealing inquiry in the UK, was also dealt with severely.

In 1997, a great song and dance was made of the planned new statutory framework to regulate the City. The FSA was hailed as the UK's equivalent of the SEC, armed with identical powers to levy fines, with a burden of proof lower than in criminal prosecutions. Since then, however, following powerful lobbying led by big City law firms representing banks and brokers, the FSA's powers and enforcement procedures have been emasculated.

Last week's attempts in the House of Lords to split Howard Davies's role as chairman and chief executive of the FSA were just the latest in a long assault on the new regime. So, too, was a government defeat by Tory peers which chips away at the FSA's statutory immunity from prosecution itself.

The Bill returns to the Lords this week, with further defeats likely. As a result, the new laws, intended for this summer, may be delayed until early next year. A further battle is also raging over the FSA's draft code of conduct, which defines 'market abuse' in the first place. The City, used to cosy self-regulation, is simply trying to protect its way of life. But the side-effect, say frustrated regulators, is that the villains will be just as hard to punish.

The case of the fugitive porn queen also demonstrates fundamental differences in the character of the regulators themselves. The probe, spearheaded by SEC staff lawyer Lionel Andre, was prompted in mid-1997 by suspicious dealings during a huge banking merger.

It has already led to two other separate trials of Wall Street traders. A swift series of subpoenas uncovered the starlet's accounts and led to the bank president. Plea-bargaining by her associate, who expects a reduced sentence, led to charges being levelled last December - little more than two years later.

Here, the regulators are hardly known for their innovative, undercover approach or speed of enquiry.

Vested interests would like them to remain that way.

fields.headline: Bourbon creams
fields.standfirst: Cowboys may appreciate the throat-scorching qualities of firewater, but a small-batch bourbon has all the subtlety and smoothness of single malt. By Michael Jackson
fields.trailText: Cowboys may appreciate the throat-scorching qualities of firewater, but a small-batch bourbon has all the subtlety and smoothness of single malt
fields.body:
Tony Parsons's bestseller, Man and Boy, begins with the birth of his first child and the presentation of a bottle of bourbon. Given the occasion, it should surely have been a small-batch bourbon, though Parsons missed that trick. Small-batch bourbons have been in fashionable bars for a year or two, but gradually they are beginning to appear in shops, not only London specialists such as the Vintage house and Milroy's but also department stores.

The image of bourbon as the firewater of the cowboy or the gangster has always been a mixed blessing and scarcely fits the small-batch bottlings. Some are sufficiently complex to suit the least macho man or boy, woman or girl. Take Baker's. Its flowery bouquet reminds me of violets and there is a suggestion of brandy snap in the palate. Or Basil Hayden's: the colour is a pinkish gold, the bouquet flowery and rose-like, the palate fruity and creamy with suggestions of chocolate. Only when water is added do I find a suggestion of cigar-smoke. Blanton's has a more purply tinge, the aroma of Turkish delight, a date-like flavour and a mint-tea finish. The best-known example, Booker's, has an orangey colour, a delicate aroma, a luscious, tongue-coating, vanilla-pod flavour - and long, lingering finish.

The small batches prove something that connoisseurs have always known, but about which other drinkers have been less confident: you don't have to labour in a Scottish glen to make a fine distillate. Whisky (the Scottish and Canadian spelling) and whiskey (the Irish and US way) are but different members of the same family. This is not a competition between Celtic magic and frontier spirit. Emigrants from Scotland and Ireland were largely responsible for the introduction of whiskey-distilling in North America, but found different grains in the New World.

Scotch whiskies taste of malted barley, heather, peat and sometimes the briney, seaweedy shores where they were matured. Irish has a grassier, oilier flavour from unmalted barley. Canadians have a rye tinge, while in American whiskies, the dominant flavour is corn (maize), leavened with rye or wheat.

In all whiskies or whiskeys, much is also contributed by the wood used in maturation. In the early days of US distilling, whiskey produced in Kentucky, and shipped in barrels from a port in Bourbon County to New Orleans, gained its oaky character en route. Today, every batch is matured in new oak. The sweetness of the corn is enriched by a vanilla-like component of the oak.

While maturation in Scotland takes place in a cool, damp climate, the warehouses in Kentucky can become very hot. In consequence, while Scots distillers lose alcohol to the 'angels', Kentuckians merely lose water. Not only the strength, but also the flavours of their whisky can concentrate during ageing.

When a distillery makes a bottling, it marries from a large range of casks to ensure a consistency of style. In Scotland, a distillery may have a dozen warehouses stretching along the waterfront. The one nearest the water will yield salty-tasting whiskies. Even within one warehouse, casks at ground level or in the middle of the building will mature differently from those up high or in a corner, due to different temperatures, degrees of humidity, or draught. Those factors are especially influential in the heat of Kentucky. A small-batch bourbon is bottled from casks reflecting a particular emphasis within the house style.

The number of barrels felt to constitute a 'small' batch varies from one distillery to the next, so the credibility of the whole notion rests on the distinctiveness of the bottlings. If there was a definition, consumers might be as willing to pay super-premium prices for small-batch bourbons as they are for single-malt Scotches. Unlike single malts, the bourbons are made from a blend of grains. On the other hand, each bourbon is typically made in a single distillery. In that respect, even the most mainstream bourbons are 'singles'.

webTitle: BT to shackle top staff with bonuses

fields.headline: BT to shackle top staff with bonuses
fields.trailText: A lucrative shares bonus scheme is to be introduced for top management at BT to try to end a long haemorrhaging of top staff to rival firms. The scheme attempts to mirror the incentive packages of the leading dot.com companies.
fields.body:
A lucrative shares bonus scheme is to be introduced for top management at BT to try to end a long haemorrhaging of top staff to rival firms. The scheme attempts to mirror the incentive packages of the leading dot.com companies.

BT surprised the City last week by announcing it was creating four businesses focused on high growth areas - in addition to separating its wholesale and retail telephone operations. Now, in a bid to ensure its new growth businesses attract and keep top talent, the company will ask shareholders to approve the new pay structure at its annual meeting in June.

The new divisions are Yell, its directories arm; BTopenworld, its Internet business aimed at the mass market; Ignite, a broadband transmission network; and BT Wire less, its mobile phone arm.

To ensure the new divisions perform aggressively, Sir Peter Bonfield, BT's chief executive, drew up the new bonus plan which will see around 500 of BT's top managers offered what are described as 'substantial numbers of shares', providing targets are reached.

BT stresses that the incentive scheme will not be as aggressive as those of some Internet companies, but analysts believe the bonuses could be as high as between 50 per cent and 100 per cent of some managers' salaries. The individual packages will be based on performances over a rolling three-year period.

While the move is partially designed to attract a new raft of entrepreneurially-minded employees to the company, it is essentially a defensive mechanism to stop more staff deserting.

'If you look at the key positions in many companies today they are filled by BT people,' a company spokesman said. They include Mike Grabiner, now chief executive at Energis, and several senior executives at Colt.

BT, which has come under fierce criticism in the past for not being able to mirror the speed at which some its leaner rivals are able to implement their business plans, is keen to throw off its slumbering giant image.

It hopes the creation of the new divisions, which could be floated off later, coupled with the introduction of the radical incentive package, will stimulate innovation and get new products to the marketplace more quickly.

'This new approach is to reflect the culture of BT as it changes,' the spokesman said.

Many analysts welcomed BT's announcements, although some doubted whether the overhaul went far enough. A note from analysts at Merrill Lynch said the moves were encouraging, but might 'not be as radical or extensive [enough] to get BT firing on all cylinders.'

webTitle: City set for the big bust

fields.headline: City set for the big bust
fields.trailText: The London stock market is set for a dramatic fall tomorrow following the biggest one-day plunge ever in New York on Friday.
fields.body:
The London stock market is set for a dramatic fall tomorrow following the biggest one-day plunge ever in New York on Friday.

Small investors, who have jumped blindly into inflated Internet and technology shares, are likely to suffer most from the sell-off. But the crash, prompted by fears of higher inflation and interest rates, will also make home-owners increasingly nervous.

A higher-than-expected hike in US consumer prices makes interest rate rises certain, with repercussions for markets the world over, economists said this weekend.

A sharp rise in oil prices was a major factor in the US inflation figures. The higher costs will affect UK industry, too, fuelling worries about recession at a time of dwindling business confidence.

The fall on Wall Street pounded all sectors, with the blue chip Dow Jones Industrial Average index dropping 616 points, or 5.6 per cent, to 10,307. But the hi-tech Nasdaq market suffered worst of all, plummeting 10 per cent to leave it a third below its all-time high in March.

Small UK investors have already seen a dramatic fall in 'Internet wonder stocks' such as Lastminute.com and now look set to have their fingers really burned.

'This has been an accident waiting to happen for some time,' said Roger Bootle, of forecasting consultant Capital Economics. 'These shares have been grossly overvalued. What was going on was akin to gambling in a casino. The risks remain enormous.'

London's FTSE-100 index of leading shares closed down 179 points at 6,178.1 on Friday as traders took fright at events in the US. The worst on Wall Street had yet to come, however. With markets in the Far East also likely to tumble tomorrow, the City is braced for the FTSE to fall below the psychologically important 6,000 support level.

The powerful US Federal Reserve has already lifted US interest rates by a quarter of a point five times since last June to restrain a runaway economy, which nonetheless grew 7 per cent in the final quarter of 1999. The US central bank is now expected to lift rates more aggressively when it meets on 16 May.

'Everyone's going to be on edge to see what happens,' one senior share trader said. 'London will follow Wall Street closely. We've just been waiting for the market to crack. And when it does, a lot of these Internet stocks, which will never make any money, will be exposed as pretty much worthless.'

Traditional 'old economy' shares, however, such as undervalued electricity, water and food companies, are likely to benefit. History shows that in times of panic investors flee into quality, defensive stocks with proven track records.

fields.headline: Hot property
fields.standfirst: When a dingy office building in Edinburgh came on the market, architect Helen Kelly couldn't resist it. Now, after extensive renovation, the property is worth four times its original price. Here's how she turned it round
fields.trailText: When a dingy office building in Edinburgh came on the market, architect Helen Kelly couldn't resist it. Now, after extensive renovation, the property is worth four times its original price. Here's how she turned it round
fields.body:
The location was perfect - just a stone's throw from Princes Street in the centre of Edinburgh. And the price was reasonable - just £110,000 for an 18th-century three-storey property. But there was a catch. The building, originally a family house, had been used as overflow office and storage space for a property consultancy and, when Helen Kelly first visited it in 1995, the drab and dismal interior left much to be desired. The need for a radical overhaul put most people off, but not Kelly, an architect. The renovation may have cost £150,000 but it has paid off handsomely. The property is now valued at £400,000.

'We actually didn't get it first time around, someone else had planned to buy it, intending to move in as it was,' she recalls. 'But no one could have lived here, it was in such a state. Second time round, it was meant to be.'

The change of use from residential to offices had resulted in uniform, boxy compartments with little attention to detailing or decor. But for Kelly, an associate at Malcolm Fraser Architects in Edinburgh, the property had, to coin the estate agents' favourite phrase, 'incredible potential'.

'I needed a new project,' Kelly admits, 'and before we'd bought it I'd already done all the background in determining if we could get planning permission, whether we could subdivide it, what kind of restrictions there were, so that by the time we did buy there was no delay.'

Kelly and her partner, Mark, chose the top two floors to create a home for themselves and their children Amy, seven months, and Sam, four. The space is surprisingly open and light, marrying contemporary aesthetics with original features.

The hall may be cluttered with mountain bikes, but the eye is immediately drawn upwards through the stairwell to the original cupola. The original spiral staircase leads to first floor, while a new metalwork version, inspired by the glass stairwells designed by Czech architect Eva Jiricna, goes up to the second. This was the biggest extravagance. 'The guys who built it were cursing me,' says Kelly. 'Every piece of steel had to be carried upstairs and then winched up for construction.'

The beauty is in the detail. Its maple treads follow in the footsteps of the original, and the beech handrail, which has been raised to guard against vertigo, ends in an elegant curve. 'I still wish the supports were smaller, that it looked finer,' Kelly frets. 'But now the light streams down from the cupola as was intended.

'I wanted to restore the spaces to their original use, so what would have been the bedrooms are bedrooms again. It was fascinating to strip back and find what was there.'

Kelly had followed a similar idea in her previous two-bedroom property, opening up the spaces, bringing in light, creating a large, open living room. It was a style of living that suited the family so well that she decided to do the same again. While the lower floor, now rented out, had retained the original Georgian detailing, the floors above were simpler, bare of cornicing and elaborate fireplaces, lending themselves to a contemporary reworking.

The top floor, tucked under the roof, originally had five rooms with only one tiny dormer window for all of them. Now there are three bedrooms and, with increased light being of prime importance, Kelly designed two larger dormer windows to the rear with two roof lights at the front.

Removing the ties and partitions that held up the roof was a major part of the engineering work, as Kelly had to find another means of support before the internal structure could be changed. Now one steel column, painted lilac, does the job. The budget was stretched on discovering that the floor had to be strengthened, but a rough stone wall at one end, discovered below layers of paint, was a welcome find.

'There are always extras,'says Kelly. 'Until you take something apart you're never sure what you're going to find. And there's always compromise. Sometimes you have to change the budget and sometimes you have to change the vision.' Her advice? 'Do as much preparatory work as possible and work out detailed budgets. If you're not doing the work yourself, find an architect and put their fees into the budget - usually 15 per cent of the total. I always add a little more overall than predicted,' she cautions.

It's also worth looking into grants, such as those awarded for lead replacement, or for bathrooms and kitchens if there are none. In converting an A-listed building from office back to residential use, Kelly was exempt from VAT on the renovation budget.

Kelly also suggests that only one person should deal with the contractors: 'Then there's no chance of someone saying, but so-and-so told me to do that. Channelling everything through one person, who then records all the details, turns it into a very tight contract.'

The crisp lines of the architecture are softened by the eclectic and relaxed interior style of a family home, where children Amy and Sam clamber around freely. When I arrived, Sam was on tour duty, pointing out the many, many stairs without batting an eyelid at the height we were ascending to the main living space. 'People said to me, "You can't have kids here!" But you don't have to compromise on modern design to have a family,' says Kelly.

In the kitchen, custom-made MDF units are combined with doors from Ikea, while the stainless-steel cooker, which looks like a semi-professional affair, is actually an average-sized model with co-ordinating stainless-steel doors covering storage space at the side. In the bathroom, sleek Philippe Starck fittings are teamed with plywood cupboards that have been coated in a birch veneer. 'It's about dressing up simple pieces and spending the money where it matters,' Kelly believes.

Now the two top floors alone, not including the rented apartment, are valued at £250,000, particularly gratifiying as the couple bought this as a home, not an investment. But Kelly has itchy feet again, and has spent two years looking for her next project. So far, possibilites have included an electrical sub-station and a warehouse into which she could insert a modern interior.

'You used to be able to pick up "ugly" stuff very easily,' she says. 'Now more people are willing to have a look.' As they realise the investment potential, properties that would have been rejects five years ago are getting thin on the ground. As Kelly says: 'The thing is, we weren't looking on this as developers - we took time to make the right decisions.'

fields.headline: Doctor in the house
fields.standfirst: Which white is the right white? Is cobalt blue in or out? Where should the kitchen go? As editor of Elle Decoration, Toni Rodgers finds patients queuing up on a daily basis with their various lifestyle ailments
fields.trailText: Which white is the right white? Is cobalt blue in or out? Where should the kitchen go? As editor of Elle Decoration, Toni Rodgers finds patients queuing up on a daily basis with their various lifestyle ailments
fields.body:
There's an occupational hazard to being editor of Elle Decoration . It's akin to being a doctor at a dinner party full of hypochondriacs. Social functions (and I'm talking me in my civvies here, not ambassador for my magazine) see fellow guests queuing up, waiting for a prescription for their interiors ailments. Like my reflexologist: 'Come to supper. And then tell me a clever way to connect the dining room to the rest of the house.'

Or the never-met-before, northern cousin's girlfriend's mum. 'Do I go wrought-iron-and-marble or wicker-and- terracotta in my sun room?' Deco 's heart may lie with white ceramic planters and day beds, but this woman wanted a straightforward either/or benediction from someone in the trade. There's even my mum, bless her, in need of a paint colour to harness her orange chenille curtains and swirly green carpet ('You remember, it's the one that Dave Hill had in his home on the Slade documentary?')

What's astounding is the mass appeal for advice coupled with a specificness of the vision. The 'I want neo-rustic-minimalism-with-a-Mexican-twist' jargon, osmosed from too much MDF-clad makeover TV. And, meanwhile, we can't move for the media (and more specifically newspapers) declaring 'homes are the new fashion'. Oh. Big. Wow. Why are people surprised?

British Lifestyles 2000 carried out a survey of over 1,000 women, asking: 'If you were assured financial security in the long-term, what would be your top priority in terms of spending?' The biggest increase over the past five years goes to home/DIY/ decorating. And the greatest ambition of 64 per cent of financially secure women? To have kids? No. Get married? Nope. Go out and have a good time buying clothes/drinking/spending money on their appearance? Uh-uh. Two-thirds of women asked wanted to_ own their own home. Why? Let's explore this on two levels:

a) In counselling and therapy-speak, the home is a metaphor for the body. Our soul is wrapped up within our skin. We express ourselves by the way we dress and strive to be 'comfortable' with our being. By extension, in our ever-decreasing slivers of personal time, our bodies exist within the 'skin' of our home. And, of late, we've discovered that with a hotel-style bathroom, decent sofa and appointment with the Dulux colour matching camera (it matches the colour of any object of your choice to the nearest Dulux shade), we can express ourselves in a way that makes us comfortable within that, too.

b) The other option: shopping is more important than politics - ergo, buying stuff for the home is equivalent to 10-tupling your previous wardrobe space.

It takes no great leap of the imagination to see why the nation has graduated from dressing itself to dressing its immediate environment. Until the mid-90s, paint companies were trickling out a few new shades every year or two (White-White, Off White, White-With-A-Bit-Of-White White, etc). And then - bam - they started living the vida loca and a carnival of new ranges rah-rahed their way on to the scene. Hot, 'fun' collections with names like Latino, Mambo and Flambé.

Which brings me on to a terribly sticky interiors issue. The one whispered in rarified design circles (particularly loudly when I arrived at Elle Deco after editing a young women's magazine two years ago): 'Does he/she Have Taste?' To Have Taste is good. To Not Have is to be cast on to the skip alongside cobalt-blue kitchen units, lime-green walls and block-paved patios. Where does it come from, this acceptability? For me, crunch time came the day after I'd been offered the editorship of Deco .

As we'd just moved house, rooms full of bare light bulbs needed shades. That day, in the Conran Shop, the pressure of making a decision was too much. 'If I choose this, I'm endorsing it for all the readers who buy my magazine.' That night, it became clear that to Have Taste was an abstract conceit. But the idea of living comfortably with something that makes you happy when you look at it and, on a good day, something that can feed, and even fulfil your dreams, that was much more feasible. And, of course, there was the sideshow of my husband muttering, 'It's a only a bloody light shade.'

Shortly after we'd settled into our new home, an architect acquaintance offered to give it (and us) the once-over. It was like taking part in a women's magazine quiz come to life. Her line of questioning: who does the cooking? Do you collect magazines? Do you like to relax together or apart? 'Together,' say I. 'Apart,' says Husband. Her solution? To punch a horizontal slit through a wall, connecting the kitchen to a reading room. I could be together, Husband could be apart. Her approach and the resulting plans were a revelation, and completely altered the way we use our space.

Sometimes, it seems that friends and readers let themselves be bullied by their homes. They're beaten into submission, living in the way they believe their Victorian builders intended them to. Where else in our lives do we live by the same rules as we did 100 years ago? Last week at lunch, a business acquaintance drew a sketch of her double-fronted home on a napkin, along with its proposed rear extension for a dining room. There seemed a more obvious solution: to shunt the kitchen to the front of the house into the unused drawing room and flow the space backwards on to the terrace and garden. 'But people don't have kitchens at the front_' she wailed. My advice? Exploit your home. Beat it into submission. Interrogate the spaces and work out how you want to live. Morph rooms into what suits you.

Serendipitously, my husband and I stumbled on a new way of looking at our own home. The dining room, with wood-burning stove, eight-seater table and chairs, flows into a south-facing living room (sofa, coffee table, etc). While we were decorating in December, the three-seater was hauled into the dining room and plonked in front of the wood burner.

Well. How cosy was that. Instead of the Saarinen Tulip chairs nigh on dissolving in the heat, we did. So a decision was made. Rooms would revert to their previous incarnations when the clocks changed. And next winter, when the nights get darker, we'll transpose the two again.

Which is kind of what makes being editor of Elle Decoration (and for that matter, any other homes magazine) so satisfying: all that access to the latest information on kitchens, bedrooms and bathrooms - and getting paid to think and explore, day in, day out, the latest and greatest ideas and instincts to enhance the space that affects us all most.

Which leads to the most oft-posed question in modern interiors, the one everyone wants an answer to: Which white is right? My own personal choice is China Cup by Crown. A white with the harsh edges rubbed off, subdued in a northern light, hazy and gauzy in full sun. Sir Terence chooses Dulux Orchard White, Nicole Farhi uses Papers and Paints Quiet White and architect Claudio Silvestrin just asks for a basic white matte. So you see, there's no correct answer. But if you choose what makes you happy, it'll be all white on the night.

fields.headline: Giving the game away
fields.standfirst: Soft play centres, ball pools, wave machines, disposable toys... should we be working harder at playing with our children?
fields.trailText: Soft play centres, ball pools, wave machines, disposable toys... should we be working harder at playing with our children?
fields.body:
The guilt crept up on me in an unlikely setting: a soft play centre in north London. If you've got children, you'll know the sort of place. If you've never visited one, imagine being inside a crazy digestive system with brilliantly coloured plastic intestines disgorging children in all directions. The air smells of socks and there are probably no windows. Parents are usually banned from joining in - and are visibly relieved, glad to be able to sit back and watch the children enjoy themselves in a safe environment.

So what was my problem? Why did I shudder to think of my children looking back on their childhood only to recall the Pirate Playhouse, off the Holloway Road? It wasn't that it pays only the most perfunctory, passing and plastic tribute to pirates. I've put it down to claustrophobia - and I don't just mean the airless atmosphere. Play itself has become stultified, because adults are policing children's play much more than they ever used to.

When I was a child, soft play centres didn't exist and parents didn't worry in the way they do now. We played out of sight, and were glad to be free. But now children are never out of our sight, and these centres offer parents a padded cell. Like hamsters in a cage, our children play obliviously on wheels and slides. Safety is what counts. But safety and imagination were never the best of friends.

Take the wave machine - a fairly recent innovation - to be found in modern indoor swimming pools. It's a perfect symbol of what's happening. Here comes the wave: it is regular, it is supervised, always the same height and fun to jump over - in a limited way. But it's nothing like the sea. For some children, these machines will be their only experience of waves. The sea is too dangerous, irregular and hard to supervise. It's like imagination.

Of course, soft play centres and indoor pools are convenient. This is partly the point. Play is structured now to make life easy for adults - often at children's expense. We have 'junk play' in the same way that we have junk food. It goes down a treat, but we all know it's second best.

Toys are the same, treated as if they were disposable - 'instant', even. Children play with them for a day - if you're lucky - then discard them. When I was a child, my toys were cherished and lasted for years. Today, there must be toy cupboards all over Britain full of plastic detritus, fallout from Christmas and birthdays.

Michael Rosen illustrates the problem in his poem 'Keith's Cupboard': In it/there's trucks, and garages, and tents/ and cranes and forts and bikes and puppets/and games, and models and superhero suits/and hats and/he never plays with any of it_ They keep buying him all this stuff/and he never plays with any of it.

German research suggests that children would do better if we stopped buying them all this stuff. I was reminded of this recently when my three-year-old twins played a game in which they wrapped up their despised old toys and presented them to each other. The toys were opened with joy and thanks, and the twins were obsessed with the game for a whole week The idea of the toy was far more interesting than the toy itself.

Some toys are so ugly it's no wonder that children reject them. But far more disturbing than any aesthetic concern is the content of the games on offer to them now, the problem being one of over-aggressive imagination management. Pokémon, for example, has been so comprehensively over-imagined by its creator that it leaves children powerless. And even the quality of this adult imagination is poor: it is violent and twee at the same time. Younger Pokémon collectors can do little with the cards other than stare at them, swap them or steal them.

And more keeps turning out to mean less. PlayStation and Nintendo games, for example, leave nothing to the imagination. At holiday villages such as Center Parcs, generally regarded as a paradise for children, everything is laid on. Theme parks are no better. Legoland, Chessington and Alton Towers offer a staggering variety of rides - and no need for children to think at all. They react with passive excitement (a very modern state), and parents are grateful: these places make everything so easy. But does anyone else, like me, watch their children experience an adult's hackneyed conception of wonderland, and regret that real magic has gone to ground?

fields.headline: The perfect... email
fields.trailText: Technology has always been about evasion. Telephones, televisions, videos, mobile phones, computers - all are designed to get you out of doing something undesirable. Email abrogates responsibility for your actions one step further
fields.body:
Technology has always been about evasion. Telephones, televisions, videos, mobile phones, computers - all are designed to get you out of doing something undesirable. Email abrogates responsibility for your actions one step further. If, for example, emails meant that someone walked into your office unannounced, uninvited, made a loud, trumpeting noise as they sat down in front of you on your desk, demanding that you hear all about the cup of coffee, sneeze, orgasm or email they simply have to tell you about, you might soon lose that sense of inquisitiveness that a You-have-mail notice manages to muster.

We live in an information age, where you can spend the entire day sending the person you share a bed with bits of binary information; where you can send detailed, intricate missives to people you once met on a beach, or be violated by round-robin emails to 400 people you've never met, with a great big 'thing' called an attachment stuck on the bottom, which refuses to behave normally and gives you the gag, information or virus that everyone else has emailed you delightedly about.

The email's miserable effect on our syntax has already begun. Already considered passé and, frankly, time-consuming are personal pronouns ('am not illiterate') and complete words like 'would' ('wd') or 'with' ('w/'). Emails will get ever-more frequent until the functional bugging of 'You got mail' signs is replaced by 'You got no mail, but that's OK, I still love you'. Welcome to the age of the solitary beep, where the perfect email will say - proclamations of love and lust aside - 'Can I come and talk to you, please?'

fields.headline: An insider's guide to...  betting
fields.trailText: Gambling is, by definition, not the safest activity with which to while away your afternoons. For starters, there's the unsavoury types you're likely to meet, wolfing Quavers and Special Brew in the betting shop at 11am
fields.body:
Gambling is, by definition, not the safest activity with which to while away your afternoons. For starters, there's the unsavoury types you're likely to meet, wolfing Quavers and Special Brew in the betting shop at 11am. Then there's addiction, debt, and, more threateningly, what you'll do to yourself with the money if you win big.

Take a few pointers from the experts. First, if you're going to bet for money as opposed to exhilaration, think about tax. If you bet online, there is no tax. If you bet off-shore, you'll be charged a commission. At a betting shop, there's a 9 per cent tariff. Always pay your tax before you place your bet - ie, as part of your wager - or you might end up with a massive sum to pay if you win. Place your bet as early as possible, and make sure that your slip is written clearly. Write either the name or the number of the party you're backing, and only one - since if you get either one wrong, your bet may be discounted. Everything is doublechecked by a security camera, so cheating is pretty hard work.

Bet on something only you know a lot about - like yourself losing weight. This, William Hill reckons, is the best chance you have of winning any money. 'You're second to bookies who make it their business to have as much information as possible available to them.' Read up on the game on the net, Teletext and in the papers. Don't always back the favourite: if they won every time, then the bookies, no matter the sport, would be redundant.

The Independent Betting Advisory Service (IBAS) has a few pointers. 'Punters need to be aware of the house rules, particularly when they're dealing with first-goal bets. Different shops have different concepts of what the rules are - and every shop should have them on display. In the rare event of them not doing so, ask.

Over the past year, out of millions of bets placed, only 600 have been the cause of complaints to IBAS. So maybe the bookies are more reputable than we give them credit for. And also be sure to enjoy it - consider the money you spend as gone, and then take heart in William Hill's incredible statistic that, out of every £1 gambled in a betting shop around the country, more than 80p returns to the punter.

fields.headline: Show girl
fields.standfirst: Evita,  Cats,  Piaf,  Sunset Boulevard. Elaine Paige has been our greatest musical star for the past 20 years, but she's never sung Rodgers and Hammerstein. Here she talks to Lynn Barber about  The King and I, singing in the nude and turning into Julie Andrews
fields.trailText: Evita,  Cats,  Piaf,  Sunset Boulevard. Elaine Paige has been our greatest musical star for the past 20 years, but she's never sung Rodgers and Hammerstein. Here she talks to Lynn Barber about  The King and I, singing in the nude and turning into Julie Andrews
fields.body:
The news that Elaine Paige is about to star in The King and I had me hyperventilating into a paper bag for some time. Elaine Paige singing Rodgers and Hammerstein - how can I put this? [Keep calm; control urge to gibber; count to 10.] I am very happy to concede that Elaine Paige is one of the greatest interpreters of Andrew Lloyd Webber ever born. Everyone agrees that her Evita was a triumph and Mark Steyn says she is by far the best of all the Norma Desmonds he's seen. I know for a fact that there are many people who can listen to her rendition of 'Memory' from Cats not only without earplugs but with positive pleasure. Fine, by all means give her that. Elaine Paige belting out Andrew Lloyd Webber, no probs, tickety-boo, take it away, Elaine.

But Rodgers and Hammerstein - we are talking sacred ground here. Admittedly, The King and I is not the greatest of their musicals, but it has, at the very least, charm and grace and lyricism and a light touch and all the things one doesn't readily associate with Andrew Lloyd Webber. Or indeed with Elaine Paige.

Thus my first question to Elaine Paige about how it felt to sing Rodgers and Hammerstein after all those years singing Andrew Lloyd Webber came through gritted teeth. If she'd said it seemed a bit boring, I might have had to bite her. But actually her answer gave me hope: 'I find it more difficult. It's more formal. I keep thinking I'm sounding like Julie Andrews - I'm sure I'm not - but one has to be more conscious of the vowel sounds and singing, as well as speaking, in Received English. And musically, it's much more lyrical. The tunes sweep about more. You know that a woman has a break in her voice - you have a chest register and then you go over the break and you're up in the soprano or mezzo-soprano area, so one is having to negotiate that much more.

'And it's a quieter kind of singing, more controlled, not belting it out. There are moments where I feel I want to sing out, but in a different way. So it's all proving rather a challenge, really, but I'm enjoying it.'

Passed with flying colours - I almost want to hug her. I never expected to like her at all - she has quite a reputation for being difficult and once told a male interviewer that she would no longer give interviews to female journalists because 'I don't trust other women in these situations. They establish a sisterhood with you and then betray it every time.' But actually I found her chatty, friendly, good humoured. She knows she's not the brightest cookie in the jar - she failed her 11-plus, went to secondary modern and then to stage school - but she seems to have her head screwed on. Tim Rice, in his autobiography, talked about her 'strange combination of sparky confidence and self- deprecating modesty', and that seems accurate - one minute she is being the star, the next she is little miss ordinary from Barnet. I think the thing is, she knows what she knows. She is confident when she talks about singing and stagecraft, surprisingly diffident when it comes to anything outside her field.

She is, I suppose, the nearest we have to a great British musical star, since the other great British musical star, Julie Andrews, shoved off to the States several decades ago. And her apartment is satisfyingly starry, with glorious views of the Thames, and lots of black lacquer and leopardskin furniture, and a Yamaha grand piano and acres of bare wooden floor on which, she says, she practises her polka for The King and I in the nude every morning. There are no books in sight, but tons of those peculiar awards and trophies that stars accumulate - heart-shaped ones from the Variety Club and a rather pretty abstract from the Chickenshed children's charity for 'inspiration' - and rows of silver-framed photographs of her meeting the Queen, the Queen Mother, Michael Caine, Roger Moore, Peter Hall, Freddie Mercury, and so on. There is a photograph of her sister and her niece. But, of course, no wedding shots, no children, because Elaine Paige is still, at 52, a spinster of this parish.

I hadn't thought till I read Elaine Paige's cuttings what a very odd job being a musical star is. I kept thinking: where's the career? How can someone be so well known on the basis of so few roles? She made her West End debut in Hair in 1969 and had minor roles in Jesus Christ Superstar , Grease and Billy ; she became a star with Evita in 1978; then she did Cats in 1983, Chess in 1986, Anything Goes in 1989, Piaf in 1993, and took over from Betty Buckley in Sunset Boulevard in 1994. But that's it - fewer than a dozen roles. But Andrew Lloyd Webber told her that Mary Martin was a star on the basis of only three roles, and she feels she's had her fair share.

Her last singing role in Britain was in Sunset Boulevard in 1995, then she appeared in a straight play, Le Misanthrope , in 1998. But since then she's been 'resting', doing the odd concert here and there, and recording an album, currently on hold. Two years ago, she seemed to imply she was giving up musicals for good - 'I feel I've got nothing left to prove where musicals are concerned' - and said she was going to concentrate on straight theatre. She often says that she regards herself as an actress first and a singer second, though you wouldn't suspect it from reading her CV. But she admits that when she did Le Misanthrope , 'I did miss the music a bit - but only in the wings, when I was waiting to go on. It seemed dreadfully quiet, rather unnerving. But the wonderful thing was that one didn't have to be quite so obsessive about one's health, and one's voice.'

So when the idea of The King and I was first mooted, she turned it down. But her agent told her to have a look at it, listen to the music, read the play - she only dimly recollected having seen the film with Deborah Kerr and Yul Brynner decades ago. 'So I thought: "Oh all right, just to keep him quiet, I will", and I played the Broadway album and I had forgotten what a fantastic score it was. I mean, each song, one after the other - you go, "Oh gosh, is that in it?" "Oh, that's a good one!" So I was sitting there thinking: "Crikey, this is a jolly good score", and then I read the play - and I hate reading plays, it's so boring usually. But I started reading, and I got quicker and quicker because it was really holding my attention. It is the most wonderful story, and by the end I was in floods of tears, it's so sad. And I was rather shocked at my own response, and I thought: "I think I really would rather love to do this."'

She has signed up to do The King and I for a year, though with a get-out clause after nine months. She didn't really want to commit for so long, but having been a producer herself (she co-produced Anything Goes with Tim Rice in 1989), she is aware of the costs of staging a big musical and the amount of time it takes to break even. 'It's a very luscious, beautifully designed show with a huge cast, so the outlay is enormous - I think it's £4 or £5 million. Not that that's my problem, but I am aware of it. And also, you know, I think: "Well if you're going to do it, give it a bash."'

But once before, she signed up for a year and then had to drop out. This was in 1993, with Piaf - a very demanding piece, by Pam Gems, in which she was onstage for two hours 40 minutes, acting Edith Piaf from age 16 to her death, and singing 15 songs, some in French, which she had to learn phonetically. It was a great critical triumph and upped her acting credibility several notches, but in the end it drove her to breakdown. 'Oh, it was awful, and I vowed to myself I would never, ever push myself to the edge that much again. It was really frightening. Because absolutely everything seemed to be impossible to deal with, just little things became major - noise, if someone had a radio on, or even the sound of traffic, or being in someone's company for longer than 10 minutes - I started to find it all too much.'

Eventually she turned up at Champneys one weekend - she was in the habit of going there straight after the Saturday performance and sleeping through till Monday - and burst into tears. 'And I could not stop. There was no real reason to weep, but I was just so tired. And the nursing staff said, "We really think we should call your doctor", and he came out there to see me and said, "You're not going back. You're absolutely exhausted and you've got to stop, otherwise you will be seriously ill." So basically that was it. It was the most terrible, terrible time. I'm not a person that gives in. I consider myself to be quite a sturdy person; I'm not a quitter. So there was an awful guilt attached to it - but I knew he was right, because I couldn't walk I was so tired. I've never known an experience like that ever, before or since. And I don't intend to ever go there again. I learned then that I would have to re-evaluate things and balance my life better.'

So she rested for a few months and then, by another of these odd happenstances that seem to be part of her career, she was asked to take over in Sunset Boulevard when Betty Buckley was ill. But wasn't she rather miffed not to get Sunset Boulevard in the first place? She actually sang a song from it before anyone else - Lloyd Webber rang her just before his marriage to Madeleine in 1991 and said he'd written this brilliant song and could she sing it at his wedding? It was 'With One Look', though at that time it was called 'Just One Glance'. So she sang it at the wedding and then, she claims, forgot about it.

But why didn't she ask him what show the song was intended for - why didn't she clamour for the role? 'I suppose I could have done. I was foolish. It didn't enter my head. I'm not particularly pushy that way - you'd have to be pretty eye to the main chance, to do that. It's a bit daft of me in retrospect. But - dumb dumb dumb - I don't behave like that. I mean, he must have known what he was writing, and one would have liked to imagine that if he thought I was suitable for the role he would have asked me to play it - but maybe that's not always the case.' Or maybe you were meant to be begging for it? 'Lynn!' - and she laughs her strange dirty cackle - 'you could have just turned me on to a new way of getting some meaty roles for myself!'

Whatever - she had to sit through the first night of Sunset Boulevard thinking: 'I would love to play this part' but never dreaming she would be asked to. And then Betty Buckley had to have an operation and Lloyd Webber asked her to take over. 'It was not long after the Piaf experience, and I remember thinking, "Oh, all those stairs !" Which is ludicrous, really, because one does not judge whether you take a musical role on the basis of how many stairs you have to climb - though there were an awful lot! But that first night, yes, I thought: "This is a role I would love to play", so I'm glad that I did in the end and had such a personal success with it.'

She filled in for Betty Buckley for a few weeks in 1994, then took over the role properly in 1995, had a successful run in London, and then finally played it in New York, breaking what had seemed like an 18-year jinx on her ever getting to Broadway. She first hoped to go with Evita , in 1978, then with Cats , then with Chess , but each time her hopes were raised, only to be dashed. Anyway, Broadway fully lived up to her expectations. 'And more! I thought: "Gosh, it really has been worth the wait." And I think had I gone with Evita , I probably wouldn't have been ready to deal with it. It was just the most perfect time to go with that particular show.'

She played Norma Desmond for nine months, then stayed on in New York enjoying herself and going to all the plays and parties and 'really living the glamorous New York theatre life'. But eventually she got homesick for her English friends and family and came back. She sold her five-storey house in Chelsea - all those stairs! - and bought her present apartment. 'I said, "I'm going to take six months off, I'm going to travel, go to the theatre, see my friends, have dinner parties, lead a real, normal life, have a few glasses of wine when I feel like it" - because obviously when I'm singing I can't drink. And everyone said to me, "Oh, you'll get fed up in three weeks, you'll be bored." And I said, "I don't think so." And I wasn't. And, in fact, at the end of the six months, I thought: "To hell with it, I'll take another six months off." So basically I had a year's sabbatical, and it was wonderful.'

But she still dithers about whether to stay in England, and says she might go back to New York when she finishes in The King and I . 'I do love it over there - I feel a different person when I'm in America. I love the energy, and it seems easier to gather people up at the last minute and say, "Let's go rollerblading in the park" - I had lots of friends that I could sort of play with over there. And there's a sense of freedom that somehow I don't seem to have here. I can't quite put it into words, but I think you're allowed to be whoever you want to be over there, and there isn't the class thing.'

She often mentions 'the class thing' and complains that the English are generally snobbish about musical theatre, and perhaps extra snobbish about her. She told the Daily Mail a couple of years ago: 'I've never played the game socially, never pretended to be something I'm not.' I guess she is mystified - as I am, slightly - by the number of articles that refer to her as 'suburban'. Of course she does come from the suburbs - she grew up in Barnet, north London, where her father was an estate agent.

But then loads of actresses, singers, writers, not to mention yours truly, come from the suburbs without being eternally branded as suburban. I think it has more to do with aspirations and taste than with geographical or class origins, and in that sense I suppose Elaine Paige is suburban. She is relentlessly middlebrow, commonsensical, down to earth, intellectually incurious. She doesn't read. She told me that in her teens her music teacher tried to interest her in opera and suggested she would be good in Mozart, 'but I thought it was rather an elite world that somebody from my background wouldn't go into. It's odd, isn't it, when you look back on your life and think, "What would have happened had I made that choice? I could have ended up down a completely different road."'

Yup - maybe she could have, though she's not weeping buckets over the thought that she might have been Kiri Te Kanawa. She told me that she'd been to hear Rene Fleming sing Rosenkavalier the other night and 'it was wonderful, but I made a note of what time she started singing - it was an hour and a quarter, that first act, and she does not stop , and I just thought, "Crikey, it would take me a week to recover from this."'

It is typical of her to think of the work rather than the art. She makes her job sound like working at the coalface. She goes into training beforehand - gives up drink and dairy products (she gave up smoking some time ago) - concentrates on keeping fit and sleeping a lot. At the beginning of a run, she says, she can sometimes have lunch with friends, but after a few months, when her voice is beginning to tire, she gives up social life completely and sometimes has to give up speaking, communicating only by notepad and fax.

She admits, 'When you asked how long I'd be doing The King and I , and I said a year, I thought, "Omigod, it sounds like a prison sentence" - you know it's going to encroach on your entire life. You go into a sort of athletic mode where you try and become superfit and stay that way, because what it really amounts to, doing this kind of work, is stamina. And so one becomes, or I become, anyway, slightly obsessive, particularly about my health, because you wouldn't want to read the letters people write when you're off and they're disappointed - it's so awful, the guilt one feels for not being there.

'This is the difference between acting in a play and singing in a musical - your voice becomes everything. The first thing you do in the morning is sing a few notes to see how you are - the voice is a very fragile thing, and it alters with the weather. fields.bodyText: The news that Elaine Paige is about to star in The King and I had me hyperventilating into a paper bag for some time. Elaine Paige singing Rodgers and Hammerstein - how can I put this? [Keep calm; control urge to gibber; count to 10.] I am very happy to concede that Elaine Paige is one of the greatest interpreters of Andrew Lloyd Webber ever born. Everyone agrees that her Evita was a triumph and Mark Steyn says she is by far the best of all the Norma Desmonds he's seen. I know for a fact that there are many people who can listen to her rendition of 'Memory' from Cats not only without earplugs but with positive pleasure. Fine, by all means give her that. Elaine Paige belting out Andrew Lloyd Webber, no probs, tickety-boo, take it away, Elaine. But Rodgers and Hammerstein - we are talking sacred ground here. Admittedly, The King and I is not the greatest of their musicals, but it has, at the very least, charm and grace and lyricism and a light touch and all the things one doesn't readily associate with Andrew Lloyd Webber. Or indeed with Elaine Paige. Thus my first question to Elaine Paige about how it felt to sing Rodgers and Hammerstein after all those years singing Andrew Lloyd Webber came through gritted teeth. If she'd said it seemed a bit boring, I might have had to bite her. But actually her answer gave me hope: 'I find it more difficult. It's more formal. I keep thinking I'm sounding like Julie Andrews - I'm sure I'm not - but one has to be more conscious of the vowel sounds and singing, as well as speaking, in Received English. And musically, it's much more lyrical. The tunes sweep about more. You know that a woman has a break in her voice - you have a chest register and then you go over the break and you're up in the soprano or mezzo-soprano area, so one is having to negotiate that much more. 'And it's a quieter kind of singing, more controlled, not belting it out. There are moments where I feel I want to sing out, but in a different way. So it's all proving rather a challenge, really, but I'm enjoying it.' Passed with flying colours - I almost want to hug her. I never expected to like her at all - she has quite a reputation for being difficult and once told a male interviewer that she would no longer give interviews to female journalists because 'I don't trust other women in these situations. They establish a sisterhood with you and then betray it every time.' But actually I found her chatty, friendly, good humoured. She knows she's not the brightest cookie in the jar - she failed her 11-plus, went to secondary modern and then to stage school - but she seems to have her head screwed on. Tim Rice, in his autobiography, talked about her 'strange combination of sparky confidence and self- deprecating modesty', and that seems accurate - one minute she is being the star, the next she is little miss ordinary from Barnet. I think the thing is, she knows what she knows. She is confident when she talks about singing and stagecraft, surprisingly diffident when it comes to anything outside her field. She is, I suppose, the nearest we have to a great British musical star, since the other great British musical star, Julie Andrews, shoved off to the States several decades ago. And her apartment is satisfyingly starry, with glorious views of the Thames, and lots of black lacquer and leopardskin furniture, and a Yamaha grand piano and acres of bare wooden floor on which, she says, she practises her polka for The King and I in the nude every morning. There are no books in sight, but tons of those peculiar awards and trophies that stars accumulate - heart-shaped ones from the Variety Club and a rather pretty abstract from the Chickenshed children's charity for 'inspiration' - and rows of silver-framed photographs of her meeting the Queen, the Queen Mother, Michael Caine, Roger Moore, Peter Hall, Freddie Mercury, and so on. There is a photograph of her sister and her niece. But, of course, no wedding shots, no children, because Elaine Paige is still, at 52, a spinster of this parish. I hadn't thought till I read Elaine Paige's cuttings what a very odd job being a musical star is. I kept thinking: where's the career? How can someone be so well known on the basis of so few roles? She made her West End debut in Hair in 1969 and had minor roles in Jesus Christ Superstar , Grease and Billy ; she became a star with Evita in 1978; then she did Cats in 1983, Chess in 1986, Anything Goes in 1989, Piaf in 1993, and took over from Betty Buckley in Sunset Boulevard in 1994. But that's it - fewer than a dozen roles. But Andrew Lloyd Webber told her that Mary Martin was a star on the basis of only three roles, and she feels she's had her fair share. Her last singing role in Britain was in Sunset Boulevard in 1995, then she appeared in a straight play, Le Misanthrope , in 1998. But since then she's been 'resting', doing the odd concert here and there, and recording an album, currently on hold. Two years ago, she seemed to imply she was giving up musicals for good - 'I feel I've got nothing left to prove where musicals are concerned' - and said she was going to concentrate on straight theatre. She often says that she regards herself as an actress first and a singer second, though you wouldn't suspect it from reading her CV. But she admits that when she did Le Misanthrope , 'I did miss the music a bit - but only in the wings, when I was waiting to go on. It seemed dreadfully quiet, rather unnerving. But the wonderful thing was that one didn't have to be quite so obsessive about one's health, and one's voice.' So when the idea of The King and I was first mooted, she turned it down. But her agent told her to have a look at it, listen to the music, read the play - she only dimly recollected having seen the film with Deborah Kerr and Yul Brynner decades ago. 'So I thought: "Oh all right, just to keep him quiet, I will", and I played the Broadway album and I had forgotten what a fantastic score it was. I mean, each song, one after the other - you go, "Oh gosh, is that in it?" "Oh, that's a good one!" So I was sitting there thinking: "Crikey, this is a jolly good score", and then I read the play - and I hate reading plays, it's so boring usually. But I started reading, and I got quicker and quicker because it was really holding my attention. It is the most wonderful story, and by the end I was in floods of tears, it's so sad. And I was rather shocked at my own response, and I thought: "I think I really would rather love to do this."' She has signed up to do The King and I for a year, though with a get-out clause after nine months. She didn't really want to commit for so long, but having been a producer herself (she co-produced Anything Goes with Tim Rice in 1989), she is aware of the costs of staging a big musical and the amount of time it takes to break even. 'It's a very luscious, beautifully designed show with a huge cast, so the outlay is enormous - I think it's £4 or £5 million. Not that that's my problem, but I am aware of it. And also, you know, I think: "Well if you're going to do it, give it a bash."' But once before, she signed up for a year and then had to drop out. This was in 1993, with Piaf - a very demanding piece, by Pam Gems, in which she was onstage for two hours 40 minutes, acting Edith Piaf from age 16 to her death, and singing 15 songs, some in French, which she had to learn phonetically. It was a great critical triumph and upped her acting credibility several notches, but in the end it drove her to breakdown. 'Oh, it was awful, and I vowed to myself I would never, ever push myself to the edge that much again. It was really frightening. Because absolutely everything seemed to be impossible to deal with, just little things became major - noise, if someone had a radio on, or even the sound of traffic, or being in someone's company for longer than 10 minutes - I started to find it all too much.' Eventually she turned up at Champneys one weekend - she was in the habit of going there straight after the Saturday performance and sleeping through till Monday - and burst into tears. 'And I could not stop. There was no real reason to weep, but I was just so tired. And the nursing staff said, "We really think we should call your doctor", and he came out there to see me and said, "You're not going back. You're absolutely exhausted and you've got to stop, otherwise you will be seriously ill." So basically that was it. It was the most terrible, terrible time. I'm not a person that gives in. I consider myself to be quite a sturdy person; I'm not a quitter. So there was an awful guilt attached to it - but I knew he was right, because I couldn't walk I was so tired. I've never known an experience like that ever, before or since. And I don't intend to ever go there again. I learned then that I would have to re-evaluate things and balance my life better.' So she rested for a few months and then, by another of these odd happenstances that seem to be part of her career, she was asked to take over in Sunset Boulevard when Betty Buckley was ill. But wasn't she rather miffed not to get Sunset Boulevard in the first place? She actually sang a song from it before anyone else - Lloyd Webber rang her just before his marriage to Madeleine in 1991 and said he'd written this brilliant song and could she sing it at his wedding? It was 'With One Look', though at that time it was called 'Just One Glance'. So she sang it at the wedding and then, she claims, forgot about it. But why didn't she ask him what show the song was intended for - why didn't she clamour for the role? 'I suppose I could have done. I was foolish. It didn't enter my head. I'm not particularly pushy that way - you'd have to be pretty eye to the main chance, to do that. It's a bit daft of me in retrospect. But - dumb dumb dumb - I don't behave like that. I mean, he must have known what he was writing, and one would have liked to imagine that if he thought I was suitable for the role he would have asked me to play it - but maybe that's not always the case.' Or maybe you were meant to be begging for it? 'Lynn!' - and she laughs her strange dirty cackle - 'you could have just turned me on to a new way of getting some meaty roles for myself!' Whatever - she had to sit through the first night of Sunset Boulevard thinking: 'I would love to play this part' but never dreaming she would be asked to. And then Betty Buckley had to have an operation and Lloyd Webber asked her to take over. 'It was not long after the Piaf experience, and I remember thinking, "Oh, all those stairs !" Which is ludicrous, really, because one does not judge whether you take a musical role on the basis of how many stairs you have to climb - though there were an awful lot! But that first night, yes, I thought: "This is a role I would love to play", so I'm glad that I did in the end and had such a personal success with it.' She filled in for Betty Buckley for a few weeks in 1994, then took over the role properly in 1995, had a successful run in London, and then finally played it in New York, breaking what had seemed like an 18-year jinx on her ever getting to Broadway. She first hoped to go with Evita , in 1978, then with Cats , then with Chess , but each time her hopes were raised, only to be dashed. Anyway, Broadway fully lived up to her expectations. 'And more! I thought: "Gosh, it really has been worth the wait." And I think had I gone with Evita , I probably wouldn't have been ready to deal with it. It was just the most perfect time to go with that particular show.' She played Norma Desmond for nine months, then stayed on in New York enjoying herself and going to all the plays and parties and 'really living the glamorous New York theatre life'. But eventually she got homesick for her English friends and family and came back. She sold her five-storey house in Chelsea - all those stairs! - and bought her present apartment. 'I said, "I'm going to take six months off, I'm going to travel, go to the theatre, see my friends, have dinner parties, lead a real, normal life, have a few glasses of wine when I feel like it" - because obviously when I'm singing I can't drink. And everyone said to me, "Oh, you'll get fed up in three weeks, you'll be bored." And I said, "I don't think so." And I wasn't. And, in fact, at the end of the six months, I thought: "To hell with it, I'll take another six months off." So basically I had a year's sabbatical, and it was wonderful.' But she still dithers about whether to stay in England, and says she might go back to New York when she finishes in The King and I . 'I do love it over there - I feel a different person when I'm in America. I love the energy, and it seems easier to gather people up at the last minute and say, "Let's go rollerblading in the park" - I had lots of friends that I could sort of play with over there. And there's a sense of freedom that somehow I don't seem to have here. I can't quite put it into words, but I think you're allowed to be whoever you want to be over there, and there isn't the class thing.' She often mentions 'the class thing' and complains that the English are generally snobbish about musical theatre, and perhaps extra snobbish about her. She told the Daily Mail a couple of years ago: 'I've never played the game socially, never pretended to be something I'm not.' I guess she is mystified - as I am, slightly - by the number of articles that refer to her as 'suburban'. Of course she does come from the suburbs - she grew up in Barnet, north London, where her father was an estate agent. But then loads of actresses, singers, writers, not to mention yours truly, come from the suburbs without being eternally branded as suburban. I think it has more to do with aspirations and taste than with geographical or class origins, and in that sense I suppose Elaine Paige is suburban. She is relentlessly middlebrow, commonsensical, down to earth, intellectually incurious. She doesn't read. She told me that in her teens her music teacher tried to interest her in opera and suggested she would be good in Mozart, 'but I thought it was rather an elite world that somebody from my background wouldn't go into. It's odd, isn't it, when you look back on your life and think, "What would have happened had I made that choice? I could have ended up down a completely different road."' Yup - maybe she could have, though she's not weeping buckets over the thought that she might have been Kiri Te Kanawa. She told me that she'd been to hear Rene Fleming sing Rosenkavalier the other night and 'it was wonderful, but I made a note of what time she started singing - it was an hour and a quarter, that first act, and she does not stop , and I just thought, "Crikey, it would take me a week to recover from this."' It is typical of her to think of the work rather than the art. She makes her job sound like working at the coalface. She goes into training beforehand - gives up drink and dairy products (she gave up smoking some time ago) - concentrates on keeping fit and sleeping a lot. At the beginning of a run, she says, she can sometimes have lunch with friends, but after a few months, when her voice is beginning to tire, she gives up social life completely and sometimes has to give up speaking, communicating only by notepad and fax. She admits, 'When you asked how long I'd be doing The King and I , and I said a year, I thought, "Omigod, it sounds like a prison sentence" - you know it's going to encroach on your entire life. You go into a sort of athletic mode where you try and become superfit and stay that way, because what it really amounts to, doing this kind of work, is stamina. And so one becomes, or I become, anyway, slightly obsessive, particularly about my health, because you wouldn't want to read the letters people write when you're off and they're disappointed - it's so awful, the guilt one feels for not being there.
