fields.headline: Fast forward
fields.standfirst: This week: Mars
fields.trailText: The loafer's guide to popular culture.  This week: Mars
fields.body:
Pretty cold up there, isn't it? Quite the opposite, actually. Tim Robbins starrer Mission to Mars entered multiplex orbit on Friday, Courtney Love has just announced that she is to play a space cop in John Carpenter's Ghosts of Mars and with similar sci-fi spectaculars Red Plane t and James ' Titanic ' Cameron's Mars IMAX also set for imminent blastoff, it's red hot. All the same, best bring a woolly if you're planning a day trip.

Any chance of finding intelligent life? Critical response says Mission to Mars ' thoughtful script, A-list cast of 'serious' thesps and 2001 -esque style reclaim the sci-fi genre from the Bug-Eyed Monster brigade that sucked us into creative black holes like Independence Day and The Phantom Menace . But with plenty of big-budget action and special effects supplying forward thrust, the pre-angst set find its inexorable G-force pins their bums to seats just the same.

Why is Mars suddenly the planetary plat du jour, then? No more Cold War, no offending irascible foreign governments and PC all dictate that, as far as mainstream movies go, general bad guy-ism and mysterious threats to truth, justice and the American way shall hail from no closer than the Van Allen Belt, at least. Where, so far as scientists have thus far ascertained, nobody gets a trade-embargo-inducing bee in their green bonnet when you razz 'em. Oh. And it's pretty astounding visually, too.

So the Yanks are ahead in the Space Race again? Not necessarily. Mission to Mars takes itself fairly seriously, but the Hollywood flag-waving that marred Apollo 13 is implicit here also. The fact that real-life astronaut hero Story Musgrave pops up as a crew member sweetens the pill, but it's Red Planet that snatches the good-taste laurels by bundling erstwhile Brit Beautiful Person Terence Stamp on board.

As if you'd ever find a groovy Brit on a Mars mission. Well, maybe not actually piloting the crate. Dear old Blighty is stealing a march on our colonial cousins in the race to our nearest neighbour, though. The all-British Beagle 2 space probe promises unparalleled observational capability, and is firmly on course for its 2003 launch.

Highest-profile publicists and financiers of said project? No less a pair than Britpop baronets Alex James and Dave Rowntree from Blur.

webTitle: Ads alone won't kindle our faith in trusts

fields.headline: Ads alone won't kindle our faith in trusts
fields.trailText: Investment trusts have pulled off a 'miraculous turnaround in fortunes', according to Daniel Godfrey, director-general of the industry body, the Association of Investment Trust Companies.
fields.body:
Investment trusts have pulled off a 'miraculous turnaround in fortunes', according to Daniel Godfrey, director-general of the industry body, the Association of Investment Trust Companies.

The figures do look encouraging. Since the AITC launched the 'its' generic advertising campaign last October, shares in investment trust companies have risen by almost 20 per cent, ahead of the rest of the market. The average discount - that seemingly intractable problem of trusts' share prices standing at less than the value of their underlying assets - has dropped from 10.7 per cent to 8.4 per cent.

But look at the kind of trusts which should have been the biggest beneficiaries of the campaign - the large generalist trusts and the income funds which particularly appeal to private investors. Here the results look rather different. The average discount on the international generalists, which include such stalwarts as Foreign & Colonial, has risen from 13.1 per cent to 16.5 per cent, while UK income trusts have seen their discounts rise from 9 to 15 per cent.

Alliance Trust, one of the biggest generalists, now stands at a 22 per cent discount, close to its all-time high. The good performers have been in areas such as small companies - which, driven by their technology exposure, have risen by as much as 70 per cent - and European funds, up an average of 40 per cent. The good performance of the sector has had little to do with the AITC and everything to do with the market's obsession with technology funds.

To be fair to the AITC, six months is too soon to judge the success of any campaign - particularly when investors have spent much of those six months so obsessed with technology and media stocks.

If discounts have not narrowed substantially in a year's time, the industry will once again be facing questions about its future. Godfrey points to the increase in public awareness of investment trusts and the record inflow into savings schemes. If these investments disappoint, that money will flow out again.

The generalists need to do more than simply rely on the AITC's campaign. They should be more aggressive in buying back their shares, which does improve performance. But as Andrew Bell, investment trust analyst at CSFB, points out, the pace of buy-backs has been slowing since last summer, perhaps because the trusts were hoping the advertising campaign on its own would do the trick. It will not.

Most of the large generalists have the power to buy back their shares. These powers have been little used.

Individual trusts are realising that they need to com plement the industry's campaign, so there is a chance performance will improve over the next year. For long-term investors, some of the large generalists - Alliance Trust, Scottish American and Monks, for example - look very attractive at these discount levels.

 Heather Connon holds shares in Alliance Trust.

webTitle: Fair ways to value my Golf

fields.headline: Fair ways to value my Golf
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I bought an M-registered VW Golf for £8,500. Six weeks later, I was involved in an accident on the M20 late at night. I had to swerve to avoid a car facing me in the middle lane. A van also swerved and wrote my car off on the hard shoulder.

My insurer, Admiral, offered me £6,100, then £6,700 when I complained. From this, they deduct my excess and £552 outstanding premium. Now they refuse to recover costs incurred since I disputed this payment.

They have devalued my car by £1,800 in six weeks but say £6,700 is the top figure from Glass's Guide. I thought I was lucky to find a Golf at the price I did.
RB, London

 Admiral says it will check again if you can produce evidence that £8,500 was the right price. Ask the showroom for a letter confirming why you paid that amount and check for similar prices with other garages, your local paper and car magazines. Ask Admiral where they think you can buy a comparable car for £6,700.

If you can convince Admiral, it should reclaim all your outgoings from the other side. But if you can't, the company can refuse your later costs, fearing the other insurer will not reimburse 'unnecessary' costs.

Pension transfer: Sky-high charge

I want to move a pension I bought from Lincoln Financial Group in April 1993 into a small self-administered pension. I was shocked to find that Lincoln will charge £10,917 to transfer a fund worth £18,356, that is 60 per cent. My financial adviser has told me that even the 40 per cent is likely to achieve a better return than if I left the whole fund with Lincoln.
GT, Chichester

 This is an astronomical charge, but Lincoln claims it is typical of policies sold in the early 1990s.

You have been hit on several sides. Your premiums throughout the first year bought 'capital' units, which have extra high annual charges of 6.75 per cent. You subsequently receive 'accumulation' units, at 0.75 per cent, but continue to pay 6.75 per cent on the capital units every year for the life of the policy. This is how the company recoups its set-up costs.

When, in 1996, you reduced your premiums, you already had enough capital units to cover the charges for the larger policy, and you will continue to pay the higher price.

Then there is a severe sliding-scale penalty for cancelling the policy within 10 years. Capital units recover the set-up charges over the life of the policy; if you cash in early, you have to repay the outstanding amount in a lump sum, which effectively wipes out all the money you paid in premiums in the first year.

This month, you passed the seventh anniversary, and the surrender penalty dropped from 40 per cent to 30 per cent, so the transfer value is now £8,834 instead of £7,946. If this had been the 10th anniversary - when the penalty disappears - Lincoln says the value would, with investment growth, be £13,500.

Your adviser may have overlooked the impact of cancelling within 10 years. If you wait three years, you will automatically get 30 per cent more than today, although you may still be better off transferring to a cheaper pension provider.

Unless Lincoln offered you compensation, which it has not, you are stuck with these fees. You could ask the original salesman to justify choosing this company in the first place.

On 17 February, I bought 200 BT shares at £10 each via the HSBC branch sharedealing service. On 13 March, with the shares at £13, I tried to sell through the same route but the bank refused because I had not yet received the sha

ificate.

I anticipated a £600 gain on 3 March but was locked in to this purchase, even though it is impossible to pass a day without bumping into reference to the stunning speed of stock trading nowadays. Has HSBC failed to make the transition to the 21st century, or was I misinformed?
PP, London

 Whatever the Stock Exchange does, you are dependent on your stockbroker's procedures. HSBC says it works to a 10-day cycle, which means it takes 10 working days after you buy for the deal to be registered, and another four days to produce the certificate. So HSBC expects to take three weeks to deliver the certificate before you can sell. Nominee accounts are quicker, but HSBC does not offer them.

Visa points: Use-by date

I have had a GM Visa card for several years, the attraction being Rebate Points towards a Vauxhall car. Recently I noticed that my accumulated points are being reduced each month. The company said there is an 'ageing off' process whereby after a certain time unused points are deducted. I suppose this proviso was hidden somewhere in the small print in the initial rules.
JM, Fortrose

 It was. GM reckons most people replace a car every three or four years, so decided to cancel points after five years to avoid, it says, creating an unlimited liability.

webTitle: Need for a rethink on post office closures

fields.headline: Need for a rethink on post office closures
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The future of sub-post offices is now under threat from government plans to encourage pensioners and recipients of benefits to have these paid directly into bank accounts.
fields.body:
The government and high street banks have been busy promoting the role that post offices can play in offering services once supplied by bank branches. Banks are busily doing deals with them to plug the gaps that have so angered customers, especially in rural areas. But even this may not be the answer. The future of sub-post offices is now under threat from government plans to encourage pensioners and recipients of benefits to have these paid directly into bank accounts. Since benefits payments represent about 40 per cent of the work carried out by sub-post offices, it is not hard to see why these small businesses are concerned. The Government needs to retrace its steps on this issue. In rural areas, pensioners and benefit recipients may get their money paid into a bank account only to find that there is no branch and no post office either from which to withdraw their money.

To many, £100,000 still seems a hefty sum of money. But it is a mere speck on the horizon when it comes to investment, as anyone trying to live off savings during retirement will know. A pension fund of this size is too small, according to the most knowledgeable advisers, to risk leaving in the stock market after retirement. Hence their recommendation to avoid schemes that do so, even though this means becoming locked into painfully low annuity rates instead.

But an eagle-eye financial adviser, Ronnie Lymburn at the Income Drawdown Advisory Bureau, has calculated from the latest Association of British Insurers sales figures that the average size of such schemes sold last year was little more than £100,000. Lymburn believes the mini mum sum required to justify the risk of drawdown is £250,000. If commission - which runs at an average of 6 per cent for company salesforces - is taken from a small sum 'it is doubtful whether the clients' best interests are being served'.

Lymburn's average will, of course, include drawdown sales involving much larger sums than £100,000. But the Financial Services Authority has already urged caution among insurers in this market. Its guidance to investors is that drawdown is unsuitable for less than six-figure sums. The new statistic suggests that salesmen could be sailing close to the wind. A closer look at the market is now called for.

fields.headline: Writeback: Sex and windfalls
fields.trailText: DM of London, like other readers, lost out on the Halifax windfall because, as a building society, it always put the man's name first on mortgage deeds. She says: 'I had a mortgage in my name from 1976 until 1983, when I entered a new, joint mortgage with my partner and his name was placed above mine, although I was the greater income earner.
fields.body:
DM of London, like other readers, lost out on the Halifax windfall because, as a building society, it always put the man's name first on mortgage deeds. She says: 'I had a mortgage in my name from 1976 until 1983, when I entered a new, joint mortgage with my partner and his name was placed above mine, although I was the greater income earner.

In October 1996, we moved and the new mortgage was solely in my name. I had had a Halifax mortgage continuously for more than 20 years but did not qualify for the payout. I raised the question of sex discrimination but apparently the Building Societies Act made this practice acceptable. I consider it highly unjust that I should not have been allowed shares when I would have been held fully responsible for mortgage repayments had my partner defaulted. I was only ever told that "we always put the man's name first".'

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Divorce? Don't forget dot.coms
fields.body:
Divorce? Don't forget dot.coms

If you are planning to divorce a dot.com entrepreneur, don't forget to look closely at the shares and options he or she may have in their business.

Chartered accountancy firm Hacker Young says Internet assets are likely to feature increasingly in divorce settlements. But partners may not always appreciate the potential value of their spouse's dot.com holdings.

Dragoslav Lazarevic, partner and head of forensic accounting at the firm, says he recently advised a woman divorcing a man who had shares and options in a high-tech business. 'The wife had been offered some money for the shares as part of the divorce settlement. On the surface, the offer didn't look too bad. But on reading the accounts, it became clear that the companies were well on the road to achieving far bigger and better things.

'Based on that information, my advice was that the shares had real potential to become very valuable. Their value may have been £60,000 today, but they could potentially be worth as much as £600,000 within two or three years.

'The wife decided to accept the shares as part of the settlement and wait to see what happens.'

Bargain sun

If you're heading for a holiday in Greece you should be quids in. Tour firm Going Places says the biggest rise in sterling against popular holiday destination currencies has been against the drachma.

For every £100 of holiday spending money you take this year, you will have £11.43 more drachma than last year.

Next best is the French franc at £9.47, followed by the Italian lire, at £9.46; the Spanish peseta, £9.18; the Portuguese escudo, £8.60, the deutschmark, £8. 54 and the Dutch guilder, £8.44.

The firm is changing holiday cash for a £2 flat fee. There is a 2 per cent commission charge for sterling traveller's cheques.

There is no charge if you sell back your unused holiday money.

Car price siege

Motorists are preparing to drive a hard bargain when they buy their next car.

More than half are hoping for savings of between £1,000 and £3,000 because of pressure on the motor industry to cut prices - pressure that was increased by a damning report by the Competition Commission last week.

A survey by insurer Churchill showed that women are more determined to hold off buying or renewing their cars than men.

Trust tuition

The Association of Investment Trust Companies will be running a series of forums for private investors throughout the year as part of its campaign to promote the trusts to small investors. Topics to be covered include who should invest, investment trust performance and how to choose a trust.

The forums, held in afternoons and evenings, are free. The next is on 10 May at Merseyside's Haydock Park racecourse. Tel: 0207 431 5222.

fields.standfirst: Retired Ken tells  Margaret Dibben  of a savings disaster - he's down by £3,500
fields.trailText: Retired Ken tells Margaret Dibben of a savings disaster - he's down by £3,500

PENSIONS: Receives £600 a month

AIMS: To use investments to boost income

Ken Duckers was a lab technician with Eli Lilley until he retired five years ago - 'I was made an offer I could not refuse.' He stopped work happily as he felt he was 'becoming less flexible in my dotage'.

Initially this gave him more time for playing in the traditional jazz band for which he has been semi-professional saxophonist for 27 years. But now he has made way for younger talent. He still plays occasionally, and has taken up wood turning.

His finances have gone less smoothly. His savings have shrunk in value in the past six months, making him wary of equity-linked investments. He explains: 'Disastrously, I lost about £1,500 on a Scottish Mutual offshore bond which cost me £15,000. I cashed it in early because it was losing money, but I had already paid the upfront charges, and had to pay a penalty because I had held it for only three years. I had bought the bond because the previous year it had risen 28 per cent.'

He also saw his Halifax Share Pep fall from £3,200 to £1,800 over six months. And he had a Perpetual High Income Bond which lost £500 in two months.

Ken asks: How can I stop the rot?'

He took comfort from his setbacks, spending the money from the Perpetual bond on a new three-piece suite and settling his credit card bills. And the Scottish Mutual bond cash went on a motor caravan, which, with his wife Lyn, he is about to take for two months touring France.

His main concern is supplementing his income now, as he still has five years to wait before receiving the state pension. Lyn, a non-taxpayer, has three years to go. 'My pension is £600 a month. I would like an extra £250 or so.'

He plans to use money from other investments, just maturing, to provide this: 'I have a GAN Millennium Bond which matured for £35,000 in March. This was paying income of £280 a month after tax. I also have a Prudential Prudence Bond of £10,000, which now gives us about £58 a month and which I can take out from March.' Their £70,000 three-bedroom detached house is paid for. As their grown-up sons do not want to inherit, Ken wonders whether they can use the equity to boost their income.

Whatever he invests in, he wants to know: 'What can I do to guarantee that I do not lose any more money and have it available, within a week or two, if I decide to spend big quite suddenly?'

Adviser 1: Ian Williams

The Prudential Prudence Bond should be retained, but taking income above the 5 per cent tax-free threshold will hinder capital growth. Bank shares will come back strongly, so I recommend holding the Halifax shares.

Mr and Mrs Duckers should both invest their £7,000 allowance in an Isa. I recommend a corporate bond fund for regular income and possibly capital growth, such as the Mercury High Income Bond Fund. This pays 8 per cent a month, so £14,000 will earn £93 a month tax free.

The remaining £21,000 should be invested in another income-producing unit trust, perhaps the Foreign & Colonial Higher Income Plan fund. This also pays 8 per cent but, outside an Isa, the income is 6.4 per cent net or £112 a month. This gives a total income of £863 a month net, but with slower capital growth than with a growth fund.

One way to release a cash sum from their property is the Norwich Union Flexible Cash Release Plan. It is a loan, maximum 18 per cent, with interest fixed currently at 8.25 per cent, but there are no repayments during their lifetime unless the property is sold. They retain ownership of their home. This could release up to £12,600.

 Ian Williams is a financial adviser with Bath-based Chartwell Investments.

Adviser 2: Joanne Cox

Mr Duckers' need for immediate access and capital security narrows his choices to bank and building society accounts or National Savings.

As Mrs Duckers is a non-taxpayer, they should put some money in her name. She can earn up to her personal allowance of £4,385 a year before paying tax, which would cover their additional income needs.

Many monthly interest accounts pay over 6 per cent with instant access, and £35,000 in Mrs Duckers' name provides £175 a month. National Savings Income Bonds attract 6.25 per cent at three months' notice.

However, deposit-based accounts do not provide capital growth. If the Duckers draw all the interest earned, inflation will eat into capital and income, so they should invest for capital growth. As the Prudential Prudence Bond is producing £696 a year, it is worth holding. If they are uncomfortable with the Halifax Share Pep fluctuating in value, selling may be the best option - but it could be worth keeping as the shares may rise.

There are many schemes to realise capital or income from property, but annuity rates are low and their income needs can be met elsewhere. I recommend putting this idea on the back burner. Any plan that allows them to build up debt against property can be restrictive if they should want to move.

 Joanne Cox is a financial adviser with Co-operative Bank.

Advice is for guidance only.

fields.trailText: Want to find out how much it will cost you to move home? Look at the Woolwich's Cost of Moving Survey on www.thewoolwich.co.uk. Solicitors' charges are up by an average 8 per cent (£372 typically for a £60,000 sale) and removal fees are up 13 per cent on the year.
fields.body:
Want to find out how much it will cost you to move home? Look at the Woolwich's Cost of Moving Survey on www.thewoolwich.co.uk. Solicitors' charges are up by an average 8 per cent (£372 typically for a £60,000 sale) and removal fees are up 13 per cent on the year.

www.smartestates.com has expanded its website to add a 'national removal register' to its property search, plus 'reduce your mortgage' and 'quick quote' mortgage calculator sections. There are many sites offering to help you to buy and sell your property. A typical one is www.propertypagesuk.com - offering to advertise your property, photograph and all, on its site for £300 if the price is under £100,000 or £600 if it is under £300,000. But it needs rather more properties than it has at the moment before it will take off.

Share-dealing is another particularly active sector of the Internet. Stocktrade (www.stocktrade.co.uk) - 'the first company in the UK to offer real-time dealing at live prices on the Internet' - has beefed up its links, working throughwww.investor-relations.co.uk, to set up links to 2,000 company websites.

You may have thought that the Isa season was over on 5 April. But Julian Hodge Bank has just launched its 2000/01 range on www.jhb.co.uk, including a fixed-rate mini Isa where, over five years, rates rise from 7 to 7.25 per cent. For those intrepid enough to deal in volatile Nasdaq shares, www.e-cortal.com is offering a commission-free dealing service in Nasdaq stocks for people who subscribe to its service by the end of May. Subscribing costs about £4 a month (6 euros).

April and May are prime months for insurers to sell travel policies. www.insure.co.uk offers single trip policies from £9.07 and annual worldwide cover from £119. As it points out, the average family is now taking at least two holidays a year, but, although the average family may get some useful information from this site, it could probably find a better deal elsewhere.

If you want a directory of useful financial sites, www.find.co.uk lists more than 3,300 sites. The most popular sectors in March were in online share dealing, personal loans, motor insurance and Isas.

webTitle: The Big Apple's fine - but I'd rather live in the Big Smoke ...

fields.headline: The Big Apple's fine - but I'd rather live in the Big Smoke ...
fields.standfirst: Graham Norwood  finds there's an exodus from across the Pond
fields.trailText: Tom Cruise does it. So does Madonna. Some reports say Woody Allen wants to do it too.Why do celebrities leave New York and come to London?
fields.body:
Tom Cruise does it. So does Madonna. Some reports say Woody Allen wants to do it too.Why do celebrities leave New York and come to London?

It might just be the quality of life - it probably isn't because of the cost of property. London is a little cheaper but the two markets are very similar, with 1999 providing big increases in house prices in both cities.

Most New York homes are rented, but costs are spiralling. A few rent-controlled flats remain available at about $700 (£440) a month but most cost much more. A one-bedroom apartment in the controversial Trump Tower - the world's tallest residential block of flats, built just across the road from the UN - can be rented now on the internet for $5,000 (£3,150) a month.

As rents soar, buying is becoming more popular. In Manhattan real estate rose by between 25 per cent and 30 per cent in 1999. Over the previous 10 years property rose in line with inflation, the equivalent of a 41 per cent hike between 1988 and 1998.

'In 1999 there were 10 sales of Manhattan homes fetching more than $10m each,' says Kirk Henckels, a director of Striblings, New York's most respected luxury real estate agent. 'In 2000 the process is, if anything, accelerating. In January and February alone there have been six Manhattan properties sold for more than $10m each,' Henckel adds. 'It's simple supply and demand.'

International estate agents Knight Frank say there are obvious parallels between New York and London. 'Both cities have their more expensive residential property markets influenced directly by the strength of the stock market and things like huge City bonuses, which fuel the buying part of the market for part of each year,' according to residential research manager Paul Belson. 'In London the prices are more cyclical. We have sustained growth in prices,then sometimes followed by prices slowing down or even a slump,' he says.

Nevertheless the firm's lifestyle survey says prime central London locations 'command values among the highest in Europe, if not the world' with up to 25 percent of buyers from overseas.

Knight Frank has compared late-1999 sales and rental figures in the most desirable London areas like the City, Hampstead, the West End and Kensington with those in similarly sought-after Manhattan and Long Island.

London's average prices provide better value, although they are not exactly cheap. But the UK is more expensive in the area surrounding the prime city area. Prices have risen dramatically throughout Greater London.

House prices in Greater London rose by 8.4 per cent during the final quarter of 1999, according to the Hali fax. Annual inflation in the region is 28.9 per cent - the highest yearly rate ever seen in the area and a figure which even optimistic market analysts admit cannot continue during 2000.

In New York outside of Manhattan, the price rises were higher than usual in 1999 but reached 10 per cent in only a few places. Their prices may still be a little higher than London, but the gap is closing fast.

Nevertheless, Americans buying in London are still impressed by what they get for their money. New York interior designer Francis Cannon is moving to London and has seen around a dozen properties on weekend visits. 'Both markets are really hot, hot, hot at the moment. I sold my apartment to the first person who came to have a look. But you get a house in London for the price of an apartment in New York, which is charming and makes it seem as if you get much better value for money,' he says.

Madonna is taking full advantage of London's good value estate agents. She is selling her five-bedroom south Kensington villa for £4.6m, having purchased it just over a year ago for £3.5m. Quite a bonus - especially as she has declined to spend even one night in it.

 Knight Frank, London: 020 7629 8171; Stribling, New York: 001 212 570 2440

webTitle: Taking the gall out of gallstones

fields.headline: Taking the gall out of gallstones
fields.trailText: Eric White has major concerns about private insurers and the National Health Service - but is 'completely' satisfied with the service he has received privately from Nuffield Hospitals.
fields.body:
Eric White has major concerns about private insurers and the National Health Service - but is 'completely' satisfied with the service he has received privately from Nuffield Hospitals.

Mr White, 78, a retired engineering worker, has undergone two 'self-pay' operations at the Nuffield Wessex, just down the road from his home in Chandlers Ford, between Southampton and Winchester.

He first made contact with the Nuffield a year ago when he needed a repair to an old hernia operation. 'It was the usual story from the NHS: they were going to take a year or so. I was in some pain and restricted in movement. My wife and I had booked a six-week holiday in November - and the NHS route didn't fit in with those plans.' So he rang Nuffield Wessex at the end of May last year, saw a consultant and had the operation at the beginning of June. He paid a fixed fee of £1,250, which would cover any extra help he might need if there were any complications.

Under typical Nuffield financing arrangements, he paid a £250 deposit, took out a 12-month interest-free loan through Mercantile Credit and agreed to repay the other £1,000 in equal instalments over the next year.

In February this year, he and his wife set off on a round-the-world trip. When they got to Hawaii last month, Mr White was taken ill with gallstones. Due to go to Australia the next day, they agreed with the Hawaiian doctors that he would get the operation done there. But he found himself caught in a financial fight while his Australian surgeon prepared to operate. His travel insurer was raising issues about the reciprocal arrangements between the UK and Australia for emergency operations, hoping that it would not have to foot the bill if it could argue that the NHS would pay.

'I was in limbo and was also getting quite agitated,' says Mr White. After two days, he decided to come home and have the operation at the Nuffield Wessex.

He has paid the costs himself and hopes to be reimbursed (with compensation) by the travel insurer. But he feels that the Nuffield again managed to take the stress out of the situation and make it affordable for him. The treatment cost £90 for a consultant's fee and a further £2,860 for the operation itself. Mr White has paid the £90, and another £1,000 upfront; the rest will be paid off over the next year. But Mr White hopes, of course, that his travel insurer will soon step in and pay.

 There are 40 Nuffield Hospitals around the country. For information ring 0800 688699.

fields.headline: Physician heal thyself...
fields.trailText: Martin Burton, a consultant surgeon in ear, nose and throat at Oxford's Radcliffe Infirmary, was one of the first people to buy XSHealth's new-style medical cover plan.
fields.body:
Martin Burton, a consultant surgeon in ear, nose and throat at Oxford's Radcliffe Infirmary, was one of the first people to buy XSHealth's new-style medical cover plan.

The 41-year-old doctor had been thinking of buying insurance for himself, his wife and their seven-year-old son for quite a time.

'I wanted to have the option of private treatment. The health service is under great pressure and great constraints. If it is possible for some of us to relieve those pressures, it leaves the service better able to help the others.'

But what stopped him getting cover in the past was the cost. He was pleased when XSHealth, an Internet-only subsidiary of WPA, launched its new plan on www.xshealth.co.uk last September. Burton, like other policyholders, agrees to meet the first £1,500 of medical bills in any one year. After that XSHealth picks up the bill. The cost for the Burton family is a little over £300 - a third of what traditional insurers would charge.

 Kevin Morgan is an independent financial adviser who has specialised in medical insurance for 15 years. He believes that the market is on the verge of an overhaul - with the traditional insurers finding that large amounts of new business go to the new 'excess' insurers.

'The excess type of policies will be very, very popular indeed,' he says. 'These charge premiums which are often just 25 per cent of the cost of traditional policies.'

Morgan, who works for adviser Litecastle, based in Hitchin, Herts, has tended to use the same 'Big Four' insurers when he has researched the market for clients. Policyholders tend to prefer the security of dealing with these big names, he says. The rest of the market tends to offer equally good products in his view - but lose out because they are not as well known as Bupa.

The reason why the new policies charge relatively low premiums is that they have an excess. On the WPA policy, for instance, the policyholder agrees to pay the first £1,500 of treatment costs in a year (£3,000 if they are 60 or over). On the traditional plan, there is no excess.

Morgan explains: 'The vast majority of PMI claims are for relatively routine treatments, costing £2,000 to £3,000 each time. Setting an excess reduces the premium quite remarkably.'

Medical insurance plans are said to be difficult to compare, because they offer different kinds of cover for different conditions, changing the rates at different ages. But Morgan says they are alike: 'There isn't a great deal to choose between them. They have very, very similar levels of cover.'

Of the 'Big Four', Morgan is partial to Standard Life: 'The premium levels have been competitive. And the literature is straightforward and easy to understand.'

Over the years, Morgan has found little to differentiate the products in their handling of claims. Litecastle monitors the views of its clients whenever they have to make a claim: 'By and large, people are very happy with the service. Once the system is under way, it's pretty seamless.'

On the figures shown above, Morgan would be unlikely to recommend Norwich Union products, because they come out far more expensive. But insurers are sometimes competitive for one age band and out of line for another.

People going to IFAs for advice on medical policies should remember that the new cheaper-style policies may not appeal to all those advisers if, like XShealth, they are not offering commission to advisers.

fields.headline: Three's a crowd
fields.standfirst: How long does it take to hate a person? Thirty six minutes precisely, if it's the 14-year-old drummer from Hanson
fields.trailText: How long does it take to hate a person? Thirty six minutes precisely, if it's the 14-year-old drummer from Hanson
fields.body:
It is 12.35pm. I'm sitting in a plush Kensington hotel room with Hanson's publicist, waiting for Tulsa, Oklahoma's blond 'child prodigy' trio to arrive. 'Do you like Hanson?' asks the publicist. Well, I don't dislike them, I say. Who could forget 'MmmBop', the most infectious single of 1997?

The door opens, and Hanson arrive. It's been three years and they've grown a bit. Isaac (friendly, courteous, Dave Grohl crossed with Stewart Copeland) is 19. Taylor (pretty, poetic, Mark Owen fused with Kurt Cobain) is 16. Zac (bratty, noisy, Meatloaf meets Angelica from RugRats) is 14. After introductions, and a bone-crunching handshake from Zac, Hanson take their seats, and discuss the impossibility of getting a decent Dr Pepper in Britain.

'I guess we'll just have water,' says Isaac.

Zac snorts loudly.

'The deal is,' booms the youngest Hanson in tones which brook no argument, 'Dr Pepper is good in the States, and bad EVERYWHERE ELSE!'

Fascinating. Does Zac have equally strong views on British drinks?

'Which ones?'

Tizer, Tango, Irn Bru?

'Haven't tried 'em!' he snaps, sighing impatiently. Obviously, I'm going to have to think of some better questions. Or some better British drinks.

12.45pm Far from being raised as unreconstructed hippie brats, Hanson come from an upstanding Christian background. They don't care to discuss this in pop interviews, so we chat a bit about their new album, This Time Around (out 1 May). It's rockier than their multi-million-selling, Brit- and Grammy-nominated debut, Middle Of Nowhere. The box-fresh melodies are still in place, but there are some distinctly Sheryl Crow and Lenny Kravitz touches, and a lot more self-assurance and swagger.

Clearly, their musical style has evolved as the boys have matured. Does Hanson feel like a different band now? Isaac and Taylor open their mouths to comment, but Zac gets there first.

'Well, hurrr, nooooo!' he sneers. 'As you can see, it's still the same three guys who've always performed together.' And with that, Zac bunches up his chubby lips until they almost touch the tip of his piggy nose, and lolls back in his chair, smirking.

Isn't he delightful?

1.06pm 'The way the band works,' Taylor is explaining, 'is that that there's three of us, and everyone has a different strength, and plays off each other.'

But are some members of Hanson more equal than others? There's usually at least one control freak in a band, I say, glaring pointedly at Zac.

'We-ell', says Isaac. 'Sometimes Taylor can be a total perfectionist, and I can be anal about things too, but I guess Zac does like to steer the band sometimes. Zac cuts straight to the chase.'

I glance over at Zac, who is almost purring by now.

'That's correct,' he says grandly. 'I don't think there's any point in beating around the bush.'

Watching him, the oddest feeling washes over me. What is it? I wonder.

1.11pm As Taylor politely explains how different experiences have contributed to changing Hanson, it hits me that I hate Zac. This is bad. You can't just go around hating 14-year-old Christian boy drummers, however obnoxious they might be. There's not long to go, I'd better pull myself together.

1.15pm Zac makes fun of my accent. He also claims not to be able to hear my question about whether Hanson were irritated at being categorised as a boy band.

'What was that you said?', says Zac, cupping his ear theatrically. 'I didn't understand the first part. You said "Something, something, zzzssscchh... something... sczzzssch..."' This guy is wasted on pop. Why isn't Hollywood clamouring?

1.16pm Isaac answers my question: 'The reason Hanson is put in certain boxes is our fan base is primarily young girls. We don't have anything against that, but we do feel that, even more now, our music is nothing like the category we're put into.'

Thank you, Isaac.

1.22pm Zac is rocking back on his chair, telling me his views on what constitutes good songwriting subject matter: 'There's constipation, and then there's love,' he drawls solemnly. 'These are the only two feelings everybody has. Whether it's man and woman, man and man, or... dog and dog! WOOF, WOOF, WOOF!'

1.25pm Zac is still woofing.

1.28pm The interview is over, and with it the longest 53 minutes of my life. Hanson are taken into the next room for photographs. Another painful Zac handshake. 'OW!' I scream, and glare at him furiously. He walks off, grinning, like Chuckie from Child's Play. Isaac and Taylor swap an anxious glance.

I learn later that a Hanson huddle was formed, views exchanged, and a very different, more subdued and courteous Zac re-emerged for the next interview.

fields.headline: The devil's in the detail
fields.standfirst: The girls of Salem are possessed. So is the stage machinery
fields.trailText: The Crucible
fields.body:
The Crucible Royal Opera House, London W2

Focus is vital in any ballet that tells a story. The audience needs clues and signposts, even if we know the plot already from mugging up the programme notes. William Tuckett does provide a scenario for his new one-act ballet, The Crucible , in the Royal Ballet's latest triple bill. He adds a disclaimer, however, absolving himself from following Arthur Miller's play in every aspect.

He uses Miller's title, though, instead of adopting an alternative, as Kenneth MacMillan did for his versions of plays or books. Choreographers are not bound to recount a story literally, beginning at the beginning, any more than filmmakers do. But just as the camera guides you where to look, so the dance- maker must direct your attention to key characters and incidents. A stage filled with actions and images is too bewildering to absorb, along with often unfamiliar music - in this case, a collage of Charles Ives pieces.

The ballet starts mysteriously, with Ives's The Unanswered Question as a prologue. Ralph Steadman's front cloth is a grotesque portrait of an inbred Puritan community bristling with crucifixes. Through the screen can be seen highlights from the story-so-far: adulterous sex and satanic dances. The cloth lifts to reveal Steadman's nightmare vision of fear and loathing in New Eng land - or maybe England now. This is a society of control freaks and hysterics. Those in command sport crosses like Teletubbies' antennae to keep them on message.

The 'possessed' girls are caricatured as vamps or virgins. Abigail, their ringleader, wears a long red Sylvie Guillem wig and flings herself at the leading man, John Proctor, in much the same insatiable way as Mary Vetsera does in MacMillan's Mayerling . Proctor appears to be the only sane person in the place, though it is soon apparent that he is racked with guilt and lust.

Tuckett's biggest problem is finding a movement language that expresses Proctor's relationship with his wife, Elizabeth. The scenario, like the play, suggests that her coldness has driven him to adultery, yet Zenaida Yanowsky is stunningly sensual. Her pas de deux with Proctor - Irek Mukhamedov powerful in the first cast, Jonathan Cope more romantic in the second - are full of erotic lifts. The contrast in Proctor's encounters with wife and mistress is mainly a matter of colouring, in acting and expressionist lighting (by Peter Mumford).

Shifts of emotion within long pas de deux are hard to follow because the hyper-active set is so distracting. Steadman plays with every device the new stage machinery can accommodate: mobile steel frames, huge shards of plastic, wire fencing, forests of wooden crosses. Demonic silhouettes leer from the undergrowth, overwhelming the purely human drama of bigotry and betrayal.

Tantalisingly, Miller's allegorical story, based on accounts of witch hunts in seventeenth-century Salem, is in there somewhere. Having re-read the play between the ballet's first two performances, I could then identify characters and motives; with out that detailed information, I was flummoxed. Tuckett's eloquence (which reads better on the second cast than the first) goes for nothing if the tragedy is incomprehensible.

The contrast in Proctor's encounters with wife and mistress is mainly a matter of colouring, in acting and expressionist lighting (by Peter Mumford). Shifts of emotion within long pas de deux are hard to follow because the hyper-active set is so distracting. Steadman plays with every device the new stage machinery can accommodate: mobile steel frames, huge shards of plastic, wire fencing, forests of wooden crosses. Demonic silhouettes leer from the undergrowth, overwhelming the purely human drama of bigotry and betrayal. Tantalisingly, Miller's allegorical story, based on accounts of witch hunts in seventeenth-century Salem, is in there somewhere. Having re-read the play between the ballet's first two performances, I could then identify characters and motives; with out that detailed information, I was flummoxed. Tuckett's eloquence (which reads better on the second cast than the first) goes for nothing if the tragedy is incomprehensible.

webTitle: Phil Hogan  has an inner-body experience

fields.headline: Phil Hogan  has an inner-body experience
fields.trailText: ...has an inner-body experience
fields.body:
We're off to Greenwich on an educational mission to see whether it's scientifically possible for the Dome to live up to its bad publicity, but my wife has completely forgotten to remind me that it's Sunday, so of course we've no sooner bought a competitively priced Network family leisure ticket than we discover that all our local railway tracks have been removed for routine maintenance, which means rather tiresomely driving round all the stations in the south-east trying to find out which one's turn it is to have the train this weekend. But at last we're there, and although big tents usually remind me of bad camping experiences (as if there are any other kind), the Dome immediately impresses me with its scope, ambition and a bold enough vision to opt for inside toilets.

First on the itinerary, though, is the Blackadder time-travelling comedy, which is every bit as hilarious as everybody says, ie not particularly, especially for anyone (such as our children) expecting Mr Bean, who I can't help thinking would at least have been spared the indignity of delivering jokes designed to appeal to all walks of life, with the possible exception of those represented by the audience. Still, we're able to make our escape in plenty of time to watch the spectacular live show, which for the first five minutes looks a bit like PE with a costume budget ('When's it going to start, Dad?'), but it finds its feet once it gets in the air, with thundering music and people flying upside down on stilts and explosions going off, as the slightly baffling story unfolds of Skyboy who falls in love with Earthgirl and together they save the planet, or possibly set it on fire, depending on how closely you've been paying attention. The children are spellbound, or at least not moaning, which is the same thing.

Afterwards, we take them to the Expensive Snack Zone to share a sausage roll and reorient our priorities in favour of Timekeepers of the Millennium, which turns out to be nothing to do with late-20th-century historiography and everything to do with firing spongy balls out of guns. Hours go by and the children are having so much fun that we can only get them out again by agreeing to buy them an orange Calippo each, which take hours more to eat while they lark about in front of the nutty mirrors that make everybody look like the Elephant Man.

By now we've got sideshow fatigue, even though we've seen practically nothing yet, so we head for somewhere called Rest, which sounds quite appealing and is housed in what is called a 'mental flotation tank' or, as we say in English, 'a big room with nothing in it'. But we're grateful enough to sit down and surrender ourselves to the soothing ambient hum of music inspired by the sound of faulty kitchen equipment for five minutes or until the children realise that nothing of interest is going to happen, whichever comes first.

So, just time to take a look at the fantastic giant boy crouching ('Off his toes, please_') and some virtual tug-of-war in Play (which has been cleverly designed without lights to make it easier to lose your children), before queuing for the Body Zone, which is so popular that someone has been employed to stand and yell at you to have your tickets ready, though of course it does save them the trouble of putting a sign up.

After 15 minutes we're in, past the beating heart, dawdling along ('Hurry up, you're blocking an artery_'), down to a little cavern with sperm wriggling about on an overhead screen. 'We're in the balls, aren't we, Dad?' says the eldest in his Rada voice.

'Er, womb, I think,' I say, taking the pierced navel as a clue, and ushering him past the pubic lice before I have some explaining to do. But the next thing I know we're in the skull. Hang on a minute - what happened to nipples? What happened to breasts?

The kids find some molars to sit on while we stand trying to work out the exact significance of a brain wearing a fez and standing in front of a microphone telling Tommy Cooper jokes, though of course it may be a cunning way of demonstrating that when a committee of six brains can't come up with a great idea, they'll always settle for the next one anybody thinks of, thereby demonstrating the power of the brain to deceive its owner and anyone within earshot.

We emerge blinking from an elbow.

'Your body needs sex,' a voice is saying.

Blimey. It's amazing the information they can get from a ticket stub...

 Tommy Cooper jokes to
phil.hogan@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Planning an Easter trip to the cinema? Better take a book

fields.headline: Planning an Easter trip to the cinema? Better take a book
fields.standfirst: Terry Jones gets to grips with the Gauls. Tigger's still bouncing. And the kids'll love Pokémon - but then they'll watch anything
fields.trailText: Astérix and Obélix Take On Caesar | The Tigger Movie | Pokémon | L'Ennui | La Nouvelle Eve | Of Freaks and Men | Up at the Villa
fields.body:
Astérix and Obélix Take On Caesar (110 mins, PG) Directed by Claude Zidi; starring Christian Clavier, Gérard Depardieu, Roberto Benigni

The Tigger Movie (77 mins, U) Directed by Jun Falkenstein; narrated by John Hurt

Pokémon: The First Movie (74 mins, U) Directed by Kunohiko Yuyama, English adaptation directed by Michael Haigney

L'Ennui (120 mins, 18) Directed by Cédric Kahn; starring Charles Berling, Sophie Guillemin

La Nouvelle Eve (94 mins, 18) Directed by Catharine Corsini; starring Karen Viard, Catherine Frot

Of Freaks and Men (93 mins, 18) Directed by Alexei Balabanov; starring Victor Sukhorukov, Sergei Makovetsky

Up at the Villa (116 mins, 12) Directed by Philip Haas; starring Kristin Scott Thomas, Sean Penn, Anne Bancroft

The Easter holidays are here. Good news for morning rush-hour drivers, bad news for adult filmgoers. The three children's offerings this week cannot in any sense be said to be family entertainment, as they'd test the patience of the most indulgent parents and grandparents. Because kids will watch anything, it behoves us to give them the best, and this trio of pictures falls far short. What they share, apart from their indifferent quality, is a hybrid character, Astérix and Obélix Take on Caesar being a French comedy dubbed into English, Pokémon: The First Movie a Japanese cartoon reworked for Americans, and The Tigger Movie a set of British characters animated by teams of Americans and Japanese.

By some way the worst, Pokémon is a movie spin-off from the Game Boy game and TV series and it pits the megalomaniac pocket monster MewTwo against the benign PokémonMew from whose DNA he has been cloned. At stake is world control and MewTwo's gang face off against assorted Pokémon and their human trainers. Crudely drawn, as if by an untalented follower of Maurice Sendak, this is sententious stuff ('It's what you do with the gift of life that determines what you are'). By comparison, Teletubbies looks like an early work by Jane Austen.

Astérix and Obélix is a live-action version of the cheerful French comic strip that began in 1959, and stars Christian Clavier as the patriotic Gaul Astérix combating Caesar's Romans with the help of a secret potion and his thick sidekick Obélix (Gérard Depardieu). It is leaden stuff that hasn't been transmuted into a Life of Brian by engaging Terry Jones to write the English dialogue and do the dubbing for Depardieu. All the accents are jokily British with the exception of the Chico Marx Italian accent used for Roberto Benigni's Detritus. There is one brilliant, hair-raising sequence in which Astérix runs the gauntlet of snakes, lions, crocodiles and tarantulas in a Roman arena.

The Tigger Movie is much inferior to Winnie the Pooh and the Blustery Day, the charming 25-minute cartoon closely based on E.H. Shepard's illustrations that brought the Disney Studio an Oscar in 1968. Rather coarsely drawn, it centres on the vainglorious bouncing Tigger as he searches the Hundred Acre Wood for his relatives, only to discover that Pooh, Roo, Eeyore and company are his real family. The one highlight is the song 'Round My Family Tree' that features various Tigger ancestors as painted by Whistler, Dali, Picasso and Van Gogh and dancing in 'Goldtiggers of Broadway'.

Two French movies of a certain quality approach the subject of obsessive love from different angles. Cédric Khan's L'Ennui, adapted from Alberto Moravia's novel La Noia (previously filmed in Rome in 1964 as The Empty Canvas with Bette Davis), centres on Martin, a divorced Parisian philosophy professor (Charles Berling) who falls for the plump, vacuous, sexually voracious 17-year-old Cecilia (Sophie Guillemin) after discovering she's driven a middle-aged painter to his grave.

His inability to possess and dominate Cecilia, his vain attempts to make her reject her young black lover, his involvement of his detached ex-wife (Arielle Dombasle) in his self-searching, are the stuff of tragi-comedy. Berling constantly loses and regains our sympathy.

As he dashes dementedly around Paris, phoning, driving, having frenetic sex, Martin cuts a touching figure. His female counterpart in La Nouvelle Eve is the frenetic Camille (Karen Viard), an intelligent, discontented, unattached woman also in her thirties and underemployed as a swimming pool attendant. She too falls in love with an unprepossessing object of desire, a short, bald, happily married Socialist Party organiser (Pierre-Loup Rajot), and pursues him relentlessly. And again like the philosopher Martin, she ends up in hospital for, and with, her pains. Camille is the sort of woman of whom in real life you'd say 'Can't live with her, can live without her'. But up there on the screen she's rather endearing.

Alexei Balabanov, whose gripping thriller Brother I praised last week, has returned to the elegant obscurity of his earlier Happy Days with Of Freaks and Men , a Gogolian fable set in turn-of-the-century St Petersburg. A sinister pornographer, Johann, specialises in photographs and films of flagellation, mostly involving young women being beaten across the buttocks by middle-aged female servants. These corrupt images he sells to middle-class clients, and manages through them to infiltrate and control two affluent households. The first is that of an elderly physician with a blind wife and adopted Siamese twins, whose singing talents Johann wants to exploit. The second is a railway tycoon whose daughter he covets. Shot in sepiatone and performed in a stylised, dream-like fashion, the picture exudes and exults in evil.

The week's British film, Philip Haas's Up at the Villa , is a disappointing version of Somerset Maugham's 1940 pot-boiling novella (or should that be novelette?) which Christopher Isherwood adapted for an unmade movie in 1945 and pronounced to be 'a bad script from a bad story'. The haughty Kristin Scott Thomas plays a penniless English widow living in 1938 Florence. Courted by a rich British diplomat (James Fox), advised by a cynical American principessa (Anne Bancroft), propositioned by an American womaniser (Sean Penn), she becomes responsible for the death of a young Austrian refugee and blackmails a fascist policeman. The acting is stiffly parodic. The pace is funereal. The dialogue, some of it by Maugham, is stilted and worse - 'Regardless of what happens to you and I,' says Fox, disgracing the Eton tie he wears. The principal interest, for students of Maugham, is the double portrait of the novelist's bisexual lover, the charming scoundrel Gerald Haxton, in the characters of Scott Thomas's late husband and the amoral socialite played by Penn.

fields.headline: Listen with Mutter...
fields.trailText: The rules are clear. No personal questions. No inquiries about her children. No straying beyond the boundaries of music. The German violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter first learned to fend off press attention two decades ago
fields.body:
The rules are clear. No personal questions. No inquiries about her children. No straying beyond the boundaries of music. The German violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter first learned to fend off press attention two decades ago. When she was 14, Herbert Von Karajan took her under his commanding wing, calling her 'the greatest musical prodigy since the young Menuhin'. A year later, she performed with his orchestra, the Berlin Philharmonic, and made her first recording. The media was mesmerised. What was the exact nature of this fellowship between the legendary conductor and his lovely protégée? Now 36, she is way past being cajoled into private revelation.

For a musician this is not unusual. Perhaps because so many, like Mutter, start out as child prodigies, they acquire a quasi-diplomatic immunity never afforded to actors or film stars. By the time their lives have grown interesting, these musicians have mastered the art of deflection. Their joys and sorrows, they argue, are there for the world to witness in the way they perform. At the same time, they may also court attention, thus feeding the enigma. Mutter began wearing her hallmark strapless dresses early in her career, tacitly inviting comment on her each and every vital statistic. When she married a German businessman several years her senior, speculation about her off-stage life subsided. But when he died four years ago, leaving her widowed with two young children, interest flared up again.

She has stood firm against it all, putting her impeccable musicianship up for public dissection and nothing else. In 1998, she played the complete Beethoven Violin Sonatas all over the world. Her performances were compelling, controversial and not universally acclaimed. Next week, she arrives in London to give five concerts of formidable difficulty at the Barbican. The series, entitled 'Back to the Future', celebrates the violin repertoire of the twentieth century, from Sibelius and Berg to Rihm and Penderecki. Four of the 11 pieces have been written for Mutter herself. Her commitment to extending the repertoire is impressive, and daring. Most of her fans would rather just hear her play Tchaikovsky again and again. Yet much of this music shows off her exemplary technique and magical high register - which she attributes to her small hands - to riveting effect.

When we met earlier in the year, she had just given the same programmes in New York, to acclaim and packed houses. In her brown trouser suit, tawny-gold hair well-groomed, eyebrows shaped into a bold, perfect arch and lips a glossy red, she has the gleaming lustre of a newly-hatched conker. She speaks warmly and vivaciously but rarely deviates. Her English is immaculate, its correctness emancipated by unexpected colloquialisms. 'The idea came from Kurt Masur who wanted me to play the works which had been specially composed for me, starting with Chain 2 by Lutoslawski. Then it grew, and we decided to examine a century of violin music. Wow! Crazy!'

Mutter grew up in the Black Forest, later moving to Switzerland, Monte Carlo and Munich. She won her first competition at the age of six, having started lessons the previous year. Playing the violin, to most people a painfully unnatural process in which gravity has to be defied merely in order to hold it under your chin, always felt entirely instinctive. 'I knew from that age that I wanted to do nothing but be a violinist. It's difficult being gifted. Nothing is ordinary in your life, except doing what is not normal for others.'

She stresses that the varied works in her Barbican series are united by a common thread of tradition, from the romantic, Brahmsian style of Respighi's Sonata to the Four Nocturnes by the highly individual American composer George Crumb. 'In this piece, Crumb explores completely new sounds. I have to make noises on the violin with a small brush, and tap the wood, like walking in a wood at night.' Not on her Stradivarius, surely? 'Boy, no! Not with the Strad. I have a newly made instrument by an English maker. I was worried at first that it should not sound like my usual playing. But it does - it's easy to play, like a down-to earth person, friendly and intelligent but a little simple-minded, not overly sensitive.'

It is no coincidence that Anne-Sophie Mutter's one escape is climbing mountains near her home in Austria. She speaks with more passion about the relative heights of different peaks near Kitzbuhl and how her dog once got stuck than on any other topic. 'I go early in the morning, about five o'clock when my children are sleeping. Then I don't feel guilty at not being there for them. Everything is possible.' Never mind the guilt. The wonder, given her punishing schedule, is that she wouldn't rather be asleep.

 Anne-Sophie Mutter's Back to the Future, with the LSO, runs from 28 April to 7 May at the Barbican (020 7638 8891). A limited edition CD of 20th Century Violin Works has just been issued on DG (28946 37902)

webTitle: Can I cope with another baby?

fields.headline: Can I cope with another baby?
fields.trailText: After the birth of our son seven months ago, my long-term partner and I split up. We have still been seeing each other, although not getting on very well. However, I have now found out I am 14 weeks pregnant by him
fields.body:
After the birth of our son seven months ago, my long-term partner and I split up. We have still been seeing each other, although not getting on very well. However, I have now found out I am 14 weeks pregnant by him. We have tried reconciliation but do not seem able to live together. I have seen a scan of my tiny but fully formed baby and cannot now contemplate a termination. Should my partner and I try to live together for the sake of the children? I don't feel as if I can cope on my own. I have found it difficult enough with just one child, I don't know how I will manage with two.
J.H. of Bath

You need more detailed advice than can be given here, and top of the list is a reliable form of contraception for the future. Even for a mother who is more securely situated, a second child following so closely on the heels of the first is exceedingly demanding. Be prepared to avoid a precipitate third pregnancy.

No two people should attempt to stay together solely on the grounds that it's better for the children. If togetherness makes the home unpleasant for each of you, it will be doubly so for them.

If you have not had professional advice from a counselling organisation such as Relate, that should be explored. Can you identify the source of the difficulties with your partner? It sounds as if it was connected with the arrival of your child, or with the attempt to share your lives more completely when the baby was expected. Your partner may be more destabilised than you, not having the same unique physiological ties to the baby, and may be jealous of the attention deflected from himself. It's also possible he is chaffing at the restrictions of domesticity and wants his freedom back. He must be made to understand that whatever happens to your own relationship with him, his duties to his children continue for the rest of his life.

You can share the upbringing of your children without being obliged to marry or even live together. With a little planning, you could even each take part-time work and alternate the childcare between you. Such an informal arrangement could make your partner more willing to commit himself (if that is his problem). Later, with maturity, a fully-fledged undertaking may emerge.

While considering your options, do not forget the possibility of having your second child adopted. This is understandably a hard decision, but it may seem preferable to abortion. Remember, there are many more longing and willing potential parents than babies available for them to adopt, and this would be one way of ensuring a good home for your child. The decision has to be made in advance of course, but can be reversed if you change your mind.

If none of these ways suit you, do consider that you are certainly not unique or alone in your predicament. Why not form your own self-help group with three or four other women in a similar situation - create a mobile cr che. The transformation in all your lives could be monumental.

Next week's problem is from J.M. of South London
Ever since he was little, my son has been prone to serious temper tantrums. He is now nine, and when he is good he is very, very good, when he is bad etc... He has been getting into fights at school and also fights with me at home - swearing and hitting - but cannot say what it is that triggers his rage. His father and I do not live together but his father admits he has a violent temper too. How can a parent help an angry child?

 Write to Observer Review or e-mail margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on next week's dilemma to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

webTitle: Once upon a time in Africa

fields.headline: Once upon a time in Africa
fields.standfirst: The brave new Zimbabwe was to be founded on reconciliation and forgiveness. But, as one young expatriate teacher recalls, the early rumblings of disquiet were there for all to hear
fields.trailText: The brave new Zimbabwe was to be founded on reconciliation and forgiveness. But, as one young expatriate teacher recalls, the early rumblings of disquiet were there for all to hear
fields.body:
On Ash Wednesday 1982, I left England for Zimbabwe. I had flu, a temperature of 105 and hardly noticed the flight out. I was on my way to St Augustine's Mission, in the Eastern Highlands, near the border of Mozambique, a famous school where the children of government ministers mixed with peasants' sons. The principal, Father Prosser, hailed, like Trevor Huddleston, from the Community of the Resurrection in England and was well-liked, not least because he had helped freedom fighters (many of them former pupils of the school) during the war. I was going there to teach English.

I had no idea what Zimbabwe was like. I must have had a sepia safari film playing in my imagination. I had to pinch myself to believe what I saw that first morning at St Augustine's: a cradle of blue-green hills, burnt orange earth, scarlet poinsettia bushes (that would shame potted Christmas presents forever). Our garden was a sort of hanging lunch - of voluptuous mangos, guavas and avocados (two kinds, green and purple).The schoolchildren greeted me as I walked along the path to the tall, red church and shook my hand warmly: 'Good morning, Miss Kellaway...' The sky, after a numb London February,was an unreal blue. I decided I must have died on the plane and woken in heaven.

It was almost two years since independence and Mugabe was arguing that Zimbabweans, white and black, should put the war behind them and work to build a new country. He called this his 'policy of reconciliation'. It had a Christian ring that would make any mission school proud. And St Augustine's was proud. Mugabe was seen as a superb leader: articulate, honest and enlightened. But when I discussed his policy of reconciliation with other teachers (black and white), they predicted it would prove naive - white Rhodesians would never vote for Mugabe. I privately felt it remarkable that black Zimbabweans seemed so quick to forgive, so free of rancour or racial hatred. In the early Eighties, there was a tide of expatriates flowing in to 'help' the new Zimbabwe. Many of them were untrained teachers, like me. We were accepted with gratitude and enthusiasm. I found the welcome humbling; it was a luxury to be needed.

My pupils at St Augustine's did not go on being as eerily polite as they were at the outset. I acquired the nickname Sssh Everybody, based on my weedy attempts to get the class to be quiet. It was a measure of the lack of any discipline problem that 'Ssh, everybody' worked. One of the boys I taught was called Nhamo which means trouble - he wasn't. Another was called Genius (he, like his friend Brilliant, was a dullard). But many of my pupils could easily have lived up to Brilliant or Clever (another popular name). I was scared by the ability of my A-level class. Even studying in a second language, most of them would have been more than a match for their English counterparts.

The work itself was anomalous. I was alive to the neo-colonial oddity of teaching Milton's Comus , Jane Austen's Emma and Thomas Hardy's The Mayor of Casterbridge . But I will never forget how Tiyani Chitepo, a charismatic boy (son of the legendary Herbert Chitepo, who would have been Prime Minister if he hadn't been blown up by a bomb), got the hang of Comus in no time, writing a bold essay on the similarity between Comus and JR in Dallas . Of course, there were also students who could not cope at all. I remember a beautiful, industrious girl called Gloria writing, as if her first sentence were a sigh: ' Emma is a very, very long novel ...'

In the evenings, I taught grown-ups, some of them old enough to be my grandparents, people who had never, in the old Rhodesia, been allowed to finish their education and who were returning to school in middle and old age to pick up from where they had left off. Nothing was more moving to me than the sight of these people hunched on tiny school chairs (the lessons, with an appropriate irony, took place in the primary school). They were so keen to learn. So optimistic. When one of my colleagues referred to this time as Zimbabwe's 'honeymoon period', I registered the phrase with dismay. Zimbabwe would surely not make the mistakes other African countries had made. It would be visionary.

I knew that Zimbabwe was giving me more than I could ever offer it in return. And I understood the love that white Rhodesians felt for the land. I loved it, too. I wished I could stay forever. But I belonged in neither the black nor white communities. I was troubled by the attitude of most of the white Rhodesians I met. They seemed to speak in a collective language. When they disparaged black people, I was struck by how often they used exactly the same phrases, as though they had conferred. Perhaps that is how prejudice is. It often seemed that it was the more intrepid and liberal Rhodesians that had left the country; those who stayed on were as ready for a 'policy of reconciliation' as they were to be bitten by a snake.

I fell in love with the country and then I fell in love with a Zimbabwean, also teaching at St Augustine's. When he got a job in Harare as a government auditor, I moved to the city with him. It was difficult to find anywhere to live together; any racism I had encountered in the Eastern Highlands was tame in comparison to what we faced from the white landlords of the suburban houses we hoped to rent. I learnt to speak rudimentary Shona, enough to know that 'kamba' means both tortoise and small house, and that there is only one word in Shona for good, beautiful, lovely, sweet, pretty, attractive. For six months, while we looked for somewhere else to live, we stayed with my boyfriend's extended family in a kamba in St Mary's township.

St Mary's is the oldest of the Chitungwiza townships. It is 25 kilometres outside Harare and has been euphemistically renamed a 'high-density suburb'. It is a vast complex of tiny houses, with no electricity. The community alternated between energy and lassitude. It was always noisy (with a cock that crowed even at midnight). The women would cook, wash, pass babies from lap to lap and sweep outside their houses every morning as if to achieve that impossible thing - clean dirt. There was not much else to do. St Mary's was like a waiting-room. People were waiting for better times.

The Shona language is not given to directness but people made no secret of their desire for an improved standard of living. They were exuberantly materialistic but with almost nothing to show for it. (When a neighbour bought a new car, a secondhand, rusty brute, a party was thrown to celebrate.) On Independence Day in 1983, I wrote home, describing a subdued mood. The crowd, I thought, seemed 'guarded, not certain whether to celebrate'. Euphoria was missing. I could guess why. Independence was the magic wand that didn't quite work, wielded by a dilatory magician.

No one said they felt cheated or disappointed. My pupils always still talked about Mugabe and independence with expectant pride but in the township, lives had not changed enough - yet. The anticlimax could sometimes be seen on people's faces. The township was full of the unemployed: old men, listless teenagers. It was easy to understand what education promised - it was seen as a way out. At least independence meant education for all. New schools were opening everywhere. I taught at Zengeza High, a vast, red-brick place in the township with 'hot seating'. More than 2,000 children attended. It was like a brave factory that was not quite sure what it was turning out. For a disorganised term or two, I was head of its English department. There were some good teachers and some flamboyantly bad ones (one of the teachers in my charge was always drunk as a lord but it never stopped him from 'teaching'. I had to turf him out of class when I found him teaching in the wrong session). How could this uneven and unwieldy school begin to fulfil the hopes of its pupils? I used to look at the slogans many children had painted on their satchels - 'Education is the key to success' - and wonder.

But even in 1983, black Zimbabweans were beginning to feel that some of Mugabe's Ministers were too greedy, that rich blacks were replacing whites. In a letter home from St Mary's, I wrote anxiously: 'There has been a quiet demonstration against those Ministers in Mugabe's government who are not practising the socialism they preach. The protesters argue that those Ministers who now own big farms should relinquish either their land or their government posts.'

There was talk at that time of banning Zapu and becoming a one-party state. The letter ended with a sense of foreboding: 'I wonder whether there will ever be real racial harmony in this country. Prejudices go so deep. The layout and architecture of Harare make it hard to imagine integration. There are the sterile, white suburbs with their flowering trees and then 20km out the townships - a tumult of noise and people and wild trees and rocks.'

I left Zimbabwe in 1986. In 1988, my boyfriend walked out on his job as a government auditor. He had been an idealistic Zanu supporter but was too disillusioned by government corruption to continue. He lives in England now. He tells me now that all Zimbabwe's problems over land redistribution should have been properly addressed 20 years ago.

In Shona, when you ask someone how they are, they reply with a sentence which, literally translated, means: 'I am fine, if you are fine.' I used to find it delightful, amusingly evasive. In the not-so-new Zimbabwe, that evasion may not be funny any more.
