fields.headline: Here's another fine mescal
fields.standfirst: Francisco Toledo is the greatest Mexican artist you've never heard of, so enjoy him while he's here
fields.trailText: Francisco Toledo
fields.body:
Francisco Toledo Whitechapel Art Gallery, 7 June

Francisco Toledo is the most famous artist in Latin America but you almost certainly won't know his name. This has nothing to do with nationality - every gringo gallery loved Diego Rivera in his day - and everything to do with the artist.

Like the fabulous figures and beasts in his art, Toledo seems to hide among siesta shadows. He hasn't agreed to a European show in almost 20 years and his work circulates like contraband between private collectors. Sightings of the artist, so ferociously handsome, so prodigally gifted, are rare enough to make news in his native Mexico.

Toledo was born in 1940 in Juchitán on the heat-parched Oaxaca isthmus. He left for Paris at the age of 19, which is roughly where the Toledo legend begins, with the penniless genius drawing on the floor in icy corridors, so homesick that Octavio Paz offered to send him an iguana in a diplomatic bag. By the time he returned, via Manhattan, where he was spotted shoeless in the winter snows, Toledo had shown in several European galleries and was making images unlike anything in Mexican art.

Scorpions in stilettos, calendar-girl cats, crabs that clap their pincers together like prize-fighters emerging from the ring - this is not so much an anthropomorphic world as one in which animals are equal with humans. Sometimes, the two conjugate in marvellous hybrids - crocodile Romeos, frog philosophers, grasshopper statesmen, all tough carapace and mid-rhetorical gesture. Sometimes, man and beast unite; the artist seduces his lover on a beach - the paint is literally mixed with sand - framed by a halo of ecstatic crabs. It is all one great zoological garden to Toledo, in which everything lives, loves and laments in the same dazzling, fertile climate.

If this sounds like some Mesoamerican trip - animals spirits conjured up on mescal - nothing could be further from the visual facts. Toledo is no whimsical folklorist, but a draughtsman in the grand tradition. His etchings have been compared with Goya and Ensor and his watercolours elaborate a whole series of invented hieroglyphs and signs as delicate and toylike as anything by Klee.

To see his work en masse at the Whitechapel is to drift through a terracotta landscape in which insects vibrate in the hot, bright air and animals move with sultry languor. But it's also to see an artist trying on a hundred different styles, amazingly fecund, salty yet suave - Mexico's answer to Picasso.

Not since Old Cojones departed the Earth himself has any artist been quite so priapic. There isn't a fish, snake or monkey in this show that doesn't wear its manhood proudly. Some critters are just uselessly concu piscent - the cobalt lizard, you feel, is too vain to get a date - while others bask in erotic hedonism. The cocky rabbit, cousin to Warner's roadrunner, has outwitted so many coyotes that he is depicted as a double-pronged king among animals. Toledo even sculpts himself in scarlet clay, lying on his back, trousers unbuttoned to the warming sun. This is not the fly-fumbling randiness of late Picasso, but an innocent relish for earthly pleasures.

Toledo loves to spin yarns - cocky rabbit is upgraded Aesop. There's also something of Kafka in his half-human insects, trapped in their reticulated bodies, and a good deal of Borgesian wit to his mythical creatures. But the stories are very often his own memories of childhood. His mother's warnings against the perils of the sewing machine generate a spectacular painting of a cat bristling beneath the whirring instrument, an electric storm of claws and needles. Best of all is his homage to the bicycle, in which the freedom machine speeds off riderless through the heat, trailing a cloud of dust behind it.

Toledo uses all sorts of material to get that onomatopoeic effect: salt, dust, chalky pigments that imitate the grainy, desiccated surface of the land. He still works on the floor, using oil-coated boards, and some of his images are exactly what they seem to be - drawings in sand. There's a transformatory touch to everything he does, conjuring tattered birds out of rubbed and abraided papyrus, embed ding a few pistachio shells in baked clay to get a planar view of Oaxaca. I doubt anybody has ever evoked the delirious hum of insects better; five pencils, tied together and zig-zagged in a skittering dance across a scrap of paper.

But you can have too much of the great outdoors; one more flash rabbit or braying donkey would probably have tipped the balance. By far the most enthralling works in this show are the self-portraits in the last gallery, a suite of etchings, lithos and sketches in which the artist sends himself up.

Toledo the hero, the art star, the titanic lover - all are reduced to foolish fables. What you see is a browbeaten man, often depicted alongside an animal in a Mexican stand-off. The comparison with Goya is there in the mordant self-scrutiny. But Toledo even has a go at introspection. There he is, head in hand, slumped at a table. Behind him, a giant toad parodies this soulful posture, one paw clutched to its mocking breast.

Sometimes, the two conjugate in marvellous hybrids - crocodile Romeos, frog philosophers, grasshopper statesmen, all tough carapace and mid-rhetorical gesture. Sometimes, man and beast unite; the artist seduces his lover on a beach - the paint is literally mixed with sand - framed by a halo of ecstatic crabs. It is all one great zoological garden to Toledo, in which everything lives, loves and laments in the same dazzling, fertile climate. If this sounds like some Mesoamerican trip - animals spirits conjured up on mescal - nothing could be further from the visual facts. Toledo is no whimsical folklorist, but a draughtsman in the grand tradition. His etchings have been compared with Goya and Ensor and his watercolours elaborate a whole series of invented hieroglyphs and signs as delicate and toylike as anything by Klee. To see his work en masse at the Whitechapel is to drift through a terracotta landscape in which insects vibrate in the hot, bright air and animals move with sultry languor. But it's also to see an artist trying on a hundred different styles, amazingly fecund, salty yet suave - Mexico's answer to Picasso. Not since Old Cojones departed the Earth himself has any artist been quite so priapic. There isn't a fish, snake or monkey in this show that doesn't wear its manhood proudly. Some critters are just uselessly concu piscent - the cobalt lizard, you feel, is too vain to get a date - while others bask in erotic hedonism. The cocky rabbit, cousin to Warner's roadrunner, has outwitted so many coyotes that he is depicted as a double-pronged king among animals. Toledo even sculpts himself in scarlet clay, lying on his back, trousers unbuttoned to the warming sun. This is not the fly-fumbling randiness of late Picasso, but an innocent relish for earthly pleasures. Toledo loves to spin yarns - cocky rabbit is upgraded Aesop. There's also something of Kafka in his half-human insects, trapped in their reticulated bodies, and a good deal of Borgesian wit to his mythical creatures. But the stories are very often his own memories of childhood. His mother's warnings against the perils of the sewing machine generate a spectacular painting of a cat bristling beneath the whirring instrument, an electric storm of claws and needles. Best of all is his homage to the bicycle, in which the freedom machine speeds off riderless through the heat, trailing a cloud of dust behind it. Toledo uses all sorts of material to get that onomatopoeic effect: salt, dust, chalky pigments that imitate the grainy, desiccated surface of the land. He still works on the floor, using oil-coated boards, and some of his images are exactly what they seem to be - drawings in sand. There's a transformatory touch to everything he does, conjuring tattered birds out of rubbed and abraided papyrus, embed ding a few pistachio shells in baked clay to get a planar view of Oaxaca. I doubt anybody has ever evoked the delirious hum of insects better; five pencils, tied together and zig-zagged in a skittering dance across a scrap of paper. But you can have too much of the great outdoors; one more flash rabbit or braying donkey would probably have tipped the balance. By far the most enthralling works in this show are the self-portraits in the last gallery, a suite of etchings, lithos and sketches in which the artist sends himself up. Toledo the hero, the art star, the titanic lover - all are reduced to foolish fables. What you see is a browbeaten man, often depicted alongside an animal in a Mexican stand-off. The comparison with Goya is there in the mordant self-scrutiny. But Toledo even has a go at introspection. There he is, head in hand, slumped at a table. Behind him, a giant toad parodies this soulful posture, one paw clutched to its mocking breast.

webTitle: Good? Not by a long stretch...

fields.headline: Good? Not by a long stretch...
fields.trailText: Elastica London Kentish Town Forum
fields.body:
Elastica London Kentish Town Forum

Justine Frischmann has spent a lot of time in recovery. There were the break-ups with boyfriends - Brett Anderson of Suede, and Damon Albarn of Blur - to get over. Then there was the disintegration of the original Elastica - bassist Annie Holland and guitarist Donna Matthews both left. And to top it all, the record company had the cheek to want another album, for which release dates came and went: the popular take became that it was time Frischmann retired disgracefully.

So the fact that she is here on stage is something of a surprise. That she looks quite so schoolgirl healthy is frankly shocking. Her hair is in a bunch; she is jumping about in a vest; she may well have had a good night's sleep recently. She looks as if the past four years never happened, although, sadly, all around her is evidence that they did.

The crowd are the same fans as before, back to give the band another chance. It's a shame the recent material doesn't warrant their fidelity. New album The Menace is, with the exception of 'Mad Dog', a series of atmospheric synth-heavy sighs. Perhaps even Frischmann knows this: the second song tonight is the 1994 hit 'Line Up' and she asks Donna Matthews, lurking beneath her fringe in the audience, to come up and play. She eventually does on an encore of 'Connection' - which only confirms that Elastica's best songs are behind them.

fields.headline: A waste of space
fields.standfirst: Boldly going into science fiction for the first time, Brian De Palma's 2020 vision doesn't really get off the ground
fields.trailText: Mission to Mars
fields.body:
Mission to Mars (116 mins, PG) Directed by Brian De Palma; starring Gary Sinise, Tim Robbins, Don Cheadle

It was a mistake to play Strauss's Blue Danube waltz at the Odeon, Leicester Square the other morning before the lights went down for Mission to Mars . To be reminded of Kubrick's classic SF movie before seeing Brian De Palma's first essay in the genre was as dangerous as it would be to have someone sing a Verdi aria before the curtain goes up on the Elton John-Tim Rice version of Aïda .

De Palma's movie comes at an odd time, a year before the setting of 2001: A Space Odyssey and two years before the centenary of Georges Méliès's 1902 milestone, A Trip to the Moon . For a century, the cinema has reflected the mood on Earth through our attitudes of fear, wonder and anticipation attendant upon the exploration of space. Fritz Lang's 1929 Woman in the Moon invented the countdown while Werner von Braun was still a schoolboy; Alexander Korda's 1935 masterpiece Things to Come saw a journey to the stars as the salvation of a troubled world; postwar SF flicks such as The Day the Earth Stood Still reflected Cold War tensions.

When space fiction started to become space fact in the late Fifties, the ground had been laid for Kubrick's landmark combination of mechanics and mysticism from which all subsequent space films stem.

In 1983, The Right Stuff treated the US space enterprise in a historical fashion, looking back to the origins of supersonic flight and the beginning of the Mercury programme in the early Sixties. This has recently been followed up by Apollo 13 which recalled how, as early as 1970, it took a near-fatal accident to capture the attention of jaded viewers.

While his friends and fellow movie brats Steven Spielberg and George Lucas were making Close Encounters and Star Wars , De Palma was directing thrillers that paid homage to Hitchcock, and over the years he's brought his kinetic flair and his taste to a variety of genres, rarely attempting to break new ground.

Now in his sixtieth year, with a grandiose screen version of the old TV series Mission: Impossible behind him, De Palma has got around to SF with a second mission movie boldly going where others have gone before.

The year is 2020 and a joint Russian-American expedition to Mars is being led by black astronaut, Luke Graham (Don Cheadle), presumably named by his parents in honour of the sky walking movie hero. Things go awry when they meet a strange Martian force that sucks the Russians into a lethal vortex, sparing only Luke. He'd been reading Treasure Island with his son before blasting off and had wondered how 'that old Ben Gunn' got marooned.

Now he knows and a quartet of colleagues set out from a space station to his rescue. They're the husband-and-wife team, Woody (Tim Robbins) and Terri (Connie Nielsen); the recently widowed systems designer, Jim (Gary Sinise); and the young engineer, Phil (Jerry 0'Connell). Time on board goes slowly and Woody and Terri dance upside down to pass the hours while Jim looks at home movies of his late wife, a fellow astronaut with whom he'd planned to explore Mars. To paraphrase the advertising slogan for Alien , in space nobody can hear you cry.

Not everyone makes it there and back, and in trying to land, the rescuers undergo a crisis that makes the Apollo 13 affair look like trouble with the dashboard lighter. They finish up stranded on the red planet equipped with some simple escape aids and some clunky B-movie dialogue. 'I don't see how a quake six months ago could have caused such distortion,' someone remarks. 'That was no quake,' someone replies just a split second after the whole audience has delivered the line in unison.

Interpreting a series of test messages à la 2001 leads to a close encounter with a higher intelligence. Entering into an all-white palace, the starry-eyed astronauts are entertained by a three-dimensional planetarium display that provides them with a history of the universe. They meet a tall, thin, androgynous extraterrestrial dressed in gold lamé, which may be the standard Martian uniform, though perhaps this exotic creature is on the way to the Oscars.

One way or the other, this scene epitomises the total absence of invention and imagination. There is the possibility that a final sequence has been cut in which it's revealed that the movie is a Tarkovskian hallucination experienced by an early astronaut who's spent his retirement watching SF movies.

This idea is not entirely my own, as it forms the background to Galaxy Quest , an hilarious SF comedy which opens in a fortnight's time and is a treat in store.

fields.headline: A store is born
fields.trailText: Only a decade ago the British department store looked to be ready for the scrap heap. From their high point in the years just after the First World War, the big stores have been in more or less continuous retreat ever since
fields.body:
Only a decade ago the British department store looked to be ready for the scrap heap. From their high point in the years just after the First World War, the big stores have been in more or less continuous retreat ever since. The recent rediscovery of the glamour of the department store is as much as anything to do with the tedium of buying everything from books to groceries on the screen. If there is any point in having shops at all, it is to recreate the theatrical qualities that made the department store what it was in the first place, and if you are going to have it in any kind of building, it had better be an impressive one.

Vittorio Radice, the irrepressible boss of Selfridges, has plenty of old-fashioned showmanship. Instead of putting up scaffolding while the London store is being refurbished, he has opted to wrap the exterior in a giant photograph by artist Sam Taylor Wood, which he calls the largest work of art in the world. It's the kind of stunt that New York's Macy's, who in the nineteenth century would clear out a whole floor for an indoor golf tournament, would recognise. Radice is also aware of the importance of distinctive architecture in helping a department store survive in the present climate. He has got Norman Foster remodelling the back of the London store, and in Birmingham he has commissioned Future Systems to design a new windowless store.

It's an important project for Selfridges and, with a budget of £40 million, an important one for Future Systems. Jan Kaplicky is an architect who has spent most of his career thinking big and building small. He has dreamt about skyscrapers and museums, but has had to invest most of his energies into designing wine coolers for the Ivy and the interiors of chic florists shops.

However, last year's unveiling of his spectacular media centre at Lord's won him recognition and prizes. Until recently Future Systems consisted of Kaplicky, his partner, Amanda Levete and a lot of hope. Kaplicky came to London from Prague in 1968, and a lot of his thinking is shaped by those years spent on the wrong side of the iron curtain. Now, after two decades labouring away at the outer edges of architectural practice, Future Systems has made it into the mainstream.

The commission for Selfridges in Birmingham fulfils the promise Future Systems has shown for so long. Their plans are the result of the rebuilding of the Bullring, the most unloved shopping development of all from the Sixties. It is one of a pair of big department stores that will act as anchors at either end of a new covered mall. But what makes it stand out from the Esperanto architecture of the conventional mall is the quality of the Selfridges design which has an architectural presence both inside, and outside the mall. It has to address the precinct of St Martin's church, the major roads that Birmingham is still trying to tame, and the mall itself.

One solution to these very different tasks would have been architectural schizophrenia: contextualism to create a suitable setting for the gothic church on one side, high-tech exhibitionism to make a landmark to be seen by passing motorists on the other, and the stage-set approach of the typical shopping mall inside, to tempt in the customers. It was not a strategy that appealed to Kaplicky, who believes in consistency, and logic. Instead he has designed a free-form shape that deals with all three aspects of the store with one voice. It is a gentle curving structure that winds in and out of the mall, to and from the street edge.

It defers to the church, it allows for entrances at a number of different levels, and it also deals with the prohibition that conventional retailing wisdom puts on windows. There is a garden and a restaurant on the roof, and two atria inside. On the outside the skin is pierced by a couple of glass bubbles that provide a showcase for passers-by.

The store will look as apparently alien to architectural tradition as one of Kaplicky's beloved spaceships. But in fact it represents something of a softening of Future Systems's pursuit of innovation. The inspiration here is not the celebration of ultra-high technology. The store is influenced by much more organic forms, and , it has to be said, some of Kaplicky's dreams from the Sixties. This will not be a titanium-skinned hull; instead the proposed cladding is made from a pretty low-tech material - circular china plates. And it is a frankly decorative skin.

In hiring Future Systems Radice is going back to the store's roots. In 1908, Gordon Selfridge brought the great Chicago architect Daniel Burnham to Britain to design a department store for him, the like of which London had not seen before. Future Systems will certainly do the same for Birmingham.

webTitle: And this looks like the real me

fields.headline: And this looks like the real me
fields.standfirst: With a new exhibition by The Observer's Jane Bown opening at the end of this month,  Björk pays tribute to the photographer who didn't try to turn her into a puffin-eating, crazy elf...
fields.trailText: With a new exhibition by The Observer's Jane Bown opening at the end of this month, Björk pays tribute to the photographer who didn't try to turn her into a puffin-eating, crazy elf...
fields.body:
Long before I met Jane, I was in the Sugarcubes. We were purists and thought the media was the devil, that they were the ones who killed Elvis and all that. We were really anti-press. Also, I'd lived in Iceland all my life; I was violently shy. So it was only when I moved to London in 1993 that I said to myself: 'You're a coward; do 5,000 interviews a day.' I jumped off a cliff into the media.

When I met Jane I had been doing interviews for about 12-14 hours every day for three months. That much exposure was like an interesting chemistry experiment. At the time, I was really into it and found it exciting, but I took it simply as an experience. To meet Jane at that point was really refreshing. She was so no-nonsense and knew exactly what she was doing. There were no show-offy tricks or fake ways to get to know me.

Sometimes, when you meet these strangers, and they're all foreigners, the idea of trying to be close and personal with someone in three seconds is really hard to deal with. Jane was different. Jane's really matter of-fact about things. I think she's definitely born with a talent. She knows. She can look at a person and she knows instinctively, straight away, who they are. She picks up more on the human side of people. A lot of photographers concentrated on the comical aspect of me and got me to do animated things - to be sort of an eskimo, puffin-eating, crazy elf. But Jane was definitely not up for that. She just takes people as they are. She picks up the down-to-earth-nature in people in about five seconds. She will just ignore everything else, and ask you to sit down. She's also very calm - that's important. If the other person is neurotic then it's not a lot of fun.

When we first met, I didn't know anything about her. I was meeting all the famous people ever and I didn't have a clue who they were. I remembered Jane more than the picture she took. There was a feeling that she didn't want to make anything out of me, was just taking me as I was, for who I am. It's very honest. It's not the strongest of descriptive words to use, but it's simply what it is. Honest. Her simplicity is the key, so to kind of throw too many words in there to try and describe it just confuses it. Although I don't know anything about her life, I can imagine her picking up that kind of honesty, say, 10 times a day. It's a consistency she has - a mood she brings. You get very grateful to be photographed by someone like that.

The second time she photographed me was when I interviewed David Attenborough. I was a little nervous because I'd never met David before and he's my absolute hero. She was asking us to embrace each other, which made me very shy. But she was the same as the first time we met. She's just bulletproof.

Jane's pictures will become part of a book about my career that I'm working on at the moment. My record company has spent five years convincing me it was the thing to do. I thought it was too self-indulgent to put a book out about yourself. But it's not really about me, it's about the people who've given me a chance to say what I want to say. There's a section where I've asked some of the people I've worked with the most to contribute something that comes from them - it doesn't have to be anything to do with me. When I work with a designer or a photographer, a video director, a musician, a producer or an engineer, for me it's all the same interaction. It's about getting to know the person and then trying to find mutual ground. Where is the place we are both at home? In most cases, I've just been an umbrella. You see all my records and it just says Björk Björk Björk all over it, but at the end of the day, it's always a collaboration.

Jane is one of several photographers - including Jurgen Teller, Nick Knight and Araki - in the book that I've chosen because they are quite truthful. People say photographers are documenting humans. It's either complete fantasy - the creative, theatrical, fantasy world - or there's the other extreme: face value. The covers of my albums are the fantasy element - they're not the way I look every day but have an element of truth to them. Jane's work is the opposite - the stark reality. Truth lies in one or other extreme.

I don't know when we'll next meet. I'm lucky, I'm my own boss. Most people in my job have 5,000 people in skyscrapers making plans, but I can do whatever I want. It's always one day at a time round my house. Jane's putting a picture of me on the front of her new book. I'm just really honoured.

 Eye to Eye, an exhibition of photography by Jane Bown, runs from 23 April to 28 May at the Foundation Gallery, Gate 13, Lamb Street, Spitalfields Market, London E1. Admission free. Open 12-3, Tuesday-Friday. 10am-6pm, Sundays. Open Bank Holiday Monday

I was a little nervous because I'd never met David before and he's my absolute hero. She was asking us to embrace each other, which made me very shy. But she was the same as the first time we met. She's just bulletproof. Jane's pictures will become part of a book about my career that I'm working on at the moment. My record company has spent five years convincing me it was the thing to do. I thought it was too self-indulgent to put a book out about yourself. But it's not really about me, it's about the people who've given me a chance to say what I want to say. There's a section where I've asked some of the people I've worked with the most to contribute something that comes from them - it doesn't have to be anything to do with me. When I work with a designer or a photographer, a video director, a musician, a producer or an engineer, for me it's all the same interaction. It's about getting to know the person and then trying to find mutual ground. Where is the place we are both at home? In most cases, I've just been an umbrella. You see all my records and it just says Björk Björk Björk all over it, but at the end of the day, it's always a collaboration. Jane is one of several photographers - including Jurgen Teller, Nick Knight and Araki - in the book that I've chosen because they are quite truthful. People say photographers are documenting humans. It's either complete fantasy - the creative, theatrical, fantasy world - or there's the other extreme: face value. The covers of my albums are the fantasy element - they're not the way I look every day but have an element of truth to them. Jane's work is the opposite - the stark reality. Truth lies in one or other extreme. I don't know when we'll next meet. I'm lucky, I'm my own boss. Most people in my job have 5,000 people in skyscrapers making plans, but I can do whatever I want. It's always one day at a time round my house. Jane's putting a picture of me on the front of her new book. I'm just really honoured.  Eye to Eye, an exhibition of photography by Jane Bown, runs from 23 April to 28 May at the Foundation Gallery, Gate 13, Lamb Street, Spitalfields Market, London E1. Admission free. Open 12-3, Tuesday-Friday. 10am-6pm, Sundays. Open Bank Holiday Monday

fields.headline: New ways to bypass  the NHS
fields.standfirst: The cost of private medical insurance is beyond most people. But whether it's your hip or your hernia, there are other ways round the problem.  Neasa MacErlean  reports
fields.trailText: If you are Mr or Ms Typical, you are probably getting a bit worried by the stories about the National Health Service buckling under the strain. You had been under the impression that the welfare state was meant to look after you 'from cradle to grave'. But you know your own finances could not cope with paying the premiums on a private medical insurance (PMI) policy. So you avoid thinking about the issues, hoping that everything will be sorted out should you ever need medical treatment.
fields.body:
If you are Mr or Ms Typical, you are probably getting a bit worried by the stories about the National Health Service buckling under the strain. You had been under the impression that the welfare state was meant to look after you 'from cradle to grave'. But you know your own finances could not cope with paying the premiums on a private medical insurance (PMI) policy. So you avoid thinking about the issues, hoping that everything will be sorted out should you ever need medical treatment.

Time is on your side. If you keep fit and avoid dangerous activities, you could well get to 65 without relying much on the NHS. Your biggest need for medical help is likely to come right at the end of your life; 41 per cent of NHS expenditure goes on over-65s.

There are two questions you need to consider about 'going private'.

How much can I rely on the NHS to meet my needs in future?

It should still be able to take care of you reasonably well in emergencies. PMI policies do not cover emergency treatment anyway. But at the other end of the spectrum, the NHS is not particularly good at providing preventative medicine. If you want to avoid falling ill in the first place, you probably need to start thinking about fitness programmes, medical check-ups, reducing stress, avoiding back pain and other issues yourself.

In the middle of the spectrum, there are the hip, cataract and other operations that are not classified as emergency treatment but considerably improve your quality of life if the operation is successful.

The big question now is whether the extra NHS funding announced in the Budget will make a difference. It is certainly substantial - £35 billion over five years, an average annual rise of 6 per cent. Healthcare expert and former MEP Brendan Donnelly says: 'It is possible that in three or four years the health service will be significantly better, and therefore that the pressure on people to buy private medical cover will reduce. The more money is put into the health service, the more work can be done on lifestyles and conditions that are not life-threatening.

In France they don't have waiting lists for most conditions. But we'll only get that when we spend as much as they do - and we're a long way off that.' An extra 6p to 8p would have to be added to income tax rates - to raise £15-£20 billion a year - to get us to French standards, according to research conducted by the Institute of Directors.

Waiting lists are likely to remain a problem in the UK. The average waiting time is six-and-a-half months for a hip replacement and six months for a heart bypass.

Julian Stainton, chief executive of WPA, does not believes the extra money will improve the NHS sufficiently to satisfy the public: 'Whatever extra money goes into the NHS, the demand for healthcare is infinite. We all want to live forever and be perfectly healthy.'

Living longer increases demand for care. In the past 100 years, life expectancy has gone up from about 60 to close on 80 years for women, but healthcare costs are soaring. As pharmaceutical research develops, so does pressure for expensive drugs (such as Viagra) to be available on the NHS.

Can I afford to 'go private' if I want to?

If you are offered a scheme through your employer, you should think seriously about it. A large proportion of the 6.5 million people covered by private insurance use this route. Your employer can often arrange a cheaper policy, with fewer exclusions.

But for most people, private healthcare is currently out of the question. To get fully comprehensive cover now, a 65-year old could expect to pay £2,000 a year in premiums.

But new ways are being developed to make private treatment more affordable. Many people are paying for their operations when the need arises. (See case study, page 5). The Observer estimates that 160,000 people had 'self-pay' operations last year. But a new breed of policies (see table, page 3) is cutting premiums by up to 80 per cent. These 'excess' policies are expected to become far more popular.

Another development is likely to be the launch of 'co-payment' plans, expected within the next year. These plans will require the policyholder to share part of the medical cost. For example, you could be asked to pay 25 per cent of costs up to a ceiling of £1,000. The reason insurers are so keen on these policies is that they encourage the policyholder to keep the costs down.

The Government is consulting with think tanks and other interested parties on the future of healthcare. Various bodies will produce ideas this year.

One of the first was the Institute of Directors, which urged that the NHS 'be redefined as the funder of "core" services ... It would not be the provider'. The core services would 'focus on serious and life-threatening diseases' and exclude preventative treatment.

This may be very close to what actually happens over the next 10 to 20 years.

Need it fixed? Then fix yourself a deal...

1: Take your notebook when you see your GP. If you think you may need an operation, you start by getting a referral from a GP. But if you want to go private by paying the bill yourself, you should probably contact several hospitals to get the best price and service. 'When you ring the hospital you need to know exactly what you are looking for,' says Peter Crane of Standard Life Healthcare's treatment information service.

2: Ask for the finance department if ringing a private hospital, or the Private Patients Unit if ringing an NHS hospital. If an NHS hospital does not have such a unit, it may still provide private treatment but they may not be so patient-friendly.

3: Get them to put their quotes on paper, stating exactly what you would be paying for. Some people have been given quotes excluding - bizarrely - surgeons' and anaesthetists' fees. There could be many types of cost, including pre- and post-operative consultancy costs, physiotherapy, and bed and board. The Nuffield group of hospitals give guarantees for all costs if people need to be readmitted soon after the op.

4: Ask to see a fixed-price quote. You will get this only after seeing a consultant.

5: Consider avoiding London if you are financially stretched. Costs can be 10 to 20 per cent higher in the capital, where healthcare salary levels are also higher.

6: Speak to several hospitals. London hip replacement prices can vary from £5,500 to £7,500, according to Standard Life. Nationwide prices on heart bypass ops range from about £9,000 to £14,000. Some price variation relates to consultants' preferences on method and equipment. So ask the consultant about the influences on price.

7: Start negotiating by discussing the timing of the op if you need to get the cost down. In times of less demand - Christmas, for example, other holidays and weekends - some hospitals will agree to a lower price so that they can use up their slack capacity.

 Tips based on an interview with Standard Life Healthcare

fields.headline: Doctored Livingstone
fields.standfirst: A plot to smear Ken, involving under-age sex and a love child? It's satire, isn't it? This exclusive extract from  Tariq Ali 's new play actually has a ring of truth...
fields.trailText: A plot to smear Ken, involving under-age sex and a love child? It's satire, isn't it? This exclusive extract from  Tariq Ali 's new play actually has a ring of truth...
fields.body:
Snogging Ken is a one-act 'entertainment' about a sinister New Labour plot to smear Ken Livingstone, which opens at London's Almeida theatre this week.

The authors

Tariq Ali: An author, film-maker, playwright and broadcaster who was involved in setting up Channel 4. His most recent television production was Fay Weldon's Big Women.

Howard Brenton: A playwright whose works include Romans in Britain and Pravda, co-authored with David Hare. He has co-written five plays with Tariq Ali, including Iranian Nights and Moscow Gold.

Andy De La Tour: A playwright and actor whose most recent appearance was in Harold Pinter's Celebration at the Almeida. He has collaborated with Brenton and Ali once before on Landslide.

Dramatis Personae

Pandora Manfidi: A Millbank Babe in her late twenties.

Lola Jones: A Labour MP in her mid-twenties.

Thick-boy Geezer: A rock star and Ken-supporter.

Douglas Hall: A former Cabinet Minister.

A young woman, PANDORA, sits at Table One. At Table Two sits a young man, THICK BOY GEEZER. They're both waiting. LOLA comes in, flustered, and sits at Pandora's table. Lights fade on Table Two.

Table One

LOLA: I'm so sorry, I'm so dreadfully sorry.

PANDORA: Sweetheart, sit down. Water?

LOLA: Something a little stronger?

PANDORA: I think not. Not today.

Pandora pours her a glass of mineral water.

PANDORA: How do you feel?

LOLA: Terrible.

PANDORA: You mustn't blame yourself.

LOLA: I wasn't prepared. I thought I was but I wasn't. I feel so guilty.

PANDORA: How many times did he do it to you exactly?

LOLA: Ten, twelve, I don't know. I tried to stop him. I wanted to shout out in protest but I couldn't. My throat had dried up. He just kept on coming at me. From all angles. How could he have abused me like that?

PANDORA: Don't torment yourself, Lola. Newsnight . Every politician loathes Jeremy Paxman.

LOLA: I feel so ashamed. I was Paxmanned!

PANDORA: Listen, sweetheart. To be Paxmanned is a baptism of fire, think of it as a slither up the learning curve.

LOLA: But look at Michael Howard, he was finished after his Paxman.

PANDORA: No he survived the interview. It was Ann Widdecombe who fisted him.

Pandora takes delicate sip of water.

LOLA: So no more interviews for me. I quite understand, I had my chance and I blew it .

PANDORA: No, no, not at all. Quite the opposite. You're a celebrity now. Everyone wants to interview you. John Humphrys, James Naughtie, even Trevor MacDonald thinks he can come up with a question.

LOLA: Oh good. I'll do better next time I promise.

PANDORA: We know you will. We're counting on you, Lola. You've put all frivolous personal pursuits aside for the sake of your leader.

LOLA: I won't let you down.

PANDORA: It's a fiasco. The whole campaign. How do we turn it round? How do we transform Frank Dobson into the winning candidate?

LOLA: What do the focus groups say?

PANDORA: We dissolved them. They all wanted to vote for Ken.

LOLA: I can believe it! D'you know, I haven't met one single person who's going to vote for Frank.

PANDORA: Or for Shagger Norris. Not to mention the Libdem thingy.

LOLA: But it's no fault of Millbank's that Ken's riding so high in the polls. He's more popular than Tony!

PANDORA: (Tetchy) Yes, yes, all right Lola. The problem is Frank. He just keeps fucking up. I told him to be cool on Question Time . Play it strong and silent, I said. And what does the fat arsehole go and say? "Make my Day". Dobbo the Donkey as Clint Eastwood? I think not.

LOLA: (Shocked) Do you talk about all us MPs like that at Millbank?

PANDORA: Only incontinent dinosaurs like Dobboplodicus that refuse to make themselves extinct. Not you, sweetheart, you're our new breed, barely hatched. A little wobbly on the claws - like last night - but you'll soon be flying high.

LOLA: But how can I help?

PANDORA: The strategic gameplan is 'New Labour, New Electorate'.

LOLA: (Alarmed) You mean cancel the election? Abolish the electorate? Not let people vote?

PANDORA: No, Lola, I was being _

LOLA: Hyperbolic?

PANDORA: Conceptual. Hearts and minds. The key to a new electorate. We can't persuade them to vote for Dobbo the Donkey. But we can persuade them not to vote for Ken. Even at this eleventh hour.

LOLA: But we can't persuade them. Frank's still on 16 per cent!

PANDORA: We can poison them.

LOLA: What?

PANDORA: Poison their minds.

LOLA: How?

PANDORA: You, sweet babe, are the cyanide pill of democracy.

LOLA: I am?

Lights down on Table One. Lights up Table Two. DOUG WATSON arrives, late. He looks round. THICK BOY looks up .

Table Two

DOUG: Is this the right table?

THICK BOY: It certainly is, Dougie. Have a pew.

Doug sits. He looks round.

DOUG: (Quietly) Is Ken on his way?

THICK BOY: Don't worry about a thing.

DOUG: Running late? Not surprised, he's a busy man.

THICK BOY: Listen, Dougie...

DOUG: Doug.

THICK BOY: Doug. Ken's not coming.

DOUG: I asked to see Ken personally. If he's doing so well he doesn't need my help, fine, forget it .

Doug starts to rise but Thick Boy stops him.

THICK BOY: No, no, don't get the wrong end of the stick. Ken is extremely pleased you've contacted us. He values your support immensely but he can't be seen breaking bread with you. In public. Not yet anyway.

DOUG: OK, well...

THICK BOY: I'm here as Ken's emissary. For the purposes of this lunch, I am his eyes and his ears.

DOUG: You mean his bagman. (They laugh) But who are you exactly?

Thick Boy looks in surprise.

THICK BOY: Don't you know? Look closely, chuck.

DOUG: (Looks) No, sorry. Should I?

THICK BOY: Thick Boy Geezer.

DOUG: Come again.

THICK BOY: Thick Boy Geezer. Me. The Brit awards? The Jug of Water incident?

DOUG: Yes of course! You're all over my daughter's bedroom.

THICK BOY: Been over so many, pal.

DOUG: Well, very pleased to meet you, Mr Geezer.

THICK BOY: Call me Thick Boy.

DOUG: Thick Boy. Has a certain ring. I'm sorry I'm late anyway. Northern Line, tsch.

THICK BOY: Ken'll soon sort that out, don't you worry.

DOUG: Actually it was 'Customer Action'. That's what they call it. Some poor fucker threw himself in front of a Tube.

THICK BOY: Tragic. Probably one of Frank Dobson's people, read the latest polls.

DOUG: I don't suppose you use the Tube much, of course.

THICK BOY: No, I'm a man of the people. I even use a bus. I'm not proud. I'm starving, let's get a menu.

DOUG: No. Thick Boy. Business first.

THICK BOY: Fair enough.

DOUG: How's the campaign looking?

THICK BOY: Frightening. Awesome. We've got people out day and night, tracking down Dobson supporters to win over. But we can't find any. They're all supporting our man. Life-long Tories too. We got retired brigadiers in Richmond canvassing for Ken. Even Jeffrey Archer's lady friends in Shepherd's Market are slipping us some readies.

DOUG: But why is he so popular? I mean the GLC was a disaster, wasn't it? Banning black binliners 'cos they were racist? I mean I ask you. Lesbian resource centres on every high street? Buggery on the rates? Forcing old ladies to spend their days on the Tube?

THICK BOY: Fair question, Doug. But ask yourself - if it was such a disaster, why did Thatcher abolish it?

DOUG: 'Cos she'd gone mad by then, that's why.

THICK BOY: You see, Tony Blair's trouble all along - why a red mist appears in front of his eyes every time Ken's name comes up - is that he believes the bollocks Murdoch feeds him.

DOUG: It's a personality defect. He likes rich men.

THICK BOY: He just doesn't realise, people liked the GLC. They don't know what it did half the time but they loved it. Fare's Fair, remember that? 10p to go where you like, firework displays every other weekend and, and, well, that was about it really. It was just great.

Doug leans in.

DOUG: (Quietly) Two hundred thousand.

THICK BOY: Sorry?

DOUG: My contribution. To Ken's campaign.

THICK BOY: Two hundred k??

DOUG: Ssssh!

THICK BOY: Fantastic. The coffers are almost empty. We were on the verge of getting Damien Hirst to embalm a baby dolphin for us. Two hundred, that's brilliant.

DOUG: I can afford it. But listen, Thick Lad _

THICK BOY: Boy. Yeah?

DOUG: This is between you, me and Ken. Nobody - and I mean nobody - must know where this money comes from.

THICK BOY: Gotcha. It's great to have you on board, Doug.

DOUG: I just want to see Tony Blair's eyeballs burst on London election night.

THICK BOY: Bugger me. You must really hate him.

DOUG: I gave him everything. My business experience, my reputation, even my house at Cape Cod. What does he do? Sacks me from the Cabinet. Has me trashed in public.

THICK BOY: Oh I see. That's why you're here, is it? Revenge.

Doug takes out a cheque and puts it on the table. Thick Boy picks it up and grins. Suddenly his grin disappears .

THICK BOY: Er, you forgot to sign it.

DOUG: I did, didn't I?

Doug smiles enigmatically.

Table One

PANDORA: So you see, Lola, we want you to poison the well of Livingstone's popularity.

LOLA: The cyanide pill? Me? How exciting!

PANDORA: You are uniquely placed, Lola, to provide a service to the party for which your reward will be something beyond your wildest dreams. And I don't mean taking it up the arse from Alastair Campbell.

LOLA: What if I fail?

PANDORA: Failure's not factored into the Project.

LOLA: What do I have to do?

PANDORA: Tell the truth.

LOLA: About what?

PANDORA: About you and Ken.

LOLA: I've never met him outside the Commons.

PANDORA: You met him when you were 15, Lola.

LOLA: Did I?

PANDORA: Oh yes. You went to interview him for your school magazine.

LOLA: What? We never had a school magazine.

PANDORA: Oh you did.

LOLA: You must be muddling me up with someone else.

PANDORA: We don't think so. We think you're our girl.

LOLA: Oh I see. It's not true, I see! Oh great. You want me to say I interviewed him when I was 15 and _ and he said something horrid! Brilliant! What? He said _ I know! Up the IRA!

PANDORA: Not bad, Lola. Only he's still saying Up the IRA and nobody turns a hair. No, we want you to say...

LOLA: I know what he said! Legalise cannabis!

PANDORA: Half the Cabinet smokes grass when Tony's not looking.

LOLA: (Thinks) I know, he said he was plotting to take over the party!

PANDORA: He actually did say that. His turn after Kinnock, remember?

LOLA: So what was he supposed to have said to me then?

PANDORA: He said he wanted to shag you.

LOLA: Oh my God. He said he wanted to shag me? Pandora, please. I can't go on Breakfast with Frost and say that Ken Livingstone wanted to have sex with a 15-year-old girl.

PANDORA: More than wanted to, sweetie. (Looks) Did.

LOLA: What??

PANDORA: And you were that 15-year-old.

LOLA: Me?? I can't do that. I'm a married woman, what will Nigel say?

PANDORA: You weren't married to Nigel when you were 15, what's the problem?

LOLA: I can't. I'm sorry. I won't.

PANDORA: For the good of the party. For Tony.

LOLA: That's obscene.

PANDORA: You're saying 'no'?

LOLA: I'm saying 'no'.

Pandora looks at her with a smile.

PANDORA: Fine.

Pandora starts to put her things away. Lola is very agitated.

LOLA: Can't I just say he held my hand?

Pandora gets up to go.

LOLA: Okay, he kissed me! On the lips! Is that enough?

Pandora starts to go.

LOLA: He snogged me!! It's all coming back! Snogging Ken! It was great!!

Pandora has almost left.

LOLA: Okay - I shagged him!

Pandora stops. She smiles.

Table Two

DOUG: Homosexuals.

THICK BOY: Come again.

DOUG: Reassure me here, Thick Boy. I mean take it as read, I've got nothing against them...

THICK BOY: Course not.

DOUG: But is Ken going to make it compulsory?

THICK BOY: Compulsory? Oh I get it. Gay marriages, that's what you're worried about.

DOUG: What's he want to do? Marry gay couples himself? Stand there with a chain of office round his neck in some kind of pink dressing gown?

THICK BOY: No, no, it's about gay rights. Pensions, that sort of stuff. If one half of a gay couple cops it, the other half gets the pension.

DOUG: Oh I see. No harm in that I suppose.

THICK BOY: Happy?

Thick Boy pushes the cheque towards Doug for signing but Doug doesn't move. Thick Boy fidgets with the cheque

THICK BOY: I'm getting a bit peckish here, Doug.

DOUG: I have to mention... the 's' word.

THICK BOY: Sex? Why, what have you heard?

DOUG: Nothing. Should I have?

THICK BOY: If there's one thing Millbank can't get him on, it's sex. With Shagger Norris up for the Tories, who do they think they're kidding? I mean I'm not saying he's not a red-blooded newt-lover, but he plays a straight bat if you get my drift.

DOUG: Actually I meant 'socialism'.

THICK BOY: Oh. That.

DOUG: He still is a socialist, isn't he?

THICK BOY: Oh yeah. But not as a day-time job. I mean, selling bonds to spruce up the Northern Line, that's hardly the dictatorship of the proletariat. A shrewd capitalist manoeuvre, you know all about them, Doug, don't you?

THICK BOY: Oh, his secret dreams, you mean? (Points to cheque) That'd be telling.

fields.headline: Explain... the Calais cup run
fields.trailText: It's one of the greatest stories in amateur sporting history, a tale so unlikely that you suspect the involvement of Hansie Cronje somewhere along the line. Tiny Calais, the French amateur side, have reached the French cup final after beating Bordeaux, 4th in the French league and last year's league champions, 3-1 after extra time in the semis - their tenth game in a tournament that doesn't allow replays.
fields.body:
It's one of the greatest stories in amateur sporting history, a tale so unlikely that you suspect the involvement of Hansie Cronje somewhere along the line. Tiny Calais, the French amateur side, have reached the French cup final after beating Bordeaux, 4th in the French league and last year's league champions, 3-1 after extra time in the semis - their tenth game in a tournament that doesn't allow replays.

Tellingly Calais have played at home in seven consecutive ties, a journey that saw them swap their 4,500-capacity ground for the more princely Stade Felix Bollaert, home of Lens, which was filled on Wednesday with 38,374 screaming spectators. The local minnows have been adopted in Lens, helped by the fact that the two teams' colours (yellow and red) are almost identical. And all this has been accomplished by a club with a skeleton staff of, er, two - manager Ladislas Lozano and chief executive Claude Thiriot. The pair have been working 14-hour days for the past month, a strain that contributed to Lozano's heart attack, suffered amid the celebrations that lasted until Thursday morning. He expects to be back to work in time to guide his team to glory in the final, on 7 May against Nantes (who, at 14th in the first division, are a pushover, surely).

While us Brits have all heard of Calais, the town is in fact very small, with a population of just 80,000 (or two Stade Felix Bollaerts). The Calaisiens ply their trade in the Nationalles, the French amateur version of the fourth division. They're currently seventh in the league, chasing the all-important fifth position - the top four sides are all the reserve teams of top-division clubs, and prohibited from promotion. Their cause hasn't been helped by the fixture congestion caused by their cup run - they're playing every three days at the moment. Neither are they a team of has-beens, rather a squad of never-weres - none of their players has ever been a professional, although that may well change in the summer when, rumour has it, several players will get their dream moves into the first division. 'I never stopped believing, even at the most difficult moments,' said Lozano. 'The team looked for inspiration and found something incredible.'

fields.headline: Gudni's late saver
fields.trailText: Bolton topped off last week's seven-goal thriller as they shared the points in an eight-goal deluge at the Hawthorns. Two former Bolton players came back to haunt the Wanderers and almost certainly kill off any hopes of a top-six finish.
fields.body:
Bolton topped off last week's seven-goal thriller as they shared the points in an eight-goal deluge at the Hawthorns. Two former Bolton players came back to haunt the Wanderers and almost certainly kill off any hopes of a top-six finish.

The Wanderers were actually up against a side that included three former Bolton players, the most recent exile being striker Bob Taylor. And it was old boy Richard Sneekes who so nearly gave the home side the lead with just a minute on the clock but a perfectly timed tackle by Mark Fish deflected the ball for a corner.

Albion took a deserved lead from the penalty spot after Fabian De Freitas was bundled over. Sneekes converted low to the corner.

Three minutes later a Taylor header flashed just wide as he met a cross from Des Lyttle. Wanderers were struggling to get out of their own half but nine minutes from the break Bo Hansen scored his third goal in a week to level the scores. Johansen whipping in a cross and Hansen headed in off a post.

It was a brief respite for the Wanderers as within a minute the home side had the lead again. Lyttle pounced to fire in a cross to the far post. Sean Flynn, the smallest player on the pitch, headed in.

Bolton pressure from the restart was rewarded after 55 minutes when Gudni Bergsson equalised. He dribbled the ball forward into the box, cre ated the opening for himself and slammed the ball home.

Then Eider Gudjohnsen found the target. Michael Johansen found him at inside-right and he took it beyond the keeper to score.

Bolton were now bossing the game but they were powerless to prevent a classic individual goal by Taylor who scored against the run of play. He was on target with an athletic bicycle kick to drag West Brom back into the match.

It ignited the Baggies as the contest reached a pulsating finish, the home side snatching the lead with two minutes to go. Sneekes put substitute Adam Oliver clear and he finished smartly.

Back came Bolton with only seconds left and Bergsson claimed his second. The defender, his head bandaged from a collision in the first half, got his header on target from a corner to seal a draw.

Bolton have now scored eight goals in their past two games and conceded seven with only four points to show for their efforts.

fields.headline: Preston surge is on
fields.trailText: The gulf was surprising and painful to West Country hearts. Preston played unspectacularly yet with the aura of champions. Rovers stumbled nervously to another defeat. They have now picked up a niggardly two points out of a possible 18.
fields.byline: David Foot at the Memorial Stadium
fields.body:
The gulf was surprising and painful to West Country hearts. Preston played unspectacularly yet with the aura of champions. Rovers stumbled nervously to another defeat. They have now picked up a niggardly two points out of a possible 18.

If Preston missed their injured midfield general Sean Gregan, Rovers needed the physical presence of their suspended striker Jason Roberts. Tactically, Rovers were lost at times. Various formations were tried during the game; none made much impact.

The visitors' defence was nominally extended a few times in the second half, but Rovers' tally of attacks was negligible. A dipping drive from Latvian international Vitalijs Astafjevs went only just over. Later, Mark Walters' oblique shot grazed the foot of the post.

Neither side immediately came to terms with a greasy, skidding surface. Preston were first to do so. From that point they were invariably more positive in possession and looking well drilled.

Rovers' manager Ian Holloway, who gave his young side time off to play golf this past week, was in sympathetic mood. 'My team played in the style I wanted and I couldn't ask for more.' He said he felt 'as though I've been mugged by this result'.

David Moyes doubtless knows he already has a First Division club on his hands, but the Preston manager cautioned, 'We aren't over the line yet. But we're getting closer. I thought we were mostly in control. And nothing pleases a manager more than when his centre-forwards make goals for each other.'

He was thinking of the first, four minutes before the interval, when the Icelander Bjarki Gunnlaugsson slid the perfect pass to Paul McKenny, whose shot hammered against the far post. It came back to Jon Macken to net his 25th goal of the season.

After 57 minutes the pattern was determined as Preston scored again. This time Gunnlaugsson was on hand to turn Macken's left-wing centre over the line.

Early on, Tepi Moilanen sprinted out of his area to foil Jamie Cureton when the small Bristol striker was charging through menacingly. It was a deceptive act of resourcefulness: Rovers' forwards made little headway from then on as the visiting defence gave absolutely nothing away. This was surely the day when Preston, 'proud' by repute, signalled their return to loftier levels.

fields.headline: Wanchope too hot for Derby
fields.trailText: Not so long ago, Paulo Wanchope was a figure of fun as far as many West Ham supporters were concerned. A waste of money they argued after one high-profile miss against Aston Villa at Upton Park. Amid the criticism, Harry Redknapp kept faith with his £3.5 million summer signing from Derby, and the gangling Costa Rican is now repaying that confidence with a flood of goals.
fields.body:
Not so long ago, Paulo Wanchope was a figure of fun as far as many West Ham supporters were concerned. A waste of money they argued after one high-profile miss against Aston Villa at Upton Park. Amid the criticism, Harry Redknapp kept faith with his £3.5 million summer signing from Derby, and the gangling Costa Rican is now repaying that confidence with a flood of goals.

A brace in midweek against Newcastle, followed by another two against his former club, have brought West Ham welcome victories after the 7-1 pasting they took at Old Trafford.

Yesterday, Wanchope fell short of the hat-trick he told friends he wanted against Derby. But first-half strikes still took his tally to nine in his last 10 games and his total for the season to 15.

He has overtaken Paolo Di Canio as West Ham's top scorer and Redknapp said: 'There are a lot of Premiership strikers who would like to have that many. He may be all arms and legs, but you don't realise how strong he is and he's also got great pace.'

This victory came at a price, with Igor Stimac suffering a broken nose and Joe Cole also carried off with bruising after taking a kick. It was a much more painful afternoon, however, for Derby who could virtually have made themselves safe from relegation. Instead, Friday's match at Bradford now assumes major importance.

Manager Jim Smith, who was without key men Horacio Carbonari and Giorgi Kinkladze, had Stefanio Eranio pull out with Achilles trouble during the warm up and had Stefan Schnoor carried off after being kicked. He said: 'There comes a time when you have to stop looking over your shoulder and get the right results yourself. I couldn't have asked any more from the players in the second half, but earlier Wanchope caught us out when West Ham were playing well.'

Wanchope came across his marker Steve Elliott to head in an angled cross from Scott Minto. Then, after a Dean Sturridge effort was disallowed for offside, Marc-Vivien Foe helped on Di Canio's corner for Wanchope to drive in his second from beyond the far post.

Visiting goalkeeper Ian Feuer saved well from Sturridge and Elliott, but it was only in the last quarter of an hour that Derby worked up a real head of steam, pulling one back through Sturridge after Darryl Powell flicked on a Seth Johnson corner.

West Ham had one or two more anxious moments, but overall were good value for the win with no-one deserving a win bonus more than Trevor Sinclair, who worked tirelessly on the right flank.

fields.headline: Taylor on course for play-offs
fields.trailText: These two sides are beginning to resemble leaders approaching the finishing line in the London Marathon.
fields.body:
These two sides are beginning to resemble leaders approaching the finishing line in the London Marathon.

While Gillingham still appear to have plenty in the tank and are winding themselves up for a sprint finish, Wigan resemble a team who can't wait for the tape after burning up too much energy early on. Having fallen behind due to their FA Cup run, Gillingham are making effective use of their spare matches over their promotion chasing rivals.

This win leaves them six points behind second placed Wigan with two matches in hand. And with games to come against Burnley and Millwall, two of the sides above them, manager Peter Taylor's optimism that 'second spot is up for grabs' appears well justified.

Gillingham fans must hope their side can avoid the lottery of a play-off following their defeat on penalties to Manchester City at Wembley last year.

Wigan, on the other hand, appear to have hit the wall. Having gone unbeaten in the League until January they have now won only five of their last 16 and, have not lost away from home for 11 months until last Tuesday, they have now been beaten on their travels twice in five days.

They must hope they discover a second wind soon if they are to hang on to their automatic promotion place. John Benson, Wigan's manager, laid the fault squarely at the door of his highly rated Northern Ireland goalkeeper, Roy Carroll, blaming him for both goals.

'He's done magnificently well for us in a lot of games but he has to take responsibility for today,' he said.

Taylor was more understanding about his keeper, Vince Bartram's failure to even make the kick-off after being held up in a traffic jam on the M25. It forced Gillingham to re-jig their team just a few minutes before the start and gave the Australian Steve Mauton his first opportunity. 'These things happen sometimes,' Taylor said.

Carroll's first mistake came in the 17th minute. Iffy Onuora's forceful run opened up the Wigan defence and he swapped passes with Nicky Southall. His shot from 15 yards lacked real power but still squeezed through Carroll's fingers on the sodden turf.

The crowd allowed for the first time in Gillingham's new main stand, rising impressively into the Kent skyline offering further evidence of the club's remarkable turn- around in fortunes since Paul Scally arrived as chairman five years ago, rose in delight.

It took less than 90 seconds for their mood to match the colour of the black sky. Michael Clegg's cross was hit more in hope than in anticipation and was going nowhere until Adrian Pennock swung a boot at it. It looped high into the air and over his keeper into his own net. It is a certainty for one of those blooper football videos that come out at Christmas.

Gillingham had Wigan penned back in their own half for most of the second period but it needed a bad mistake by Carroll in the 82nd minute to secure the breakthrough. He came for a cross and appeared to have collected it comfortably, only to drop it on landing.

The ball squirmed its way to Junior Lewis on the edge of the penalty area and he showed a mature head to kick it over two defenders on the line.

'It was a real cool finish,' said Taylor. He could soon be saying the same about his Gillingham team.

fields.headline: Sickener for Graham
fields.trailText: The Tottenham manager George Graham is in hospital with rheumatoid arthritis, apparently on steroids. This match will have done little for his recovery after Aston Villa, from two goals down, scored four of their own in 12 astonishing second-half minutes.
fields.byline: Ian Ridley at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
The Tottenham manager George Graham is in hospital with rheumatoid arthritis, apparently on steroids. This match will have done little for his recovery after Aston Villa, from two goals down, scored four of their own in 12 astonishing second-half minutes.

It was a Spurs decline within a decline, their run of four defeats in five games taking them into the bottom half of the table and prompting new calls last night for the chairman Sir Alan Sugar to resign. Within minutes of the final whistle, a group of around 150 angry supporters had gathered outside the main gates chanting 'We want our Tottenham back.'

It had been planned anyway but its intensity was fuelled by a result that looked unthinkable after an hour, with Tottenham coasting thanks to goals by Steffen Iversen and Chris Armstrong and Villa looking a shadow of the side comfortably sixth in the Premiership as well as FA Cup finalists.

Then Villa got a break, an assistant referee spotting the handball, missed by the referee Rob Harris, that enabled Dion Dublin to pull a goal back from the penalty spot and spark the remarkable revival. 'We were grateful to the linesman,' said Villa manager John Gregory, unlike his counterpart in rude health and due to run the London marathon this morning. 'He was 35 yards away to the ref's 10 and spotted it. Still, Mr Harris got the minute's silence for Hillsborough right.'

It was a moment that showed again the brittle character of this Tottenham team; potentially fluent when things are going for them, usually porous when the going gets tougher. The first hour showed the former, the last half hour was all about the latter.

They had the fillip of an early goal, too. David Ginola's pinpoint cross found the head of Iversen who had only to guide the ball home from six yards. It should have been more before the interval, with Armstrong chipping Stephen Carr's through ball into David James's arms before looping an overhead kick on to the bar and Villa looked grateful for the break.

The gratitude was short-lived, however, as a minute into the second half Armstrong made amends, this time clipping Carr's ball round James before sliding home. Then controversy, then amazement, then acrimony.

As Paul Merson's corner came in, Gareth Barry appeared to push Iversen and Ugo Ehiogu headed down for Dublin to shoot goalwards. Iversen's arm intervened but it took the Villa players' protests to send Mr Harris to his assistant for the penalty to be awarded.

After consultation, Mr Harris also looked about to send off Stephen Clemence but then decided against it, he and the linesman unsure as to the identity of the offender. His indecision upset both John Gregory, who thought Iversen should have been sent off, and the Spurs assistant Stewart Houston, who conceded the handball but lamented the Barry foul.

Dublin duly stroked home the penalty and Villa scented reprieve. Soon he had volleyed home the hitherto subdued Benito Carbone's cross with a brilliant overhead kick and Spurs were reeling. Next, the towering Dublin returned the compliment, heading down for Carbone to drive a curling shot into Ian Walker's top right corner. Finally, Walker's 250th Spurs appearance was further spoiled by Alan Wright's arrow-straight 25-yard half-volley into the goalkeeper's top left corner.

After that, James grabbed Ginola's shot on his line at the second attempt and tipped over Clemence's shot but the Spurs' fans anger was reaching boiling point. 'It's not nice but it's part of football,' said Houston. 'We are trying to rectify the problems and we have just got to get out on the training ground and work with the boys.' He and Sugar might reflect that there are good games to miss.

fields.headline: Savage riposte delights his boss
fields.trailText: Leicester City manager Martin O'Neill was never afraid to use unusual methods to gee-up Robbie Savage. 'I used to say he lacked only one thing - and that was ability,' O'Neill recalled after a victory which owed a debt to Savage's midfield performance.
fields.byline: John Wardle at St James's Park
fields.body:
Leicester City manager Martin O'Neill was never afraid to use unusual methods to gee-up Robbie Savage. 'I used to say he lacked only one thing - and that was ability,' O'Neill recalled after a victory which owed a debt to Savage's midfield performance.

O'Neill's words were his way of telling Savage he was in danger of not fulfilling his Premiership potential. Whatever Savage thought of his manager's tongue-in-cheek opinion, the impact has been apparent this season.

Now all he lacks, apart from an extra half-yard of pace perhaps, are the goals that his energy deserve, but Savage did hit the target with a stunning strike yesterday to add to Tony Cottee's opener.

It was the Welshman's first of the season and that represents a paltry return.O'Neill said: 'I think he should get more, but he turns round and tells me he scores spectacular goals. I just don't want to wait four years for the next one.'

Yesterday's effort was certainly spectacular, while Savage's performance epitomised the admirable approach of City, already destined for European competition and minus several influential players. They remained single-minded, organised and patently determined not to succumb at St James's Park as so many have done recently.No manager could ask for more at this stage of the season.

O'Neill said: 'Newcastle were not at their best, but winning at St James's Park under any circumstances is great. My players are absolutely delighted.'

Their pleasure will be diluted slightly by the knowledge that this was a Newcastle team whose FA Cup semi-final disappointment was compounded by an undeserved setback at West Ham in midweek.

It was always going to be a difficult day for them, as it was for Uriah Rennie, who refereed intelligently against a backcloth of jeers from fans who will never forgive him for the controversial dismissal of Alan Shearer in the opening game of the season.

So the last thing Newcastle needed was an early goal from Leicester. Cottee claimed his tenth of the season in the sixth minute when he met Andrew Impey's devastating low cross with a first-time shot that keeper Shay Given could only divert into the top corner.

City, again forced to employ Matt Elliott as a makeshift striker because of their injury problems, almost added another seven minutes later when Cottee's shot was deflected on to the roof of the net by Alain Goma. Relieved, Newcastle should have levelled seconds later when a careless backpass by Neil Lennon let in Kieron Dyer, Newcastle's liveliest performer before the interval.

Dyer's cross cut out keeper Tim Flowers and, with only Phil Gilchrist on the line, Gary Speed put his shot too close to the defender.

Robert Lee went close either side of half-time before City stretched their lead in the 52nd minute through Savage's rare goal. The danger appeared to have petered out as Savage was diverted wide, but he suddenly unleashed a stunning cross-shot past Given.

Didier Domi headed against a post and almost created a goal for Nolberto Solano. Otherwise, Leicester's defence coped with second-half pressure, with Gerry Taggart dealing impressively with Alan Shearer.

Newcastle manager Bobby Robson said: 'That's three defeats in seven days. We've had a dreadful week and it has made us all a bit miserable.'

City, again forced to employ Matt Elliott as a makeshift striker because of their injury problems, almost added another seven minutes later when Cottee's shot was deflected on to the roof of the net by Alain Goma. Relieved, Newcastle should have levelled seconds later when a careless backpass by Neil Lennon let in Kieron Dyer, Newcastle's liveliest performer before the interval. Dyer's cross cut out keeper Tim Flowers and, with only Phil Gilchrist on the line, Gary Speed put his shot too close to the defender. Robert Lee went close either side of half-time before City stretched their lead in the 52nd minute through Savage's rare goal. The danger appeared to have petered out as Savage was diverted wide, but he suddenly unleashed a stunning cross-shot past Given. Didier Domi headed against a post and almost created a goal for Nolberto Solano. Otherwise, Leicester's defence coped with second-half pressure, with Gerry Taggart dealing impressively with Alan Shearer. Newcastle manager Bobby Robson said: 'That's three defeats in seven days. We've had a dreadful week and it has made us all a bit miserable.'

fields.headline: Keane on the mark
fields.trailText: An inspired display from Robbie Keane lifted spirits and revived Coventry's hopes of a top 10 finish in the Premiership.
fields.body:
An inspired display from Robbie Keane lifted spirits and revived Coventry's hopes of a top 10 finish in the Premiership.

Gordon Strachan's side had gone into the game on the back of seven defeats in nine games, but it hardly showed in their general performance and they were worthy winners. Keane in particular was back to his irrepressible best, scoring one goal and making the other as he tormented the Boro defence throughout.

There was little goalmouth action in the opening 25 minutes and there was a languid, end-of-season feel about the proceedings, although Boro did opt to play three up front, but to little effect.

The first clear-cut chance fell to Coventry after 15 minutes, when Noel Whelan was given a clear run at goal from a long clearance but saw his low shot beaten away by Mark Schwarzer.

The home side were then forced to make a change in the 26th minute when Youssef Chippo was replaced by David Burrows after picking up an ankle injury.

Strachan duly reorganised, slotting Burrows in at left-back and pushing Stephen Froggatt into a more forward role, and after 33 minutes Coventry broke the deadlock thanks to a helping hand from Middlesbrough's midfielder Paul Ince.

Keane played a neat one-two with Whelan and raced clear of the visitors' back line. His left-footed shot was blocked by Schwarzer, but the rebound cannoned into the chest of the unfortunate Ince, who was powerless to stop the ball rebounding across his own line.

Eustace failed to convert two gilt-edged chances in the opening six minutes of the second half, before Coventry eventually doubled their lead in the 63rd minute when Whelan played the ball into the path of Keane, who stroked the ball wide of Schwarzer into the corner.

But within three minutes the visitors reduced the arrears when Ziege converted from the penalty spot after Campbell had been brought down by Eustace.
