fields.headline: Hansie Cronje, mystery man
fields.standfirst: A blunder by Indian police and support at home may let an international man of mystery off the hook
fields.trailText: A blunder by Indian police and support at home may let an international man of mystery off the hook.
fields.body:
Wessels Johannes Cronje ended the week much as he had started it: international man of mystery.

In the nine days since police in Delhi alleged he and three, possibly four, of his teammates had accepted money to fix matches against India, the South African captain has been variously depicted as duplicitous, upstanding, God-fearing, philandering, craven, cowardly, righteous, light-hearted. Walter Mitty never had as many lives.

Perhaps the pain of this complex individual will be eased soon, however. The Observer has learned that, because of a procedural blunder in taping his claimed phone calls with the London-based bookmaker Sanjeev Chawla, Cronje will almost certainly never have to face the legal charges being made against him in India.

While the emphasis in the internal investigation had quietly shifted into other areas of the South African team, the captain seemed to be emerging from the scandal with not only the sympathy of his countrymen growing by the day but with the immunity visited upon him by the incompetence of his prosecutors in Delhi.

Also, a key element in his defence, but one on which few people have picked up on, was always going to be that he was not using his own mobile phone in India. 'I did take mine over but did not use it at all,' he said towards the end of an emotional press conference last Saturday. He had dropped his and broken it. According to one of his closest media friends, Trevor Chesterfield, the phone he used in taking calls from Chawla belonged to the team manager, Goolam Rajah.

So the intrigue builds. Lawyers last night expressed scepticism that the police there had obtained the necessary permission before bugging Cronje's calls. Should the courts rule that the phone-tapping was unauthorised, the accused might be able to claim 'lack of due process'.

Insiders say that many permission orders are passed after the tap has been carried out. In other cases, detectives simply browbeat telephone companies to co-operate without seeking formal clearance from the police commissioner or India's Home Secretary.

In theory, the police are bound by regulations that the 'use of intercepted material shall be limited to the minimum'. This hardly squares with the press conference nine days ago in which Dr KK Paul, the head of Delhi police's crime branch, released the most damning extracts of the transcripts to a stunned public.

In the unlikely event, then, that Cronje is ever extradited to India, prosecutors will struggle to secure a conviction. The likelihood is that the whole affair - like so many match-fixing allegations before - will be forgotten soon enough.

Yet, as the International Cricket Council prepare to throw more platitudes at the problem tomorrow at what they laughingly describe as a crisis conference, denials continue to drown out the increasingly hysterical allegations.

If the truth is to be found in among this mess, it will take a considerable shift in moral perception by everyone in the game, from players to officials, many of whom are jaded insiders well aware of the rumours at least going back to the Headingley Test of 1981. Public utterances don't always match whispered asides. One county cricketer told me recently players often bet on themselves. Not that they throw matches - but, if a tailender who fancies his chances with the bat spots his name at outrageous odds to top-score in a low-scoring match, and he has been exposed to the county game's gambling culture for any length of time, the odds are he will have a few bob on himself. What could be wrong with that, many will ask? Very little, surely.

But, on the bigger stage, when serious money and very serious players are involved - people with criminal connections - the rules change. As we revealed in these pages last October after suspicions about Pakistan in the World Cup, the consequences of crossing the faceless string-pullers of international cricket betting on the sub-continent can be terminal.

And still, not one investigation has yielded a single satisfactory result. The only player to be effectively ostracised is the volatile Pakistani batsman Salim Malik, who might count himself unfortunate when so many others named have drifted in and out of the punishment cell.

But Hansie, as he is affectionately known by those who have come to admire his perceived rectitude, was always going to be treated differently. You only have to read the acres of testimonials to his character to understand that. He is honest, he is well-educated, he is tough and fair - he is white.

Shamefully, most reasonable people would say, hi colour of skin and general respectability have changed the tenor of the debate. It was fine throwing mud at Pakistanis, and even colonial scallywags like Shane Warne and Steve Waugh, but this time the accusations are being levelled at cricketers whose propriety had supposedly set them as men apart - none more so than Cronje, a devout Christian from a deeply religious family.

So who exactly is this man Cronje? Depends where you're coming from.

'By the time we got to work on Friday morning,' recounts Ivor Powell of South Africa's liberal Mail and Guardian newspaper, 'there was already a pile of faxes nearly as thick as the telephone directory. The editor, Phillip van Niekerk, had already been on radio twice, defending the paper from more than robust attack.'

What crime had been committed? It was the uncompromising message on their billboards all over the country: 'F*** you, Hansie Cronje.' As abrasive editorial comment, it was hard to match. The response, in graffiti everywhere, was just as virulent. 'F*** you, Mail and Guardian,' and 'F*** you 2'.

Powell says, 'South Africa's biggest news agency threatened, before 10 o'clock in the morning to withdraw the title from all of its thousands of outlets - not only this edition, but in perpetuity. One fax threatened to withdraw 2,000 subscriptions; another just looped on the refrain men tioned at the top of this paragraph. One telephone caller said she always knew we were "just communists_ no_ black-loving communists... no, no, black arse kissing communists_ but_"

'There were hundreds of callers in the course of the day. They were almost all white, and they were outraged, some simply because of the word, but mostly because we were breaking ranks. It was, as a colleague observed, like being in South Africa in the late Eighties, when truth mattered far less as a value than the solidarity of the "volk" and any questioning of authority was an automatic betrayal. We needed, we felt, to inject some reality, one way or another, into a situation that was growing increasingly bizarre.'

This is not a picture you will have seen painted in many milder, more mainstream versions of events. But it reflects the real heat of the debate in South Africa, a debate drawn along clear racial lines.

Cronje has always been represented - rightly so his friends say - as the ideal captain of a predominantly white sporting team to represent the rainbow nation. It is not that simple.

Until his fall from grace, Cronje had been too good to be true. Part of a minor cricketing dynasty - his father also played for South Africa - in the Afrikaner hinterland of the Free State, Cronje made his provincial debut in 1987 at the age of 18.

By the age of 21 he was captain, before being selected for the national team at the age of 23. Two years later he was the team's regular captain, becoming by the time of his dismissal this week the most successful captain in South African cricketing history.

But, as Powell says, the Cronje story has many little twists in it. The 'legend version' has it that 'Cronje was a symbol of the Afrikaner's journey out of the lager of apartheid isolation to the brave new world of internationalism, a post-apartheid hero for those still struggling to cast off the shackles of an apartheid mindset'.

He could also be an irritable adversary whose thirst for a win bordered on the fanatical. In 1998 the Australian press all but called him a cheat after television footage showed him rolling the ball under his studded foot during a one-day international. No official action was taken. During the same tour Cronje caused a stir when he hurled a stump through the door of the umpires' changing room after his side had lost a Test match they should have won in Adelaide.

Last week was his trial. He did not come through it with the decorous calm you might expect of a man painted in heroic colours. He made a somewhat surly public appearance where he remained silent, with Sports Minister Ngconde Balfour, oddly, telling the world what Hansie had said, while Cronje's spiritual mentor, the former bodybuilder and charismatic pastor Ray McCaulay, looked on benignly in the background.

The United Cricket Board announced it would be calling on government to institute a commission of inquiry. After meetings on Friday between government and the UCB, the commission was announced, but a judge is still being sought to head it.

If the reaction seems a little uncommitted, it probably is. One cabinet minister frankly admitted that cricket was not top of the government agenda - the real consideration was how the scandal would impact on South Africa's bid to host the Football World Cup in 2006.

It is white South Africa that cares passionately about cricket; black South Africa is hooked on football. Apartheid of a different sort, but separation just the same.

It was the issue of bringing the communities together that, tangentially at least, might be at the heart of Cronje's present predicament. It has been widely acknowledged that he stormed out of a meeting two years ago with Ali Bacher when the man who has striven to restore South Africa's credibility after decades of the boycott suggested the quota system proposed by the government should at least be tried.

Cronje was defiantly opposed to it. He argued (not without some support in the black community) that Test players should be picked solely on merit.

The two were not so united last week that even a passing inspection of their media appearances did not reveal simmering tension. Cronje back-tracked on Bacher's original statement that he, Cronje, had accepted between $10,000 and $15,000.

He later recanted, but insisted he had not done anything to damage South Africa's reputation, nor had any of his teammates.

Yesterday, Herschelle Gibbs, one of the others accused, broke his silence. 'I felt bad but I knew I was innocent,' he told the Cape Argus . 'Nothing would ever make me do something irresponsible. I think somebody who would become involved in anything like this would have let their country down, and themselves and the team. It is terribly unprofessional.'

He added: 'Nobody approached us. When we were told about it, we were terribly shocked.'

Again it is a denial littered with escape clauses, as was Cronje's assertion that he had not been 'entirely honest'. Gibbs then adds the almost obligatory hymn of praise for his captain: 'He is a great man and one of the greatest captains who has ever played the game. I've known him for a good few years and I've still got the utmost respect for him. He will always be a great friend of mine.'

There is a theory that Cronje has fallen on his sword for the good of his fellow-accused. This might be the case. But he has done so reluctantly, flushed out by media insistence and without the fulsome explanation that the doubters still demand.

In the eyes of his public, however, the more he is flogged, the more he is loved. The Johannesburg Star surveyed South African opinion and found that 94 per cent of respondents supported Cronje and/or believed he was innocent. Callers on talk radio were equally vocal in their belief that, even if Hansie had erred, he should be forgiven.

Perhaps this is the proper Christian response. Truth and reconciliation, Nelson Mandela called it.

Additional reporting by Luke Harding in Delhi.

If the truth is to be found in among this mess, it will take a considerable shift in moral perception by everyone in the game, from players to officials, many of whom are jaded insiders well aware of the rumours at least going back to the Headingley Test of 1981. Public utterances don't always match whispered asides. One county cricketer told me recently players often bet on themselves. Not that they throw matches - but, if a tailender who fancies his chances with the bat spots his name at outrageous odds to top-score in a low-scoring match, and he has been exposed to the county game's gambling culture for any length of time, the odds are he will have a few bob on himself. What could be wrong with that, many will ask? Very little, surely. But, on the bigger stage, when serious money and very serious players are involved - people with criminal connections - the rules change. As we revealed in these pages last October after suspicions about Pakistan in the World Cup, the consequences of crossing the faceless string-pullers of international cricket betting on the sub-continent can be terminal. And still, not one investigation has yielded a single satisfactory result. The only player to be effectively ostracised is the volatile Pakistani batsman Salim Malik, who might count himself unfortunate when so many others named have drifted in and out of the punishment cell. But Hansie, as he is affectionately known by those who have come to admire his perceived rectitude, was always going to be treated differently. You only have to read the acres of testimonials to his character to understand that. He is honest, he is well-educated, he is tough and fair - he is white. Shamefully, most reasonable people would say, hi colour of skin and general respectability have changed the tenor of the debate. It was fine throwing mud at Pakistanis, and even colonial scallywags like Shane Warne and Steve Waugh, but this time the accusations are being levelled at cricketers whose propriety had supposedly set them as men apart - none more so than Cronje, a devout Christian from a deeply religious family. So who exactly is this man Cronje? Depends where you're coming from. 'By the time we got to work on Friday morning,' recounts Ivor Powell of South Africa's liberal Mail and Guardian newspaper, 'there was already a pile of faxes nearly as thick as the telephone directory. The editor, Phillip van Niekerk, had already been on radio twice, defending the paper from more than robust attack.' What crime had been committed? It was the uncompromising message on their billboards all over the country: 'F*** you, Hansie Cronje.' As abrasive editorial comment, it was hard to match. The response, in graffiti everywhere, was just as virulent. 'F*** you, Mail and Guardian,' and 'F*** you 2'. Powell says, 'South Africa's biggest news agency threatened, before 10 o'clock in the morning to withdraw the title from all of its thousands of outlets - not only this edition, but in perpetuity. One fax threatened to withdraw 2,000 subscriptions; another just looped on the refrain men tioned at the top of this paragraph. One telephone caller said she always knew we were "just communists_ no_ black-loving communists... no, no, black arse kissing communists_ but_" 'There were hundreds of callers in the course of the day. They were almost all white, and they were outraged, some simply because of the word, but mostly because we were breaking ranks. It was, as a colleague observed, like being in South Africa in the late Eighties, when truth mattered far less as a value than the solidarity of the "volk" and any questioning of authority was an automatic betrayal. We needed, we felt, to inject some reality, one way or another, into a situation that was growing increasingly bizarre.' This is not a picture you will have seen painted in many milder, more mainstream versions of events. But it reflects the real heat of the debate in South Africa, a debate drawn along clear racial lines. Cronje has always been represented - rightly so his friends say - as the ideal captain of a predominantly white sporting team to represent the rainbow nation. It is not that simple. Until his fall from grace, Cronje had been too good to be true. Part of a minor cricketing dynasty - his father also played for South Africa - in the Afrikaner hinterland of the Free State, Cronje made his provincial debut in 1987 at the age of 18. By the age of 21 he was captain, before being selected for the national team at the age of 23. Two years later he was the team's regular captain, becoming by the time of his dismissal this week the most successful captain in South African cricketing history. But, as Powell says, the Cronje story has many little twists in it. The 'legend version' has it that 'Cronje was a symbol of the Afrikaner's journey out of the lager of apartheid isolation to the brave new world of internationalism, a post-apartheid hero for those still struggling to cast off the shackles of an apartheid mindset'. He could also be an irritable adversary whose thirst for a win bordered on the fanatical. In 1998 the Australian press all but called him a cheat after television footage showed him rolling the ball under his studded foot during a one-day international. No official action was taken. During the same tour Cronje caused a stir when he hurled a stump through the door of the umpires' changing room after his side had lost a Test match they should have won in Adelaide. Last week was his trial. He did not come through it with the decorous calm you might expect of a man painted in heroic colours. He made a somewhat surly public appearance where he remained silent, with Sports Minister Ngconde Balfour, oddly, telling the world what Hansie had said, while Cronje's spiritual mentor, the former bodybuilder and charismatic pastor Ray McCaulay, looked on benignly in the background. The United Cricket Board announced it would be calling on government to institute a commission of inquiry. After meetings on Friday between government and the UCB, the commission was announced, but a judge is still being sought to head it. If the reaction seems a little uncommitted, it probably is. One cabinet minister frankly admitted that cricket was not top of the government agenda - the real consideration was how the scandal would impact on South Africa's bid to host the Football World Cup in 2006. It is white South Africa that cares passionately about cricket; black South Africa is hooked on football. Apartheid of a different sort, but separation just the same. It was the issue of bringing the communities together that, tangentially at least, might be at the heart of Cronje's present predicament. It has been widely acknowledged that he stormed out of a meeting two years ago with Ali Bacher when the man who has striven to restore South Africa's credibility after decades of the boycott suggested the quota system proposed by the government should at least be tried. Cronje was defiantly opposed to it. He argued (not without some support in the black community) that Test players should be picked solely on merit. The two were not so united last week that even a passing inspection of their media appearances did not reveal simmering tension. Cronje back-tracked on Bacher's original statement that he, Cronje, had accepted between $10,000 and $15,000. He later recanted, but insisted he had not done anything to damage South Africa's reputation, nor had any of his teammates. Yesterday, Herschelle Gibbs, one of the others accused, broke his silence. 'I felt bad but I knew I was innocent,' he told the Cape Argus . 'Nothing would ever make me do something irresponsible. I think somebody who would become involved in anything like this would have let their country down, and themselves and the team. It is terribly unprofessional.' He added: 'Nobody approached us. When we were told about it, we were terribly shocked.' Again it is a denial littered with escape clauses, as was Cronje's assertion that he had not been 'entirely honest'. Gibbs then adds the almost obligatory hymn of praise for his captain: 'He is a great man and one of the greatest captains who has ever played the game. I've known him for a good few years and I've still got the utmost respect for him. He will always be a great friend of mine.' There is a theory that Cronje has fallen on his sword for the good of his fellow-accused. This might be the case. But he has done so reluctantly, flushed out by media insistence and without the fulsome explanation that the doubters still demand. In the eyes of his public, however, the more he is flogged, the more he is loved. The Johannesburg Star surveyed South African opinion and found that 94 per cent of respondents supported Cronje and/or believed he was innocent. Callers on talk radio were equally vocal in their belief that, even if Hansie had erred, he should be forgiven. Perhaps this is the proper Christian response. Truth and reconciliation, Nelson Mandela called it. Additional reporting by Luke Harding in Delhi.

fields.headline: Cronje is Sergeant Bilko
fields.trailText: Double Bilko. What more could students of deception ask for, every morning on BBC2? And how very educational is the return of the grinning grifter.
fields.body:
Double Bilko. What more could students of deception ask for, every morning on BBC2? And how very educational is the return of the grinning grifter.

Take Thursday. In episode two Bilko, Zimmerman and Papparelli, on furlough in San Diego, crash a Navy craps game. Ernie gets in with a seven-dollar stake and cleans up. Naturally, the game is busted and, masquerading illegally as sailors, Bilko and his confederates are shipped aboard the Saratoga, headed for six months at sea.

'I'm thinkin', I'm thinkin',' Bilko says as the three soldiers ponder a life in the Navy. Papparelli feigns appendicitis - a scam that is quickly sussed; Zimmerman prepares to jump overboard - until it is discovered the waters are full of sharks; then Bilko tries to convince the ship's company the captain has gone mad. No deal.

'I'm thinkin', I'm thinkin',' Bilko says.

Finally, the master sergeant of duplicity is reduced to the most desperate strategy: The Truth. He goes to the captain to admit they are soldiers and they want to go home to Camp Fremont to accept the consequences of their folly. Before Bilko can blurt his confession, however, the guileless captain tells them the Saratoga is stopping in San Francisco en route to Alaska and the crew will get 36 hours shore leave. Escape is thus effected... but not before Zimmerman and Papparelli haul Bilko away from one last temptation: a sailor overheard at the bus depot giving out details of another craps game.

For Bilko read Hansie Cronje, with the captain of the Saratoga the rudderless International Cricket Coun cil, oblivious to the storm and the sharks circling about about them, not to mention the anarchy below decks. Cronje - like Bilko, like Jeffrey Archer, like Neil Hamilton, like Jonathan Aitken - lied until he could lie no more. He confessed because he had to (though it might yet emerge that he was protecting others in doing so).

Bilko and Cronje are Shakespearian in their vulnerability, a throw of the dice away from moral and financial oblivion, doubly so because they think themselves beyond normal probity.

Bilko, though, was always saved by his comic persona, a winner in defeat just before the credits rolled. There is no light relief in Cronje's script. This is no TV comedy. The gig is up for Hansie and there will be no re-runs for nostalgics.

Another tragic dimension to the twisting and turning Cronje saga is the generally unchallenged perception that this is an unprecedented crisis for the game. It is an opinion formed in a reality vacuum by people accustomed to mouthing platitudes, as well as other dreamers who forget - or never knew - that skulduggery has been part of cricket since it started. The only reason cricket evolved into a series of contests, or challenges, is that its patrons chose to do so for money. These were otherwise 'meaningless' fixtures, the same criticism ascribed to the one-day carnival that rolls from Toronto to Delhi to Sharjah, wherever a mobile phone can reach a bookmaker.

It is not a universal blindness. For instance, while cricket-loving nice-guy John Major is probably shocked - which would not be a wholly surprising reaction from a man who gave credence to Archer and company - along with a conveyor belt of other over-quoted old farts, hard-heads like Tony Greig and Bob Woolmer are not so easily convinced.

Yet generally these past few days it has been soundbites everywhere, and hardly a drop of commonsense. Nasser Hussain, who I thought might be more earthbound, said on television on Wednesday night he had never even been approached and that, no, he didn't think the plethora of 'meaningless' one-day matches increased the likelihood of players being tempted by the blandishments of bookmakers. Of course not.

Let's go back 138 years to another 'meaningless' cricket match: An All-England XI v a combined NSW-Victoria team of 22 over three days at the Outer Domain in Sydney in February, 1862.

The tourists, unbackable and unbeatable on this first England tour, had been freely wined and entertained the night before and sharp characters descended upon the ground to get some action.

England batted first and were bowled out for 60, much to the surprise of the genteel citizenry, but not the gambling coves. The Combined team replied with 101, bowled England out for 75 in their second innings and polished off the required 35 runs while losing nine wickets.

David Frith, one of the game's pre-eminent historians, reveals all in his latest book, The Trailblazers, the first English cricket tour of Australia: 1861-62 .

'Already there were rumbles of suspicion and displeasure among those who had put money on the Englishmen to win this match or to remain unbeaten on the tour,' Frith writes. 'Surely they would not be so foul as to throw a match? The upright character of the captain [HH Stephenson] suggests that no such thing were possible, but gossip is sometimes unstaunchable.'

When the unstaunchable suggested the unthinkable, 'immediately the theorising began. Not only were there unpalatable suggestions in some quarters that the match might have been thrown: were they over-indulging off the field of play?' (As if.)

Frith recounts that 'years later, in his book, Billy Caffyn [strike bowler and formidable batsman] said that "scarcely a day passed without our being entertained to champagne breakfasts, luncheons and dinners" and, when thinking back to this match, he wrote that "we once more had high jinks at Sydney". Might this have contributed to his dual batting failure?'

In conversation last week with a media player of some clout, I suggested it was sad that truth had become such a disposable commodity, that footballers and managers and chairmen and other sporting figures hardly bothered with public utterances that rose above the bland and 'meaningless'. Not really, he said. 'If you have to protect a commercial or personal interest by not telling the whole truth, wouldn't you do it?'

A world full of Bilkos... I'm not sure I could stand the excitement.

fields.headline: Cleaning up in dirty cash
fields.standfirst: The gambling boom in India is fuelled by the latest technology.   Luke Harding reports from Delhi
fields.trailText: The gambling boom in India is fuelled by the latest technology. Luke Harding reports from Delhi.
fields.body:
It was Mumbai's best kept secret. On 12 March, several hours before South Africa and India took to the field in Bihar, India's poorest and most chaotic state, six of the city's underworld bookmakers held a discreet meeting. They knew something the other bookmakers did not. South Africa, they felt confident, would lose the match.

Their confidence was not merely based on a hunch. According to police sources in Mumbai, the six had advanced huge sums to Sanjay Chawla, the London-based bookmaker, to bribe the South African captain Hansie Cronje. Cronje's forecasts for the previous one-day match in Cochin had proved erratic. But this time he did not disappoint, it is alleged.

Cronje's side won the toss but managed to notch up only 199 runs. India swiftly swept past that total with the loss of four wickets. The ground at Jamshedpur, a previously unremarkable steel city, rang with Indian cheers. 'It was a very comfortable victory,' a spokesman from India's Board of Cricket Control declared.

The fallout in Mumbai from South Africa's poor performance was swift and devastating. It tore like a hurricane through the city's vast illegal betting industry. While those few in the know celebrated, Mumbai's other illegal syndicates - who had backed an in-form South Africa to win -- faced terminal losses of £150,000 each.

'The six have gone underground but we know who they are,' one police source said yesterday. 'Only these six knew that South Africa would lose the match. They had provided money to Sanjay Chawla.'

Police activity has now shifted from Delhi to Mumbai, with speculation yesterday that a local politician may be involved. Police are already examining telephone records from the Taj Mahal Hotel in Mumbai, where both Chawla and Cronje stayed between 20-24 February, well before the now infamous one-day series began on 9 March.

The tentacles of the betting industry, however, stretch much further to Karachi, Pakistan's lawless port city, and into the Gulf, where one-day tournaments are held at Sharjah. In another intriguing twist, police now believe Chawla may have stopped off in Dubai before returning to London, where he is now in hiding. Players, coaches, sports journalists and pundits are all involved, detectives believe.

Now picture the scene in the kitchen of a small house in Delhi. In one corner is a table covered with papers under which three telephones are half buried.

Three busy men operate the phones and at the height of activity there is a call every 20 seconds. Three more keep records. The boss phones round the world for updates on a variety of matches or barks an order to bring down the odds on one player and raise them on another. There's a man to watch the television set that blares so loudly that only the man working his phone can hear it.

When all three ring at the same time the noise is deafening. And sometimes one of the men will turn up the radio so that he can check the way a match is going. Bedlam.

A phone rings.

'Hai!' A pause as the punter sets up the bet.

'The odds are 75-100.' Another pause.

'Done.' No hello and no farewell. No 'and how's the wife' or a comment on the weather. In seven seconds it's all finished.

Although two engine-driven mini taxis and man-propelled rickshaws stand outside the house, you will not find many willing to take you there. If you want a bet you have to rely on a hotel servant slipping you a phone number on a scrap of paper.

Even then you may receive a mysterious visitor to check you out and if there is any doubt about your bone fides that number will go out of action immediately.

Once the phone is slammed down, a bet for as little as 100 rupees or as much as a 100,000 is made. A scratched note on a pad in curling Hindi script is the only record.

One man controls much of the overall Indian betting empire: Dawood Ibrahim, Mumbai's most celebrated mafia don, who manages his illegal businesses from Pakistan. Police only stumbled upon Cronje's involvement in match-fixing while investigating an extortion plot by Ibrahim's gang involving a Delhi tyre company. Whether he is directly implicated in the Cronje affair is not clear.

Underground betting has turned into a booming concern in India because of the country's restrictive gambling laws. While betting on horse-racing is legal, gambling on cricket - the national passion - is not. As a consequence hundreds of illegal bookmakers have sprung up. They generally operate from home, or from small office premises in the backstreets of big cities. The motor that drives gambling is the cellphone: a small bookie would have at least seven phone lines; bigger ones more than 20. Another modern invention has helped increase the illegal betting market tenfold in the past five years. The increased amount of satellite television - up to three international matches a day can be seen in some parts of the Indian sub-continent - means greater interest from the man in the street.

Like any underworld concern, the business is regulated. 'The people who are betting are known to the organisers,' Dr KK Paul, the head of the Delhi crime branch investigating the Cronje scandal said yesterday. 'It is a closed ring.' In Mumbai alone, there are around 200 bookmakers. But only the 'very big' operators can raise the huge sums needed to throw matches, detectives say.

For most bookmakers, the minimum stake is around £70; the maximum £7,000; more can be placed in Mumbai and Delhi. The overall turnover during an India match is estimated by police at £35 million. Much of the money wagered is black - the fruits of extortion, a rampant practice in Mumbai, drug-running and films.

There seems little prospect that the Cronje affair will lead to any diminution in the volume of illegal gambling; everyone, including those in the dressing room, has too much to lose.

fields.headline: A new winter's tale
fields.trailText: The ridiculous annual pursuit of live cricket terminated at Derby yesterday. Hardly surprising that this is so often such a futile trek since the authorities opt to begin playing cricket in winter.
fields.body:
The ridiculous annual pursuit of live cricket terminated at Derby yesterday. Hardly surprising that this is so often such a futile trek since the authorities opt to begin playing cricket in winter.

This season has started earlier than ever before. No doubt the ECB computer dictated that this was the only way to fit in all the fixtures, now that the Benson and Hedges competition has been restored to the domestic calendar. However, the computer might also have been fed some data outlining why the season traditionally began at the end of April. This was based on old-fashioned common sense; the knowledge that there was just a chance of some sunshine then and a chance for cricketers to play properly.

Instead, tales of frostbite and washouts merely add to the ridicule attracted to the game in a week it would rather forget.

There was some cricket at Derby, most of which was enjoyed by the home side. There was rain as well.

Derbyshire are the Wimbledon FC of cricket. No one seems to like them much; not many watch them; they are constantly strapped for cash; their ground is windswept and yet they survive. Last year, they attained First Division status in the Championship, unlike supposed 'giants' Warwickshire and Middlesex, yet still half the side left for greener pastures.

Even so Derbyshire were purring yesterday in a match that saw six players making their debut for a new county and Phil DeFreitas rejoining one he left a decade ago.

They bowled Leicestershire out for 86, with new boy Tim Munton to the fore, taking two for 15 from his ten overs.

In reply, Derbyshire were 22 for three from eight overs when the rain intervened. All very tantalising for Dominic Cork's team; another two overs and we would have had a match - of sorts.

For Leicestershire, debutant Trevor Ward, recently of Kent, was the only man to reach double figures.

Otherwise, the Derbyshire attack , according to captain Cork, 'bowled well as a unit'.

The pitch seamed, the bowlers maintained a full length and batting was always awkward. Chris Lewis had to retire hurt with a damaged hand, but could not prevent the slump on his return.

The ever-reliable Munton was happy with his start and at least the rain enabled him time to get to know his new colleagues a little better.

Alongside Munton in the team is the old Northamptonshire stalwart, Rob Bailey. Matt Dowman has been signed from Nottinghamshire, and Michael Di Venuto is the new overseas player.

All gelled happily in the field, so I'm told, though Lewis caused some jitters when Derbyshire batted, especially when he induced Di Venuto to pull to mid-on. I saw that dismissal, but not, as you may have guessed, the Leicestershire collapse. For my pursuit of cricket began at Edgbaston - there was a marvellous straight six from Somerset's Marcus Trescothick before the rain set in at Birmingham.

The dutiful trek north was barely worthwhile, especially when marooned in football traffic. It's a summer game, for heaven's sake.

fields.headline: 'Never bet on anything that talks'
fields.standfirst: Sound advice from William Hill, and the wary ECB are keen on it
fields.trailText: Sound advice from William Hill, and the wary ECB are keen on it.
fields.body:
The alarm bells are ringing and so they should be. The epicentre of the betting scams may be Mumbai, but the epidemic could strike anywhere, including England. If it does the game is destroyed.

John Carr, as a director of the ECB, had been formulating new betting regulations before Cronjegate. There will be no delay now. The issue of betting, instead of falling under the vague umbrella of 'bringing the game into disrepute', will be spelt out. Rules will state that players, match officials, or officers of any professional club cannot bet on a match in which they or their club are playing.

There is a culture of cricketers throughout the ages enjoying a bet, though until recently it was mostly on the horses. One current county player reckons that at least a third of today's professionals are punters with their own accounts. While they do not bet on their own matches, there is concern that the relationship between players, pundits - there's always plenty of activity in the Press and broadcasting boxes - and bookmakers is too cosy.

The publicity director of Sporting Index, one of five spread betting companies in the UK, is indeed a recently retired professional cricketer, Graham Cowdrey, and he stresses how anxious he is that investigations into the Cronje affair are speedy and comprehensive. However he does not believe that spread betting in this country - which unlike betting with bookmakers is regulated by the Stock Exchange - in any way undermines the integrity of the game.

'Everyone has jumped on the bandwagon here suggesting that it's a spread betting problem,' he says. 'But the Cronje affair is not a problem for us. We don't bet on sub-continent games unless they involve England or are part of a World Cup. And they have to be televised here to attract our punters. We had no markets during the recent India- South Africa series.'

There is very little spread betting, as we know it, in India, contrary to many theories expounded in the past few days, but there are markets on an individual batsman's score and many other 'novelty' bets. All cricket betting is illegal in India but the network is huge and cricket dominates the market.

A popular bet is an 'over-under' which is less sophisticated than spreads. These are straight bets with fixed odds on whether, for example, Herschelle Gibbs will score more than 20 or less than 20. The return for the punter is the same whether he scores nought or 19 going low; 36 or 136 going high.

Sporting Index offer a wide selection of quirky markets - 'fun bets for fun punters' as Cowdrey describes them. In the World Cup you could bet on the number of sightings of John Major on TV or 'Strapping Jocks', the number of sixes hit by Scottish batsmen in the tournament. These are attention seekers, but not big money spinners.

'The serious punters,' says Cowdrey, 'bet on markets like the number of runs a particular player may score in the series or the team score in any innings.'

The only market they have ever closed was the timing of the first throw-in in football after West Ham famously booted the ball into touch three seconds into a match. He's confident that they would spot a scam swiftly. If they did they would inform the relevant sporting authority immediately.

There are spread bet markets on domestic cricket in England, notably on televised one-day matches. 'We have professional cricketers - and golfers - as clients and they can trade as long as they are not betting on games or tournaments in which they are participating.'

Do they get preferential terms since they could be a source of valuable information? 'Absolutely not,' says Cowdrey. 'They have no special arrangements. We are desperate for information. It's crucial to get it half an hour ahead of the others, but we won't pay for it from players or coaches. If our clients believe we have an unfair advantage, they'll give up.' Cricket constitutes six per cent of their business (far less with the high street bookmakers). Football predominates with 60-65 per cent.

Such a selection of markets must whet the appetite of the gambling man. Take Jack Bannister, for example, for 20 years a Warwickshire professional cricketer, then a bookmaker, now a cricketing broadcaster and journalist and therefore in an ideal position to monitor the relationship between cricket and betting.

Bannister confirms that there were plenty of copies of Sporting Life in the dressing rooms of the Fifties. 'Until 1963 we could only bet on the horses. Then the Gillette Cup was started and I can remember having the opportunity - and taking it - of a wager on Sussex to win the trophy along with my old team-mate Ray Hitchcock.'

One-day cricket created a new, though limited market for cricket punters. Bannister recalls that as a bookmaker in 1973 he offered bets on all competitions and it was worth his while to take out advertisements in the cricket magazines. From his own painful personal experience he can chart the emergence of spread betting.

'It was in 1993. Warwickshire were in the final of the NatWest and I'd had a chat with the umpires and several players and all of them said the wicket was soft, tricky for batting. All agreed that 240 was likely to be the maximum score. What happened? Sussex scored 321 and Warwickshire got them.' That heavy loss was enough to remind him of the wise words of William Hill, who told Bannister as a youngster 'Never bet on anything that talks.' This still seems like a damned good policy.

Of course cricket and betting goes back way beyond the Bannister era. Just in case you are concocting a thesis focusing on the decay of modern society, remember that William Lambert, the best all-rounder of his day, was banished from the game for 'selling' a match between Nottinghamshire and England in 1817.

fields.trailText: WENGER: I WON'T GAMBLE ON RUUD
fields.body:
WENGER: I WON'T GAMBLE ON RUUD

Arsene Wenger is close to a £12m move for Robbie Fowler after ruling out a bid of over £20m for Ruud van Nistelrooy: 'I like Ruud, but not at that price.'

OLSEN IN CRUNCH TALKS: JOE WAITS

Egil Olsen is set for talks with Wimbledon's Norwegian owners over his future at Selhurst Park: Joe Kinnear has been lined-up for a shock return.

AND THE REST...

Alex Ferguson has upped his interest in 21-year-old, £7m-rated Marseille midfielder Stephane Dalmat - also a target for Inter ; George Weah has asked Gianluca Vialli for another year at Chelsea : 'It would be great to come back for pre-season training and spend at least a year with the lads'; Walter Smith has dismissed reports of an Everton bid for Sheffield Wednesday's Alan Quinn; Leeds are preparing an multi-million pound offer to take Steve McManaman from Real Madrid ; Martin O'Neill is back in the market for West Ham's Paulo Wanchope - a £3m deal has been discussed, and could be part-financed by selling wantaway Theo Zagorakis to AEK Athens ; Sergi has rejected a move to Chelsea by agreeing to join Spanish league leaders Deportivo La Coruna ; Newcastle are considering a £4m move for Real Sociedad winger Sa Pinto - the man Roberto Carlos says is 'better than Beckham - what I'd call a proper winger' - they're also after Feyenoord's Marc Bosvelt; Sunderland are chasing Brann Bergen's teenage striker Azar Karadas; Tottenham have made a £2.5m move for Nigeria's highly-rated striker Julius Aghahowa; Charlton are set to sign Rangers star Jonatan Johansson in a £1.5m summer deal; and a Daily Mail full page exclusive reveals how Emlyn Hughes thinks Chelsea might win something this season.

webTitle: Park the Panda and be a toff

fields.headline: Park the Panda and be a toff
fields.standfirst: Will Buckley  secretes his jalopy behind a convenient Daimler, and discovers the joys of very, very fine Armagnac on a stylish break  à deux at Tylney Hall
fields.trailText: Nigella Lawson was right to argue that parents should have a half-term too. After all the stress involved in hanging around the school gates to drop the kids off and then hanging around again to pick them up, every parent deserves a holiday - time to remind themselves of what things were like before the nippers came mewling and puking into their lives.
fields.body:
Nigella Lawson was right to argue that parents should have a half-term too. After all the stress involved in hanging around the school gates to drop the kids off and then hanging around again to pick them up, every parent deserves a holiday - time to remind themselves of what things were like before the nippers came mewling and puking into their lives.

Wonderful theory; just one niggle in practice: where do the children play while you're on half-term? Because, lovely as they are, they're rarely invited to stay for longer than a quick video and a rushed tea. Which gives you the chance to watch Countdown without interruption, but precious little else. And then we got lucky. After a deal of finagling we persuaded a compliant babysitter to move in for a long weekend and gunned the Fiat Panda towards Tylney Hall, Hampshire.

Driving down the M3 we calculated that - excluding weddings, on the ground that the presence of a hundred other guests prevents these being considered as romantic breaks for two - this was our first weekend à deux for four years. All a bit baffling, really. We tried some non-kid small talk, mentioned the weather, and lapsed into a happy silence.

Hiding the Panda behind a convenient Daimler, we made our way, with some trepidation, towards Tylney Hall. The point of a Top Notch Country House Hotel is that it should look imposing and impressive; a side-effect of this is that it is easy to be daunted. It's the golf-club moment. Do you look wrong? Will they summarily evict you for wearing the wrong jumper?

We needn't have had any fear. The staff couldn't have been more friendly and accommodating. We were given a guided tour - 'over to your right, an unrivalled view of Basingstoke' - before being shown to our room. This was marginally bigger than our flat: four-poster bed, big bathroom, and a living-room with two sofas, four armchairs, a bottle of champagne, some dried fruit and a television tuned into Sky Sports One.

It didn't take long to unwind and in half an hour we found ourselves sitting on a bench in the grounds and looking at a lake. Next stop, the cocktail bar where the ebullient Thomas promised us 'I make the very best gin and tonics'. He did too. Then dinner. And then back to Thomas who had moved up to Armagnac. Very, very fine Armagnac: 'I think you might enjoy this one, sir. An old friend of mine makes his own and brings me over a bottle now and then.' He produced a litre of 1930 Armagnac which tasted even better than it sounds.

Thomas, obviously, was an excellent fellow, an ex-member of the D'Oyly Carte with a fine baritone voice equally adept at discussing topics ranging from the local pubs to whether there might be a strange sub-sect of people living in the basement of Dolphin Square. A fine time was had by all.

Day two was, if possible, even more relaxing. A quick swim in the morning, a frame of snooker, a comfortable walk to a country pub, and a kip in the afternoon. We could have played golf but 'darling, how do you fancy caddying for me?' is a question I've always found something of a mood-wrecker on a romantic weekend. We could have gone sight-seeing but... why bother? Instead we did nothing, which was precisely what we wanted to do. And Tylney Hall - and this is intended as a compliment - provided the perfect surroundings for doing nothing. It was notable how many other residents wended their way to the local pub to have lunch.

In the evening, another meal and - you'd be a fool not to - more Armagnac with Thomas's co-waiter attempting to out-Thomas Thomas with an equally fine vintage. A choice of drinks and a choice of three bars, all with log fires, in which to drink them. You could go on a sophisticated pub-crawl without leaving the hotel. Perfect.

Now, before anyone accuses me of seeing everything through Armagnac-clouded glasses, a few quibbles. The food is fine but not outstanding. But when a dispute arose halfway through a bottle of Lebanese red as to whether it was off, they provided an immediate replacement.

My only other - the only other possible - complaint is that the coffee was on the watery side of bland. You could, of course, bring your own Thermos but that would be churlish given the excellent standards everywhere else. Better, if you must, to complain, but seeing as it took half a bottle of red before we had the guts to mention there might be something wrong with the wine we were hardly likely to get our acts together over an espresso. Nor, frankly, could we be bothered. We were having far too good a time to start whingeing.

Weekend rates at Tylney Hall (01256 764881) start at £195 per double room per night including breakfast and table d'hote dinner.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Atletico crisis: Jesus saves?
fields.body:
Atletico crisis: Jesus saves?

Administrators sent in to investigate the financial mess at Atletico Madrid have warned that the club is 'technically bankrupt' and needs 13,000 million pesetas (£47m) to survive.

Atletico were placed in administration last year after president Jesus Gil - famous for hiring and firing 23 managers over the last 13 years, and accumulating 10 years worth of suspensions for comments made about referees - was jailed amid allegations of a corrupt sponsorship deal.

He and his board were then suspended while the investigation was conducted - and, it was assumed, Gil's reign at the club was over. Now though, with relegation and liquidation pending, the 67-year-old has been given the chance for one final spell in control, albeit overseen by two court-appointed officials.

Last week he warned supporters who asked if he could turn Atletico round and stave off receivership: 'I'm Jesus Gil, not Jesus Christ'. However, he's kept the faith: 'We will still be here next season. This is both the end of a nightmare, and the beginning of a long-cherished dream.'

Germans march for right to riot

Fears of trouble in Charleroi have continued to mount after 200 German militants marched through Berlin to protest against new anti-hooligan legislation.

The measures, aimed at controlling the 10,000 German fans expected to travel to Belgium in June, met opposition from the group on the basis of restriction of civil liberty. 'We have no lobby group but we have the same rights as other people,' said a spokesman. 'We're here to fight against discrimination.'

'Yes, you may describe many of us here as hooligans,' added another, asking to be named only as Dirk. 'But we don't attack old ladies and we don't rob banks. We're neither terrorists nor criminals. We're football fans, sportsmen.' German police estimate that 3,000 known hooligans live in Germany, with another 5,000 'prone to violence'.

Primavalle playing for big time

Primavalle - an amateur Italian club from Rome's most deprived suburb - have made big news in Japan after using a Playstation games console to teach their squad tactics. The plan was the brainchild of coach Fabrizio Proietti Formaggio (left), who installed the machine after Primavalle's players refused to listen to his team talks. Since then, the club have surged to the top of the Italian seventh division, attracting interest from the fascinated Japanese J-League.

'This is very strange,' says Proietti. 'It happened because my son spends hours in front of the thing, so I thought it could be a good way to get more attention from my players. And it has. Our best Playstation player, Emiliano Lezzi, set up the game for me, changing the names of the Serie A players to the names of our players, and changing the characteristics to match ours - then we just play. The boys are transfixed by it.'

Now Hidetoshi Nakata's former team, Shonan Bellmare, have approached Proietti with a request to take his ideas to Japan.

'My family and I run a cake shop here in Primavalle,' says Proietti. 'One day the telephone rang and a journalist told me that she had heard a Japanese club wanted to sign me. I spoke with my wife, and we decided that if this was true, we were ready to leave. None have contacted me officially so far, but I hear they are rather impressed'.

fields.headline: Ipswich move closer
fields.standfirst: League review Jason Tomas
fields.trailText: David Johnson pounces to seal a crucial victory as Manchester City are held by the battling Mariners
fields.body:
THE BATTLE FOR that second automatic promotion spot in the First Division was given another dose of tension yesterday with the gap between Manchester City and Ipswich cut to one point.

City were disappointing at Grimsby, where they failed to capitalise on a Spencer Prior headed goal after only six minutes. Grimsby were able to get back on level terms 10 minutes later, through Alan Pouton - his first goal for the club - and from that point, City were very much on the back foot.

Steve Livingstone and Lee Ashcroft both squandered good chances to put Grimsby ahead; and seven minutes from the end, City seemed fortunate not to have Danny Tiatto sent off for apparently hauling Kevin Donovan down from behind when the Grimsby man had a clear run on goal. City's manager, Joe Royle, admitted: 'It was a good point for us because we did not deserve any more.'

The result for Ipswich was even better. They won 1-0 at Stockport, thanks to a David Johnson goal just before half time. It stemmed from a clearance by Ipswich keeper Richard Wright and brought Johnson's total for the season to 19.

THE SURPRISE OF the day was surely Birmingham's 1-0 defeat at home to Nottingham Forest. However, Birmingham did have a good excuse - an own goal by Darren Purse.

Wolves, the leaders of the small group of teams still hoping to break into the play-off zone, also went down 1-0, at Norwich. They had Simon Osborn sent off for a second bookable offence.

THE MOST ENTERTAINING match was Bolton's 4-4 draw at West Bromwich Albion. The home team were ahead three times but were eventually denied victory by Gudni Bergsson. The Icelandic star, the longest-serving foreign import in the English game, scored the second of his two goals in the 90th minute - two minutes after Adam Oliver had put West Brom 4-3 ahead.

THE ONLY NATIONWIDE team to have scored more goals than Charlton are Barnsley, who brought their total to 84 with the 2-2 draw at Port Vale. It was hardly surprising that one of their goals came from Craig Hignett, arguably their most effective attacking player this season.

Hignett - who has scored 19 goals this season - said: 'It is a big change from my Middlesbrough days. The job I was given there was mainly a defensive one; I would be running up and down the right or left flank, and it would be up to players like Juninho and Emerson to create the goals. Now I am in that position, which is what I have always wanted.

'Last season, when we played five at the back, I was used in a free role just behind the strikers. Now it is 4-4-2, and I have had to become more disciplined. But the main thing is that, while I have defensive responsibilities, I can still go wherever I want when we have the ball.'

In addition to his goal against Port Vale, he created Barnsley's second, for John Curtis. But Barnsley's chances of automatiuc promotion were dented by a last-minute Tommy Widdrington penalty.

fields.headline: Growing pains of Ronaldo
fields.standfirst: Brazilians blame Italians for star scorer's career-threatening injury - which leaves him picking up £160,000 a week for nothing.  Simon Evans reports from Milan
fields.trailText: Brazilians blame Italians for star scorer's career-threatening injury - which leaves him picking up £160,000 a week for nothing. Simon Evans reports from Milan.
fields.body:
The weight of expectation and corporate interest, not to mention the size of his upper body, probably combined to bring Ronaldo to his knees last week. The theories of why the Brazilian should break down again are doing the rounds once more and there is a sinister air to each of them with talk of bodybuilding drugs and the demands of big business.

Alessandro Trabattoni, hired by Inter to work on Ronaldo's knee over the past two seasons, says he told the club the problem was physical imbalance that forces the Brazilian to put undue pressure on his right knee. 'Ronaldo loads his right knee. In difficult moments a great part of his weight is concentrated on that point,' says Trabattoni.

In Brazil questions are being asked about where that weight has come from. There is a belief his knees are unable to cope with the heaviness of his upper body and thighs. His latest comeback, four months after an operation to his troubled right knee, lasted just six minutes and the manner of his downfall seemed to support Trabattoni's theory.

Ronaldo, on as a second-half substitute in Inter's Italian Cup final with Lazio, ran at the defence with his upper body swerving, offering a brief glimpse of the player we once knew. Then he fell to the floor, screaming in pain having ruptured the same kneecap tendon which had caused his absence for much of the season.

When Ronaldo left Cruzeiro in 1994, at the age of 17, to join PSV Eindhoven, he was over 5ft 10in tall and weighed nearly 12st. Six years later, he stands one-and-half inches taller and over a stone heavier.

Moises Cohen, who last year operated on the knee of Brazilian veteran Rai and is considered one of Brazil's leading specialists, told the sports daily Lance : 'If we compare the Ronaldo of PSV Eindhoven with the Ronaldo who went on to the field against Lazio, we can see that they are two different people. He has a different build. Only his teeth are the same.

'Nature didn't produce his body to have the weight that it carries today. Ronaldo is the most famous case. But every day I see athletes, from various sports, increasing their muscular mass artificially. This provokes terrible anomalies in their bodily systems, which, inevitably, create problems.'

The mysteries continue and the lack of clarity about Ronaldo's injuries is hardly helped by Inter's determination to play down every setback. Last season Ronaldo opened up about his injury, admitting in a television interview that he was suffering from a 'chronic' knee problem.

The following day Inter claimed the buck-toothed Brazilian had made a linguistic error and that he merely meant to say he had a 'long-running' knee problem.

However, even Inter's spin doctors have been unable to offer an explanation for what happened to Ronaldo before the 1998 World Cup final when the Italian club criticised the decision to play him after he fell ill before the game, apparently suffering from convulsions.

The world could see something was not right as Ronaldo wandered the field in a daze as Brazil lost to France. But neither Inter nor Brazil offered a reason over what caused him to pass out in his hotel room - epilepsy, a reaction to pain killers and other theories have been denied, but no answers given. Both anti-epilepsy tablet and painkillers such as cortisone are known to weaken knee tendons.

There is also a suspicion that the player's commercial backers are too eager to see him back on the field. Ronaldo's annual earnings from endorsements for a range of companies are reported to be £5 million, on top of his yearly salary of around £3 million paid by Inter and the club's backers Pirelli. That is around £160,000 a week.

Following Thursday's latest operation it will be another eight months before the former World Player of the Year can play again. But while Inter, as usual, talk optimistically of his return next season, the way in which he collapsed has prompted fears that his career may be over.

The problems with Ronaldo's right knee go back to his first operation in 1996 when he was still playing in Holland for PSV Eindhoven. During his season with Barcelona, and his successful start to his career in Italy the problem appeared to fade. But the pain reappeared during the 1998 World Cup finals and four times last season he was sidelined with injuries.

Inter were criticised for rushing him back, particularly after his hapless performance against Manchester United in the Champions League where he was clearly not fit. Some suggest he has been the victim of the same policy this time.

Former Brazil international Zico, who himself never recovered from a knee injury sustained in 1985, said: 'I don't agree with the way Ronaldo came back into the team, always with the idea of it being as quickly as possible. I think it was absurd for him to come on in the second half of a decisive game such as the one against Lazio. It would have been better if he had played a couple of friendlies first.'

Inter say his return had been sanctioned by the man who carried out his operation - French knee specialist Gerard Saillant. Saillant has gained a reputation as the surgeon to sporting stars, particularly after he helped Michael Schumacher back to fitness after his Silverstone crash last year.

The French professor has defended his decision to allow Ronaldo back on to the field. 'Ronaldo trained in public for two weeks before his comeback and he was 100 percent,' he said, 'He collapsed the third time he put his weight on his knee.'

While no one in Italy questions Saillant's approach, there has been criticism in Brazil of the player's personal physio, Brazilian Nilton Petroni. Like Saillant, he is sought by top athletes to help swift recovery from injury and last December Ronaldo left Milan to train with Petroni in Brazil. He will do the same now.

Yet Nivaldo Baldo, a leading Brazilian physiotherapist, said: 'The big problem with Ronaldo's injuries are the mysteries which surround them. I don't agree with a lot of the procedures adopted by Petroni during Ronaldo's recovery.'

Ever since the World Cup final, another of his backers, sportswear giants Nike , who have a lifetime contract with the player worth a reported $3.2 m a year, have been seen as the villains of the piece. Although the company denied they were responsible for Ronaldo playing in the final, they have come under fire for putting the player through too many games as part of their massive sponsorship deal with Brazil.

Nike's Brazil spokesman Ingo Ostrovsky said: 'Nike and Ronaldo have a long relationship and the company will continue backing him.' But Brazilian marketing experts say if his career were to end now, he would be useless for promoting sports products. 'Maybe mobile phones or cars,' said one. 'But if he stops playing now, his image as an athlete is over.'

There is another incentive for Ronaldo to return. According to Gazzetta della Sport , Inter have insurance policies worth £65m if Ronaldo's career was ended by injury. But the policies do not pay out if the injury is to his troubled right knee.

Final
first for
soaringStoke
fields.standfirst: Peter Lansley
fields.trailText: TWO OF THE season's more circuitous managerial changes mean that the characters leading out the teams for today's sell-out Auto Windscreens Shield final can each lay claim to a Wembley first.
fields.body:
TWO OF THE season's more circuitous managerial changes mean that the characters leading out the teams for today's sell-out Auto Windscreens Shield final can each lay claim to a Wembley first.

Neither Stoke City, managed until mid-November by Gary Megson, nor Bristol City, until four months ago led by Tony Pulis, were faring particularly poorly in the Second Division when the switches were made due, basically, to the vagaries of geography.

Megson's Stoke were eighth when an Icelandic consortium took charge and installed former national team manager Gudjon Thordarson, who today becomes the first Scandinavian to take charge of a club for a domestic Wembley cup final.

Meanwhile, on a sodden January night when Bristol City, having risen comfortably into mid-table, were chiselling a way past Cheltenham Town in this competition's second round, Pulis, only six months into the job, was preparing to leave Ashton Gate to take charge at Portsmouth, primarily because of its proximity to his Dorset home.

His successor, Tony Fawthrop, who has scouted at City for 11 years, promptly won the divisional manager of the month award for February, and was asked to take care until the end of the season. This afternoon the 57-year-old will become the first caretaker-manager to lead out a team out for a domestic Wembley cup final.

Fawthrop and Thordarson will then meet England coach Kevin Keegan, chief guest for the day, and stand proudly by their teams as Abide With Me , the traditional FA Cup anthem, is played in memory of the late Sir Stanley Matthews, the Stoke City legend.

It should be quite an occasion, probably the last time any team will be supported at Wembley by so many of their own fans: Stoke have sold their 36,000 allocation and Bristol City just about all their 35,000.

Thordarson, who twice managed IA Akranes to the Icelandic domestic double (in 1993 and 1996) and took KR of Reykjavik to two cup victories (in 1994 and 1995), is something of a legend in Iceland.

He has not lost a domestic cup tie since 1992 (Stoke were already out of the major knockouts on his arrival) and made such progress with the national side that they almsot qualified for Euro 2000, only losing 3-2 to the world champions France in his last game last autumn.

'When I arrived here in mid-November, I never had it in my mind I'd be leading Stoke out at Wembley by mid-April,' he said. 'But we worked hard, me and the players, in the wind and the rain at Chesterfield and Blackpool, and I am very proud to get to Wembley.'

Thordarson may also become the first manager since Brian Clough in 1992 - twice in a fortnight for Nottingham Forest - to name his son in a Wembley team as Bjarni Gudjonsson, a £250,000 signing from Belgian champions Genk, hopes to play at right wing-back.

webTitle: How Leeds can help to heal

fields.headline: How Leeds can help to heal
fields.trailText: Football matters little in these circumstances, it is said. In the wake of the death of the two Leeds fans, it is unimportant. In fact, the opposite is true. Starting today, this week will show how important is the game in the lives, and the healing process, of a city in mourning.
fields.body:
Football matters little in these circumstances, it is said. In the wake of the death of the two Leeds fans, it is unimportant. In fact, the opposite is true. Starting today, this week will show how important is the game in the lives, and the healing process, of a city in mourning.

This weekend the mind has inevitably returned to the tragic events at Hillsborough on the 11th anniversary of the 96 deaths. Then, in the wider scheme, football did indeed become an irrelevance - until it emerged that the people of Liverpool wanted the FA Cup to be completed. Duly it was, on an uplifting afternoon at Wembley as their team won the trophy with Everton fittingly playing their part in the extra-time redemption.

Who knows how it will end for Leeds United this season? Perhaps today's Premiership game against Arsenal, who play in Lens this week, offers a glimpse of the Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen in a month's time. What can be said is that after the funerals of Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight on Monday and Tuesday this week, Thursday's potentially powder keg return against Galatasaray represents a chance to fulfil - healthily - some unfinished business with the Turks.

It was clearly difficult for the shattered Leeds youngsters to perform properly in the Ali Sami Yen stadium 10 days ago and it has been argued here that the result should have been expunged and a one-off semi-final re-arranged, behind closed doors on neutral territory. Now that Uefa have reluctantly but necessarily accepted the need for an away-fan ban at Elland Road as a damage-limitation move, fingers can only be crossed that all will respond with the restraint being called for by police.

Reports from Turkey suggest that fans there, along with many Galatasaray exiles in London, will defy the ban. That was the view of many supporters on Friday night as they streamed from the Besiktas Stadium after Galatasaray grabbed an uninspiring 1-1 draw in the Istanbul derby. There was a tragic backdrop to that game. A Turkish man was stabbed to death after a row broke out between two men watching the derby on television in a coffee house in the city.

Those defiant fans should realise just how inflammatory a gesture travelling to Leeds would be by imagining how it would be regarded if a host of English fans descended upon their country a fortnight after two of their number had been murdered.

For Leeds supporters, meanwhile, it is an opportunity to counter the reports that came out of Turkey that the behaviour of some of them was provocative and instead present the less aggressive, maybe even forgiving face of the English game as exhibited by its decent followers.

Understandably, many may still be in the anger stage of their grieving process in Leeds, fuelled by outrageous suggestions from the Turkish sports minister that the club is trying to profit from the deaths to come through the tie - when clearly the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has always sought to respond appropriately and honourably. Disdain rather than violence is surely a better response.

In the angry aftermath, there have been many hot-headed statements in the press of both nations but Fikret Unlu's - taking in racism, opportunism and England's fitness or otherwise to stage a World Cup - has been the most offensive. Many Turks, though, have also decried it; besides which, the authorities there have moved swiftly to charge four men with the murders.

While Ridsdale has done much on behalf of the club to lead the community healing, now it falls also to the team to try and lift their city through their efforts on the pitch. It may be asking too much of them to win today - after all, they have lost three games in a row while Arsenal are on a run of three wins - and re-establish their Champions League credentials, but a spirited performance will do much to cheer supporters in their first home game since Galatasaray.

Then, on Thursday, if the crowd respond with the more acceptable face of English fan passion, Leeds can yet turn around the 2-0 deficit. It may not be the revenge that the more rabid would prefer but it would surely be more satisfying.

'Even the second leg remains meaningless in the circumstances. It is immaterial when judged against two people's lives,' says Peter Ridsdale. You know what he means, and hesitate to disagree, not having had the unhappy experience of walking a mile in his shoes. As well as being a vehicle for the evil of some, though, football still has a huge capacity for good. Let us hope we see it this week.

webTitle: Ferguson believes it will be all right on the night

fields.headline: Ferguson believes it will be all right on the night
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson, incurable romantic that he is, fully expects one of the great European nights when Real Madrid visit Old Trafford on Wednesday.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson, incurable romantic that he is, fully expects one of the great European nights when Real Madrid visit Old Trafford on Wednesday.

Never mind that the present Real side is not as good as the one that won the Champions League two years ago, let alone the sides that carried off the European Cup six times before that. Manchester United versus Real Madrid is a fixture with resonance, and Old Trafford will be packed to the rafters to watch it.

'There's a nostalgic connotation which goes right back to the early days of the European Cup,' the United manager explained. 'The Busby Babes played Real Madrid, then the side which won in 1968 beat them on the way to the final.'

Ferguson imagined Real felt the same way about United, especially now they are defending champions, and was a little shocked to see empty seats at the Bernabeu for the scoreless first leg. But the revamped and absurdly bloated Champions League has not been the success with continental spectators it has on these shores, which is why Uefa are already talking about streamlining the competition. 'Presumably that means reducing the number of matches, and as long as we can keep the quality I would be in favour of that,' Ferguson said. 'Seventeen matches in a European campaign is a lot, and so much depends on what sort of a group you find yourself in. Last season, for example, we were in a group with Bayern Munich and Barcelona so it was exciting from the word go. This time, with due respect to Sturm Graz and Croatia Zagreb, it wasn't quite the same and we didn't really get going in the first phase. We got through and that was all.'

After berating his players for a careless performance in the first leg Fergu son would like to see United turn on the style on Wednesday. He would not say no to a scrappy 1-0 victory, of course, but Ferguson believes teams should be true to their instincts and knows a big match in front of a demanding home crowd can bring the best out of his players. 'Drawing 0-0 was not the perfect result away from home, because Real now know they can change things round with a goal at Old Trafford, but all we've got to do is win on the night. It's like a league match now, we need to win but that is a challenge we can respond to. Our home form has been good, so the situation is perfect for us.'

True enough, but the situation isn't bad for Vicente Del Bosque's team either. Even though Real's home form since the first leg has amounted to a victory over Celta Vigo by a single Raul goal and a dreary 0-0 draw with Espanyol, last year's runners up in the Spanish league are sufficiently lively in attack to fancy their chances of a goal or two. Hierro and Roberto Carlos are both expected to return on Wednesday, though if Nicolas Anelka is to figure Ferguson fancies it will only be from the substitutes' bench. 'I can't see him playing from the start, it would be too much of a risk,' he said. 'I don't think they will be leaving out Raul or Morientes.'

Those two players plus Steve McManaman came perilously close to sending United to defeat in the Bernabeu, and because the tie is so evenly balanced Ferguson is sure they will be similarly deployed away from home.

'Real won't come to defend, they will play the way they believe in,' he said. 'They have a lot of nice footballers, and Raul and Morientes are talented players. They will put their faith in their attacking ability, which is admirable. That's what we plan to do too though, so there should be goals in this game.'

There should have been goals in the last game, of course, there were certainly plenty of goal chances. The best fell to McManaman and Andy Cole, and it is fair to say the United fans were more surprised than their Spanish counterparts when their man missed a sitter. Cole has been clinical for most of the season, though even had his first leg header gone in United would still find themselves approaching the second game in the same way - wanting to win.

'It's what we prefer,' Ferguson said. 'We will play much better, we know that. Our home record will carry us through.'

webTitle: Oh man, here come the rhino!

fields.headline: Oh man, here come the rhino!
fields.standfirst: Roving the Kenyan bush in an old taxi,  Paul Smith infuriates a four-ton beast
fields.trailText:
'Rhino, in de grass, wid de horn!'
That was my guide, George, and I hoped he was referring to the horn on the rhino's nose. I had never considered rhinos to be particularly well camouflaged, but as George became more and more agitated in the driver's seat, I strained my eyes to see the creature amongst the wavy yellow stems.
fields.body:
'Rhino, in de grass, wid de horn!'
That was my guide, George, and I hoped he was referring to the horn on the rhino's nose. I had never considered rhinos to be particularly well camouflaged, but as George became more and more agitated in the driver's seat, I strained my eyes to see the creature amongst the wavy yellow stems.

'You see 'im. Dere is a mother, a father and a baby. Man, they so ugly.' George was a taxi driver who had picked me up in Nairobi, and he had somehow managed to talk me into letting him act as my safari guide for the afternoon. He had insisted that he would show me 'all de animals,' and so far he wasn't doing a bad job.

I still couldn't see the rhino, though, and I began to wonder if he was hallucinating. After all, his animal identification skills were limited, everything vaguely antelope-like was termed 'gazelle', and anything resembling a monkey was labelled 'baboon'. For all I knew he could have been looking at a family of tortoises or something, and assuming that they were rhinos.

As I watched intently, I suddenly saw movement. George was clamping his fists to his nose and excitedly making trumpeting noises, as the male ambled out into the open.

'You' see 'im now? He use de horn to kill food.'

This was another of George's unique insights into the animal kingdom of southern Africa. He was making it up as he went along, but it all served to make things interesting.

Following the huge bull came the slightly smaller female, and then the sprightly youngster, skipping along and chasing a terrified butterfly. Why it didn't just fly a bit higher, I'll never know.

'Get a photo. Show your friends,' George insisted, taking the words out of my mouth. Tentatively, I leant out of the window of our ageing Peugeot taxi. Rust fell to the floor in orange flakes as I positioned my arms on the door and raised the camera to my eyes. Through the lens I saw the expression on the face of the bull change from contentment, to curiosity, to furious anger.

'Uh-ho, 'im not 'appy,' George said, with impressive understatement. Before I knew it, the rhino's head was bowed and he was charging. George tried frantically to restart the engine and I placed my head between my legs, bracing myself for impact in the way they show us all on an aircraft safety drill card. I was convinced that the papier-mché taxi would be crushed by the rampaging four-ton beast.

Just in time, the engine started with a splutter. George accelerated away from the crazed animal, leaving me with minor whiplash injuries and a rather closer view of a fibrous rhino horn than I would have liked. Still in shock, I watched the angry rhino contemplating our escape via the taxi's rear-view mirror.

'You wanna go back and get your photo?' George inquired, concerned that I had missed out.

'I'll buy a postcard,' I managed to stammer.

Paul Smith, 23, from Liverpool, is taking a masters degree in zoology at Southampton University
