webTitle: English revival is as sound as the pound

fields.headline: English revival is as sound as the pound
fields.trailText: This month English football has overtaken Italian football as the best in Europe. How has that happened?
fields.body:
This month English football has overtaken Italian football as the best in Europe. This is generally understood, but what most people have missed is why that happened, and just how crucial this week's Champions League quarter-finals will be. If Manchester United and Chelsea overcome Real Madrid and Barcelona, and if Lazio, the only Italian side left in the competition, are knocked out by Valencia - and all that seems likely - then English clubs could dominate Europe for years.

It so happens that I know how English football reached this exalted point. That is because my previous job was as currency correspondent for the Financial Times , where I wrote a daily column explaining why some currencies had risen while others had fallen.

Every day around noon, a few minutes after I arrived, a graphics designer named Graham would come to my desk. Graham's job was to draw the daily chart that accompanied the column, but before we could discuss that, he would talk about Chelsea.

Initially, this was rather depressing. 'Furlong aaargh blah blah, Gavin Peacock blah blah, draw maybe next week blah blah,' would be a typical monologue.

Gradually, it changed. 'We've signed Ed de Goey,' Graham might say, or 'We're in for Tore Andre Flo.' Later, as the stresses of his job got to him, Graham began claiming that Chelsea had bought Didier Deschamps and Marcel Desailly.

Eventually he would ask what chart he should draw. 'Pound against the D-Mark,' I would reply. 'Did that on Tuesday,' Graham would say. 'Pound's up massively again,' I would explain.

It took me a while to realise that the rise of Chelsea and the rise of sterling were two sides of the same pound coin. Over the past five years the pound has jumped almost 50 per cent against European currencies. Unfortunate as that is for British exporters, it is good news for football fans. When a British club offers £10 million for an Italian-based player, the Italian club converts the sum into lira and finds it worth almost half as much again as it would have been in 1995. The foreign player produces a calculator, converts his salary into pounds, and smiles.

To illustrate the importance of the pound: in the seasons after it collapsed on Black Wednesday in 1992, few foreign stars came to Britain. I suspect the chancellor, Gordon Brown, has engineered a strong currency in order to help the British game. Brown is known to be a football fan, so nutty about the game in fact that a few years ago he was considering mortgaging his house, and getting a few others to do the same, in order to buy Raith Rovers.

Events intervened: Labour won power, and Brown now has to run Britain single-handedly. But had the Tories won the last election, then this week Raith would surely be poised to qualify for the semi-finals of the Champions League.

The pound has taken English football this far, but the rest is up to Chelsea and Manchester United. The Champions League is a sort of jobs' fair, where the best clubs in Europe parade before potential employees. Every year, the best players from outside the elite - this year, Mario Jardel, Ruud van Nistelrooy and Sergii Rebrov - have to choose between signing for an Italian, an English or a Spanish club. Others decide whether to move from one elite team to another: Patrick Kluivert of Barcelona apparently has an offer from Chelsea.

Wherever a great player signs, he will earn millions. So he generally chooses the club that he thinks plays the best football in the best league.

A few years ago, this was unquestionably the Italian Serie A. But the balance has shifted. There was an Italian club in nine out of 10 European Cup finals from 1989 onwards, but there was none last year and there will probably be none this year. In the past 14 months, Chelsea and United between them have eliminated four Italian clubs. If both survive in the Champions League this week, the best players will decide that the English league is best, and will flock here.

The prophecy is self-fulfiling. The more good players that come, the more English clubs will dominate Europe and more top players will come.

Admittedly Italy has certain natural, non-footballing attractions, chiefly the food, the weather, and attractive city centres. But against that there is a European tradition of sympathy for English football. In a mansion somewhere on the continent, one of the greatest players of his era sits watching Premier League games on a channel he receives illegally. English football is more fun than Italian, he explains, and furthermore, he grew up on it. So did many others.

Only one thing can stop English football now: a slump in sterling. A recent report says that German industrial production rose three per cent in February. The continental currencies could soon recover. If that happens, the good times should be enjoyed while they last.

webTitle: A fine mess sends out wrong sort of message

fields.headline: A fine mess sends out wrong sort of message
fields.trailText: The FA's latest PR disaster over the Chelsea-Wimbledon tunnel fracas comes in a week when a much worse case of bureaucratic bungling took place. But, because it involved clubs outside the Premiership, it received very little attention.
fields.body:
The FA's latest PR disaster over their handling of the Chelsea-Wimbledon tunnel fracas inquiry comes in a week when a much worse case of bungling by football bureaucrats took place. But, because it involved clubs outside the Premier League, it received very little attention.

Last October Colin Todd resigned as the Bolton manager and was replaced by Sam Allardyce. Not much of a story you may think, except Allardyce was the manager of Notts County at the time and broke his contract to join Bolton. Notts County were rightly miffed. All they could do, however, was to appoint a new manager and take their complaint against Bolton for poaching their manager to the Football League.

When the case was finally decided last week it came as little surprise that Bolton were found guilty of breaching Football League regulation 20.1, which states that one club can't offer employ ment to a manager who is in the employment of another. Now if the Football League were really serious about ending this practice of poaching managers they could have deducted points from Bolton or hit them with a big fine. They fined them just £45,000. I know it's not likely, but say the manager in question was Sir Alex Ferguson - does that mean that Sir Alex is worth just £45,000?

The answer is no, he is actually worth nothing, because the League did not make Bolton pay a penny compensation to Notts County. The fine just went into the League's coffers.

I rang the Football League to ask them why Notts County had not been compensated, or at least given the money from the fine. I was told that because County had immediately replaced their manager with someone else they could not put a figure on the loss of Allardyce. This is incredibly logic.

He said after the decision that 'effectively they [Bolton] walked all over us, and this judgement doesn't really deter the bigger clubs from doing it again.' Davey probably understates his case, as the decision will actually encourage clubs to poach other clubs' managers. For the Football League to say that they can't put a monetary value on a manager is a cop out. If we can value players then why not managers?

Davey also said that the smaller club suffers when a bigger club acts unilaterally and in this case Notts County not only lost their manager but in the process of pursuing their case, paid out there were £100,000 in legal fees. Instead of appealing against the fine Bolton should apologise to Notts County and offer to pay County's legal costs as they would in a normal court of law.

And then there is the FA. Just when we thought that they were making some sensible decisions, such as their strong stand on the Leicester cup tickets scandal and their bold action over the racist taunting of Emile Heskey, they make a complete hash of the latest disciplinary hearing involving Chelsea and Wimbledon.

My Chelsea mates were convinced that Wise would face a ban, but to their astonishment, and his obvious joy, he got off with a paltry £7,500 fine. Chelsea were fined just £50,000, which Ken Bates will no doubt describe in his programme notes as a major violation of human rights.

Leeds and Spurs are entitled to think that their fine of £150,000 each was a little excessive by comparison for what was no more than one of those handbags at dawn incidents.

The difference of course is that there are no TV pictures of the goings-on in the tunnel and, conveniently for Chelsea, there was no video evidence. Yet, we were told that a video camera operates in that area. So what happened to it that day?

fields.headline: Beware wounded Barca
fields.standfirst: Chelsea's triumph has sent Barcelona into a shock decline as the second leg looms.
fields.trailText: Chelsea's triumph has sent Barcelona into a shock decline as the second leg looms.
fields.body:
Who would have thought that 10 captivating minutes at Stamford Bridge would turn Barcelona's world upside down? One moment they were European favourites, still on course for league and cup honours at home, and in fine fettle. The next they hit the skids, falling headlong into a cyclone of three defeats, three goals conceded each time, three trophies disappearing from sight in the storm. The shellshock ignited by Chelsea in the first leg of their Champions League quarter final has made Barcelona implode.

Normally, Luis Figo's away goal would provide the kind of lifeline Barcelona would seize with relish. Normally, a 2-0 win at the Nou Camp would be easily achievable. But a quick flurry of unexpected humblings has left them battered and bruised before Chelsea have even set foot on Spanish soil.

Last week Louis van Gaal called his players into a meeting to thrash out their problems. He accused them of being responsible for bad results because they are the ones on the pitch and what can he do when he doesn't play? (So much for his usual image of the big controller with a grand plan.) He warned that big changes were afoot, promising to drop a host of players - Patrick Kluivert, who had dared to criticise his manager in the press, wasn't even taken to their League match at Oviedo this weekend.

The Catalans are traumatised. Morale is crushed. Optimism has been mugged by a burst of ructions and recriminations. 'Awful. Disaster. A big mess,' lamented the Nou Camp's expert from Marca , Spain's biggest selling newspaper. 'Everything has changed and now they are not favourites for anything.' Humiliation at home to Mallorca has distanced them from League leaders Deportivo La Coruna. A heavy loss to Atletico Madrid in the Spanish Cup semi-final means Barcelona would have to win 4-0 in the second leg even though they could be deprived of Rivaldo and with eight Dutchman called up for international duty. The feeling in Catalunya is it's Chelsea or bust.

Beware the wounded animal, reckons Gianluca Vialli. He goes into the Nou Camp mindful of the potential for a backlash. 'The fact they lost another couple of matches worries me a bit because I know that to beat Chelsea is now their main concern,' he explains. 'I don't think they can win La Liga and they might be out of the Spanish Cup as well. But they have still got a chance to win the Champions League and I am sure they want to do well against us because it's the only target they have left this season.'

What a contrast with Chelsea, currently infused with such confidence they must be virtually kicking the dressing room door down so keen are they to take on all comers. In their own way they have been as profoundly effected by the Barcelona experience at the Bridge as their adversaries. The belief they can win every game right now owes much to that new pinnacle.

'The fact we beat Barcelona 3-1 at home, in only the first leg, has made us realise that we can compete with everybody - and we can beat everybody - when we are on top of our game. That's a great achievement but has got to be something to inspire you to work harder to get better,' says Vialli. 'If we're going to be perfect and play our best football ever, yes, we've got a chance to win the Champions League. First of all we've got to get through this match against Barcelona - because if we manage to go through I think the confidence will be so high it would be difficult to stop us.

'We've got to play with the same attitude we had at Stamford Bridge. If you approach Barcelona with a negative attitude you're going to get spanked because they play such great offensive football. They are very good going forward and if you just try to defend sooner or later they score, and then they score again, and then their confidence goes higher and higher and they become unstoppable. So we will try to play our game: defending solidly when they've got the ball but also trying to cause damage when we've got the ball. It's going to be the same kind of match even though deep down we know we are starting with a slight advantage.

'I think we need to score. I'm not saying one, two or three goals, but we have to try to impose ourselves, knowing they are a great side with fantastic players up front. But I think we can create problems for them if we play with the same attitude we showed at Stamford Bridge.'

fields.headline: A top concierge reveals all
fields.trailText:
Carylon Bay Hotel, Cornwall
Tony Dormand, head concierge
fields.body:
Carylon Bay Hotel, Cornwall
Tony Dormand, head concierge

Any celebrity guests?
Tony Blair stayed here a month ago for one night on a whistlestop tour around Cornwall. He held an emergency meeting here with the Irish Prime Minister Bertie Ahern in one of our function rooms. The Du Maurier Festival takes place nearby every May and that draws lots of authors such as Pam Ayers and Ruth Rendell who come and stay.

Any unusual requests?
A guest requested haggis for breakfast which is not on our menu. We got it by sending a staff member sprinting to his aunt's house to get some, which she happened to have in the fridge. We like to be able to rise to the challenge. We have a helipad and some guests like to have the option of arriving by helicopter.

What about sightseeing?
The surrounding area is very much a garden county and there are some beautiful gardens. The most popular one is the Lost Gardens of Heligan. They were the gardens of a large country house that had all sorts of staff who left to fight in World War I and never returned. The place fell into disrepair and the surrounding countryside just swallowed the grounds up. A group of local businessmen have developed it and have saved as much of the original as possible. Daphne du Maurier set her novel, Jamaica Inn, in the pub of the same name which is on Bodmin Moor, a very short drive away. It's a very popular tourist destination as a result of the novel and there are very nice shops and eating places there. It's beautiful if you catch it in the sun at the right time of year. We're also very lucky to be close to some lovely fishing villages, such as Mevagissey.

What about eating out?
People looking for something a little less formal than our restaurant should try a real Cornish pub for a Cornish pasty, such as The Rashleigh Inn in a little village called Polkerris. It's right on the beach and has oak beams and an open fire. Rick Stein's The Seafood Restaurant is in Padstow about 20 minutes away. He can just walk out of his front door with a bucket and spade to dig up mussels and clams to take them home and cook them.

What about a night out?
New Quay is a very lively village about 15 or 16 miles away from us. It mostly caters for discos for the younger set,but there are Sixties and Seventies nights for slightly older guests. The Cornwall Coliseum is very near us and has a nightclub attached.

The Seafood Restaurant: 01841 532 700
The Lost Gardens of Heligan: 01726 845 100
The Jamaica Inn: 01566 86250
The Rashleigh Inn: 01726 813991

webTitle: Out of the pampas, a grasshopper

fields.headline: Out of the pampas, a grasshopper
fields.standfirst: Hannah Lewis finds creativity amid humidity in the Bay of Bengal
fields.trailText: I was staring up at the palm trees and wondering how much damage a full coconut could do if it landed on my head when a shadow crossed my eye-line, then another and another.
fields.body:
I was staring up at the palm trees and wondering how much damage a full coconut could do if it landed on my head when a shadow crossed my eye-line, then another and another.

I sat up alarmed to find a group of immaculate schoolchildren in their blue and brilliant-white uniforms, hair pasted to their heads, staring at me.

A tiny boy about five years old shinned up the nearest coconut tree and knocked down a fruit. He cracked it open and gave it to me. The children stood in a circle and watched my face as I drank. Then all hell broke loose.

The children started ripping off their uniforms in unison; starched white shirts were kicked in the sand, shoes and socks flew through the air, shorts and skirts were relinquished with wild abandon until the whole group were charging around the beach in their droopy pants with the ageing elastic defying gravity.

They ran around the beach, up and down the trees and in and out of the sea with healthy savagery, relieved to be outside after a humid day incarcerated in the classroom. The beach was their playground. They taught me Bengali words by writing and drawing pictures in the sand and created things out of the pampas grass - a pair of glasses, a pipe, a grasshopper.

We spent the afternoon together until the sun set and the fires were lit in the neighbouring huts. The smoke began drifting up through the thatched roofs and the children were called in for their evening meal. We said a sad farewell and I walked along the dirt road to Number 2 village to the road-side food stand that serves the best samosas on the planet.

This was Havelock, one of more than 300 tropical islands that make up the Andaman and Nicobar Islands in the Bay of Bengal, far removed from mainland India. Most of the islands remain uninhabited and are densely forested surrounded by coral reefs rich in marine life.

There is a sense of community in Havelock with families living side by side with their animals in small thatched huts and sharing outdoor washing facilities with their neighbours. With good fertile land and a good climate, most foods can be grown and the Bengali settlers remain self-sufficient.

With only one bus serving the island, most people travel on foot to the villages which are not named but are distinguished by numbers 1-7.

As well as the food stand, Number 2 village is also the home of 'the chilli man' - a man who can eat the most fiery chilies without flinching, whereas other mortals, myself included, come out in raging blisters at mere skin contact with the vegetable.

It is a bureaucratic nightmare to get to the Andamans, (which is inadvertently a good thing), but it is well worth the queueing, the waiting and the frustration to stay among a community as yet unspoilt by tourism - a rare find in India.

Hannah Lewis, 29, from London, is a freelance writer and radio producer.

fields.headline: Hawaii facts
fields.trailText: The fiftieth US state comprises more than 100 islands of which the six major ones are (from north to south) Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, Lanai, Maui and Hawaii with a total population of about 1.2 million.
fields.body:
The fiftieth US state comprises more than 100 islands of which the six major ones are (from north to south) Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, Lanai, Maui and Hawaii with a total population of about 1.2 million.

Currency US dollars: £1 buys $1.58.

Visas Britons do not need them.

Climate Temperatures hover around 31C all year round while water temperatures range from 24 to 28 degrees. Rainfall is heaviest in the mountainous, rainforested interiors.On the North Shore the surf is high between November and March.

Getting there The Hawaiian Dream (020 8470 1181) has return fares to either Honolulu or Maui from £444 with United Airlines via Los Angeles or San Francisco. Air New Zealand (020 8741 2299) has four flights a week to Honolulu via Los Angeles from £497.

Getting around Oahu has a efficient transport system known as 'The Bus' - each ride costs $1;otherwise car hire is advisable.

Attractions Oahu: Hana'uma Bay National Fisheries and Wildlife Preserve; Polynesian Cultural Centre; Sea Life Park. Kauai: Waimea Canyon; Na Pali Cliffs. Hawaii: Volcanoes National Park; observatories on Mauna Kea.

Further information www. windsurfmaui.com (for Maui) and www.hhsurf.com (for Honolulu).More details from the Hawaii Visitors & Convention Bureau (020 8941 4009) or visit website: www.gohawaii.com

fields.headline: Posh pilgrim's progress
fields.standfirst: Martin Bright is rejuvenated by the air of calm - and the quality of the tapas - in Spain's holiest city
fields.trailText: Of course, you are supposed to arrive at Santiago de Compostela after a pilgrimage of several hundred miles - on foot, or at least a donkey. You are not really meant to jet in for a weekend break and stay in a posh hotel. But such is the poverty of my spiritual life that I just did not have the necessary time to spend hiking from the fleshpots of London to the green hills of Galicia.
fields.body:
Of course, you are supposed to arrive at Santiago de Compostela after a pilgrimage of several hundred miles - on foot, or at least a donkey. You are not really meant to jet in for a weekend break and stay in a posh hotel. But such is the poverty of my spiritual life that I just did not have the necessary time to spend hiking from the fleshpots of London to the green hills of Galicia.

Santiago de Compostela, nestled in a natural wooded bowl in the lush landscape of north west Spain, is the Catholic Church's holiest site outside the Vatican. Since the ninth century, this tiny city in has been welcoming pilgrims at the end of the Camino de Santiago which runs from the French border at St Jean Pied de Port through various Spanish holy sites. This makes it Europe's oldest tourist resort.

There is something immediately rejuvenating about the light and air of southern European as you step off the plane. In fact, this is the perfect place to spend a few days and small enough that you can get to see pretty much everything on offer in that time.

Arriving at Santiago on a Sunday without a map or guide is not ideal, but we found that there was something about the place that meant that if you wander around aimlessly for long, you always end up at the Praza do Obrodorio, the vast central square at the centre of the city.

There, outside Santiago de Compostela's eighteenth-century cathedral, we met Jorge, a beautifully turned out middle-aged Galician selling tapes and CDs recorded by his band of troubadours. He swept his sloppy black hat from his head in salute and gathered about him an enormous black cape festooned with multi-coloured ribbons - this was clearly the sort of living tourist attraction that could easily get on your nerves.

But Jorge knew exactly what he was doing. Polite, with perfect English, he explained that he and his fellow musicians came from a tradition stretching back to medieval times. They played at weddings and civic occasions and to tourists of course, but mainly for the love of the troubadour's art. Most were students earning a little on the side although he himself was a pharmacist.

'A pharmacist,' I said. 'How very interesting. But where is your band of musicians now and how do you expect me to buy your tapes if I don't know what they sound like?'

Slightly affronted, Jorge reached deep into the folds of his cape and pulled out an ageing cassette recorder and inserted a tape. It was pleasant enough - Spanish guitars with Celtic and Arabic overtones - if you can imagine that - and a quite pleasant tenor lead. It was clearly aimed at the tourist market, but not bad all the same.

I have never encountered such a respectful sales pitch and it set the tone for the whole stay in Santiago. 'By the way Jorge, what does the title of the cassette mean,' I said as he swept away.

'Songs of the Pharmacist,' he said. I knew I was going to like this place.

The Praza do Obradoiro is dominated by the vast cathedral dedicted to St James the Greater, the disciple whose remains were thought to have been discovered in Galicia in the ninth century.

The story of James's reputed links with northern Spain are central to everything that goes on at Santiago. On the death of Jesus, the disciples are said to have wandered the world spreading his teachings and St James chose Spain for his ministry. On his return to Jerusalem, James was beheaded by the authorities, but his followers managed to seize his body and smuggle it back to Spain. Landing in Galicia, near the modern village of Padron, they carried the saint by cart inland and buried him just outside Santiago. The cathedral itself is dominated by a giant thirteenth-century effigy of the saint embellished with gold and dressed as a pilgrim. In a slightly ghoulish practice devotees can queue to to pass behind the statue and poke their fingers through the golden casing of the statue and touch the wood below. The Spaniards are proud of St James, especially because he later miraculously returned to help them drive out the Muslim occupying forces. He thus earned himself the name 'James the Moor-Slayer' and throughout Santiago, including the cathedral, there are gruesome images of St James as a soldier of Christ wielding a bloody sword with the dusky heads of Muslims strewn at his feet.

Ferdinand and Isabella, the Spanish monarchs who finally drove the Moors from the Iberian peninsula, built the other great building on the Praza do Obradoiro. Since 1953, the Hotel Reis Catolicos has been a Parador, one of a chain of sumptuous state-run hotels. This is fitting for a building that was set up in the late fifteenth century as a hostel to welcome the pilgrims as they arrived in the town. Built around a series of interconnected courtyards, this has to be one of the most beautiful hotels in the world. After wandering in one evening for a drink at the bar, we decided to spend as much time here as possible. The restaurant is superb and if, just once in your life you have the chance to stay here , you must take it.

Indeed the food in Santiago was universally good. In the tiny roads leading to the cathedral, the bars serve great tapas and the local speciality of octopus, fresh from the Atlantic. There is also a very lively market (Mercado de Abastos) a little off the tourist beat in the east of the city where you can pick up local meats and the large breast-shaped cheeses that are the speciality of the region.

Unlike Lourdes, or Mont St Michel, Bethlehem or even the Vatican itself, Santiago has managed to avoid the worst excesses of the kitsch to which only the truly devout seem to be able to attain. Don't get me wrong, there are plenty of tourist shops selling little plaster models of becloaked pilgrims bearing the trademark woodenstaff and I'm told that in the summer at the height of the pilgrimage period, the crowds can become unbearable. Maybe it's because of the presence of an ancient university or maybe because Galicia is still fairly isolated from the rest of Europe, but there is an air of contemplation and retreat that affected even this staunchly secular soul.

Martin Bright was a guest of Travelscene (020 8427 8800). He flew with Iberia from London Heathrow to Santiago de Compostela and stayed at the five-star Hotel Sol Melia Araguaney. Two nights cost £455 per person (three nights are £527) including B&B accommodation and schedule flights.

Since the ninth century, this tiny city in has been welcoming pilgrims at the end of the Camino de Santiago which runs from the French border at St Jean Pied de Port through various Spanish holy sites. This makes it Europe's oldest tourist resort. There is something immediately rejuvenating about the light and air of southern European as you step off the plane. In fact, this is the perfect place to spend a few days and small enough that you can get to see pretty much everything on offer in that time. webTitle: A riot of colour by the wild sea

fields.headline: A riot of colour by the wild sea
fields.standfirst: Bright fruit and flowers usher Harriet Lane to a region where modern luxury and simple joys coexist
fields.trailText: Around Larnaca, the earth is arid and flinty, hard on the eyes, but as you travel west - quite abruptly, as if someone has flicked a switch - the landscape is suffused with green.
fields.body:
Around Larnaca, the earth is arid and flinty, hard on the eyes, but as you travel west - quite abruptly, as if someone has flicked a switch - the landscape is suffused with green. Solitary olive trees on parched hillsides give way to grass-lapped groves. Orange thickets drip with fruit as bright as headlamps. Blue bags, tied over ripening bananas to deter birds, snap in the wind as you pass through plantations. If you stuck a Kirbigrip in the ground around here, it would grow roots and chuck out some blossoms overnight.

Every front step and window ledge seems to be given over to the offhand cultivation of plants, and we're not just talking the ubiquitous marigolds and hot-pink geraniums that look so fetching against whitewashed Cyprus walls. No, here in old olive-oil containers on a shaded porch are freesias, a tangle of roses and flame-coloured ranunculus, a flower I've only ever seen in good florists marked £5 a bunch. Arum lilies, those elegant, sepulchral trumpets beloved of upmarket hairdressers, are growing willy-nilly in a front yard where six identical black dresses are flapping on a washing line.

Perhaps the stout, black-clad matron pegging them out knows something about the weather we don't. The sky is full of enormous clouds, moving between the hills and the sea as slowly and ominously as icebergs. April in Cyprus is officially early summer, but we won't be leaping into the surf during this visit.

At the Anassa, a luxurious year-old resort a little along the coast from the fishing village of Latchi, at the westernmost tip of the Greek side of the island, the pale-blue shutters have broken from their catches and are slamming against the bal cony railings. The owner, an imaginative-sounding man, told his architect that every bed must have an uninterrupted view of the sea, and as my head rests on the pillow I can look out on to the navy waves. Between the beach and the hotel, the pool-side parasols are furled against the gale and splatters of rain.

The Anassa looks like the seaside would look if it was designed by Armani. It nods at the vernacular - red roofs, white walls, even a church (air-conditioned for those mid summer rock-star weddings) - without conceding an inch on comfort or style or convenience. It is a fabulous resort for people who measure their holidays against the International Luxury Index: Frette on the bed, Molton Brown in the bathroom, Ty Nant in the minibar. At its three restaurants, you are more likely to eat red Thai curry with king prawns than anything wrapped in vine leaves. The curry is delicious, but sometimes, wandering back along the glossy cream marble floors to your room, you may forget where on earth you are.

This is why it's a good idea to hire a car. The district of Paphos is comparatively undeveloped, at least in the context of relentlessly concreted Greek Cyprus, and in hill villages like Kathikas and Lyso, where old men while away grey afternoons with roll-ups and earthenware pots of wine, it feels as if nothing much has changed around here since Aphrodite (who was born locally and famously bathed in a now rather fetid rock pool not far from the Anassa) was a gel. Yes, there are roadside notices stating, in English, that villas called Diane and Philip and Joanne are for hire, but there are also the vivid, touching frescos at Ayios Neophytos, a church and hermitage founded by a twelfth-century saint, where monks wield feather dusters behind the iconostasis; the fishing boats tethered at Ayios Yeoryios, where traces of Neolithic, Hellenistic and Roman settlements have been found; and, high up in the Paphos forest there's the tiny hamlet of Stavros tis Psokas.

Guidebooks urge you to go there for the Mouflon sheep - the quarry of medieval huntsmen and their trained leopards, and now the emblem of Cyprus Airways - but there's a distinct sense of anti-climax when you finally seize the wire of their enclosure and peer in at the shapes occasionally shifting in the bushes. The Mouflon plainly aren't interested in the fact that the pilgrimage to see them took you two hours on a precipitous dirt track high in the mountains. But Stavros, with its 1940s British-built canteen and picnic benches, and its family of friendly, dusty cats with green eyes, is an agreeable, cedar-scented place to have a glass of beer, even if you did forget to pack a jersey, and it must be blissfully cool and quiet in the hot months.

The car is also useful if the relentlessly international good taste of the Anassa begins to pall, just a little. The local cooking has to be one of the great peasant cuisines of the world, and it's a mystery why it has failed where Italian has succeeded. In the town of Polis, a few kilometres away from the Anassa, in the tiny 'Old Town' restaurant, we sat down to mezze and a bottle of wine, while the draught from the windows wafted the glorious scent of a gardenia plant, plonked on a nearby shelf, in our direction.

This is what we ate. Fresh sesame bread, dunked in roasted tomatoes and a chunky garlic and aubergine paste. A green salad, doused in olive oil and sprinkled with coriander and a handful of green olives. Pitta filled with grilled halloumi and drizzled with thyme honey. A ravioli made with feta and ham. Salmon in vine leaves. Wild asparagus in a buttery sauce made with egg yolks and lemon. Pork stuffed with feta and herbs, with a few fried potatoes. Chicken cooked with spinach, red, yellow and green peppers, and lots of olive oil. To finish, a thimbleful of the gritty local coffee, with a glass of water and a piece of almond cake soaked in honey. The whole shebang took about three hours to eat and cost eight quid a head. There are worse ways to spend a stormy evening in Cyprus.

Harriet Lane travelled with Seasons in Style (0151 342 0505), which offers seven nights B&B at the Anassa starting at £1,120 per person based on two sharing a studio suite, including return flights with Cyprus Airways from London to Paphos and private transfers. One week's car hire costs from £139.

webTitle: Swim nude or you're an outlaw

fields.headline: Swim nude or you're an outlaw
fields.standfirst: Jennifer Coyle gambles with a trailer trash fantasy on the road to Las Vegas
fields.trailText: The World's Tallest Thermometer read 104F when we pulled in to Baker, California, for cheeseburgers. The third week of our epic American road trip had been an exhilarating but exhausting visit to Los Angeles: it was time to recharge before making our fortunes in Las Vegas.
fields.body:
The World's Tallest Thermometer read 104F when we pulled in to Baker, California, for cheeseburgers. The third week of our epic American road trip had been an exhilarating but exhausting visit to Los Angeles: it was time to recharge before making our fortunes in Las Vegas.

A tiny desert springs resort inauspiciously marked on our ragged road map promised to be the saviour of two weary girls. Speeding out of of town, I gave in to the temptation of the empty Old Spanish Trail highway and nudged the speedometer ever upwards. Thanks to my bravado, we shot past the turn-off for Tecopa Hot Springs and spent a frustrating hour meandering around the lonely roads, peering for an elusive sign in the twilight.

'I saw y'all driving around out there, I been lookin' at shooters since sundown.' The jovial proprieter of Tecopa Springs Trailer Park greeted us from his 5oft tall observation tower, where we learnt he spent most evenings stargazing and trying to solve maths problems based on the patterns of shooting stars. Overjoyed at the prospect of living out our trailer trash fantasies, we forgot to be weary with the excitement of exploring our desert trailer home, complete with resident cat and cactii garden.

We strolled to the thermal springs, centre of Tecopa life. Long before weary immigrants revived here before continuing to the Californian goldfields, the Native American Paiute tribe brought their sick people to bathe in the healing waters. The segregated bathing houses are now just ramshackle enclosures, open to the skies and the warm winds that veil everything in red dust.

Inyo County bylaws posted outside the pools sternly require patrons to bathe in the nude. Meekly, we stripped before braving the cooler of the two pools (average temperature 108F) gingerly; amateurs compared to the petite Japanese women already submerged. They lined up to introduce themselves to the squealing girls in the shallow end.

Like us, they were en route to Vegas, but as fervent anti-gambling missionaries their aim was to save souls in Sin City. Mine was to ricochet between as many casinos as possible, so I left them practising their fire and brimstone spiels and paddled into the hotter pool, empty but for a wizened local hanging from an exercise bar over the water. Lying in the shallows as she swung like a demented monkey, I watched shooting stars in the clear night sky overhead.

Thoroughly detoxified and relaxed, we floated tranquilly back to our trailer after midnight. Confined to air-conditioned havens by day, the locals congregate outdoors by night, and for the junior population this is a chance to make the most of the desert thermal winds and fly huge incandescent kites. In the observation tower, we shared a beer and watched their creations swoop and dive above us like oversized lightning bugs. In the distance, the orange haze over Las Vegas was beckoning us, but for a moment I was certain that we'd already hit the jackpot in Tecopa.

Jennifer Coyle, 24, from Dublin, is a graduate trainee at Reuters.

fields.headline: United title in the bag
fields.trailText: It's a procession. Manchester United's sixth Premiership title in eight years is no longer a case of expectation or anticipation, it's simply a matter of waiting. Sir Alex Ferguson coyly wrote in his programme notes that there is always a but in football. Come on Fergie, with four points needed from five games (half a team of understudies) the only but about this latest Old Trafford title needs an extra 'T', plays in midfield, and with a ferocious strike took United's goal rush to 19 in four games.
fields.body:
It's a procession. Manchester United's sixth Premiership title in eight years is no longer a case of expectation or anticipation, it's simply a matter of waiting. Sir Alex Ferguson coyly wrote in his programme notes that there is always a but in football. Come on Fergie, with four points needed from five games (half a team of understudies) the only but about this latest Old Trafford title needs an extra 'T', plays in midfield, and with a ferocious strike took United's goal rush to 19 in four games.

Given that the Premiership will surely be sewn up any day now the burning question is, is that enough? Would the cat that gorged itself on all the cream going last season be satisfied with just the one pot?

Retaining their European crown is such an alluring ambition the demands of Madrid's visit on Wednesday meant this result was achieved despite fielding a handful of second-string players. This was a team picked with the Real deal in mind. Ferguson made six changes from the team who drew in the Bernebeu before overcoming Middlesbrough. What a substitutes' bench, with Dwight Yorke flanked by Ryan Giggs and David Beckham, omitted for the first time since baby Brooklyn fell ill in February.

Although their understudies lacked some of their charisma, Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, with Quinton Fortune and Paul Scholes in support, proved capable of weaving delicate yet devastating attacking ploys just the same.

Even a shadow United side are expected to possess enough quality to breeze past most Premiership opponents. It certainly looked that way after only two minutes, Solskjaer profiting from a howler of a mistake by Darren Williams. The England under-21 defender, the Norwegian breathing down his shoulder, was harassed into an underhit backpass. Solskjaer seized the chance to dance round Thomas Sorensen before tapping into an empty net.

But aside from that early opportunism there was not a great deal to separate the two teams in the opening half. Ferguson warned that Sunderland could perform with the warrior spirit once associ ated with their manager, and United could not afford to be too casual. It's significant, then, that the one crucial cog who is immune to the effects of rotation is Roy Keane.

Lesser characters than the United captain might have been softened up by Alex Rae's studded lunge, but Keane spun round to explain he didn't take kindly to such physical interventions. Point made, on with the game.

Once the visitors eked their way back into it, they manufactured half-chances of their own, with Niall Quinn and Kevin Phillips beginning to flourish. Their best opportunity came just before the break, when Mikael Silvestre trod on the ball and it squirmed loose for Phillips to chase. He raced clear and Jaap Stam clipped his heels. Referee Mr Jones might have been a little lenient in punishing the Dutchman with only a yellow card.

Another early Solskjaer goal as the second half got under way re-established United's supremacy. It was a fine solo effort, as he controlled Teddy Sheringham's hoisted pass with his chest before again baffling Williams and beating Sorensen with clinical ease.

Quinn was cursing when he knew he fluffed a golden chance after Raimond Van der Gouw fumbled. Nothing at the moment seems capable of upsetting United's procession. You almost pity the rest of the Premiership when Beckham is brought on to stretch his legs for the final 25 minutes. Instant buzz. Seconds later Nicky Butt lashed in United's third goal with a firm angled drive and another rout was in the making. When substitute Henning Berg bundled in United's fourth, Sunderland pretty much gave up the ghost.

But for Sorensen's athletic tip-overs to deny Gary Neville his first and Solskjaer his hat-trick, United would have marched closer to that 100-goal Premiership ambition. Goals, goals, goals, is that all they ever think about at Old Trafford?
fields.bodyText: It's a procession. Manchester United's sixth Premiership title in eight years is no longer a case of expectation or anticipation, it's simply a matter of waiting. Sir Alex Ferguson coyly wrote in his programme notes that there is always a but in football. Come on Fergie, with four points needed from five games (half a team of understudies) the only but about this latest Old Trafford title needs an extra 'T', plays in midfield, and with a ferocious strike took United's goal rush to 19 in four games. Given that the Premiership will surely be sewn up any day now the burning question is, is that enough? Would the cat that gorged itself on all the cream going last season be satisfied with just the one pot? Retaining their European crown is such an alluring ambition the demands of Madrid's visit on Wednesday meant this result was achieved despite fielding a handful of second-string players. This was a team picked with the Real deal in mind. Ferguson made six changes from the team who drew in the Bernebeu before overcoming Middlesbrough. What a substitutes' bench, with Dwight Yorke flanked by Ryan Giggs and David Beckham, omitted for the first time since baby Brooklyn fell ill in February. Although their understudies lacked some of their charisma, Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, with Quinton Fortune and Paul Scholes in support, proved capable of weaving delicate yet devastating attacking ploys just the same. Even a shadow United side are expected to possess enough quality to breeze past most Premiership opponents. It certainly looked that way after only two minutes, Solskjaer profiting from a howler of a mistake by Darren Williams. The England under-21 defender, the Norwegian breathing down his shoulder, was harassed into an underhit backpass. Solskjaer seized the chance to dance round Thomas Sorensen before tapping into an empty net. Ferguson warned that Sunderland could perform with the warrior spirit once associ ated with their manager, and United could not afford to be too casual. webTitle: Owls wake up to survival call

fields.headline: Owls wake up to survival call
fields.trailText: Did you know that on 15 April 1961 Jimmy Greaves scored a hat-trick when England beat Scotland 9-3? Or that 27 years ago today Bobby Charlton announced he would be retiring at the end of the season?
fields.body:
Did you know that on 15 April 1961 Jimmy Greaves scored a hat-trick when England beat Scotland 9-3? Or that 27 years ago today Bobby Charlton announced he would be retiring at the end of the season?

These interesting facts come to you courtesy of the 'It happened On This Day' column in the Carling FA Premiership bulletin, a feature which shamefully failed to record what happened on this day 11 years ago in this very stadium. Neither the bulletin nor the Sheffield Wednesday programme made any mention whatsoever of the biggest disaster in English football. Strange, to say the least, on a day when all the games kicked off at six minutes past three.

At least the minute's silence was perfectly observed, with the crowd maintaining a moving silence. Perhaps the best tribute of all would have been a memorable football match, but there was little chance of that with Wednesday in dire straits and Chelsea on economy setting in advance of their visit to the Nou Camp on Tuesday.

A second successive victory for Wednesday this season has rarity value though, and, while the odds are still stacked against survival, people might now start crediting Peter Shreeves for an improvement which never looked likely. Shreeves was full of praise for the character and application Wednesday showed in picking up only their sixth win of the season at Wimbledon in midweek, but supporters did not appear to share the acting manager's optimism that the 2-0 victory might prove a turning point. Vendors of War of the Monster Trucks, the Wednesday fanzine, were attempting to drum up trade before kick-off by cheerily advertising a Relegation Special.

That was about as cheery as the afternoon got until the 50th minute, when Ed de Goey enlivened the proceedings considerably by bringing down Gilles de Bilde to concede the penalty from which Wim Jonk gave Wednesday the lead. Nothing of note occurred in the first half, save for de Bilde hitting the side netting and Wednesday pointlessly constructing a shooting chance which fell to Andy Hinchcliffe on his right foot, but the home side surprised everyone with a goal just after the interval which opened up the second half.

De Bilde, to be fair, spent the afternoon trying to spring Chelsea's offside trap, though he saw the flag so often one would not have put money on him ever succeeding. When Andy Booth's through ball put him in a foot race with former Wednesday defender Emerson Thome, however, there was only going to be one winner. De Bilde's turn of speed and spritely turn left the Brazilian on the floor, and when he rounded the goalkeeper for good measure only an illicit ankle tap from De Goey prevented him slipping the ball into an empty net. Wednesday fans were rightly incensed that the Chelsea keeper received only a yellow card instead of the mandatory red for a professional foul - Thome could have brought De Bilde down without conceding a penalty, but was discouraged by the knowledge that as last man a foul would mean certain dismissal.

Five minutes after taking the lead Booth had a chance to make the game safe, but could not get enough power into his header from Peter Atherton's cross and De Goey saved on the line. The George Weah show then followed, or at least a cameo of the Liberian's talents, as he hit first Kevin Pressman's post and then his crossbar in the space of two minutes. Pressman knew nothing about the first, a snapshot from Chris Sutton's knockdown on the edge of the area which he was relieved to see bounce back into play, but he invited the second by unwisely attempting to dribble out of trouble in his penalty area. Weah simply took the ball off him, turned and shot from memory before Pressman could retreat to his line. In the circumstances, hitting the bar was not bad, but had Weah taken his time he might have made sure.

Tore Andre Flo joined the attack for the final 20 minutes, but though Gustavo Poyet forced a good save from Pressman, Chelsea were well beaten in the end and did not take it well. Sutton was lucky not to join Marcel Desailly in the referee's book for berating a linesman, and Poyet appeared to be cautioned after the final whistle as a group of Chelsea players surrounded Durkin. The real Chelsea will be back on Tuesday, while the new Sheffield Wednesday have home games against Sunderland and Leeds in which to show their revival is no illusion.

fields.headline: No cigar for Dell boys
fields.trailText: One season soon Southampton will cry wolf once too often and go down. But as another term of turmoil draws to an end, this win should ensure they will be back again in August for their 23rd consecutive season in the top division.
fields.body:
One season soon Southampton will cry wolf once too often and go down. But as another term of turmoil draws to an end, this win should ensure they will be back again in August for their 23rd consecutive season in the top division.

It was no classic celebratory match, but the right result on the day. Glenn Hoddle now has a chance to prepare the team in his own image for the next survival mission.

Watford, doomed by the sane before kick-off and given a chance by only those who should be committed and probably will be, had lost their previous eight away games as they toiled at the foot of the Premiership table.

It obviously came as a surprise to Micah Hyde to have a great chance to give Watford the lead just seconds into this match. David Perpetuini's low cross from the left skimmed through a group of players to Hyde at the far post. He controlled well enough, but got under the ball with his shot and it flew a few inches over the corner of post and bar.

Southampton - looking fairly relaxed in the knowledge that they will probably escape relegation however bad they are - found space just as easily at the other end as Kevin Davies scored his sixth of the season to earn his team a fourth- minute lead.

Wayne Bridge stepped in from the wing, played a one-two with the impressively fat Le Tissier, and found Davies with his back to goal on the edge of the penalty area. The Southampton striker was allowed to turn unchallenged and score with a low left-foot shot.

Watford had an effort disallowed for offside when Allan Smart netted after 17 minutes, while Jo Tessem thought he had doubled Southampton's lead in the 30th minute before he was penalised for a foul.

This was not Premiership football as we would like to know it. On the positive side, it was fun to watch the players sliding around in the rain, it was played in a competitive spirit and the fans did their bit by cheering throughout, having impeccably observed the pre-match period of silence in memory of the Hillsborough disaster 11 years ago.

The second half continued to be a good advert for a downsized Premier League, although there was one stunning piece of goalkeeping by Watford's Alex Chamberlain.

As Southampton continually threatened to increase their lead, Kevin Beattie was put clear on goal and cracked a volley from close range. Chamberlain's reactions were remarkable to get his body behind the ball, keeping it out of the net and Watford in the game.

The visitors, with Icelandic striker Heidur Helguson on from the restart, struggled to get past the halfway line and they defended for long spells.

Chamberlain made further good saves from Dean Richards and Southampton substitute Marian Pahars, who then added a deserved second goal with 14 minutes to go. Le Tissier curled in a corner from the left and the Latvian Pahars, the smallest player on the pitch, headed in from six yards out.

There was no coming back for Watford now, but they already knew that before kick-off.

webTitle: Why I say goodbye to aloha

fields.headline: Why I say goodbye to aloha
fields.standfirst: Rupert Brooke might have been inspired by the soft Hawaiian sea, but on a second, unexpected, visit Lynn Barber is less than enamoured with a place that has oodles of geography but not much history. Even the surfing beach boys are less than a hit.
fields.trailText: I went to Hawaii this year entirely by mistake. I said I wanted to interview Paul Theroux, and next thing I knew the office was phoning me about flights to Honolulu. How was I to know he lived in Hawaii?
fields.body:
I went to Hawaii this year entirely by mistake. I said I wanted to interview Paul Theroux, and next thing I knew the office was phoning me about flights to Honolulu. How was I to know he lived in Hawaii? I thought he lived on Cape Cod. And whereas most journalists - nay, most people - would probably leap and gambol and clap their hands and cry hoorah at the thought of a winter break in Hawaii, it just so happens that I had been to Hawaii once before.

It was to cover the Gotcha Pro Surfing Championship in 1987, when surfing was briefly supposed to be the new Wimbledon or the new Formula 1. I forget why. What it meant was that every surfer came with at least two businessmen attached, who insisted that you talk about 'the product' or the logo before you could interview their boy. And boy, were their boys disappointing! I'd imagined them, from Beach Boys songs, as carefree dropouts who were either surfing or stoned. This lot were as fretful and uptight as bankers, endlessly discussing their Feccs - fast energy complex carbohydrates - and worrying about the occupational hazards of surfer's ear and lower back pain. Many of them were born-again Christians, who told me that Christ was the first surfer: 'He walked on water but He didn't need a board.'

Moreover, 1987 was the year they decided to hold the surfing championships on Sandy Beach, near Waikiki, instead of on one of the famous surfing beaches on the North Shore. It was a horrible, dull cove full of choppy waves, not the great pipelines Hawaii is famous for, though apparently bad waves are a better test of surfing skill. (That is why professional surfers are surprisingly respectful of the British championships at Newquay.) Anyway, I got thoroughly fed up and the one day I tried to escape from Sandy Beach, I crashed the car within five minutes and have never dared drive an automatic again.

So that was my first experience of Hawaii. (Incidentally, it's now supposed to be spelled Hawai'i but nobody out there seems to have noticed.) I thought I'd try harder to enjoy it this time, but it does have certain insuperable disadvantages, viz:

1 It is an incredibly long way away: an 11-hour flight to Los Angeles, two or three hours getting lost in LA, another five hours to Honolulu. (Incidentally, note to smokers: Gate 68 is the magic number; it has a smokers' cage on the roof.) So, l8 hours minimum - in which time you could practically fly to Australia. And you should fly to Australia because:

2 Hawaii is monumentally boring. Oh it's pretty, I suppose, with its wonderful rainbows, mountainous hinterland and fabulous surfing beaches, but it's also very built-up and suburban, with a motorway as sticky as the M25. I'm talking about the main island, Oahu, where 80 per cent of the population lives. Apparently, the other islands are much emptier. Waikiki, the beach area of the capital, Honolulu, is one of the most densely populated places on earth, with at least l00,000 people packed into one-seventh of a square mile. About half the tourists are American and the other half Japanese, and they all pile into buses to visit Pearl Harbor together. Very rum.

3 Hawaii is, of course, part of the United States - the locals get upset if you say you're going to the States - but noticeably more expensive because everything has to be flown in. They call this, cynically, the 'paradise tax'. (Almost everything in Hawaii comes with the word Paradise attached, and/or the word Aloha , which means hello or welcome or something. In shops, it becomes almost as irritating as, 'Have a nice day.') Anyway, the combination of American and Hawaiian influence produces gastronomic disaster. All meals, whatever you order, consist of a fishburger served in a basket with tasteless chips. Hawaiians are very proud of their fish and disguise them with so many different names it's impossible to avoid them all, but there is one they're particularly keen on called mahi-mahi , which tastes like old cod. Oh yes, and they seriously expect you to drink mai tai, which is basically rum with gloop. Just say no.

4 Sightseeing tours of Hawaii assume a fascination with Hawaii Five-O, Magnum and Tom Selleck which I frankly don't share. We spent a lot of time gawping at houses where Selleck once lived, and visiting places where various Hawaii Five-O scenes were shot. The tour guide lost me at the outset when she said: 'Oh you're English - did you bring Hyacinth with you?' Apparently, there is a television character called Hyacinth Bucket though I have no idea which part she plays in Hawaii Five-O . An alternative sightseeing tour features a visit to the pineapple plantations. Would you drive 40 miles to see a field of cabbages? Right.

5 Or you can visit Hawaiian sacred sites. I only saw one, but was reliably informed by Theroux that it is the Westminster Abbey of Hawaii, so presumably this is as good as it gets. It is called Pu'u O Mohuka Heiau ( heiau means a temple), and is believed to have been built in the eighteenth century. But it has since fallen down and consists of a heap of blackened stones. However, it has a lovely view of Weimea Bay, which is something you can't say about Westminster Abbey.

6 Hawaiian 'music' - fat girls in hula skirts, warbling to fat men with ukeleles. Enough said.

7 The common cliché about Hawaii is that it has lots of geography and no history. Actually it does have history - the usual tale of a once flourishing culture clobbered to death by missionaries - but you can learn about it much more easily in Britain, where we have books, than in Hawaii. Hawaii remains essentially a pre-literate society. The only reading matter is to be found on T-shirts and usually consists of the word Aloha, though once in a while you find a whole sentence, namely, 'I went to Hawaii and got lei-ed.' Buy all your guidebooks before you go - if you must go. There is a surprisingly wide range of them in Waterstone's.

So, despite all that, is there any good reason why you should go to Hawaii? Well yes, if you are a surfer you have to go because it is the place where surfing was invented and has the best surfing beaches in the world. If you are a keen canoeist you should go, because it offers everything from sea kayaking to outrigger canoeing, and Honolulu has the only airport in the world to feature a statue of a canoeist. If you are an astronomer you will dream of visiting the observatory on the big island, which has four of the best telescopes in the world. And if, like me, you are a collector of kitsch you will thrill to the souvenir shops of Waikiki which offer such Jeff Koonsian treats as a snowstorm containing Father Christmas in a hula skirt.

Oh yes, and Hawaii also has fabulous rainbows and a generally delightful climate, and on my last day I discovered the International Market where you can eat Japanese, Korean, Thai, Chinese, and Vietnamese, and avoid the dreaded mahi-mahi burger. That's all folks, but I'll give the last word to Rupert Brooke, who wrote in Waikiki:

And dark scents whisper; and dim waves creep to me,
Gleam like a woman's hair, stretch out, and rise;
And new stars burn into the ancient skies,
Over the murmurous soft Hawaiian sea.

Sounds irresistible, doesn't it? Go if you must.

Hawai facts

The fiftieth US state comprises more than 100 islands of which the six major ones are (from north to south) Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, Lanai, Maui and Hawaii with a total population of about 1.2 million.

Currency US dollars: £1 buys $1.58.

Visas Britons do not need them.

Climate Temperatures hover around 31C all year round while water temperatures range from 24 to 28 degrees. Rainfall is heaviest in the mountainous, rainforested interiors.On the North Shore the surf is high between November and March.

Getting there The Hawaiian Dream (020 8470 1181) has return fares to either Honolulu or Maui from £444 with United Airlines via Los Angeles or San Francisco. Air New Zealand (020 8741 2299) has four flights a week to Honolulu via Los Angeles from £497.

Getting around Oahu has a efficient transport system known as 'The Bus' - each ride costs $1;otherwise car hire is advisable.

Attractions Oahu: Hana'uma Bay National Fisheries and Wildlife Preserve; Polynesian Cultural Centre; Sea Life Park. Kauai: Waimea Canyon; Na Pali Cliffs. Hawaii: Volcanoes National Park; observatories on Mauna Kea.

Further information www. windsurfmaui.com (for Maui) and www.hhsurf.com (for Honolulu).More details from the Hawaii Visitors & Convention Bureau (020 8941 4009) or visit website: www.gohawaii.com

The only reading matter is to be found on T-shirts and usually consists of the word Aloha, though once in a while you find a whole sentence, namely, 'I went to Hawaii and got lei-ed.' Buy all your guidebooks before you go - if you must go. There is a surprisingly wide range of them in Waterstone's. So, despite all that, is there any good reason why you should go to Hawaii? Well yes, if you are a surfer you have to go because it is the place where surfing was invented and has the best surfing beaches in the world. If you are a keen canoeist you should go, because it offers everything from sea kayaking to outrigger canoeing, and Honolulu has the only airport in the world to feature a statue of a canoeist. If you are an astronomer you will dream of visiting the observatory on the big island, which has four of the best telescopes in the world. And if, like me, you are a collector of kitsch you will thrill to the souvenir shops of Waikiki which offer such Jeff Koonsian treats as a snowstorm containing Father Christmas in a hula skirt. Oh yes, and Hawaii also has fabulous rainbows and a generally delightful climate, and on my last day I discovered the International Market where you can eat Japanese, Korean, Thai, Chinese, and Vietnamese, and avoid the dreaded mahi-mahi burger. That's all folks, but I'll give the last word to Rupert Brooke, who wrote in Waikiki: And dark scents whisper; and dim waves creep to me, Gleam like a woman's hair, stretch out, and rise; And new stars burn into the ancient skies, Over the murmurous soft Hawaiian sea. Sounds irresistible, doesn't it? Go if you must. Hawai facts The fiftieth US state comprises more than 100 islands of which the six major ones are (from north to south) Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, Lanai, Maui and Hawaii with a total population of about 1.2 million. Currency US dollars: £1 buys $1.58. Visas Britons do not need them. Climate Temperatures hover around 31C all year round while water temperatures range from 24 to 28 degrees. Rainfall is heaviest in the mountainous, rainforested interiors.On the North Shore the surf is high between November and March. Getting there The Hawaiian Dream (020 8470 1181) has return fares to either Honolulu or Maui from £444 with United Airlines via Los Angeles or San Francisco. Air New Zealand (020 8741 2299) has four flights a week to Honolulu via Los Angeles from £497. Getting around Oahu has a efficient transport system known as 'The Bus' - each ride costs $1;otherwise car hire is advisable. Attractions Oahu: Hana'uma Bay National Fisheries and Wildlife Preserve; Polynesian Cultural Centre; Sea Life Park. Kauai: Waimea Canyon; Na Pali Cliffs. Hawaii: Volcanoes National Park; observatories on Mauna Kea. Further information www. windsurfmaui.com (for Maui) and www.hhsurf.com (for Honolulu).More details from the Hawaii Visitors & Convention Bureau (020 8941 4009) or visit website: www.gohawaii.com

fields.headline: Bradford blues at Goodison
fields.trailText: A sixth consecutive defeat - the third by a 4-0 margin - will surely be sufficient to consign an honest and hard-working, but ultimately inadequate, Bradford to whence they came. For anyone with respect for the club and their manager Paul Jewell, and they should number many for the way they have conducted themselves this season, this was painful viewing. It was as if, after months of being written off as relegation certainties, Bradford had finally embraced their own publicity.
fields.body:
A sixth consecutive defeat - the third by a 4-0 margin - will surely be sufficient to consign an honest and hard-working, but ultimately inadequate, Bradford to whence they came. For anyone with respect for the club and their manager Paul Jewell, and they should number many for the way they have conducted themselves this season, this was painful viewing. It was as if, after months of being written off as relegation certainties, Bradford had finally embraced their own publicity.

Mountaineering references have figured large in Jewell's metaphorical arsenal all season, increasingly so in recent weeks, in which results have been so uniformly depressing that the Bradford players would have been better advised to replace detachable studs with crampons in their kit bags.

'We know there's a mountain to climb,' Jewell had said on the eve of the Goodison trip, with reference to his team's fading survival hopes. Within 74 seconds of kick-off, an afternoon hike on the Yorkshire Moors had turned into a full-scale assault on Everest.

Everton had already carved out one vaguely promising opening through Don Hutchison when the same midfielder switched play from right to left, bringing in Stephen Hughes whose pass, dummied by Phil Jevons on his home Premiership debut, allowed Mark Pembridge to score with an impressive 15-yard strike. Worse was to follow.

In the 13th minute, David Weir had to curtail his 'goal' celebrations as his header from a Stephen Hughes cross hit the foot of the post. Two minutes later Everton made sure and were 2-0 in front. A great pass from Hutchison sent Jevons chasing into the area, where he was judged to have been brought down by keeper Matt Clarke. It looked a harsh decision but David Unsworth cared little for justice, converting from the spot.

There was a brief contraflow with Everton perhaps keen to give fans at the Gwladys Street end of the ground some first-hand action, and Paul Gerrard leapt into life to block a Dean Saunders shot on the line. It was a brief interlude and first-half traffic returned to its familiar pattern. Mark Hughes shot, Clarke parried and Pembridge missed an open goal from the rebound. It was followed by Hutchison shooting narrowly over from 20 yards and Jevons miskicking from just six yards following a fine cross from Mark Hughes.

Whatever the intent of Jewell's half-time team talk, it did not work. Everton's passing grew in stature, their play in confidence, and it took less than 10 minutes of the second period to add to the lead. Stephen Hughes's pass to namesake Mark was skilfully turned goalwards for Nick Barmby to sweep in.

Robbie Blake would later enjoy two promising forays into the area, ending in good saves from Gerrard, while Stuart McCall would also test the keeper and the substitute Isaiah Rankin missed two glorious opportunities. It hardly mattered, as John Collins showed four minutes from time, driving the ball in from 15 yards after a right-wing Barmby cross.

webTitle: Powell pops back to sponsor Beeb

fields.headline: Powell pops back to sponsor Beeb
fields.standfirst: Ex-Radio 1 DJ turned showbiz agent reinvents himself again to pioneer charts deal
fields.trailText: Ex-Radio 1 DJ turned showbiz agent reinvents himself again to pioneer charts deal
fields.body:
Peter Powell, the former disc jockey, not the stunt kite inventor, lights the first of several cigarettes.

'This,' he ventures, 'is the first interview I have given for 11 years. When I left Radio 1, I decided I wouldn't be doing them any more. And right the way through some of the, erm, rougher times recently' - he pauses and laughs - 'including that stuff with my missus, I haven't said a word.'

Powell laughs again. All the 'stuff with his missus' was the tabloid feeding frenzy that followed the break-up of his marriage to Anthea Turner - TV star and cousin of the CBI boss Adair Turner - who left him for businessman Grant Bovey. The tale was spiced up by the fact that Anthea was a key client of Powell's enormously powerful talent agency, James Grant Media.

She still is. 'Oh yes, we still represent her - she's still one of my best mates,' says Powell who, at 50, retains an alarming resemblance to the public figure of more than a decade ago.

What has coaxed Powell into breaking his vow of silence is his bid to break into another arena of business through his new venture, Worldpop. This name gathered much more currency at the end of last week when it became the first sponsor of the BBC's revered Top 40 - the only chart, as the slogan goes, based on retail sales of singles, and the keystone for Top of the Pops and Radio 1's chart show. So the Top 40 'run down', which Powell used to rattle through so cheerfully in the ToTP studio, will now, according to the BBC purists, be infected with the taint of sponsorship.

But new director-general Greg Dyke accepts that this kind of deal is the way forward for the BBC.

For Powell it is a breakthrough for Worldpop's profile, which he stresses several times is ' not a dot.com - it's a media company'. However, in essence the £7 million funding from 3i and Chase Venture Capital, which gives the new firm an overall value of £35 million, was drawn to the project by the opportunities new technology offered it.

Powell's partner at James Grant, Russ Lindsay, said of Worldpop that the group wanted it to be the 'Reuters of pop'. Which, says Powell, was particularly apposite as the company is 'in the middle of negotiations with Reuters to provide their pop and entertainment news'.

Worldpop is the kind of hybrid made possible by the Internet and digital technologies. With two the technology company Dream Time, and licensing outfit TLC, joining Powell's company as founding partners, the Worldpop concept is based around a website which offers content, such as interviews and gossip, to other outlets.

It also compiles its own Worldpop charts which produces a global pop chart and, by building a community of pop fans around it, Powell is convinced that the company will also become a major research source for record companies.

'What is really exciting about this is the community that you create around the website - our constituents, young people, can't get enough in terms of information.'

Powell says the business, which will have former record company executive Martin Heath as its chief executive, has five potential sources of revenue.

'First we will have targeted sponsorship for the [young] hard-to-reach user group. Second, there is a business-to-business market for our research services. Then we have an outlet with the formatting of television and radio programmes, there is business-to-business revenue for our content sales, and finally we estimate we might get about 10 per cent from e-commerce,' he says.

Hearing Powell discuss the 'B2B' revenue models for business seems a long way from the man who used to spin Duran Duran and Spandau Ballet interspersed with the kind of natter which characterised the bland Radio 1 of the Eighties.

'I have always been interested in business. When I was 17, I was a salesman for expanded metal dung passages for piggeries - it was my dream to be a salesman for ICI,' says Powell.

This endured until he heard the first day of Radio 1's broadcasting, when he made up his mind that he wanted to become a DJ. Which he did, via the BBC's West Midlands station.

He was 'so appalling, I was quite rightly removed from the morning show to a half-hour youth club slot in the evenings,' he says.

From there, rather miraculously, he re-emerged at Radio Luxembourg, and then finally came the pinnacle - the honour of wearing the Radio 1 bomber jacket.

While Chris Evans' transition from behind-the-mike talent to behind-the-scenes mogul was louder and more spectacular, Powell was in many ways a pioneer, in that he was completely happy to give up all the trappings of fame to concentrate on being an agent.

'I don't really know why more "talent" doesn't go into management of one type or another. I'm really quite surprised they don't.'

James Grant Media has a large amount of television and radio talent on its books. Apart from Anthea, there is Zöe Ball and the scourge of Saturday morning TV, the Geordie duo Ant and Dec, the mature Phillip Schofield and several hundred others. Powell says he will continue agenting as chairman of James Grant Media, though he expects to devote more time to building the Worldpop business with Heath and the other partners.

He is careful to point out that this venture does not tread on the toes of either record companies or the existing music magazine market.

Thus Powell shows his professional roots. In terms of 'owning' the talent and the outlets, he might yet make even such marginal competitors feel threatened.

'I suppose this is a kind of third reinvention for me,' says Powell. 'I know it will be a fairly hard slog to create a success, but I strongly believe that this is the future.'

And what better way to start a reinvention than by getting your name back on to Top of the Pops.
