fields.headline: Mouse to house
fields.standfirst: Whether it's bed linen or the bathroom sink, the internet has it covered. Robin Barton visits 60 of the best building sites
fields.trailText: Whether it's bed linen or the bathroom sink, the internet has it covered. Robin Barton visits 60 of the best building sites
fields.body:
SHOPPING CHANNELS & DIRECTORIES

bbc.co.uk/homeandgarden/ Useful links sections (for instance to antiques or garden centre sites)

british-shopping.com Enormous directory of UK online shops with more than 2,000 shopping links. Simple and effective, a padlock denotes whether secure shopping is available at each site

excite.co.uk/shopping/ Rudimentary homes and gardens section

lycos.co.uk/webguides/shopping/guide/ Good selection of links in the home and garden directory, spanning both the Argos and Conran ends of the market. However, several links produced error messages

shoppingunlimitied.co.uk The Guardian 's own site. Reviews a small but perfectly formed selection of shopping sites

shopsmart.com Enjoyable and comprehensive directory with fewer categories than above (a good thing). It ranks each link and provides a short description of the 1,400 secure UK shops. Unfortunately, the useful price-comparison tool cannot be used in the home and garden section

which.net/shopping/ Lists which retailers follow the Which? online code of practice. Which? members also have access to a guaranteed lowest-price online shopping centre

THE HIGH STREET

conran.co.uk Tentative plans for e-commerce, but you can look at a limited selection of items from the Conran Shop, or buy restaurant mementos, such as ashtrays

debenhams.co.uk Just flowers, gifts and wedding paraphernalia so far, but set to expand

habitat.net No facility to buy online yet, but quite fun to browse through the colourful site featuring the Habitat range

ikea.co.uk No UK site yet, but refers you to the comprehensive global site, which will tell you where to find your local store

liberty-of-london.co.uk Surprisingly, a step ahead, with secure online shopping and a standard £5 delivery charge for the UK. Currently, just a small range of accessories for the kitchen, bedroom, and so on is available

next.co.uk Next Directory account holders can purchase items from the well-designed Homeware section. Since goods are charged through customers' accounts, no financial details pass through the internet. All other conditions and policies as per the mail-order directory

DIY/HOME IMPROVEMENTS

diy.com B&Q's website. At the moment, it is not possible to buy from the site, but you can browse through the huge product ranges, email their experts with your burning DIY dilemmas and find your local store

improveline.com A complete home-improvement service incorporating a database of 90,000 screened building contractors, advice, ideas and information. For inspiration, you can even nose about Giorgio Armani's Sicilian home. There are plans to introduce an e-commerce element to the smart site

design-online.co.uk A growing directory of suppliers and services, from feng shui to upholsterers

hi-revolution.com The free find-a-pro service matches home owners with vetted trade professionals, while the comprehensive style-revolution magazine offers tips and ideas

BEDS & BEDDING

ironbed.co.uk The home site for the Iron Bed Company is quick and professional. You can order online from their whole range: transactions are secure, and after a deposit of £50, you pay on delivery (usually within four weeks).

sofabeds.co.uk In contrast, this site looks homemade and doesn't offer much accountability. No online shopping, but you can look through their range of sofabeds

futons-direct.co.uk A thoroughly neat site from the small Oxfordshire manufacturer. Decide what you want, email the specifications, and they will call you back to take the order

FURNITURE

okadirect.com This site is full of bamboo, rattan and exotic furniture, specially chosen from around the world by an expert team

lordship.co.uk Large range of furniture to purchase online. However, it is not clear how secure this sluggish site is. Unlike many sites, Lordship emphasises its competitive pricing and offers free delivery within the M25

furniture-on-line.co.uk Appearances can be deceptive, but in this case the site simply looks better and works effectively. Shopping from the well-illustrated ranges (living room, kitchen, dining room, children's room, bedroom and office) is secure and easy

theholdingcompany.co.uk Solutions to storage problems should be found in this great selection of shelves, trunks, wardrobes and cupboards. The choice of materials covers most bases, from denim, leather, and bamboo to zinc and Perspex. Online transactions are not yet secure, although this should be rectified soon

design4living.co.uk A new site with some great products. Navigate it room by room and pick up a Neoprene bath mat by Authentics, £25, or a Waring juicer, £270. There's also a magazine which was not up and running at time of going to press

new-heights.co.uk Showcases a stylish range of solid-wood furniture for bedrooms, living and dining rooms. The furniture, in maple, walnut, ash or maple, is imported from New England. It is possible to buy online, and customers will soon be able to have a live webcam tour

marieguerin.com If anything catches your eye here, you can send an email request and the company will get in touch (but check the price list first)

podsofbrazil.com Fantastic pods (beanbags, to the layman) in every sort of leather and hide from this Somerset firm. Prices from £250. No online ordering just yet

KITCHENS

gourmetcook.co.uk Small selection of pots and pans available over the internet. Transactions are secure and the process seems open and accountable, although any savings may be minimal

kitchen-sinks.co.uk Large range of kitchen sinks on offer from ten manufacturers, but it isn't clear how secure the transactions would be

contemporaryliving.com Kitchen-oriented goods - teapots, linen, candlesticks, and so on - can be bought online and are usually delivered within a week for a standard charge of £3.50

smallislandtrader.com Three sections to this cluttered site: china, crystal and cookware with products from Villeroy & Boch, Le Creuset and Sabatier knives

kitchen-taps.co.uk Ostensibly sells taps, but was so slow I couldn't find out any more

watershedonline.com Order Ariston ovens and bright Amana freezers online. They will call back to arrange payment

magnet.co.uk A comprehensive site, with everything and the kitchen sink

ALTERNATIVE

mathmos.co.ukname The complete range of the original lava lamps is available from this great-looking site. Transactions should be secure, but it isn't clear how long deliveries take. A highly entertaining site to visit

kitsch.co.uk The place to go for Elvis fridge magnets

clickdeco.com Offers a range of assorted goodies, like the Buddha money box, but I wasn't sure if transactions were secure

eatmyhandbagbitch.co.uk Sells classic collectors' items and vintage post-war furniture, such as a 1966 white leather Alda armchair (a mere £2,500), probably to design obsessives. Credit-card transactions will be secure within the month. The superb site has a simple and funky 50s feel and interesting links to European and US classic design sites

inhabit.co.uk Not sure whether patience pays off with this glitchy site. There is a small but nifty range of home accessories, but while the transactions are supposed to be secure, the only contact details supplied are email addresses

INTERIOR DECORATION

designersguild.com Designed to inspire rather than shop from, this site is packed with sumptuous visuals of dream homes, with ideas for paints, wallpaper and soft furnishings

webTitle: Poisoned town condemns its movie-heroine lawyer

fields.headline: Poisoned town condemns its movie-heroine lawyer
fields.standfirst: Julia Roberts' screen portrayal of a human rights crusader could be a long way from the truth, reports Ed Helmore
fields.trailText: Julia Roberts' screen portrayal of a human rights crusader could be a long way from the truth, reports Ed Helmore
fields.body:
The Julia Roberts film Erin Brockovich may be a hit both here and in America, but for many residents of the dusty town of Hinkley, on the edge of California's Mojave Desert, the record-breaking settlement of their legal case against a powerful public utility has not ultimately proved as rosy as the movie depicts.

The film, which opened in Britain last week, is about a brash single mother who starts a job as a law clerk and goes on to win $333 million for more than 600 of Hinkley's residents who were being poisoned by chromium 6 leaking from a gas transmission plant owned by Pacific Gas & Electric. The film suggests that the victims were satisfied with the outcome.

Not so. Many now say the film misrepresents what happened and the true story is far less than the populist victory shown on screen.

'The movie is mostly lies,' says Carol Smith, one of those depicted in the film. 'I wish the truth would come out, because a lot of us are upset. I understand that the movie is going to make Erin Brockovich and the attorneys out to be heroes. But where's our money?'

Since the case never went to trial and was settled behind closed doors before a panel of arbitrators, neither transcripts of the proceeds nor records of how the settlement was disbursed have ever been made available to the public, or even the victims themselves.

A number of beneficiaries to the settlement are now preparing to sue their lawyers, including Brockovich's firm, Masry & Vititoe.They are complaining that their awards were smaller than they deserved, that their lawyers kept their money for six months after the settlement was made without paying the interest, and that there was little or no apparent logic behind the varying amounts of money that they received.

Moreover, they say some of their lawyers took some of the judges in the case on a Mediterranean luxury cruise, a potential conflict of interest.

Many residents who suffer from the debilitating effects of chromium poisoning, ranging from nosebleeds to cancer, are unable to reconcile the enormous pay-out with the paltry cheques they received.

Under their agreement with with Ed Masry (who is played in the film by Albert Finney) and two other law firms, the lawyers received 40 per cent of the settlement, or $133m. That should have left $196m for the victims, or roughly $300,000 each.

But many have received $100,000 or less, and neither PG&E nor the lawyers will release records of their accounting. Carol Smith's husband, who had 17 tumours removed from his throat, received only $80,000. An elderly resident in the town was awarded $25,000.

Ron Gonzales, who grew up next to the plant and suffers skin problems, says that he initially received only $100,000, a sum that was doubled after he complained to Masry. His sister, who had most of her cancerous lower intestine removed, received about $2m. Gonzales charges that Masry and Brockovich advised residents not to appeal against their pay-outs.

'Masry and Brockovich got greedy,' he said. 'They could have settled for less and given the money to the people that deserved the money. Masry is portraying himself as such a big hero. He and Erin are claiming to be saviours, but Erin got more than my sister did. And my sister's sick.' Contacted by Salon magazine, Brockovich herself did not seem to understand the process of private arbitration or the fact that the records of the case remain secret.

Her former employer, Masry, was unable to explain the process either. 'Why are you being stupid?' he retorted. 'It was a complicated $333m settlement. Are you an idiot?'

One of the most damaging allegations against Masry and the other lawyers concerns the settlement to the town's 100 children. In California, lawyers are usually only allowed to take 25 per cent of any pay-out to minors. But the judges in the case allowed the lawyers to take one-third.

Moreover, the clients were billed an extra $10m for expenses that were never detailed, although some suspect Brockovich was paid out of this money.

Earlier this year, Masry settled a second suit against Betz, the makers of the poisonous chromate, for about $75m. As soon as that money is dispersed, Masry's firm may be sued by a Bakersfield lawyer named Mike Dolan over the issues of the minors' fees and the expenses. Dolan has calculated that the average pay-out to the 81 townsfolk he has spoken to is $151,000.

He plans to demand release of the lawyers' accounts on behalf of his clients. 'They threatened to drop anyone from the Betz litigation if they went with me,' said Dolan. 'But as soon as my clients get their cheques, I am going to sue them.

'They had absolutely no right to take a third of the kids' money, and I want full disclosure of how the expenses were calculated and how the entire amount was dispersed.'

But in a small town where the sudden influx of money has caused ruptures, attitudes are divided.

For different reasons, many now regret allowing the case to be settled by arbitration rather than in a court of law. Roberta Walker, who suffers from a number of chromium-related conditions, is one who wishes it had gone to court. 'PG&E ripped us off,' she said. 'They're the villains here. The lawyers just took what every lawyer would take. I wanted carte blanche on medical expenses, and I didn't get that.'

Lynn Tindell, who got $50,000, also said she wished the case had been settled in public. Her anger is directed at Masry and the other lawyers. 'I feel like I was treated like a country hick that didn't understand plain English. We are the ones who made those guys zillionaires.'

Moreover, the clients were billed an extra $10m for expenses that were never detailed, although some suspect Brockovich was paid out of this money. Earlier this year, Masry settled a second suit against Betz, the makers of the poisonous chromate, for about $75m. As soon as that money is dispersed, Masry's firm may be sued by a Bakersfield lawyer named Mike Dolan over the issues of the minors' fees and the expenses. Dolan has calculated that the average pay-out to the 81 townsfolk he has spoken to is $151,000. He plans to demand release of the lawyers' accounts on behalf of his clients. 'They threatened to drop anyone from the Betz litigation if they went with me,' said Dolan. 'But as soon as my clients get their cheques, I am going to sue them. 'They had absolutely no right to take a third of the kids' money, and I want full disclosure of how the expenses were calculated and how the entire amount was dispersed.' But in a small town where the sudden influx of money has caused ruptures, attitudes are divided. For different reasons, many now regret allowing the case to be settled by arbitration rather than in a court of law. Roberta Walker, who suffers from a number of chromium-related conditions, is one who wishes it had gone to court. 'PG&E ripped us off,' she said. 'They're the villains here. The lawyers just took what every lawyer would take. I wanted carte blanche on medical expenses, and I didn't get that.' Lynn Tindell, who got $50,000, also said she wished the case had been settled in public. Her anger is directed at Masry and the other lawyers. 'I feel like I was treated like a country hick that didn't understand plain English. We are the ones who made those guys zillionaires.'

fields.headline: The cherubic Giovanni Ribisi
fields.standfirst: A man on the fast track
fields.trailText: In Boiler Room a group of cutthroat stockbrokers want to make a fortune. The young Wasps cold-call susceptible hicks and persuade them to part with their savings for a fistful of risky shares. These designer-clad predators quote Michael Douglas's Gordon Gekko at length and aspire to the kind of opulent lifestyle depicted in hi- hop music videos.
fields.body:
In Boiler Room a group of cutthroat stockbrokers want to make a fortune. The young Wasps cold-call susceptible hicks and persuade them to part with their savings for a fistful of risky shares. These designer-clad predators quote Michael Douglas's Gordon Gekko at length and aspire to the kind of opulent lifestyle depicted in hi- hop music videos.

Cleverly, the protagonist is the cherubic Giovanni Ribisi, who plays 19-year-old Seth on the fast track. His baby face suggests innocence but his actions prove otherwise. He graduates from running an illegal casino from his apartment to the more profitable corporate scam.

The tale of pinstriped youth corrupted resembles Oliver Stone's Wall Street, while the harsh language and office culture recall David Mamet's Glengarry Glen Ross. Unlike Charlie Sheen in Wall Street, Ribisi gives a performance of subtle depth. His phone schmooze is powerfully seductive; not since Tom Cruise's oleaginous agent in Jerry Maguire has anyone been so effective with a handset.

Ribisi is also Boiler Room's narrator, a role which he fulfils in another one of this year's critically acclaimed US movies, The Virgin Suicides. His involvement in both films marks the 24-year-old actor as something of an indie movie talisman.

He is one of those actors you may recognise but can't quite place. If his face is familiar, it's probably from Saving Private Ryan, in which he plays dedicated medic Wade. He's the one who believes the mission to send eight men to recover the missing soldier is a just one. 'Hey, think about the poor bastard's mother.'

Before the Second World War epic, Ribisi was best known as a hard-working child actor. Teatime television viewers may remember his regular appearances in The Wonder Years, Blossom and My Two Dads. At 18, he decided to pursue serious projects and get a new manager. His mother had previously been in charge of his career.

For two years, starting in 1996, he had a recurring part as Lisa Kudrow's suitably kooky half brother in Friends. As Frank Jr, he persuaded Phoebe to become a surrogate mother for him. Despite the exposure, Ribisi regretted the decision. 'It's one of the biggest regrets I've had because it becomes embarrassing for me. I don't want to be controlled or manipulated by fear that my career is going to go into the toilet if I don't take a role.' There have been other recent roles he would rather forget: The Other Sister and The Mod Squad.

After heading the cast of Boiler Room , he is back as a supporting player. First, Gone in Sixty Seconds, an action heist movie starring Nicolas Cage, Angelina Jolie, Vinnie Jones and plenty of fast cars, and then The Gift, a Keanu Reeves thriller. So the former child star is doing rather well. Like Seth, he is a player with a big future - as long as he keeps his head and doesn't upset his employers.

fields.headline: Take your partners
fields.standfirst: America's oldest swingers are the stars of the latest festival hit
fields.trailText: When Austin Powers claims he 'put the Ger into Swinger, baby!' the spoof spy inadvertently acts as a warning against partner swapping. But sex and, by extension, swinging is everywhere these days. It's even the subject of a fascinating feature documentary doing the rounds of US film festivals.
fields.body:
When Austin Powers claims he 'put the Ger into Swinger, baby!' the spoof spy inadvertently acts as a warning against partner swapping. But sex and, by extension, swinging is everywhere these days. It's even the subject of a fascinating feature documentary doing the rounds of US film festivals.

In The Lifestyle: Group Sex in the Suburbs, director David Schisgall turns his lens on the type of folk that probably wouldn't make Powers horny. They're the band of over-60s, paunchy, middle Americans who own Florida condos and vote for lower taxes. They are distinguished solely by their liberal attitude towards sex. In a rave review the New York Times described it as 'the antidote to Stanley Kubrick's elegant, fearful erotic dream, Eyes Wide Shut '.

Schisgall's film follows a year in their lives culminating with the annual Lifestyle convention - the climax of the swingers' year, no less. It details a network of ageing orgiasts attending social evenings, which begin by the poolside barbecue and finish with writhing bodies on the living-room floor. Some of the footage is explicit, but the effect of seeing such routine sex is hardly titillating. Rather, The Lifestyle looks at the reality behind society's fascination with carnal behaviour. As Schisgall explains: 'We've opened the door to the parents' bedroom, and shown the sex act in all of its natural beauty and horror.'

As you would expect, eccentrics and fanatics emerge. One adherent speaks of a future 'sexual utopia', while others attend a dedicated swingers' church. But the overwhelming impression is of ordinary people doing extraordinary things. Like their monogamous peers they recognise the power of the grey pound and vote. Dr. Robert McGinley, president of the Lifestyles Organisation, estimates there are three million swingers in the US and wants to organise them into a pressure group.

Their attitudes certainly reflect mainstream America. Bisexuality is encouraged among women, but male homosexual activity is prohibited. A stray glance between men would lead to expulsion. But the swingers who appear in The Lifestyle are cheerful enough and most have been married for decades. For them the secret of a healthy marriage is simple. You have to keep your mind and the bedroom door wide open.

fields.headline: Write-offs no more
fields.standfirst: The writer's lot is not a happy one. Or such, at least, is the received wisdom, fuelled by Hollywood movies and fretful scribes. But as smart script-driven films shake up the film industry, Mark Morris welcomes the advance of the screenwriter and explodes a few myths about the hack's lot
fields.trailText: The writer's lot is not a happy one. Or such, at least, is the received wisdom, fuelled by Hollywood movies and fretful scribes. But as smart script-driven films shake up the film industry, Mark Morris welcomes the advance of the screenwriter and explodes a few myths about the hack's lot
fields.body:
In 1996, a young man, the twentysomething Charlie Kaufman was hawking his scripts around Hollywood. Conventional wisdom was that they were far too weird. One of them, Human Nature, was partly about a woman with excess body hair. Kaufman describes it as 'a comedy, but sad'. You try selling that to Disney.

Yet something about Kaufman's writing made people want to see his impossible movies and Stephen Soderbergh tried to get Human Nature off the ground. It seemed a perfect match. Soderbergh had grown more experimental as his career went on but still had the tattered remains of a reputation from sex, lies and videotape . If anyone could take the strange premise of Human Nature and put it on screen it was him.

Marisa Tomei committed herself to the film; Frasier star David Hyde-Pierce was interested. Soderbergh proved his commitment by turning down the more obviously commercial Out Of Sight , which had George Clooney attached to it.

Kaufman was about to achieve the impossible: emerge from nowhere and have his bizarre vision turned, intact, into a medium-sized film. This wasn't supposed to happen, not for a writer - always considered Hollywood's most despised citizens.

And it didn't happen. Soderbergh ended up making Out Of Sight after all, and saved his career. Human Nature got booted around between studios. All was as it should be.

Except that three years later Kaufman has a Bafta for his other script, the no less strange Being John Malkovich , while Human Nature will now star Patricia Arquette and a third Kaufman script, Confessions Of A Dangerous Mind , looks like emerging from development hell.

'Being John Malkovich wouldn't have existed without Charlie Kaufman,' admitted Columbia Pictures chairwoman Amy Pascal. Now that might seem crushingly obvious to you: since the idea was entirely Kaufman's, and the words were Kaufman's, then of course the film couldn't have happened without Kaufman. But for a studio executive to concede that writers have their uses, well, that's news.

So are writers finally getting their dues? It seems like it, not least financially. The list of writers edging into the million dollar per movie bracket gets longer by the week. And it's not just the cash: they are getting noticed. In the great American Beauty publicity bonanza, Alan Ball certainly hasn't been forgotten. Wonder kids Adam Herz ( American Pie ) and Ehren Kruger ( Arlington Road, Scream 3, Reindeer Games ), both 27, have Hollywood at their feet. Herz has been given $2 million to write and direct a film. Kruger is furiously busy, despite the limited success of the films he wrote from scratch. Then there's Susannah Grant who, after Erin Brockavich - directed by Steven Soderbergh, incidentally - and the Sandra Bullock vehicle, 28 Days, is challenging the Ephron sisters' monopoly on the 'funny, female, bankable writer' market.

Soon one of Hollywood's oldest jokes, about the starlet so dumb she tried to advance her career by sleeping with a writer, will be obsolete.

Well, maybe. It's worth questioning this story of writers' lowly status. How do we know that scriptwriters are badly paid, abused, bullied, and their work taken for granted? Because they tell us so. 'Beating up on writers is a Hollywood blood sport,' according to John Gregory Dunne in his recent book Monster: Living Off The Big Screen .

Dunne's book - about how he and wife Joan Didion spent eight years writing the utterly forgettable Michele Pfeiffer-Robert Redford film Up Close And Personal - is part of a fast-growing literary subgenre. For a supposedly powerless figure, the writer's mastery of language means they can always have the last word.

Which brings us to the enduring image of Hollywood's attitude towards writers: America's greatest novelists, playwrights and wits left to drink themselves to oblivion while the culturally barren studio bosses got some hack or other to take the fancy words out. Fitzgerald, Faulkner, Chandler and Dorothy Parker - all shafted by the studios.

In this version of events, the problem starts with the writers' late arrival in Hollywood. After all, until 1927 they weren't necessary. With the dawn of the talkies, writers were shipped in from the East Coast and for the studios they were an extra unwanted expense.

The writers, on the other hand, brought prickly egos and a lack of experience at being mere cogs in the machine. Ironically, one result was that in Hollywood, writers - normally solitary people - became heavily unionised. The Writers Guild Of America (West) has even managed a number of solidly maintained strikes, including one in 1988 that ran for five months. Impressive for a union with various millionaire members.

And - in what some claim is no coincidence - a disproportionately high number of writers were victims of the House UnAmerican Activities Committee.

Yet there is a problem with the idea of the much abused screenwriter. Let's start with the supposedly underpaid nature of screenwriting. Here's the more-honest-than-most William Goldman: 'For the hardcover publication of my first novel I was paid $5,000. Such was the glory of its reception that, for my second novel, I was paid $2,500. For Harper, my first Hollywood film, I received $80,000.'

Put simply, scriptwriting is far more lucrative than any other method of earning a living with words. And while journalists and novelists get fully paid only for work that makes it into print, plenty of screenwriters are able to survive on development deals alone.

Then there is the question of having your work messed about with. It's true that scarcely any film makes it to the screen as originally written by the writer. But that's because film-making is a collaborative process. In fact, most writing - this article included - is a collaborative process. Modern novels suffer precisely because you often do get the words straight from the writer's word processor.

And although most scriptwriters have had the upsetting experience of having a cherished script taken away from them, few have ever turned down the opportunity to rewrite someone else's pet movie.

Writers with genuine voices of their own, such as Dick Clement and Ian La Frenais, always seem happy enough to contribute anonymous script polishes to Jerry Bruckheimer blockbusters.

And as for that lowly status, did you hear the one about the dumb blond starlet who slept with the cinematographer to get ahead? In Hollywood only actors, producers and (sometimes) directors count. Everyone else is just there to do their job. It's just that writers have a loftier view of themselves. Nevertheless it can only be a good thing when people like Charlie Kaufman, or Election writer-director Alexander Payne, or the Rushmore team of Wes Anderson and Owen Wilson, are getting attention. All have genuinely startling ideas, the kind that can't be cobbled together by committee.

If Hollywood wants more films like Being John Malkovich and fewer sequels, no one is going to complain.

On the other hand, the rise of Susannah Grant is probably more interesting to industry insiders trying to track the successor to women-friendly script machine Ronald Bass - if the dismal 28 Days is anything to go by.

But don't get too carried away by the idea of writers taking over the town. They have their own Icarus to remind them of the perils of too much expectation. It was only a couple of years ago that Kevin Williamson established himself as that rarest of beasts, the genuine star writer.

Scream director Wes Craven was furious when I Know What You Did Last Summer was tagged as being by 'the creator of Scream ', but no one else could see the problem. Williamson was the Scream guy, a real writer-as-auteur: his trademarks were all over everything he did.

And soon everyone else was sticking in a few self-referential gags and giving their teen characters bigger vocabularies, while Williamson himself was so busy all he could contribute to Halloween H20 was a quick outline.

Then his second TV series, WasteLand, bombed and his directorial debut, Teaching Mrs Tingle, did worse. Rightly so: it's a terrible film that sounds like a bad Kevin Williamson parody.

He's not finished, by any means: Dawson's Creek should keep him topical for a couple of years yet. But his long talked-about romantic comedy, Her Leading Man , will need stars and a decent director. The idea - fizzing around in the air between I Know What You Did Last Summer and The Faculty - that Williamson could be a film's major selling point has gone.

Scriptwriters - already well-paid, now even better paid and getting a bit more recognition in the business - should be happy as they are. The only real stars in Hollywood are the ones up on the screen.

webTitle: A film you can afford to miss

fields.headline: A film you can afford to miss
fields.standfirst: No one likes Mission To Mars, but it could still be a hit.  Adam Smith reveals a PR strategy that can turn a turkey into a golden goose
fields.trailText: No one likes Mission To Mars, but it could still be a hit. Adam Smith reveals a PR strategy that can turn a turkey into a golden goose
fields.body:
Ever felt you've been had? You might if you've already been seduced into a cinema to watch Brian De Palma's Mission To Mars, which opened on Friday. Just consider yourself a victim of a movie industry strategy known as 'hit-and-run' - one of the cynical, risky but often effective dark arts that marketing departments employ to flog films they know to be well below par.

The strategy is simple. In the weeks before release the film is kept tightly under wraps. There are fewer press screenings than normal and these are scheduled to be near or beyond magazine deadlines. Handy screening rooms in the centre of London are eschewed in favour of obscure sites and screenings tend to be scheduled not at the office-friendly 6.30pm but at 9pm.

Then, the week before release, a huge advertising campaign will hit TV, radio and billboards before the movie opens simultaneously on thousands of screens, presented - with little or no critical context and zero word-of-mouth - as a must-see blockbuster. Attendance will peak on the Saturday night before cinemas work out that they've got a dud. And a week later, it will be gone.

Mission To Mars has already pulled off the trick in America, where it was released last month. In its first weekend it made $23.1 million, an impressive performance by any standards. By week two, as poisonous word-of-mouth spread, the take fell by a gigantic 52 per cent to $10.9m. Two weeks later its slide down the chart had transformed into a plummet with a paltry $6.4m. But that huge opening weekend meant that by the time the film slinks off the screen the studio will no doubt have recouped its investment and will possibly make a small profit.

'The idea is to make as much noise as you can, get in with a fair number of prints and then get out,' says Charles McDonald of independent publicity company McDonald & Rutter. But this can backfire dreadfully. 'If you limit press screenings it becomes obvious that there's a problem. You can make films more or less difficult to see, but unless you want to turn the whole thing into an issue - "the movie the critics hated but you'll love!" - you're always better to show it.'

There is also the question of financial risk. Pulling off a hit-and-run release requires the manufacture of a large number of prints (costly items at up to £900 a time) as well as investment in an intensive and unavoidable advertising campaign. 'The whole thing can rebound in a terrible way,' says McDonald. ' The Avengers demonstrated how you can really screw things up.' Indeed the 1998 adaptation of the cult TV series was a Waterloo for the hit-and-run release. The film, rumoured to be in trouble throughout its production, was scheduled for simultaneous worldwide release (in order to avoid Internet gossip) and the producers issued a memo declaring, much to the entertainment press's mirth, that 'the press and the public would be allowed to discover The Avengers together'. In other words there would be no press screenings.

And the result? The story effortlessly migrated from dismal reviews on page 36 to front page 'What a Flop!' news pieces. The delighted Sun went so far as to dispatch a hack dressed as a turkey to a London cinema.

So the film was never judged on its merits or lack of them but was instead held up as an example of the archetypal Hollywood disaster. In fact, it wasn't - it was just averagely poor.

'There you had a screw-up because, arguably, the bulk of the potential audience for The Avengers was not film buffs at all but simply people who had vaguely fond memories of the TV series,' says McDonald. 'But after it had been held up to ridicule there was no way they could be seen to go and see it.'

'I doubt anyone outside the industry could spot a hit-and-run release if it's done properly,' says one senior PR who has structured such campaigns. 'If it's such a big film that you're going to release it anyway, your trailer will have been in cinemas for six months, and with an action movie you can cut a fantastic trailer out of nothing.

'So your punter awareness will have been building without them having any information about it.'

Mission to Mars opened on Friday. Read Philip French's verdict in The Review section

The strategy is simple. In the weeks before release the film is kept tightly under wraps. There are fewer press screenings than normal and these are scheduled to be near or beyond magazine deadlines. Handy screening rooms in the centre of London are eschewed in favour of obscure sites and screenings tend to be scheduled not at the office-friendly 6.30pm but at 9pm. webTitle: Baby bounty plan to woo women

fields.headline: Baby bounty plan to woo women
fields.trailText: A raft of 'family-friendly' measures is planned by the Government to meet increasing dissatisfaction among women voters. Among the ideas  are higher maternity pay, an increase in financial support for poorer families for the first year of a child's life and a 'baby bounty' for employers who take back new mothers to work on a part-time basis.
fields.body:
A raft of 'family-friendly' measures is planned by the Government to meet increasing dissatisfaction among women voters.

Among the ideas being considered are higher maternity pay, an increase in financial support for poorer families for the first year of a child's life and a 'baby bounty' for employers who take back new mothers to work on a part-time basis.

The measures are from a policy blueprint drawn up by Harriet Harman, the former Social Services Secretary, to tackle the growing perception that the Government is not doing enough to help women balance work and home commitments.

The 13-point plan urges the Government to 'lead by example' and show a new, modern face. Civil servants should be allowed to work part-time if they have family commitments. This right could be extended to Ministers, who might be allowed to share jobs.

The plans will be considered by the Treasury and action is expected in the autumn.

The moves come after new evidence of dissatisfaction with the Government's performance among women vot ers who switched to Labour in the 1997 general election.

A report by the respected pollster, Deborah Mattinson of Opinion Leader Research, said that although the Government still held the support of women they were becoming disillusioned with Labour's performance.

Women are 7 per cent less likely than men to say they are satisfied with the Government. Among the key age group, 35- to 44-year-olds (the fabled Worcester woman that the Government is so keen to woo), that figure increases to 13 per cent.

Mattinson said: 'Women are the ones who take the kids to school, who visit the hospitals. They can't be told everything has improved. It is all about delivery.'

One woman told a focus group: 'I thought that they [Labour] were going to be so different, but now I worry that they are just like all the others - out for themselves without any interest in the likes of us.'

Other family-friendly policies being considered by the Government to try to reverse the trend include introducing payments for parental leave and allowing parents time off until their child is five.

Harman's document proposes a doubling of the right to maternity leave to a year.

webTitle: With the beetles and the sloths

fields.headline: With the beetles and the sloths
fields.standfirst: A wooden canoe carries Heather Buttivant  to a laid-back Colombian haven
fields.trailText: Mompos, in Colombia, is not a popular tourist destination. Lying with a drip in my arm, watching the bats flitting between the rafters of the hospital, I could see why.
fields.body:
Mompos, in Colombia, is not a popular tourist destination. Lying with a drip in my arm, watching the bats flitting between the rafters of the hospital, I could see why.

After six months in the Andes, I desperately missed open water and oxygen, and enthusiastically accepted a friend's invitation to his family home on the Caribbean 'coast'. Now here I was, 12 hours from the nearest beach, with an unco-operative stomach and a monster beetle making steady progress up my leg.

Despite the lack of sea, Mompos has plenty of water. It perches on an island in the vast Magdalena river delta. The area consists of a raft of swampy islands, mostly populated by sunbathing iguanas. The town's inaccessibility within a country renowned for violence and drugs has allowed Mompos to preserve its character and laid-back charm.

Mompos can be reached only by boat, in our case a wooden canoe. As we drifted into the current, the boatman was still wrestling with the motor. Everyone crossed themselves vigorously until finally it started.

As we rounded a bend, it was a dazzling sight. The endless green banks suddenly gave way to white colonial buildings - the towers of the seven Catholic churches tall among them. The town appeared to have been transplanted straight from the Spanish countryside into these swamps.

Despite appearances, Mompos's culture is distinctly un-Spanish. From the sloths and monkeys in the park to the pervasive vallenato accordion music, the town is proudly Colombian. Canoes laden with bright fruits and disturbingly large fish line the marketplace. I was quickly absorbed into its relaxed routine.

The town is safe and welcoming, with pristine colonial architecture right down to the cemetery. Haggling in the bustling market is a popular pastime, and the traders soon know your name (I was 'La Barbie' because of blonde hair and an unpronounceable name). Friendly craftsmen eagerly demonstrated their traditional work making intricate gold filigree jewellery, in return for a sale or a beer. Days were otherwise spent sitting in the shade in the cafés and parks; chatting or just watching people and donkeys go by. For even lazier days, Mompos's hotel has a pool - a welcome relief from the unrelenting heat.Every evening, spectacular black and white clouds of cormorants and garzas descended to roost in the few trees standing in a nearby lake.

Illness struck in December, but fortunately I had recovered in time for Christmas. Multi-coloured lights and nativity scenes decorated the streets. All night the rum flowed freely, and we danced in the dusty streets.

I spent a month in Mompos, taking the children out, going to market and removing frogs from the kitchen. A strange holiday, certainly, but a complete break from the outside world (especially when the Telecom office burned down) and an unforgettable experience.

I remain forever grateful to the doctor who took the beetle off my leg.

Heather Buttivant, 23, from Newquay, Devon, is a fast-stream graduate working for Customs and Excise in Brussels.

fields.headline: Naipaul's achievement
fields.trailText: VS Naipaul is perhaps more generally acknowledged than any other novelist today to be the finest contemporary writer of English prose fiction. Who are the other contenders? Saul Bellow? John Updike? Martin Amis? It's a pretty short list but certainly, if I was asked to nominate a top 10 for the last century, Sir Vidia Naipaul would be high on my list of contemporary great writers, admittedly a more than slightly fatuous exercise beneath the eye of eternity.
fields.body:
VS Naipaul is perhaps more generally acknowledged than any other novelist today to be the finest contemporary writer of English prose fiction. Who are the other contenders? Saul Bellow? John Updike? Martin Amis? It's a pretty short list but certainly, if I was asked to nominate a top 10 for the last century, Sir Vidia Naipaul would be high on my list of contemporary great writers, admittedly a more than slightly fatuous exercise beneath the eye of eternity.

I have read Naipaul ever since In A Free State won the Booker Prize in 1971. I fell in love with his work immediately and then went back to discover the novels that, for many people, are his best: A House for Mr Biswas, The Mystic Masseur, The Suffrage of Elvira and Miguel Street.

When A Bend in the River, possibly his masterpiece, was published in 1979, I was living in America and I can still recall the excitement of handling the beautifully produced Knopf edition and travelling with Salim into Naipaul's heart of darkness in the boiling summer heat of New York City. That was the novel which seemed to place Naipaul head and shoulders above his contemporaries, and to set the edgy exactitude of his prose in a class of its own.

Throughout this time, although he has written journalism when fiction was unavailable to him, although his later novels, notably The Enigma of Arrival, have hovered uneasily on the edge of autobiography, and although he has been anatomised, sometimes cruelly, in Paul Theroux's Sir Vidia's Shadow, Naipaul himself, with admirable discretion, has steered clear of the explicitly personal.

So it's all of a piece with his fastidious reticence that when Naipaul did choose to commit himself to some pages of memoir, they should be entitled Reading & Writing: a Personal Account, and should be first published in the New York Review of Books, a lifelong supporter of his literary journalism.

The magazine has now brought out a beautiful little hardback edition (New York Review Books £10, pp64) of Naipaul's text. For his admirers, it will be an essential part of their collection, a succinct and sometimes moving account of one writer's beginnings.

Reading & Writing is a typical Naipaul performance: as sharp and lucid as a spear of glass, nostalgic, contrary and wonderfully haughty. In miraculously few words, he takes the reader to the heart of his native Trinidad, 'an immigrant Asian community on a small plantation island in the New World', describing his peculiar, anglicised education in the last days of empire. His father wrote short stories and loved to read aloud to his son fragments of English literature - 'scattered pages from the early chapters of Oliver Twist, Nicholas Nickleby and David Copperfield... one or two of Lamb's Tales from Shakespeare '.

The young Naipaul decided to be a writer at the age of 11, but for many years this ambition was, he says, 'a kind of sham'. As well as disparaging his vocation, he also affects disdain for his craft. He claims twice that his 'imaginative life' was found in the cinema, and, in conclusion, wonders mischievously, 'whether the talent that once went into imaginative literature didn't in this century go into the first 50 years of the glorious cinema'.

Never mind. Along the way, he answers his critics, evokes his early years and elucidates his sense of a double separation from English literature. If fiction could not take him all the way home, his work has none the less been an imaginative refuge for millions. Whatever he likes to say now, he remains the central figure of a glorious explosion of contemporary fiction in the English language.

webTitle: Rape victims' babies pay the price of war

fields.headline: Rape victims' babies pay the price of war
fields.standfirst: Up to 20,000 women were raped during the Kosovan carnage. Now the victims are bearing children fathered by their Serb tormentors. In this harrowing dispatch, Helena Smith reports on the awful fate awaiting the offspring of conflictKosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Up to 20,000 women were raped during the Kosovan carnage. Now the victims are bearing children fathered by their Serb tormentors. In this harrowing dispatch, Helen Smith reports on the awful fate awaiting the offspring of conflict.
fields.body:
He was a healthy little boy and Mirveta had produced him. But birth, the fifth in her short lifetime, had not brought joy, only dread. As he was pulled from her loins, as the nurses at Kosovo's British-administered university hospital handed her the baby, as the young Albanian mother took the child, she prepared to do the deed.

She cradled him to her chest, she looked into her boy's eyes, she stroked his face and she snapped his neck. They say it was a fairly clean business. Mirveta had used her bare hands. It is said that, in tears, she handed her baby back to the nurses, holding his snapped, limp neck. In Pristina, in her psychiatric detention cell, she has been weeping ever since.

'Who knows? She may have looked into the baby's face and seen the eyes of the Serb who raped her.'

The words are uttered coolly, undramatically, by Sevdije Ahmeti almost as a matter of course. Ahmeti, tireless human rights activist, mother and member of Kosovo's transitional government, does not want me or anyone to sensationalise this poor woman's plight. 'She is a victim too. She is just 20 years old and cannot read or write. She has been abandoned by her husband. Psychologically raped a second time.'

She reels off Mirveta's details from a thick, yellow notepad. 'She is repenting, of course, but the attitude that she is a cold-blooded murderer is wrong. Who knows what this poor girl has been through? Who knows why she didn't abort?

'There were marks, signs of bites and bruises over her body, her intimate parts. We want to protect her; we will try to get her a new lawyer.'

This is what Ahmeti does: she speaks for the estimated 20,000 women now carrying Kosovo's dark secret. The innumerable women who were raped, and impregnated, abandoned by family and friends. The women outcasts violated, tortured and left for dead; the 'touched' women, who have now heaped shame on the houses of their husbands. The women who see the war every day, in their minds, in their bodies, through their rape-babies.

It is Friday morning and there are snowflakes splattering the window panes of the Centre for Protection of Women and Children which Ahmeti set up in 1993. Women trudge up the hill on which the centre stands, daintily side-stepping the litter and carrion birds that defile so much of the province.

Sometimes, when they are feeling strong, they step inside. Sometimes, if Ahmeti is lucky, a woman will even tell her story. So far, 76 women, mostly young and beautiful, the daughters of eminent Kosovars and village elders (women targeted by the Serbs) have been mus tered enough courage to enter the centre.

For everyone who had come there, Ahmeti said you could count at least a hundred more. They are just the tip of the iceberg; the very few who have managed to break the 'metallic silence' that surrounds the issue of being 'touched'.

For rape is not a word that Kosovar women ever use. This is not Bosnia; there is no cosmopolitan Sarajevo. There is only provincial Pristina. In the villages and hamlets, where the Yugoslav police, military and Serb paramilitaries evidently ran amok, rape has yet to enter their ancient lexicon.

'These are simple women, women who have been degraded, disgraced, and will carry this trauma like a bullet for the rest of their lives,' Ahmeti murmurs, chain-smoking. 'Raped women all over the world find it hard to speak, here they can hardly do it at all.

'They rarely tell each other... we've had cases of suicide, the lunacy of women losing all access to their children if it gets out.'

Mirveta, the pretty infanticidal mother, is no exception. She is typical of the selection process pursued by the perpetrators, according to a Human Rights Watch report released last month.

As they tried to ethnically cleanse Kosovo, paramilitaries - often aided by masked Serb neighbours - systematically searched villages for girls of prime, child-bearing age.

It was about power and control, humiliation and revenge. And what better way to damage the enemy's morale than to hit at his family? 'Our society is a traditional one where Albanian men are brought up to see themselves as breadwinners and protectors,' Ahmeti points out.

'Once you touch the woman, you touch the honour of the family and you provoke the man to react. The Serbs knew this. Belgrade had, for years, put out propaganda that the only thing Albanian women could do was produce like mice. So daughters were gang-raped in front of their fathers, wives in front of their husbands, nieces in front of their uncles, mothers in front of their children, just to dehumanise, just to degrade.'

It is estimated by the World Health Organisation and the US-based Centre for Disease Control that as many as 20,000 Kosovar women (4.4 per cent of the population) were raped in the two years prior to Nato's forces entering the benighted territory. Numbers to match Bosnia, if not more.

But unlike Bosnia, where international organisations were located throughout the war, the province was on its own. If, as Human Rights Watch argues, politicians did not exploit the fate of the women (which would have been a way of drumming up support for the Nato bombing campaign), aid organisations also played it down.

'I think there was a deliberate policy to keep it quiet. We knew, in such a patriarchal society, where the perception of rape is so medieval, that it would probably cause a lot of social distress,' said Gamilla Backman, an adviser on violence prevention at the World Health Organisation. 'Making revelations just to shake mentalities might have had the opposite effect and made life even more difficult for victims brave enough to speak.

'The international community has got cynical about rape. Time has shown, with the women of Bosnia, how very little talking can achieve.'

By the time the province was liberated, hundreds of women who had been plucked from columns of refugees as they tried to flee the Serb onslaught were discovered wandering the hills, often disoriented, drugged, half-naked and half-crazed.

'There was always so much focus on the refugees who managed to get out and so little on the people who stayed inside - the 700,000 of them who suffered the real trauma,' said Ahmeti.

How many of these women then found themselves pregnant will remain a mystery. How many gave birth is almost impossible to determine because of taboo.

Local humanitarian groups, including the Red Cross, have estimated that 100 rape-babies were born in January alone. Innumerable others almost certainly came into the world on bathroom floors and kitchen tables, behind the high-walled homes of family clans who have vowed never to speak.

'Only God knows,' said Professor Skender Boshnjaku, Kosovo's leading neuropsychiatrist, who specialises in women's illness, 'how many have been born in secret. I know of children who are being brought up by their grandmothers, women who want to protect their daughters. These babies will know a lot of hate, they will not have a lot of love.'

The issue of babies 'born of violence' is not a subject Kosovars find easy to address. Boshnjaku concentrates on his shoes when the conversation veers in the direction of the rape-babies. Did he think I would be able to talk to some of the victims?

No, he said flatly. Albanian women did not talk about themselves. They did not talk about their feelings. They used language economically, usually to convey the essentials of their primitive lives. They were 'the property of men, to be bought, sold and betrothed before birth'. They are 'sacks to be filled,' he says, citing the Kanun, the medieval war-and-peace code of behaviour still adhered to in these parts.

'Ours was a society built on generations of hate. There are older Albanians who speak Serbian, but generally there was very little interaction between our people and the Serbs. And now,' he said, waving his hands desperately, 'there are these babies.'

Even Ahmeti, who hails from a family of open-minded, well-travelled intellectuals, finds the phenomenon of Albanian-Serb progeny un-comfortable. Some women will accept them, some will nurture them begrudgingly, some will reject them. But, she said, they will not be dumped in orphanages and they will not be left in baskets and boxes on the streets.

'They are innocent children, they are not to blame,' she said. 'People, here, will take them into their homes and married women will be able to cover up. Our hope is that they grow up without the guilt of their mothers.' The local authorities are about to start a television campaign appealing for prospective parents. 'It concerns me greatly that some are calling them "children of shame".'

But rape, I am told on my first night in Pristina, is worse than death. To be an Albanian who gives birth to a child sired by a Serb is to be sentenced to a living hell.

Pedric, who told me this, is young and worldly. 'If I were normal, I would keep the kid, accept my wife. But in Kosovo, in our culture, death is better than rape. I could not accept my wife. She would be dirty, evil, the castle of the enemy,' he booms. 'A lot of women have been very sensible. They have kept quiet about it, they have given birth at home and, if they are even more sensible, they do what that woman (Mirveta) did last month. They kill their scum-babies.'

Agron Krasniqi, a gynaecologist at Pristina's University Hospital, is also at the table. 'All of us, we were conducting abortions around the clock,' he said. 'Only a few weeks ago we had a woman who came to the hospital and said she was raped and could we help. She was six months pregnant. There are so many women like that...Women who couldn't physically make the journeys to hospitals and private clinics because they couldn't afford it or didn't dare tell their husbands. 'We try to cradle them, hug them whenever we can, because we now know how important the first six months are in a baby's life. Before we didn't do it, and you could see the difference.'

Did the mothers ever return to claim them? 'Never,' he said. 'And we don't really have any idea who they are because they usually come alone, very early, around 5am so no one will see them and then they give us false names. An American woman, a midwife, came the other day. She wanted to adopt Teuta, our oldest one, but the authorities don't want any to go abroad, they want them to stay here.'

We went to the barn and she showed us its big lime-coloured doors. 'They came, they separated the women from the men, they took all our documents and then they took away the young ones. It is said that, in tears, she handed her baby back to the nurses, holding his snapped, limp neck. In Pristina, in her psychiatric detention cell, she has been weeping ever since. 'Who knows? She may have looked into the baby's face and seen the eyes of the Serb who raped her.' The words are uttered coolly, undramatically, by Sevdije Ahmeti almost as a matter of course. 'She is repenting, of course, but the attitude that she is a cold-blooded murderer is wrong. Who knows what this poor girl has been through? Who knows why she didn't abort? 'There were marks, signs of bites and bruises over her body, her intimate parts. We want to protect her; we will try to get her a new lawyer.' fields.headline: Videos  by Philip French
fields.standfirst: The Blair Witch Project | The Winslow Boy | Dreams That Money Can Buy | The Iron Giant
fields.trailText: The Blair Witch Project | The Winslow Boy | Dreams That Money Can Buy | The Iron Giant
fields.body:
The Blair Witch Project
(1999, 15, Pathé, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail)

The most cleverly publicised picture of last year, Daniel Myrick and Eduardo Sanchez's hip, postmodern horror flick abandons suspense from the outset by purporting to be the footage shot by three film students who disappeared without trace in October 1994. They were making a documentary about the bizarre legend surrounding an ancient witch in a remote Maryland wood and what we see seems real and convincing, as well as establishing the growing tension between the trio. In relation to cost (around $60,000) it's the most profitable film of recent years, and the DVD contains the material used to promote and validate the picture.

The Winslow Boy
(1999, U, Col-TriStar, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail)

First filmed 50 years ago, Terence Rattigan's understated, well-made 1946 play about pride, social injustice and family life turns on an Edwardian father challenging the Royal Navy when his teenage son is expelled from cadet school. Respecting craftsmanship and recognising affinities, David Mamet has done Rattigan proud with this carefully made, subtly acted new version starring Nigel Hawthorne as the stubborn father and Jeremy Northam as the brilliant advocate (a character modelled on Sir Edward Carson) he engages.

Dreams That Money Can Buy
(1946, 12, BFI, VHS Retail/Rental)

The Berlin-born Hans Richter (1888-1976), pioneer of Dadaism and experimental moviemaker, spent three years on this avant-garde classic during his wartime New York exile. Part satire on Hollywood, part avant-garde grab-bag, this curate's egg of a picture uses a surreal story about a poet conjuring up clients' dreams as the framework for seven episodes devised by Max Ernst, Fernand Léger, Man Ray, Marcel Duchamp, Alexander Calder and Richter himself. Paul Bowles, Darius Milhaud and John Cage provided the music. Ray's sequence centres on an interactive movie, Duchamp recreates his Nude Descending a Staircase . Capturing the artistic mood of its time, the playful movie (largely financed by Peggy Guggenheim) cost a mere $15,000.

The Iron Giant
(1998, U, Warner, VHS/DVD Rental/Retail)

Excellent full-length animated movie, a fable about the environment, peace and the continuity of life, based on a story Ted Hughes told his children in the 1960s. The film's writer-director Brad Bird (best known for The Simpsons ) has moved the story to a 1957 America, consumed by nuclear angst and McCarthyism, where a little boy protects a mysterious mechanical giant. This funny, heartwarming, visually pleasing liberal take on the Fifties is reminiscent of classic Disney cartoons. A splendid half-term treat for the whole family that sadly proved a box-office failure.
fields.bodyText: The Blair Witch Project (1999, 15, Pathé, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail) The most cleverly publicised picture of last year, Daniel Myrick and Eduardo Sanchez's hip, postmodern horror flick abandons suspense from the outset by purporting to be the footage shot by three film students who disappeared without trace in October 1994. They were making a documentary about the bizarre legend surrounding an ancient witch in a remote Maryland wood and what we see seems real and convincing, as well as establishing the growing tension between the trio. In relation to cost (around $60,000) it's the most profitable film of recent years, and the DVD contains the material used to promote and validate the picture. The Winslow Boy (1999, U, Col-TriStar, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail) First filmed 50 years ago, Terence Rattigan's understated, well-made 1946 play about pride, social injustice and family life turns on an Edwardian father challenging the Royal Navy when his teenage son is expelled from cadet school. webTitle: You've got your gong - now clear off

fields.headline: You've got your gong - now clear off
fields.standfirst: Jane Horrocks moans that acting is a snooty profession obsessed with accents. Gawd help us
fields.trailText: Jane Horrocks moans that acting is a snooty profession obsessed with accents. Gawd help us
fields.body:
In thespian circles, there are two rituals which I have always found somewhat emetic. One is the sight of luvvies air-kissing as they exchange spurious gongs; the other is the sound of the very same luvvies blaming the Government, the world or some astrological malice for the fact that they're out of work. Last week, we were treated to plenty of both.

Michael Caine's peers fawned as they presented him with what the Mirror called 'Britain's highest showbusiness accolade, a Bafta fellowship'. Caine thanked the friends who turned up for a free lunch in his honour at the Variety Club and pointed out for the benefit of possible employers that none of them currently had jobs.

He then described his own career as an arduous triumph over British snootiness and complained that the elders in the profession still condescended to him as a cheeky cockney. Asked to name names, he glowered and said that the guilty parties 'know who they are'. Jane Horrocks, who played the singing guttersnipe in Little Voice, took up Caine's gripe, though without his diplomatic obliquity. She dreamt up a conspiracy which got her on to the cover of the Express. 'There is a lot of snobbery in the British film industry still. The middle and upper classes in the profession get hailed when those from the lower classes don't.'

Any attempt to stir up class warfare in our envious society excites the tabloids. In America, if you don't like the class you were born into, then you quit it by your own vigorous efforts. Only here do people expect others to feel guilty about their disadvantages.

Caine's stance is offensively retrogressive. He calls himself 'every bourgeoisie's nightmare - a cockney with intelligence and a million dollars'. This paraphrases the traumas of less enlightened days, when the Ameri can bourgeoisie supposedly lived in fear of blacks with portentous penises.

Where was Caine when Mrs Thatcher turned this country upside down, infesting the Essex marshes with millionaires and arranging for plumbers to earn more than professors? I suppose he was on a film set, not the best place from which to take stock of the real world.

Caine awards himself all the credit for ending the hegemony of chaps in blazers who blundered in through French windows with tennis rackets under their arms and demolished plates of cucumber sandwiches. But the character he played in Alfie was merely a more humorous and ingratiating version of John Osborne's hero in Look Back in Anger.

He has also forgotten the colleagues who snarled and railed in rough, regional voices before him: Burton, Finney, Courtenay, all of whom, incidentally, combined classical roles in the theatre with grittier parts in films and never had cause to accuse producers of bias.

Skilfully capitalising on their proletarian personae, Caine and Horrocks seem to forget that their profession is about self-transformation. Acting involves the cultivation of alternative selves, which makes it an exercise in social mobility. Low-born Archie Leach from Bristol re-created himself as dapper, classless Cary Grant; obscure young women from the slums like Norma Jean Baker or Greta Gustafsson were reincarnated as Monroe or Garbo.

The movies have always entranced us with such magical alterations of reality. In The Talented Mr Ripley, Matt Damon fantasises his way out of a New York basement and into a Venetian palazzo. An actress who prides herself, like Horrocks, on her Lancashire drone, merely advertises her lack of vocal versatility.

Bob Hoskins, supporting Caine, moaned about discrimination and claimed that in Hollywood producers regarded him as 'a classical face', while at home he, too, was demeaned by the snobs. He overlooks the fact that Jonathan Miller cast him as Iago in a BBC television Othello , with the Welsh Anthony Hopkins as the Moor. He's also sadly deluded if he fancies that Hollywood envisages him as a romantic lead: his latest role on American television is as Noriega, the bloated, Panamanian despot.

Nowhere in the world would the face or physique of Bob Hoskins qualify him as 'classical', which is perhaps why no one ever wants him for Hamlet. Beauty, alas, is as undemocratically distributed as talent.

Those who are overpaid for playing games of make-believe should accept their gongs with grace and then go quietly, rather than demanding more.

fields.headline: A waste of space
fields.standfirst: Boldly going into science fiction for the first time, Brian De Palma's 2020 vision doesn't really get off the ground
fields.trailText: Philip French: A total absence of invention and imagination. There is the possibility that a final sequence has been cut in which it's revealed that the movie is a Tarkovskian hallucination experienced by an early astronaut who's spent his retirement watching SF movies.
fields.body:
It was a mistake to play Strauss's Blue Danube waltz at the Odeon, Leicester Square the other morning before the lights went down for Mission to Mars. To be reminded of Kubrick's classic SF movie before seeing Brian De Palma's first essay in the genre was as dangerous as it would be to have someone sing a Verdi aria before the curtain goes up on the Elton John-Tim Rice version of Aïda .

De Palma's movie comes at an odd time, a year before the setting of 2001: A Space Odyssey and two years before the centenary of Georges Méliès's 1902 milestone, A Trip to the Moon. For a century, the cinema has reflected the mood on Earth through our attitudes of fear, wonder and anticipation attendant upon the exploration of space. Fritz Lang's 1929 Woman in the Moon invented the countdown while Werner von Braun was still a schoolboy; Alexander Korda's 1935 masterpiece Things to Come saw a journey to the stars as the salvation of a troubled world; postwar SF flicks such as The Day the Earth Stood Still reflected Cold War tensions.

When space fiction started to become space fact in the late Fifties, the ground had been laid for Kubrick's landmark combination of mechanics and mysticism from which all subsequent space films stem.

In 1983, The Right Stuff treated the US space enterprise in a historical fashion, looking back to the origins of supersonic flight and the beginning of the Mercury programme in the early Sixties. This has recently been followed up by Apollo 13 which recalled how, as early as 1970, it took a near-fatal accident to capture the attention of jaded viewers.

While his friends and fellow movie brats Steven Spielberg and George Lucas were making Close Encounters and Star Wars, De Palma was directing thrillers that paid homage to Hitchcock, and over the years he's brought his kinetic flair and his taste to a variety of genres, rarely attempting to break new ground.

Now in his sixtieth year, with a grandiose screen version of the old TV series Mission: Impossible behind him, De Palma has got around to SF with a second mission movie boldly going where others have gone before.

The year is 2020 and a joint Russian-American expedition to Mars is being led by black astronaut, Luke Graham (Don Cheadle), presumably named by his parents in honour of the sky walking movie hero. Things go awry when they meet a strange Martian force that sucks the Russians into a lethal vortex, sparing only Luke. He'd been reading Treasure Island with his son before blasting off and had wondered how 'that old Ben Gunn' got marooned.

Now he knows and a quartet of colleagues set out from a space station to his rescue. They're the husband-and-wife team, Woody (Tim Robbins) and Terri (Connie Nielsen); the recently widowed systems designer, Jim (Gary Sinise); and the young engineer, Phil (Jerry 0'Connell). Time on board goes slowly and Woody and Terri dance upside down to pass the hours while Jim looks at home movies of his late wife, a fellow astronaut with whom he'd planned to explore Mars. To paraphrase the advertising slogan for Alien, in space nobody can hear you cry.

Not everyone makes it there and back, and in trying to land, the rescuers undergo a crisis that makes the Apollo 13 affair look like trouble with the dashboard lighter. They finish up stranded on the red planet equipped with some simple escape aids and some clunky B-movie dialogue. 'I don't see how a quake six months ago could have caused such distortion,' someone remarks. 'That was no quake,' someone replies just a split second after the whole audience has delivered the line in unison.

Interpreting a series of test messages à la 2001 leads to a close encounter with a higher intelligence. Entering into an all-white palace, the starry-eyed astronauts are entertained by a three-dimensional planetarium display that provides them with a history of the universe. They meet a tall, thin, androgynous extraterrestrial dressed in gold lamé, which may be the standard Martian uniform, though perhaps this exotic creature is on the way to the Oscars.

One way or the other, this scene epitomises the total absence of invention and imagination. There is the possibility that a final sequence has been cut in which it's revealed that the movie is a Tarkovskian hallucination experienced by an early astronaut who's spent his retirement watching SF movies.

This idea is not entirely my own, as it forms the background to Galaxy Quest, an hilarious SF comedy which opens in a fortnight's time and is a treat in store.
