fields.headline: Burning desire
fields.standfirst: There's nothing like a dish of red and green chillies to bring tears of joy to your eyes
fields.trailText: There's nothing like a dish of red and green chillies to bring tears of joy to your eyes
fields.body:
'Now I want you all to pop one of these into your mouth and suck, then tell me what you think,' said Chef Yates, who presided over his brood of wannabe young chefs like a twinkly eyed Santa Claus. Lambs to the slaughter, we obeyed, rolling the little seeds over and over in our mouths in that exaggerated way so typical of people who aspire to the pompous sobriquet of gourmet. The sudden explosion of tears and expletives were heard in the next kitchen and Chef Yates and his spluttering, yowling class was carpeted by our battle-axe head of cookery. From that moment on, I hated chillies. I had discovered food that hurts, food that can make you cry. I let no chilli past my lips for the next 10 years.

So how come, 20 years on, I crave food that hurts? Why do I hunt out farmhouse Cheddar sharp enough to make the veins stand out on the roof of my mouth, or a tarte au citron so acidic as to make me close one eye and shudder? How come I delight in that little dab of English mustard that gets my sinuses to smart, the horseradish that makes my eyes water and the chillies that sting as much on the way out as they did on the way in.

Was it the mollycoddling mother, the over-bearing father, the school bullying or the academic failure that has made me now crave foods that pain me? Could it have been my rejection by the blood-and-guts life of the restaurant kitchen, the string of disastrous affairs or the humiliation that is unrequited love that has sent me in search of food that makes my colour rage and my tongue swell? Perhaps I have become some sort of culinary masochist. Perhaps I should go and work for Gordon Ramsay.

There is, as I write, chocolate in my desk drawer (well, a tube of Smarties); a bag of new organic Kettle Chips as big as a pillow in the kitchen cupboard, not to mention the tub of peanut butter on my bedside table, yet they can all stay there - what I want is something with chillies in. Better make that 'what I need'. I 'need' to feel that sting on my lips, that rush of heat at the back of my throat, the gut-tightening sensation of swallowing something full of little red birdseyes, tiny green pepinos or long, fat Anaheim chillies.

The kid who cried in cooking class now holidays where he can be sure of getting curry hot enough to make his lips numb, rather than where there is a guarantee of sunny skies and sex on tap. As blissful as a Cornish cream tea, or as bracing as a beachside lunch in the south of France can be, I now head off where the food is hot, tart and heavy with spice. Thailand with its stinging green curries; Kerala and its mouth-popping grilled seafood; even Sri Lanka's endless white beaches got a visit last year.

Neither am I too fussy whether I am staying in the cushioned minimalism of an Aman resort or getting my adrenaline rush in the fly-blown sleaze of the wrong side of Bangkok, it is that whip-and-kiss mixture of chilli-meets-citrus-meets-coconut that rings my bell.

The general rule is that the smaller the chilli, the hotter it is. Well yes, and no. An innocuous looking chilli that once produced nothing short of cardiac arrest in a peculiarly macho photographer friend of mine was distinctly medium in size. Typically it was a rogue chilli hiding in a plate of mild, gently pickled fruits in a restaurant in Delhi. He may have deserved it. But I cannot handle them all, and I have met many who would still think of me as a chilli-wimp. The one I cannot cope with is the lantern-shaped habanero that turns up in many West Indian recipes. Someone must buy them - they sell them in most of the major supermarkets - but one breath of its fiery juice and I double up and scream for mummy. Yet give me a Thai fish cake no bigger than a two-pound coin and a dish of that sweet hot goo that comes with it and I am as happy as can be.

The chilli that really intrigues me is the small red birdseye that comes in net purses in oriental food shops or those quasi Thai spice packs in the supermarket. It is most at home in lemon grass and coconut curries, yet you see it in Indian markets, too. The supermarkets, incidentally, label them Bird Eye rather than birdseye presumably so thickoes like me won't confuse them with fish fingers. They are more like bird's feet, really, no bigger than your little finger, and by turn either devastatingly hot or faintly disappointing.

On its home territory, this tiddler turns up in everything from fish curry to salads of raw green mango and cellophane noodles. It is one of the hottest varieties, though not as punchy as the miniature prik khee noo suan, which I think translates as mouse's pooh. Navigate your way through the floating market in Bangkok, or for that matter any market from Bombay to Colombo, and you'll find more varieties than you can shake a stick at, most of them hot and some them excruciatingly so. Some even the local cooks cannot put a name to. Not that it matters to me, just so long as I get to feel a little pain.

Prawn cakes with chilli, coriander and lemon grass

Fragile little prawn cakes, all hot and lemony. Prawns are less obliging than white fish or crab and need something to bind them in a fishcake; use egg, if you wish, but I have used mayonnaise before now. Totally inauthentic, of course - though American cooks put a dollop in their crab cakes - but it binds and adds a certain creaminess to the finished cake. These cakes are rich, hot, citrus and spicy. They need a little salad or rice to go with them. Last time I made them, I had sticky rice and some spinach salad with them, and a mango afterwards. I suggest that you cook one first to check it for seasoning. They are at their best when somewhat wobbly and crumbly, so avoid the temptation to over-mould them. A gentle pat with floury hands will suffice. Makes about 12, serving three each.

400g prawns, defrosted

2 small or one large stalk of lemon grass

2 small cloves of garlic

2 thin spring onions

2 small, hot chillies

a small handful (about 10g) of coriander leaves

1 tsp of nam pla (fish sauce)

1 egg plus 1 egg yolk or 4 tbsps mayonnaise

flour

Squeeze the prawns in your hands, to remove any water - otherwise they are inclined to spit during cooking. Chop them very finely, or better still blitz them for a few seconds in the food processor, then tip them into a mixing bowl.

Peel back the outer leaves of the lemon grass so that only the tender hearts are left, then chop the soft inner leaves very finely. Peel the garlic and chop it, cut and discard the green bits from the spring onion and finely slice the white, then slice the chillies thinly removing the seeds if you wish. I leave the little seeds in, because this is one recipe where I like a serious amount of heat - but it is up to you. Add all this with the coriander leaves and, if you have them, a couple of the coriander roots thoroughly scrubbed, to the food processor with the nam pla and whiz to a rough pulp.

Tip the pulp into the prawns and mix well, adding a little salt as you go. It is worth remembering that nam pla and prawns are themselves salty. Beat the egg and the egg yolk lightly and stir into the prawns, with a dusting of flour. The mixture should be moist enough to shape into patties the size of a flattened golf ball yet firm enough to hold together. Add more egg or flour, if they appear to be falling apart.

Over a moderate heat, warm enough oil in a frying pan to cover the bottom. When it is hot, add six or so of the slightly flattened cakes to the hot oil and leave for a few minutes until golden on the underside. Turn them with a spatula - they will be fragile - and cook the other side. They will be done in three or four minutes. Lift them carefully out on to kitchen paper, keeping them warm whilst you fry the next batch.

Roast squash with chilli butter

Once, pumpkins and squashes were confined to the autumn. Now they are available all year and, unlike asparagus and peas, it doesn't matter that they come from overseas - they hardly have what you might call a short shelf-life. Serves 2 as an accompaniment.

500g pumpkin or squash

50g butter

1 tbsp of ground nut or vegetable oil

2 tbsps of dry sherry or vermouth

a medium sized red chilli, seeded and chopped

Cut the pumpkin into wedges and cut out the seeds and fibres from the core. There is no need to peel it, everyone can scrape the soft flesh off the skin at the table. Mash the butter with the oil, dry sherry, a little salt, ground black pepper and the seeded and chopped chilli.

Spread the chilli butter over the pumpkin and place in a roasting tin. Cover the tin with kitchen foil and put in a preheated oven at 180 C/gas mark 4. Leave to roast for 45 minutes, then remove the tin foil, spoon any juices over the pumpkin and return to the oven for a further 15 minutes or so, until the pumpkin is truly tender. You should be able to effortlessly crush it with a fork.

Neither am I too fussy whether I am staying in the cushioned minimalism of an Aman resort or getting my adrenaline rush in the fly-blown sleaze of the wrong side of Bangkok, it is that whip-and-kiss mixture of chilli-meets-citrus-meets-coconut that rings my bell. The general rule is that the smaller the chilli, the hotter it is. Well yes, and no. An innocuous looking chilli that once produced nothing short of cardiac arrest in a peculiarly macho photographer friend of mine was distinctly medium in size. Typically it was a rogue chilli hiding in a plate of mild, gently pickled fruits in a restaurant in Delhi. He may have deserved it. But I cannot handle them all, and I have met many who would still think of me as a chilli-wimp. The one I cannot cope with is the lantern-shaped habanero that turns up in many West Indian recipes. Someone must buy them - they sell them in most of the major supermarkets - but one breath of its fiery juice and I double up and scream for mummy. Yet give me a Thai fish cake no bigger than a two-pound coin and a dish of that sweet hot goo that comes with it and I am as happy as can be. The chilli that really intrigues me is the small red birdseye that comes in net purses in oriental food shops or those quasi Thai spice packs in the supermarket. It is most at home in lemon grass and coconut curries, yet you see it in Indian markets, too. The supermarkets, incidentally, label them Bird Eye rather than birdseye presumably so thickoes like me won't confuse them with fish fingers. They are more like bird's feet, really, no bigger than your little finger, and by turn either devastatingly hot or faintly disappointing. On its home territory, this tiddler turns up in everything from fish curry to salads of raw green mango and cellophane noodles. It is one of the hottest varieties, though not as punchy as the miniature prik khee noo suan, which I think translates as mouse's pooh. Navigate your way through the floating market in Bangkok, or for that matter any market from Bombay to Colombo, and you'll find more varieties than you can shake a stick at, most of them hot and some them excruciatingly so. Some even the local cooks cannot put a name to. Not that it matters to me, just so long as I get to feel a little pain. Prawn cakes with chilli, coriander and lemon grass Fragile little prawn cakes, all hot and lemony. Prawns are less obliging than white fish or crab and need something to bind them in a fishcake; use egg, if you wish, but I have used mayonnaise before now. Totally inauthentic, of course - though American cooks put a dollop in their crab cakes - but it binds and adds a certain creaminess to the finished cake. These cakes are rich, hot, citrus and spicy. They need a little salad or rice to go with them. Last time I made them, I had sticky rice and some spinach salad with them, and a mango afterwards. I suggest that you cook one first to check it for seasoning. They are at their best when somewhat wobbly and crumbly, so avoid the temptation to over-mould them. A gentle pat with floury hands will suffice. Makes about 12, serving three each. 400g prawns, defrosted 2 small or one large stalk of lemon grass 2 small cloves of garlic 2 thin spring onions 2 small, hot chillies a small handful (about 10g) of coriander leaves 1 tsp of nam pla (fish sauce) 1 egg plus 1 egg yolk or 4 tbsps mayonnaise flour Squeeze the prawns in your hands, to remove any water - otherwise they are inclined to spit during cooking. Chop them very finely, or better still blitz them for a few seconds in the food processor, then tip them into a mixing bowl. Peel back the outer leaves of the lemon grass so that only the tender hearts are left, then chop the soft inner leaves very finely. Peel the garlic and chop it, cut and discard the green bits from the spring onion and finely slice the white, then slice the chillies thinly removing the seeds if you wish. I leave the little seeds in, because this is one recipe where I like a serious amount of heat - but it is up to you. Add all this with the coriander leaves and, if you have them, a couple of the coriander roots thoroughly scrubbed, to the food processor with the nam pla and whiz to a rough pulp. Tip the pulp into the prawns and mix well, adding a little salt as you go. It is worth remembering that nam pla and prawns are themselves salty. Beat the egg and the egg yolk lightly and stir into the prawns, with a dusting of flour. The mixture should be moist enough to shape into patties the size of a flattened golf ball yet firm enough to hold together. Add more egg or flour, if they appear to be falling apart. Over a moderate heat, warm enough oil in a frying pan to cover the bottom. When it is hot, add six or so of the slightly flattened cakes to the hot oil and leave for a few minutes until golden on the underside. Turn them with a spatula - they will be fragile - and cook the other side. They will be done in three or four minutes. Lift them carefully out on to kitchen paper, keeping them warm whilst you fry the next batch. Roast squash with chilli butter Once, pumpkins and squashes were confined to the autumn. Now they are available all year and, unlike asparagus and peas, it doesn't matter that they come from overseas - they hardly have what you might call a short shelf-life. Serves 2 as an accompaniment. 500g pumpkin or squash 50g butter 1 tbsp of ground nut or vegetable oil 2 tbsps of dry sherry or vermouth a medium sized red chilli, seeded and chopped Cut the pumpkin into wedges and cut out the seeds and fibres from the core. There is no need to peel it, everyone can scrape the soft flesh off the skin at the table. Mash the butter with the oil, dry sherry, a little salt, ground black pepper and the seeded and chopped chilli. Spread the chilli butter over the pumpkin and place in a roasting tin. Cover the tin with kitchen foil and put in a preheated oven at 180 C/gas mark 4. Leave to roast for 45 minutes, then remove the tin foil, spoon any juices over the pumpkin and return to the oven for a further 15 minutes or so, until the pumpkin is truly tender. You should be able to effortlessly crush it with a fork.

fields.headline: Potted history
fields.standfirst: Begonias, bromeliads, busy Lizzies... Monty Don wouldn't give any of them house room. When it comes to the great indoors, only cut flowers will do
fields.trailText: Begonias, bromeliads, busy Lizzies... Monty Don wouldn't give any of them house room. When it comes to the great indoors, only cut flowers will do.
fields.body:
I have a deep, irrational and well-nourished dislike of house plants. Well, not entirely irrational, because most of them are ugly. Why do people suspend all aesthetic judgement just because they are dealing with a plant? It sometimes happens when gardeners become more interested in collecting and growing plants than in making and caring for a garden. It always happens when people become obsessed with a particular genus - and whenever people start to keep house plants. Coleus are the worst. Crotons come a close second. The combination of lime greens, yellows, and burgundy-browns is repulsive. And before you write in, I know they are now known as Solenostemon scutellarioides - as if that makes any difference. You can change your name, but you can't hide.

Flicking in one easy swoop of prejudice from the Far East to South America, we alight on begonias. If begonias were a song, they would be the kind of maudlin croon performed by a 'family entertainer' in a toupee that leaves you turning inside out with embarrassment. The leaves have a bat's-wing quality, with colourings reminiscent of the pavement outside a pub at closing time on a Saturday night. A little over the top? I've only just begun.

I have never understood the attraction of 'jungle' plants crammed into a living room. Don't people know how horrible the jungle is? Interesting, for sure, but horribly so. My wife lived in New Guinea for years and she says that the jungle is ugly. I saw a programme on telly the other day about the relationship between the great film director Werner Herzog and the utterly compelling actor Klaus Kinski, both locked into mutual loathing halfway up the Amazon. While Kinski claimed affinity with all nature, Herzog took the camera to one side to tell it the truth about the jungle: 'I hate it,' he intoned, his face a mask of depression and obsession. 'I hate the way it destroys everything. Everything is killing everything else. The birds don't sing - they scream.' Most house plants scream, too - or else look you dully in the eye and drone in a monotone about how much they hate your living room.

If every plant has its moment, then all the ficuses, ferns, spider plants and gawky palms collecting dust are a poised at exactly 5.35pm on a wet Sunday afternoon. Poinsettias and anthuriums are an ugly con-trick, busy Lizzies vapid, bromeliads are like the product of an expensive cracker and, to my genuine regret and bewilderment, I have always found the waxy, cold-blooded beauty of orchids to be profoundly unsexy. Should an orchid be sexy? Of course. It scarcely exists otherwise.

The main problem for house plants lies in the house. Indoors is dark - even a window in full sun cuts out 25 per cent of the light, and levels fall with every foot that you move away from the window. Indoors is dry and subject to huge temperature variations, especially in winter, when central heating kicks on and off. Thus the only plants that survive tend to be those that lurk in dry shade, clinging on to their evolutionary niche. You trawl the globe looking for plants that will toler- ate your home - lovely as I am sure it is for humans - and the result is nothing like a garden. Gardens are centred in locality, gloriously parochial and dictated by minute details of soil, weather and exposure. Take all that away and you end up with airport-lounge gardening.

I could have lied, of course. A gardening column should perhaps wheel out advice like a doctor administering to kneecap and liver alike, but it is not my way. I am not proud of it. Indulging in prejudices never added a jot to the sum of human happiness or wisdom. I am also aware that I am lucky enough to have a garden in which to indulge all my horticultural needs, and that there are plenty of people without one who grow what they can indoors. I was talking about this with a friend whose house is stuffed with house plants on every windowsill. She said that although she now has a garden, after years of living in a flat, she could not live without the softening effect of house plants indoors. OK, it's a view. But I am not sure that I want indoors to be softened in such an obvious way. I would rather have a bare room where the softness came from the way the sunlight splashed across the walls. But the temporary nature of a vase of flowers is something else altogether. This, I think, is the problem: house plants go on too long. They are like Christmas decorations in May or birthday garlands six months after the day, when you are older and no wiser.

How can I share the pleasure that house plants so obviously give to so many people? For a start, I like bringing pot-grown plants indoors at their prime. I write this looking in the eye an agapanthus that has been flowering indoors for the past month. It was outside all summer and then rested in the greenhouse over winter. We do this with a couple of citrus trees, cowslips, snowdrops, primroses, violets, hyacinths and narcissi, all grown in terracotta pots; and also with lilies and geraniums with scented leaves. None lasts nearly as long as identical plants that remain outside all the time - but they give a lot of pleasure. When they are past their best, they are all stashed away out of sight until next year. So they are hardly house plants.

I love cut flowers - in tiny, delicate vases or as great explosions of leaf and flower, all brought indoors as theatre and decoration. But when they start to fade, they all go on to the compost heap.

I like the halfway house of a conservatory and would happily grow daturas and brugmansias in one. We have Brugmansia sanguinea and B versicolor growing in the greenhouse, which gets in the way of everything else but flowers from August through to November and is wasted in there. If the pots were not so heavy, I would bring them indoors when they flowered, so a conservatory would be ideal. The citrus would like it, too. And salvias would be good in the conservatory or in a very bright room, mainly to continue the work they do perfectly well outside until the frosts come. Cuttings taken from healthy plants in spring, before they went outside, would be ideal, and the over-wintered 'house' plants could be pruned back and planted out each May. This is the point - house and garden combining rather than house plants seen as a separate zone.

Is this any good? Am I getting there? The honest truth is that I think if I really had no garden - no possibility of an allotment, no little yard, however dingy - I would forgo house plants and buy cut flowers daily. When we lived in London, I would often go and cut a bunch of flowers from the garden to take as a present when going to friends for dinner. I suspect no one realised the agonies that had gone into deciding which to cut. Should I leave that wonderful tendril of clematis for ourselves to relish over the coming week, or knock their socks off with it? I usually went for the socks-off alternative, looking for cheap admiration. But perhaps it always looked like a soggy, cheapskate bunch of flowers. A pot plant would probably have gone down better.

fields.trailText:
Alhambra by Michael Jacobs
Photographs by Francisco Fernandez
(Frances Lincoln, £30)
fields.body:
Alhambra by Michael Jacobs
Photographs by Francisco Fernandez
(Frances Lincoln, £30)

The Alhambra was possibly the greatest architectural flowering of Islamic civilisation and is a reminder of how different Europe might have looked had the Moors been able to push beyond their westerly outpost in southern Spain. Instead, the last Muslims were forced back into North Africa in the fifteenth century, leaving behind little but their brief cultural legacy.

This book is a wonderful alliance of fine writing that explains the historical context of Islamic Granada and the Moorish style and beautiful photographs that capture both the expanse of the palace complex and the fine stylistic details. The author and photographer were given access to rooms rarely opened.
Jonathan Cook

Landscapes of Tuscany, by Elizabeth Mizon
(Sunflower Books, £9.99)

The walks, picnic sites and car tours featured in this book give a real flavour of Tuscany's beauty. Mizon concentrates on trips off the beaten track, with excellent maps, photos and information on places of interest. Practical advice on how to travel to walks and picnics by car or public transport makes holiday planning easier as does clarity over the length of walks, some of which are more than 10 miles.

Will Green

fields.headline: Poor student storms book world
fields.trailText: First came  Wild Swans , then  Falling Leaves . Now an equally authentic story of rural China, written by a British student, is expected to surpass both those bestsellers.
fields.body:
First came Wild Swans , then Falling Leaves . Now an equally authentic story of rural China, written by a British student, is expected to surpass both those bestsellers.

Justin Hill's first novel is only half written, but The Drink and Dream Teahouse has already earned him an unprecedented £150,000 book deal with publisher Weidenfeld and Nicolson.

The sum was agreed last month following a fierce battle between five publishing houses and is thought to be the largest one-book offer made to a first-time novelist on sight of just a partial manuscript. The book business is still prepared to bank on the British reader's obsession with all things Oriental.

With Arthur Golden's semi-factual study of Japan, Memoirs of a Geisha , still selling well, hunger for detailed chronicles of lives lived out in far-flung places grows unabated. That trend is expected to catapult Hill from his student digs in Preston, Lancashire, to a place among London's literati. And it could not have come at a better time for the penurious 28-year-old.

'I went to my bank the day before I approached the publishers and they told me I only had £9 left in my account. I was very worried how I was going to make it last through the weekend,' Hill told The Observer .

So he decided to persuade someone to look seriously at the first 150 pages of the novel he was working on. Five publishers were soon interested and an auction between the top three bidders finally closed in a draw. Two made matching £150,000 bids and Hill chose at his leisure.

'As soon as I knew the deal was concluded, I went out to the supermarket and bought myself an £8 organic chicken. To spend that much money on a chicken was a great feeling, even if it did leave only £1 in my bank account.'

He is now considering buying a house in London when his course at Lancaster University has finished.

Hill, who grew up in York, is a former English language teacher who worked with Voluntary Service Overseas and is now studying creative writing. He has lived and worked in China twice, most recently last year, and taught English as a foreign language in Eritrea, from where he had to be airlifted when the war with Ethiopia broke out.

He has already written a commercially unsuccessful travel book about China, A Bend in the Yellow River , which, five years ago, was also published by Weidenfeld and Nicolson, unknown to Weidenfeld's fiction editor, Neil Taylor.

'I was not working here then, so I did not pick up on the coincidence,' said Taylor. 'Funnily enough, I think we also rejected his second factual book too, a decision Justin says he now understands.'

Taylor was deeply im-pressed with the opening chapters of Hill's new book, which tell the fictional story of the effect on two families of the closure of an old-fash ioned, revolutionary-style factory in inland China. Hill's completed 300-page saga is due out this time next year.

'The story is immediately involving in the way the best novels are,' said Taylor. 'The characters move and speak, they are real for the reader and they invite a tender complicity in their loves, losses and dreams.'

Taylor said the early pages reminded him of the work of the new wave of Chinese film directors.

French publisher Gallimard has also brought the book. 'Never before in our history have we acquired a novel in translation on the strength of a partial manuscript,' said a spokesperson.

Even the process of writing the book has been surprising for Hill. 'The themes may be the same, but it is not the story I set out to write. There is romance; in fact, there is almost everything. Lots of food too.'

The current feast of Oriental literature began in 1993 with Jung Chang's Wild Swans and was followed up by publication of her friend Adeline Yen Mah's similarly bestselling Falling Leaves in 1998. It has lasted longer than the publishing interest in India that sprang up in the wake of Arundhati Roy's The God of Small Things .

'There was a huge boom in Indian fiction,' said Taylor, 'but it was never really picked up in the United States. It seemed to be a European thing. There is a feeling in publishing that the Indian novel has had its day. There were just too many of them.

'But there is still an interest in story-telling that is exotic and yet fairly familiar. Memoirs of a Geisha , for instance, was an extraordinary story, with no Westerners in it, yet somehow readers here are able to relate to it.'

'There was a huge boom in Indian fiction,' said Taylor, 'but it was never really picked up in the United States. It seemed to be a European thing. There is a feeling in publishing that the Indian novel has had its day. There were just too many of them. 'But there is still an interest in story-telling that is exotic and yet fairly familiar. Memoirs of a Geisha , for instance, was an extraordinary story, with no Westerners in it, yet somehow readers here are able to relate to it.' vanessa.thorpe@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: After the Panzers, the plunderers
fields.standfirst: Conquerors have always carried away the spoils of war - but the Nazis and their agents took art theft to its nadir as Jonathan Petropoulos tells in The Faustian Bargain
fields.trailText: Conquerors have always carried away the spoils of war - but the Nazis and their agents took art theft to its nadir as Jonathan Petropoulos tells in The Faustian Bargain
fields.body:
The Faustian Bargain: The Art World in Nazi Germany
Jonathan Petropoulos
Penguin £20, pp395
Buy it at BOL

Walter Benjamin argued that communism aims to make the arts political whereas fascism, and that is more damaging, seeks to aestheticise politics. Like many of Benjamin's ideas, this proposal is highly intriguing but difficult to substantiate. Almost all types of totalitarian rule aspire to control the arts, to use them for propaganda, to ornament the rituals which enact the scenarios of ideology.

This investment in the aesthetic is as characteristic of Augustan or Neronian Rome as it is of the France of Versailles and of Napoleon's imperium. The very notion of the totalitarian implies the marshalling, the control of emotional responses which architecture, music, the plastic arts and literature are empowered to manipulate.

These generalities took on heightened intensity in the case of national socialism. Hitler had hoped to be an artist, was steeped in Wagnerian and romantic music and regarded the German cultural legacy, barring its few Jewish intruders, as second to none. His victories were to climax in the construction of the world's finest museum to be located in Linz. The epic stagings of Nazi mass rallies succeeded in endowing brutal kitsch with undeniable magnificence. To this day, documentary records of those torches in the night, of the Führer striding towards his podium through tens of thousands of absolutely motionless acolytes, retain their shaming spell. No other ideology has found a comparable aesthetic, a comparable rhetoric and choreography of iconic gestures.

Thus the regime had its art policies from the outset. The mortal struggle against Weimar democracy and racial impurity entailed the identification and elimination of 'degenerate' forms of painting and sculpture even as it entailed the burning of corrupted and corrupting books.

It was precisely the prodigal, experimental energies of Weimar aesthetics, the cosmopolitan liberalities of the avant-garde, often Marxist and even Bolshevik in its sympathies, which necessitated merciless cleansing. The more so as a major portion of the art market, of art criticism and art-historical scholarship happened to be in Jewish hands.

By the late 1930s, the aryanisation of the arts had robbed or done to death most of its verminous victims. Exhibits of condemned works contrasted with those of the monumentality, marmoreal purity and muscular heroism integral to the promise of a new order. With Hitler's conquest of much of Europe, this process assumed a vast scale. Behind the Panzers came the art thieves. Professor Petropoulos cites official German estimates which put at some 21,000 the number of works of art looted in the occupied territories, notably France, the Netherlands and Poland. The agents of mass larceny were museum custodians, historians of art in the academy, servile dealers and middlemen of more or less vulgar provenance. Their motives ranged from Nazi convictions to careerism and naked greed.

This book recounts the biographies of some of the most prominent among the vultures. It tells of the stellar curriculum of Hans Posse, director both of the State Painting Gallery in Dresden and the Führermuseum. Ernst Buchner came near to presiding over the bureaucracy of plunder. Hitler awarded him a special Iron Cross. Dealers, often with accomplices in the Reich at large provided Hitler, Goering and lesser fry with choice desiderata. The arch villain in Petropoulos's rogue's gallery is Kajetan Muhlmann. Resplendent in Gestapo uniform, this adroit, charming hooligan played a crucial part in the despoilation of the Netherlands and Poland.

The book spurts to angry life when Petropoulos records the postwar immunities and pardons enjoyed by these corrupt pirates. A very few committed suicide. The major players suffered the minor inconveniences of often benign de-Nazification procedures at the hand of largely indifferent, even sympathetic US occupiers. Others kept out of sight and re-emerged into respectability and cushioned retirement.

The trouble with this concerned, justly incensed survey is one of missing or avoided context. Conquerors have looted and brought home the treasures of their defeated foes since the beginnings of recorded history. Ancient Rome was crammed with statues and artefacts transported in triumph from Iberia to Jordan, from Batavia to Egypt. What would the (Napoleonic) Louvre or the British Museum be without their acquisitions by force? The extent of Soviet pillage at the close of the war and thereafter remains difficult to assess.

The frequently close association of Nazi art policies and robbery with the Holocaust is a specific, loathsome feature. But this would have been a more significant book had Petropoulos discussed the phenomenon of the dissemination of art via conquest, the more so as this issue - witness the Elgin Marbles - is very much under debate.

fields.headline: The girl most likely to
fields.standfirst: Amy Jenkins created a TV hit with This Life, scooped a £600,000 advance for her first novel and wants to direct her own film screenplay. Men can still be a problem though...
fields.trailText: Amy Jenkins created a TV hit with This Life, scooped a £600,000 advance for her first novel and wants to direct her own film screenplay. Men can still be a problem though...
fields.body:
'Amy Jenkins is the media darling thirtysomething who "has it all",' gushes the author biography on the proof copy of her first novel, Honey Moon , reminding us that she is also the 'daughter of political columnist Peter Jenkins and stepdaughter of Guardian commentator Polly Toynbee'. You can't help feeling they might as well have added 'and if that hasn't immediately turned you against her, just remember she was paid £600,000 for this book on the basis of one chapter and that doesn't include the film rights'.

'I was furious about that,' Amy Jenkins says. She's sipping Aqua Libra in London's Groucho Club (where else would you expect to find a media darling?) but this is the only nod to the image projected on the book jacket. In all other respects, she seems understated - quiet, measured, younger than her 33 years and not spoilt by the hype and her sudden fame.

'What they put on the back of the proof was appalling,' she continues. 'It's not even as if my parents were that famous; if my dad had been Laurence Olivier, that would be different. I don't suppose many people have even heard of my dad.'

They will almost certainly have heard of This Life , though, the other name that is always invoked when emphasising Jenkins's credentials. The cult television series about a group of young London lawyers sharing houses, beds, fags and court cases was her first writing break after dropping out of a law course at University College, London and drifting for a few years, 'drugging and clubbing and running my market stall down Portobello'. Its success was undoubtedly the rationale behind the inflated advance paid for Honey Moon . 'That and the first chapter,' she says, slightly defensively.

Since This Life, the rise of Amy Jenkins has appeared irresistible. As well as her book deal, she has been involved in a number of film projects, one of which, Elephant Juice , has been shot by Miramax starring Emmanuelle Béart and This Life 's Daniela Nardini (it has yet to find a distributor). She is also the subject of a BBC documentary, Amy Jenkins: This Life, That Girl , to be screened in July. The 50-minute programme is a profile of her life and work, with contributions from Polly Toynbee, among others.

This tectonic shift in her fortunes is, in part, thanks to 'a serious amount' of therapy. By the end of her 'wasted years', she has said: 'My life was falling apart. I was unemployed. I had huge debts. I felt so bad most of the time that I was driven to seek help. I've needed an awful lot of therapy to become who I am today.'

It is also due to Danny Boyle, the director of Trainspotting , who Jenkins met at the time she went into therapy and who encouraged her to write. Boyle helped her put together a script that led to her finding an agent and eventually having her proposal for This Life read by executive producer Tony Garnett at the BBC, who was looking for someone to write a twentysomething drama of a kind that hadn't been made before.

It's easy to assume that her family connections must have made life easy in terms of getting her work noticed. 'It was a help to me in that I met a lot of interesting, well-connected people,' she says, 'but I never, ever managed to get nepotism to work for me - and I tried, I really tried. I'd endlessly be sent off to meet someone who knew someone who might be able to get me a job in the film industry, but no one ever did.'

Jenkins is happy to admit that Honey Moon is not as original in concept as This Life . It's a Single Women's Novel, part of the now well-established genre arguably invented by Helen Fielding with The Diary of Bridget Jones. ' I was deliberately aiming for that market,' Jenkins says, 'but when I conceived the novel, in 1998, a lot of those books weren't out, so I didn't realise I was just one of a hundred. I thought it was quite a new thing, actually.'

Bridget Jones , which Jenkins thinks is 'brilliant', is clearly an influence on Honey Moon , as are Ally McBeal ('fantastic television drama') and Sex and the City , which she sees as embodying the dilemma faced by professional women in our time. 'The women in Sex and the City spend all their time complaining about how they can't find a man, but when you look at it, they get men all the time; they just don't want any of them,' she says.

The problem is that they don't want to compromise the dream, and they don't have to. The dream has always been there, the Mr Darcy figure or whoever, but in the past, women have had to be practical because they needed to find a man, so they learnt to settle for less than the dream. Now that women can support themselves quite happily without a man, why would they need to compromise?'

This perennial dilemma - fantasy versus reality, passion versus companionship - is the crux of her novel. Her narrator, Honeymoon Holt, is on the verge of marrying nice, decent but unexciting Ed when she begins to have doubts, mostly centred on Alex (referred to variously as 'the Love of Her Life' or 'the One'), a man with whom she had instant, terrifying chemistry but whom she hasn't seen for seven years. When Alex reappears in her honeymoon hotel, also newly married, the choice between romantic fantasy and something more prosaic, but potentially more durable, is forced dramatically upon her.

Strikingly, both Honey and Ed are orphans, like Jenkins herself. 'I don't consider myself an orphan,' she says, almost quizzically, when I mention this. 'My mother died when I was six, but I was 26 when my father died, so it's not the same.'

But did losing both parents while she was relatively young give her an edge of independence? 'I do think that when you've laid your parents to rest in your psyche, that's when you really grow up,' she says. 'And your parents don't necessarily need to be dead for that to happen. It's an underlying truth that growing up is about resolving parental issues.'

Is this something she feels she has achieved? 'I don't know that I've achieved it, but I believe I am coming to terms with it. In the novel, it's a dramatic device. It's the case with a lot of literary heroes or heroines, even Harry Potter, that they're dispossessed by their parents; it's an easy way of signifying that they're going down their path alone, which we all are. It had a resonance with me that Honey and Ed should have lost their parents.'

Peter Jenkins died while she was still unemployed, coming to the end of her party years. She had not yet started writing professionally. Asked if her father's death had affected her confidence, she says: 'It's not impossible that it's linked, that, while my father was occupying centre stage as a writer, I felt I couldn't, but then my stepmother also occupied centre stage and still does, so perhaps that theory doesn't work. Life isn't that straightforward.'

Jenkins describes herself as 'very unsuccessful in relationships'; she once said she was 'terminally single', a phrase she often finds quoted back at her. She lives alone in a four-storey house in Chelsea which she inherited from her grandmother. Five years ago, it was filled with friends from UCL and the club scene, who provided her with the inspiration for This Life . Now it's just her. 'I don't claim to have any of the answers. There isn't anyone in my life that I think of as "the Love of My Life", but I always used to have this fantasy, you know, that it should have been X.' But if there is a moral to Honey Moon , it could be that, as Jenkins says: 'It's not like that; the fantasy thing isn't true. What feels like passion ends up being pain and loneliness in the end.'

There is an element of her own experience in the book, she admits, but more in the way characters articulate thoughts of hers than anything in their particular situation. 'I tend to go for _ ' she hesitates, about to say 'stereotypes', and changes her mind. 'Not stereotypes - that's a derogatory word - but what we call "on-the-nose" characters. But I start from the premise of, "Let's have a nice guy, let's have a bastard, let's have a wacky girl" - quite broad definitions which I then twist.'

Honey Moon will undoubtedly sell in thousands. Film rights have been sold to Columbia, where someone Jenkins refers to as 'a proper Hollywood scriptwriter' is turning it into a screenplay. She is immersed in her next project, writing a feature film she hopes to direct herself. 'Film is what excites me,' she says, 'but I'm happy to have novel writing as another string to my bow. I love the idea that I could write novels in my old age.'

The prospect of the eightysomething single women's novel momentarily flashes before my mind's eye. If the genre ever comes into being, it seems certain that Jenkins will corner the market. Unless, of course, her terminal singleness is cured in the interim.

 Honey Moon is published on 4 May by Hodder and Stoughton, £16.99

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: A bold venture that attempts to unpick the knot of disagreements among women
fields.body:
Index on Censorship: Women who Censor
Edited by Judith Vidal-Hall

£8.99, pp194

Index on Censorship is the bi-monthly magazine devoted to protecting and promoting freedom of expression; former Channel 4 boss Michael Grade has just become its new chair. Fittingly, the current issue of Index has a provocative cover: a red-lipsticked mouth stitched up. This is a collection of writing which attempts to unpick the angry knot of disagreements among women (a premise taboo enough in itself), over sex, violence, abortion, veil-wearing, female circumcision, and censorship as self-protection. It is a bold venture, if not exactly 'a good read'.

Lynne Segal makes a powerful case for 'sweet reason', or why pornography, however vile, should not be censored. Judith Levine paints a bleak, somewhat over-emotive picture of the regressive fallout from pro-life activism in the US, where there is 'a near-total public silence' on 'the A-word'. Irena Maryniak - we are not told anything about her - reports on how domestic violence ('the culture of giving the wife something to think about') has proliferated in under-employed Eastern Europe. Most abused women say nothing, though, because of 'the weakness of their position in law, their fragile sense of personal dignity and anxiety for themselves and their children'.

But it is the personal stuff that sticks - an anonymous girl's account of her genital mutilation ceremony; more surprisingly, Yasmin Alibhai-Brown buckling in the middle of a blazing piece on the plight of young British Asian women forced into arranged marriages 'with grim determination' by their mothers: 'As the only Asian woman columnist in the mainstream press, I get calls from a huge number of distressed girls. They ask me for help I cannot give them and it breaks me up.'

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: Italo Calvino's blend of memory and imagination is well served by translator Tim Parks
fields.body:
The Road to San Giovanni
Italo Calvino
Vintage Classics £5.99, pp150
Buy it at BOL

Before his death in 1985, Calvino had been planning a collection of 'memory exercises', his wife Ester Judith Singer explains in her preface to the elegant Vintage Classics edition. The collection was never finished, but The Road To San Giovanni brings together five autobiographical essays, written between 1962 and 1977, all brimming with Calvino's beautifully crafted prose, dry humour and continual questioning of his own writing and memory.

The title essay, a colourful, sensual evocation of his childhood, is a perfect example of the memoir form, highlighting the interlacing of memory and imagination. 'A general explanation of the world and of history must first take into account the way our house was situated,' it begins, painting a picture of the town and surrounding landscape, with asides on how the bookish boy Calvino felt his unlikeness to his earthy father that call to mind Seamus Heaney's early poems. Calvino has been very well served by his translator, Tim Parks.

The title essay, a colourful, sensual evocation of his childhood, is a perfect example of the memoir form, highlighting the interlacing of memory and imagination. 'A general explanation of the world and of history must first take into account the way our house was situated,' it begins, painting a picture of the town and surrounding landscape, with asides on how the bookish boy Calvino felt his unlikeness to his earthy father that call to mind Seamus Heaney's early poems. Calvino has been very well served by his translator, Tim Parks.

fields.headline: Three men and a baby
fields.standfirst: LIfe bears down on the characters in Meir Shalev's Four Meals
fields.trailText: LIfe bears down on the characters in Meir Shalev's Four Meals
fields.body:
Four Meals
Meir Shalev, translated by Barbara Harshav
Canongate £10, pp331
Buy it at BOL

To Zayde, the hero of Israeli writer Meir Shalev's fourth novel, Four Meals, the past is divided into men who loved their mothers and men who didn't, though all are now dead or totter anciently down the streets, 'bent over like an upside-down L'. Existing, in this novel, lies heavy on the back. Life wrecks the human frame, the past oppresses, memory drapes a patchy shawl over the shoulders, chaffing at the skin.

Zayde's mother, Judith, came to a small village in Palestine between the world wars. Muscular, independent, preferring to live in a cowshed than share a house with a man, she was adored but never entirely won by three suitors: Rabinovitch, a man of unusual stockiness who cradled heavy rocks to his breast; Sheinfeld, who kept canaries and taught himself to sew and dance; and Globerman, a vodka-slugging cattle dealer. All three men claim Zayde as their son and provide for him according to means and disposition: Globerman gives him riches, Rabinovitch houses and clothes him, and Sheinfeld cooks him delectable meals - the four meals of the title. During each meal, Sheinfeld unravels a portion of the events which led to Zayde's birth.

Shalev's novel has much in common with the current trend for literary genealogy championed by diverse camps. W.G. Sebald, Andrew O'Hagan and Ahdaf Soueif have taken their tales from the inquisitive motion of present to past, young to ageing-dying-dead. Kate Atkinson and Linn Ullmann dust their stories with moonshine, turning memories to shimmering tricks of the light. Excavation becomes survivors' homage to those who went before, who endured wars, diaspora, penury or heartbreak to leave their successors in a position of relative ease. The search, generally, is for the particulars of personality, the force of individual desire unearthed in faded accounts.

Where Shalev seems to deviate is in his insistence on the identity-eroding likeness of people to others. Present spills into past, people slide into their predecessors, gender spills into gender. Rabinovitch's mother, deprived in him of the girl child she covets, teases Zayde's hair into a dazzling braid.

Zayde has inherited aspects of all his fathers. The key players are disappearing even as the picture of the past grows more vivid - Sheinfeld's last dinner takes place in his absence, the host being dead. Handed the burden of the story, Zayde is left troubled by whether he has unearthed anything tangible at all: 'This story, I soothe myself, refuses to be fiction,' he thinks, uncertainly.

Despite all our poring over details, says Shalev, our attempts to know our ancestors may fail to draw them out; once fervent and determined, they are now mutely entangled in the dense mass of the past.

fields.headline: Architecture in 18 words
fields.standfirst: Adrian Forty restricts himself to an examination of just 18 words in Words and Buildings, but does architecture really have such a limited vocabulary?
fields.trailText: Adrian Forty restricts himself to an examination of just 18 words in Words and Buildings, but does architecture really have such a limited vocabulary?
fields.body:
Words and Buildings: a Vocabulary of Modern Architecture
Adrian Forty
Thames & Hudson
Buy it at BOL

Adrian Forty's first book tried to tell us why refrigerators are white. Apparently, it's to make us use more electricity. He took a similar line on the Underground map: it is the result of a plot by London Transport to persuade commuters to travel further by making the city look smaller than it actually is.

By titling his book Objects of Desire and putting one of those oh so ironical, oh so mid-Eighties recycled images of a housewife in a cocktail dress gazing in wonder at her new, all-electric kitchen on the cover, Forty managed to make all this look of the moment (circa 1986). Unwittingly, he also launched a thousand glossy magazine features about matt-black calculators, rubber fountain pens and those strange kettles with a whistle like a steam locomotive, endlessly recycling his title to increasingly irritating effect.

Words and Buildings misses out on the snappy title, but it does play a lot of the contemporary graphic tricks that clued-up publishers use to make slabs of heavy-duty academic prose look as if they have escaped from the narrow confines of the research assessment exercise compound and out into the wider world of culture and can be read as literature. Instead of deconstructing objects, Forty is now trying to analyse the uses that architectural critics make of language, not, it has to be said, a subject of exactly mainstream interest. But the jacket design does its best to imply thoughtful reflectiveness with a wider currency. A duotone, four-colour black-and-sepia image implies quality, learning, and insight.

The subject matter of the photograph is more significant still. A balding man, shooting a cuff, Havana in hand, in dark jacket and immaculately tailored trousers, remains impassive as an older, silver-haired man with a black tie, his arm in blurred motion, attempts to engage him in conversation. The old man is Mies van der Rohe, the most formidable modernist architect of them all, nearing the end of his career. On the table between the two you notice a half empty bottle of bourbon. Is this a Proustian moment in some Left-Bank café? And who is the young man looking on in the background?

Yet this photograph is not what it seems. Bizarrely, it reappears on page 12 with a very different crop, and de-aestheticised by being rendered in plain black and white. It is revealed to be something very different, not photographic art at all, but a fleeting unfocused snap shot. What is Forty trying to tell us by using the same image twice, but in such different ways?

The bald, and as far as we can tell utterly unknown figure on the cover is not the centre of attention at all. The image it is meant to be a representation of an architectural conversation, a demonstration of Forty's thesis that architecture can be as much shaped by words as by drawings. It is Mies himself, also with cigar, shaking his hand for emphasis who is the point of the picture. And it is not a dialogue, but a monologue. The young man is Mies's grandson. A woman appears in the background and sees Mies's presence as important enough to merit taking a photograph. This is Berlin in 1967, and Mies is here for the unveiling of his design for Germany's new national gallery.

For Mies, a tutorial with one of his students at the Illinois Institute of Technology could take the form of half an hour of silence while the master smoked a Havana. He is a paradoxical choice for the cover of a book about language. As Forty acknowledges, Mies was always suspicious of words, and indeed famously pronounced that architects should 'build, not talk'.

Reading Forty's book, it is hard not to agree. The first half is a canter through the subject to establish the way that architects and critics use words, and are used by them. It is rarely with much grace or elegance. The second part provides a dictionary of the words that have formed the core vocabulary of modernist architectural critics. There are, however, just 18 of them, implying a silence that would have impressed even Mies. Some of these words are clearly far more significant as far as Forty is concerned than others. 'Form' for example, gets 24 pages which lead us through the nuances of the two German words for form, and the gradual evolution of the meaning of the word in English from its older sense of shape or mass to its avant-garde modernist suggestion of 'essence'.

'Formal', on the other hand, gets a perfunctory single page, while the section on 'user' is scarcely less skimpy. The list includes 'history', 'structure', and 'truth', all words which certainly form part of the Chinese whispers that pass for architectural debate. And Forty elucidates the fascinating twists and turns in the evolving meaning of language as spoken in the world of architecture. But in the end, he poses more questions than he answers.

Why attempt to deal with these words, but not, for example, 'rational', 'iconic', 'hierarchy', 'articulation' or, most significant of all, 'modern', to name just a few words that could be seen as being just as central to the language of architecture. Why does Forty limit himself so arbitrarily to a vocabulary of just 18 words. Is architecture really such a monosyllabic tongue?

fields.headline: The twins of the father...
fields.standfirst: Knowledge is the key to the questions posed by Anne Enright in What Are You Like?
fields.trailText: Knowledge is the key to the questions posed by Anne Enright in What Are You Like?
fields.body:
What Are You Like?
Anne Enright
Jonathan Cape £10, pp260
Buy it at BOL

The combination of sins of omission - a father's denial, a complicit, hypocritical church and a sadistic medical profession - mean that twins Rose and Maria grow up ignorant about who they are and where they come from. The resulting low self-esteem manifests itself in Maria as an inability to take charge of her life and in Rose as an obstacle to personal growth. While the tone of prize-winning Irish writer Anne Enright's second novel What Are You Like? is sad, the story nevertheless rings clear and true.

Masterfully written (if a little demanding on its readers), the novel suggests that having access to facts about family history gives individuals power. Without access to the facts, individuals remain incredibly vulnerable, suffering paralysing crises of identity, doomed to repeat 'in ignorance' the secret, traumatic events which formed them.

Narrated from multiple points of view, the story begins with the young women's grief-stricken father, Berts. Unfortunately, Berts's distorted and incomplete version of his wife's death and daughter Maria's birth sets the novel off to a slow start. While Berts's story is important (it sets up the central premise of the plot - the crucial omission of the fact that his wife died giving birth to twins), it nevertheless delays the point at which the novel adopts Maria's far more engaging point of view.

From the second chapter on, the novel slowly builds up momentum, cutting back and forth between 20-year-old Maria's New York love affair with heartless, tormented Anton and her unhappy childhood in Dublin with Berts and his family with his second wife, Evelyn.

The tension increases when the adult Maria discovers a curious photo in Anton's bag. The 12-year-old girl in the photo is identical to Maria at that age, but Maria can't remember the photo being taken, nor has she ever met Anton before. Because Maria doesn't really know who she is, she initially misrecognises it as a forgotten photograph of herself. Later, finding another photo - this time the girl is pictured playing with a younger Anton - Maria confronts him. They row and then he walks out of her life, never to return. All Maria manages to find out is that Anton knew the other girl briefly when he was a teenager. This unhappy affair is enough to push disempowered Maria over the edge.

But it's not until the narrator enters the haunted-but-sympathetic psyche of the nun who signed Maria's twin sister Rose's adoption papers that the story becomes properly compelling (Maria's fish-eye-lens version of reality means the reader can only ever partially identify with her plight). And when the subsequent chapter introduces Rose herself, all the character/narrators are in place for the novel to move towards the collision of the two young women's lives.

With stylistic echoes of early Joyce, in particular Dubliners, Enright's writing dazzles the reader with its control, even as it frustrates with its distance. The elegant modernist prose and ever-changing point of view means the reader contemplates what are potentially page-turning events from a position of relative detachment. And yet the greater detachment leaves the reader free to move backwards and forwards between plot and subplots, making the various associations and connections and observing the novel's numerous parallels. For example, Anton's abandonment of Maria underlies and mirrors Berts's unhealthy paternal detachment; Maria and Rose's disempowerment by secrets and lies is echoed in Evelyn's practiced denial as the daughter of an amicable alcoholic.

The novel works as an allegory for the contemporary political situation in Ireland. In an extended metaphor, the twin girls represent a united, reconciled Ireland. Whereas Maria grows up in Ireland, weakened to the point of self-destruction by the dishonesty and denial within which she unknowingly lives, Rose is adopted by a well-meaning but incompetent English couple. In spite of all the advan tages Rose's comfortable middle-class life affords her, she sees through the hypocrisy and rejects it in favour of the violent truth of blood. It is only once Rose has uncovered the facts and confronted Maria and her biological father that healing can begin. What Are You Like? is a tightly crafted novel with serious, thought-provoking themes.

fields.headline: For a few scholars more
fields.standfirst: Peter Conrad's enthusiasm for teaching is rekindled after reading Jonathan Smith's The Learning Game
fields.trailText: Peter Conrad's enthusiasm for teaching is rekindled after reading Jonathan Smith's The Learning Game
fields.body:
The Learning Game
Jonathan Smith
Little, Brown £14.99, pp224
Buy it at BOL

The educational reformers of the Seventies did only too thorough a job of deschooling society. At Oxford, I teach students who, despite their fine minds and enviable electronic skills, are often scarcely literate, baffled by grammar, syntax and punctuation, and hence unable to articulate their runaway ideas. I asked one of these a while ago whether she'd received any training at school in the use of her native language. 'Oh no,' she pertly replied, 'we got free milk instead.'

During a long career at Tonbridge School, Jonathan Smith has taught scores of pupils to read intelligently, to write correctly and to love literature. He holds forth in a room bedecked with portraits like votive images - ursine Betjeman, bilious Larkin - and with print-outs of his favourite poems. He reveres the memory of Tonbridge's old boys like E.M. Forster, and has helped to extend the line: among his own grateful pupils are Vikram Seth and the poet Christopher Reid. As well as the transmission of literary enthusiasm, he also finds time to direct school plays, coach the cricket team and write novels and radio plays.

If Smith weren't so modest, I'd suspect him of sanctity. Come to think of it, why not? Once, stung by the social ignominy of his unrespected, underpaid profession, he insisted on calling himself a 'schoolmaster', not a teacher. His father, who followed the same trade, reminded him that: 'Jesus was a teacher and he wasn't ashamed of it.'

Nevertheless, Smith mercilessly derides both the sentimental veneration of the teacher as a tribal elder, and the more hip and happening notion that education should be a party (with lashings of free milk laid on). He knows that the job requires the dreary vigilance of a policeman and the psychological dexterity of an actor. Learning is a grind, which a talented teacher can transform into a game.

His memoir serves as a reminder of how fast and disorientingly educational practices have changed. He attended a rural primary school after the war, where he sang nursery rhymes, learned the alphabet by studying pictures of apples, bats and cats and became numerate by counting on his fingers. In an exercise book, he transcribed prayers, punctuation tests and rules governing the use of the apostrophe.

He polished his penmanship by copying a sentence which contained all the letters of the alphabet: 'I packed my box with five dozen liquor jugs', a nonsensical and vaguely risqué statement which in itself changes an educational chore into a treat. Nowadays, students rely on a computer programme to check their spelling and have calculators to do their sums for them. Handwriting is no longer the signature of personal identity: you simply choose a fashionable font to represent you. How much progress has this gadgetry really prompted? Interestingly, Andrew Motion has begun to campaign for a return to one ritual of those unenlightened days, the rote learning of poetry, which trains the mind and gives the emotions a work-out.

Smith is properly scornful of the political correctness which debars teachers from patting students on the back and ignores advice to leave the door open when talking to a pupil alone. He also exposes the slump in standards which is covered up by the habit of 'positive marking'. At Oxford, we're informed in advance that roughly 20 per cent of candidates must get Firsts. If an examiner doesn't come up with the requisite proportion, a smiling computer regrades the papers and 'scales' them optimistically upwards.

My life, like Smith's, was irradiated by my discovery of literature, and I, too, have always wanted to evangelise for it. Nevertheless, when a pretentious colleague once asked me what the 'telos' of my teaching was, I found it hard to answer and pretended to be mystified by the word. Smith replies for me, in a tribute to the man who taught him history: 'His main purpose was to capture your interest, to fascinate you into taking the subject seriously. If you took it seriously, it became fun. If you became absorbed, you loved it.'

The Learning Game is a true, wise, morale-boosting manifesto. Having read it, I can hardly wait for the Oxford spring break to end!

Nevertheless, when a pretentious colleague once asked me what the 'telos' of my teaching was, I found it hard to answer and pretended to be mystified by the word. Smith replies for me, in a tribute to the man who taught him history: 'His main purpose was to capture your interest, to fascinate you into taking the subject seriously. If you took it seriously, it became fun. If you became absorbed, you loved it.' The Learning Game is a true, wise, morale-boosting manifesto. Having read it, I can hardly wait for the Oxford spring break to end!

fields.headline: The fragile Holocaust
fields.standfirst: It's one of history's most potent events. But what does it mean? Peter Novick digs deep in The Holocaust and Collective Memory
fields.trailText: It's one of history's most potent events. But what does it mean? Peter Novick digs deep in The Holocaust and Collective Memory
fields.body:
The Holocaust and Collective Memory
Peter Novick
Bloomsbury £18.99, pp373
Buy it at BOL

There is no more famous quotation about moral failure in the past century than Martin Niemöller's mea culpa about the Holocaust: 'First they came for the Communists, but I was not a Communist, so I said nothing. Then they came for the Social Democrats, but I was not a Social Democrat, so I did nothing. Then came the trade unionists, but I was not a trade unionist. And then they came for the Jews, but I was not a Jew, so I did little. Then when they came for me, there was no one left to stand up for me.'

You know that. Everybody knows that. There is a Voltairean force and clarity about the five sentences which make them unforgettable, canonical. Or not. When Time magazine used them, they moved the Jews to the first place and dropped both the communists and the social democrats. Al Gore dropped the Lefties too, and then dropped the trade unionists for good measure.

Gore, Time and a speaker at the 1992 Republican convention all added Roman Catholics, who weren't on Niemöller's list at all. In the heavily Catholic city of Boston, Catholics were added to the quotation inscribed on its Holocaust memorial. The US Holocaust Museum drops the Communists but not the Social Democrats; other versions have added homosexuals.

So what is truth? asked jesting Himmler. The Holocaust has become the single most potent moral event of our times, our symbol of absolute evil, our hellfire in history, the place where we imagine ourselves tested hardest; our instinctive reference point for anything else that appals us.

But the Holocaust's very size, the way it looms, means that it is not simple, and that it is used and abused in countless ways. Who controls this memory and gives it meaning? Who distorts it? To whom does it ultimately belong and what is its ethical effect, half a century on?

Today, scores of US cities have Holocaust museums; the Holocaust is on the curriculum of thousands of schools; Holocaust films, books, TV series and articles are a staple of American culture... and therefore, though a little less so, of our culture too. The David Irving libel case has become the nearest thing liberal London society gets to a trial for witchcraft or blasphemy.

What does all this mean for Jews and gentiles? Does it inculcate not only a victimhood but also a death-fixation which is actually very un-Jewish? Does it teach people here, today, now, real lessons or has it simply become a glib way of identifying Evil as being something other, far away - Nazis as the Monsters from Outer Space, rather than educated and in some ways mainstream Europeans of only 70 years ago?

Very occasionally, books about hard subjects come along that are so good you want to go about pressing them on everyone you meet. Peter Novick, a Chicago history professor and a Jew, has written such a book, a history of how Americans, and, in particular, American Jewry, thought about the Holocaust from the 1940s, when it was actually happening, to the present day. He asks very uncomfortable questions in The Holocaust and Collective Memory, page after page of them. In general, his tone is wry, cautious, almost weary.

At one highly significant moment, however, it rises into flaming anger at the hypocrisy underlying a lot of Holocaust piety. Novick is talking about the death of a million children in the Holocaust while the world 'stood by'. Then he swerves to recall the Rwanda slaughter and note that 10 times that number currently die every year in the world of malnutrition and preventable diseases:

'The possibilities for rescuing millions of children around the world who die, no less horribly, from malnutrition and disease are readily available - and are largely ignored. The United States is, by a wide margin, the wealthiest country in the world. In the humanitarian assistance it offers to the poorest nations, as a percentage of GNP, it ranks, also by a wide margin, last among the industrialised countries.

'Every American President in recent years has had moving words to say about how shameful it was that the United States stood by as millions died. If one President has been moved by, or has noticed, America's standing on the list just mentioned, if he has expressed shame and mortification at that standing, it's escaped my research.'

The Holocaust, in other words, may be becoming an excuse; in the words of another critic mentioned by Novick, 'never again' may have come to mean merely 'never again would Germans kill Jews in Europe in the 1940s'. One might as well say, he goes on: 'Never again the slaughter of the Albigensians.'

Is it possible that these images of ultimate horror, conveyed with such brilliance by writers, film-makers, rabbis, preachers, politicians and historians, may be having little real moral effect? No, clearly not. Their value as a lesson has been immense, in repressing casual racisms in Western society - and repression can be a very good thing, a delicate burying of what is 'natural' until it disappears. But the Holocaust has become exploited, by politics and every group with a grievance. Its centrality is relatively recent, fragile and may die away again.

After all, it took a long time for the Holocaust to rise in the US public consciousness. Postwar Jewish survivors were discouraged from speaking out. One Jew who grew up among Zionists in Detroit in the Fifties recalled that the Spanish Civil War was a more evocative event in his community than the Holocaust. The Cold War and Germany's switch from enemy to ally meant 'harping on' about it became a sign of suspect Communist leanings.

Later, Jewish pride and worry about Israel, the Eichmann trial, the growth of ethnic particularism, strong Jewish influence in Hollywood and US intellectual life generally, and the celebration of victimhood in US politics, all helped to turn the tide in a most spectacular way. It has become something taught in almost every American school, as much part of how Americans understand themselves as the Declaration of Independence or the Civil War.

And the effect of this? Forced to generalise, I would say it has been good for liberal society, but ambiguous at least for Jews. Among gentiles, it has caused racism to become unrespectable for the first time in history, and taught a deep horror of the police state, though it is also used far too glibly by politicians who wish to avoid trickier evils.

On the other hand, it may have trapped the people whose forebears were trapped by Hitler. Novick quotes another writer, Leon Wieseltier, as he closes this brilliant book.

Such a collective memory as the Holocaust, he argues, 'leaves the individual and the group too sceptical about change... don't be fooled, it teaches, there is only repetition... in the memory of oppression, oppression outlives itself. The scar does the work of the wound... injustice retains the power to distort long after it has ceased to be real. It is a posthumous victory for the oppressors when pain becomes a tradition.'

That is a Jewish problem. For my part, I would consider my children dangerously ill-educated if they didn't have some emotional awareness of the Holocaust.

Liberal society is more at risk the fewer the people who remember. But anyone who thinks this is simple, or a 'given' or forever, should read Novick and know better.

fields.headline: Modernism made hard
fields.standfirst: In City of God E. L. Doctorow weaves a reproach to postmodernism out of the tale of a turbulent pries
fields.trailText: In City of God E. L. Doctorow weaves a reproach to postmodernism out of the tale of a turbulent priest
fields.body:
City of God

E.L. Doctorow
Little, Brown £15.99, pp272
Buy it at BOL

The sixties, far more than the so-called millennium, were a period of anticipated apocalypse - we were on the brink of an understanding that would yield ecstatic mutuality, but also possibly just in time for the collapse of everything. Aquarian optimism was crowded by paranoia and, in America, this became the very tone of writers as different as Thomas Pynchon, Allen Ginsberg and E.L. Doctorow: urgent, prophetic, setting the stories of multiple characters side by side as if, together, they would yield the real story.

Doctorow brings this conjunction of paradoxical expectations to a novel about the penultimate year of the past millennium. It addresses only the big questions: is the physical universe incongruent with the spiritual and, taking the mind-body question along the route that more closely concerns most of us, can true love and individual identity occupy the same human space? Along the way, there is even a poetic Marxist analysis of how one of the grosser forms of materialism - corporate capitalism - subverted the intrinsically idealist business of early movies, which was to show the truth about the rotten material conditions created by capitalism.

The apocalyptic aspect here is that these big questions feel as if they are on the verge of being answered. On the brink of the new century, they are tossed around, hinted at, posed and implied in monologues by, among others, Einstein, Wittgenstein, an Episcopal priest in the process of defrocking himself, a survivor of a Nazi-ruled Jewish Lithuanian ghetto, and a New York writer named Everett who may be the ventriloquist animating all of them - itself a comment on the relative powers of the Creator and a creator.

None of this is self-evident, however, as you read along, migrating from voice to voice, often without obvious hints about who is speaking. The core story concerns the Episcopal priest, Father Thomas Pemberton, or Pem; Everett (who is writing about Pem); and Sarah, an Upper West Side rabbi. Everett finds Pem's determination to believe in God while disbelieving biblical myth and church creed spiritually seductive, and looks on with a certain bemusement as the unchaste, hard-drinking priest is attracted to Sarah. Sarah is married to a fellow rabbi, Joshua, with whom she has founded a temple to explore how to believe in God while disbelieving biblical myth and the sanctity of traditional rituals.

Writer, rabbis and priest were brought together by a news item about the disappearance of a large cross from Pem's scruffy church; Joshua has found it on the roof of their synagogue. At first, it seems as if the story will be about how the cross's disappearance is related to its reappearance, which will somehow be revealed through airing the big questions, along with the story of Sarah's father, the Lithuanian Holocaust survivor. But Doctorow is quite cavalier about the mystery, as he is about what happens to Joshua when visiting a Lithuanian synagogue, as if to say that solving such questions in the manner of a crime novel will obscure the larger, more pressing mysteries (and crimes, such as genocide) by creating an illusion that, God in his heaven or not, all's right with the world.

Further, what you thought was the story of Sarah's father turns out to be a fabrication of Everett's, as does a first-person narrative by a former CIA spook, and a series of disquisitions about birds that culminates in one about a city of birds founded on a garbage dump - the implication being that they are us, or us after the catastrophe if we don't deal with these questions in a more satisfactory way. Other fabrications, such as a certain set of screenplays, turn out, eerily for the protagonists, to be true.

If millenarian optimism and paranoia were the moral tone of the 1960s, the diffracted and self-reflective lines of modernism were the high culture's dominant aesthetic. Ragtime, Doctorow's high-minded bestseller, came out of that, a version of modernism for the masses; modernism, you could say, made easy. City of God is not only modernism made hard again but a reproach to the glib, easy sampling that is postmodernism, in which nothing means anything. For modernists, almost everything meant too much. Ragtime was, in its just-after-the-Sixties time, as big as Titanic in 1999. Knowing that, somehow, makes apocalyptic warnings hardly seem worth it.
