fields.headline: Count your Lessings
fields.standfirst: Carol Klein's biography of Doris Lessing may make her subject feel as if she's been mugged...
fields.trailText: Carol Klein's biography of Doris Lessing may make her subject feel as if she's been mugged...
fields.body:
Doris Lessing

Carole Klein
Duckworth £18.99, pp284
Buy it at BOL

In the first volume of her autobiography, Under My Skin, Doris Lessing wrote that in 1992 she had heard of five American biographers working on her. One of them, she supposed, must be 'concocting a book out of supposedly autobiographical material in novels and from two short monographs about my parents. Probably interviews, too, and these are always full of misinformation.' She is writing her autobiography (she says wryly, without much hope) out of 'self-defence', as an attempt to 'claim her own life'.

Carole Klein's very bad book must be one of those pending biographies. Kitty Kelley's life of Nancy Reagan was once described as a literary 'drive-by shooting'. Klein is more respectful of Lessing, but she may still make her subject feel as if she's been mugged.

Klein presents her subject's resistance as an advantage. Because Doris Lessing declined to be interviewed for this book, she writes, she has been able to rely on published sources and interviews with acquaintances (many of whom appear, queasily, as people 'who wished to remain anonymous'), without 'the benefit or hindrance of the subjective lens through which she would have viewed my thoughts'.

Lessing is, admittedly, an extremely difficult and intractable subject, and not just because she's very much alive and kicking. Like other major writers who have moved through complicated processes of transforming their own life into fiction and out into large political and social issues, and who have never stopped growing and changing in their beliefs and opinions, Lessing is a hard nut to crack.

To do her justice, Klein doesn't entirely collapse the tricky relation between the work and the life, but she doesn't analyse it, either. We have to make do with this sort of thing. 'She explored her African past in her books', or 'She postulates that a great many women begin to write out of a need for self-understanding', or 'Lessing's own conflicts surrounding motherhood have all been rendered in her fiction'.

Lessing's wilfulness, stubbornness, scorn, arrogance, coldness and irritability, and her refusal to be accountable for what she's done, are frequently emphasised, with corroborating evidence from (usually anonymous) rejected assistants or thwarted interviewers.

The text is littered with typos and errors and the prose style is shoddy and clichéd ('a girl who roamed the African veldt'... 'the pages continued to erupt from her typewriter'. It has the air of being written uncorrected and at high speed. But then I suppose the point was to get in first.

fields.headline: Is this the new Kundera?
fields.standfirst: Last summer we named Aleksandar Hemon as a writer to watch out for - now the Bosnian refugee's stunning collection of stories has proved us right
fields.trailText: Last summer we named Aleksandar Hemon as a writer to watch out for - now the Bosnian refugee's stunning collection of stories has proved us right
fields.body:
The Question of Bruno

Aleksandar Hemon
Picador £12.99. pp230
Buy it at BOL

The asylum seeker is our everyman. Aleksandar Hemon, a Bosnian, arrived in Chicago from Sarajevo in 1992 with two suitcases and $300. He was 28, on a month-long journalist's exchange programme, but when war broke out at home he made an application to be a political refugee, and stayed.

In Chicago, Hemon worked at anything he could get: as a kitchen helper and a bike messenger; he was happy to find a job in a bookshop for a while. He slept on the bare wood floor of a tiny apartment, spending any spare money on guilty telephone calls to his family, who lived under siege. And he sustained himself with dreams of writing fiction, teaching himself English by reading Lolita, underlining the words he didn't understand.

After three years Hemon found himself writing stories in his adoptive language. They were attempts to detail the disjunctions of the life he had found in Chicago, and the cruelty in the lives he had left behind in Sarajevo, linked tales of exile and loss driven by an urgency to comprehend. Hemon's stories are collected in The Question of Bruno. They amount to an intimate biography of the Balkans in the last century, as well as a surreal exploration of displacement. Each one reads as if it were written to address a pressing psychological need in its author.

Hemon's publisher brackets him with Nabokov and Kundera, and in some senses both comparisons are justified. Like Nabokov, Hemon writes with the startling peeled vision of the outsider, weighing words as if for the first time; he shares with Kundera an ability to find grace and humour in the bleakest of circumstances. In part his book is a history lesson, but it is history felt on a human pulse. He imagines his way back into the troubled soul of his home city, and tells its tales from within.

Some of the stories are rooted in reported experience. 'A Coin', for example, which is told in the voice of a young Bosnian woman helping a cameraman document the war, begins and ends in sniper's alley, and finds pathos and absurdity among the detritus of life and death.

'Suppose there is a point A and a point B,' the woman says. 'You have to run from point A to point B and the faster you run, the more likely you are to reach point B alive. The space between point A and point B is littered with things that sprinting citizens have dropped along the way. A black leather wallet, probably empty. A purse, agape like a mouth. A white plastic water vessel, with a bullet hole in its centre... A wet loaf of bread with excited ants crawling over, as if building a pyramid.'

But if the terrain of many of Hemon's stories is the banal cartography of war, the substance is often fantastical. 'The Life and Work of Alphonse Kauders' is a bullet-point biography of a Yugoslavian Zelig, bee-keeper, pornographer and statesman, each 'fact' of whose life is more outlandish than the last: 'Alphonse Kauders said to Rosa Luxemburg: 'Let me penetrate a little bit, just a bit, I'll be careful,' he says. 'Alphonse Kauders, in the course of time, put a revolver on Gavrilo Princip's temple, for he had burned a bee with his cigarette,' he goes on.

Hemon gets away with his game playing in two ways: by consistently making sentences that hoard surprises; and by demonstrating that reality throws up as many impossibilities as any acrobatic flight of fantasy. Often, the stories offer personal footnotes to epoch-making events; in one, Hemon family folklore (shared at a gathering of the clans christened by his father 'The Hemoniad') casts cousins, uncles and more distant ancestors as extras in the long march of European history. A great-grandfather plays an accordion on a street corner while Archduke Franz Ferdinand passes on his way to begin the century's bloodletting; earlier walk-on Hemons are discovered in the Iliad and Antigone; one is in the crowd at Calvary, another enjoys an orgy in Gargantua and Pantagruel.

fields.headline: You couldn't make him up...
fields.standfirst: Joe Klein's forthcoming follow-up to his bestselling Primary Colors confirms Bill Clinton's status as the most written-about US President in history. What makes him such an inspiration for the creative imagination?
fields.trailText: Joe Klein's forthcoming follow-up to his bestselling Primary Colors confirms Bill Clinton's status as the most written-about US President in history. What makes him such an inspiration for the creative imagination?
fields.body:
Next week will see the simultaneous worldwide publication of Joe Klein's heavily embargoed second novel, The Running Mate . The eager expectation attending this follow-up (it is emphatically not a sequel) to Klein's acclaimed international bestseller, Primary Colors , is both a tribute to Joe Klein's powers of invention and also, more intriguingly, to the grip that the forty-second President of the USA still exerts on the Anglo-American imagination.

Four years ago, profiling William Jefferson Clinton on the eve of his disastrous second term as President, The Observer wrote: 'Clinton is a figure for the playwrights, a man of Shakespearean dimensions.' A line that was probably intended to hint at the necessary complexity of any characterisation has been proved spookily prescient in a quite unexpected way. Bill Clinton has inspired America's creative community, its writers, journalists and filmmakers as no other President in living memory, not even JFK or Nixon.

As the Bush-Gore contest moves towards its decisive phase and the New York senatorial race hots up and before Bill'n'Hillary have even departed the White House, there have been more books written about Clinton than any other American President in the twentieth century, according to the New York Times . Leaving aside the right-wing trash produced by Vermin Books, aka The Viper Press, about the Whitewater investigation and the suicide of Vince Foster, there is already a shelf's worth of journalistic commentary, from Bob Woodward's The Agenda (1996) and Jeffrey Toobin's A Vast Conspiracy (2000) to Christopher Hitchens's splenetic indictment of eight years of 'conservatism, cowardice and corruption', No One Left To Lie To (1999).

There are also contributions from the First Couple themselves, a his'n'hers of self-promotion, Between Hope and History (1996) and It Takes a Village (1995), vain attempts to offer voters coherence, gravitas and vision where there had been only fuzziness, sniggering and scandal. You can also consult several memoirs by retired and exhausted Clintonistas, from Robert Reich's Locked in the Cabinet (1997) to George Stephanopoulos's All Too Human (1999), each of whom, while shaking his head over the dreadful frailties of 'Slick Willie', reveals an awestruck fascination with the man.

If you want to be a fly-on-the-wall in the Clinton 1992 campaign war-room; if you want to know how the Clintons faced the cameras after the first Gennifer Flowers bimbo eruption; if you want to ride in the limousine as the President rewrites his State of the Union address en route to the Capitol and then, when the teleprompter fails, goes on to ad lib the first seven minutes without missing a beat; if you want to stand in the Oval Office when the leader of the free world comes in from his morning jog; if you want to be harangued and abused and shouted at by a red-faced, finger-stabbing, pizza-gobbling, card-playing, tearjerking good ol' boy; in short, if you want to see the warts-and-all side of a supremely professional politician supremely packaged for popular consumption, then these books, especially All Too Human , are hard to resist.

Most awestruck of all is the infamous Starr Report, a bizarre compendium of soft porn and prurient innuendo, tricked out with lurid and salacious grand jury testimony, that now seems fatally obsessed with the President's sexual appetite and completely negligent in its duty to explain to the American people why the President should be run out of town.

But amid this welter of print, the man himself remains elusive, like all great politicians. Perhaps the conundrum of Bill Clinton is an essential part of his appeal. He was caught with his trousers down in the Oval Office, yet somehow managed to wriggle free, like an indestructible cartoon character. When people say, as they often do of him, that 'character' is the issue, they are unconsciously putting their finger on his fascination. From a dramatic, or fictional point of view, Clinton is all character and perhaps nothing but. Hence the books.

Interestingly, the first of these came not from America but Britain. Robyn Sisman's 'what if?' novel, Special Relationship , published in 1995, has an American candidate, now favoured to win the presidency, spending a year at Oxford as a Rhodes scholar. Six days before the election, he learns a shocking truth - that he fathered a son with his English girlfriend, Annie Hamilton. Now that son, ready to tell the world the truth about his parentage, is coming to America _

Sisman was indeed at Oxford with Clinton and those who know him say you have to start with the handshake. Another Oxford contemporary, Geoffrey Robertson QC, described an encounter with Clinton at a college reunion in 1983. 'He shook my hand in this extraordinary way. It was amazing. I remember saying, "Wow! so that's a gubernatorial handshake". It was an amazing experience.'

The handshake is the essential opening gambit of American politics. Joe Klein acknowledged this when he opened his satirical novel Primary Colors with a brilliant evocation of candidate Jack Stanton's vote-wooing clasp:

'I couldn't tell you how he does it, the right-handed part of it ... I can, however, tell you a whole lot about what he does with his other hand. He is a genius with it. He might put it on your elbow or up by your biceps; these are basic reflexive moves. He is interested in you. He is honoured to meet you _ he'll flash that famous misty look of is. And he will mean it.

Post-Monica, we can't read that passage in quite the same naive way as before and Klein's satire, which became an enjoyable Mike Nichols film starring John Travolta and Emma Thompson, is now less an inside-the-beltway journalistic scandal than the precursor of an extraordinary number of celluloid reworkings of the Clinton years. It's in film scripts as much as in books that the many-layered drama of the Clinton presidency has been played out.

Here again, the Shakespearean comparison is apt. Dramatists of all stripes have always been suckers for power and its mesmerising corruptions. Just as the young Shakespeare spent an important part of his apprenticeship as a playwright exploring and subtly commenting on the dark heart of the Plantagenet and Tudor dynastic triumph, so the scriptwriters of Hollywood have refracted the bruising national experience of Clinton's two terms through the strange public prism of the multiplex.

There is a further irony to the dream factory saying to itself that the play's the thing to catch the conscience of the king. Throughout his presidency, Clinton and Hollywood have seemed closely linked. In the early days, it was on the runway at LAX that the President had his infamous $200 haircut. Towards the end, during the darkest hours of the Lewinsky crisis, prominent film industry figures like Steven Spielberg, Tom Hanks and Barbra Streisand supported him with money and endorsements.

At first, during the honeymoon period, Hollywood expressed its fascination with the First Couple in films like Rob Reiner's The American President , a soft-centred, romantic comedy, starring Michael Douglas and Annette Bening, which seemed to argue that the President, portrayed here as a handsome widower, should be allowed to have his own private life.

The American President , which now seems like Mary Poppins compared to what actually followed, both in film and in real life, also contained a snippet of dialogue that says all you need to know about the people around Clinton and is alleged to have come directly from Stephanopoulos himself. 'It's Christmas,' a presidential aide tells the Stephanopoulos character. 'It's Christmas?' comes the incredulous reply. 'Yeah,' says his colleague. 'You didn't get the memo?'

The moviemaking liberals' mood of indulgent teasing did not survive Clinton's disappointing first term. By 1996, Clint Eastwood's Absolute Power , a darkly compelling regurgitation of Drudge Report scuttlebut and Arkansas gossip about rape and drug-smuggling, made no attempt to show President Gene Hackman as anything other than a depraved and murderous psychopath.

By the time Barry Levinson's Wag the Dog (1997) appeared, politics and the movies had become interchangeable, it seemed. The film was a fairly broad satire in which a President involved in a sex scandal cooks up a small war to distract the nation's attention, but White House spokepersons found themselves having to deny, as US strike forces were deployed against 'Islamic terrorists', that this was not a ' Wag the Dog ' scenario, an attempt to draw attention from the Lewinsky scandal.

Elsewhere, fact and fantasy blurred, as it often does in American life, when Robert De Niro hit the phones to persuade Republican Congressmen not to impeach the President. He failed. Hollywood also responded to the newsworthiness and enduring popularity of the presidency under Clinton by coming up with blockbusting adventure films , notably Independence Day (1996) and Air Force On e (1997) - in which the commander-in-chief takes on the forces of evil in single combat, films which seem to reflect the sense of drama Clinton has brought to the post of national chief executive.

The novelisation of Clinton on the screen has not - yet - been matched in books. For a thinly disguised picture of the Clinton White House, such as Joe Klein might have written if he had continued to fictionalise the career of Jack Stanton, you have to turn to Aaron Sorkin's superb political soap opera, The West Wing (Sky TV), in which life and art are so inextricably scrambled that one of the advisers on an excellent script turns out to have been Mandy Grunwald, a former Clinton White House staffer.

The West Wing 's President Bartlett, brilliantly played by Martin Sheen, is a hyperactive hamster, a herbivorous creature of gregarious, smooth-talking charm, just another face of the Bill Clinton the world has never fully seen.

Other inspirational presidents include:

Abraham Lincoln 1809-65 Sixteenth President

Films: Abraham Lincoln's Clemency (1910); Lincoln the Lover (1913); Birth of a Nation (1914); The Life of Abraham Lincoln (1915); Abraham Lincoln (1925); Abraham Lincoln (1930); Of Human Hearts (1938); Young Mr Lincoln (1939)

Fiction: A Bullet for Lincoln by Benjamin King (1993).

Theodore Roosevelt (1858-1919) Twenty-sixth President

Films: This is My Affair (1937) In Old Oklahoma (1943) Buffalo Bill (1944); My Girl Tisa (1948) The Wind and the Lion (1975).

Fiction: Murder in Georgetown by Elliot Roosevelt (1992); Alice & Edith: the Two Wives of Theodore Roosevelt - a biographical Novel by Dorothy Clarke Wilson.

Woodrow Thomas Wilson (1856-1924) Twenty-eighth President

Fims: Wilson (1944) account of his efforts to keep the US out of the Second World War.

John Fitzgerald Kennedy 1917-1963 Thirty-fifth President

Films: PT 109 (1963); JFK (1991)

TV: Kennedy (1983) Johnny We Hardly Knew Ye (1977); Kennedy (1981)

Fiction: If JFK Had Lived: a Political Scenario by R. Reginald (1982)

Richard Milhous Nixon 1913-1994 Thirty-seventh President

Films: Millhouse: A White Comedy (1971); All the President's Men (1976); Secret Honor (1984) Born Again (1978). Kissinger and Nixon (1995); Nixon (1995) .

Fiction: Murder at the Watergate by Margaret Truman.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.standfirst: Alain de Botton enchants Rachel Redford with his mellifluous tones and intriguing anecdotes
fields.trailText: Alain de Botton enchants Rachel Redford with his mellifluous tones and intriguing anecdotes
fields.body:
The Consolations of Philosophy

Alain de Botton

Read by the author

Running time 3 hrs

Penguin £8.99
Buy it at BOL

How Proust Can Change Your Life

Alain de Botton

Read by Samuel West

Running time 3hrs

CSA Telltapes £8.99
Buy it at BOL

Short of money? Take consolation from fourth-century Epicurus who shows us that although we may desire cashmere and crustaceans, such things will not make us happy. Feeling intellectually inadequate? Let Montaigne comfort you. Is the ploughman not manifestly happier than those who have climbed the upper branches of the tree of knowledge?

In the work of six great philosophers, Alain de Botton seeks answers to the riddles of today's human unhappinesses. His musings are studded with intriguing anecdotes and illustration, from his own pain at watching The Elephant Man to the beauty perceived by Peruvians in stretched ears. Whether or not his theses are convincing, his voice is so enchanting and his ideas so engaging that the listener is indeed consoled.

Did you know that Proust's doctor brother was such a dab hand at excising the prostate that such operations were known as 'Proustectomies'? That a typical snake-like Proustian sentence could encircle the base of a wine bottle 17 times? A store of such observations enrich de Botton's beautifully read text which has the seductive, tangential meandering of Proust's own work and gives real insight into the 'indigestible nougat' of his writing.

Sit down with tea and madeleines and enjoy listening to both these tapes over and over again.

fields.headline: Industrial-strength Shakespeare
fields.standfirst: The Almeida's Richard II is the hottest ticket in town. Only it's not at the Almeida...
fields.trailText: Richard II | The Force of Change | Blue/Orange | The Villains' Opera
fields.body:
Richard II Gainsborough Studios, London N1
The Force of Change Royal Court Upstairs, London SW1
Blue/Orange Cottesloe, London SE1
The Villains' Opera Olivier, London SE1

You cross the pavements of Shoreditch, step into an old Metropolitan Railway power station, and find yourself in a version of pre-industrial England. The space is huge; around it are long windows, domed as if they belonged in a cathedral. Light drizzles through the dusk; you can see a few knights standing around; you hear birdsong and plainchant. The stage of the Gainsborough is a wide, green field. You might begin to think things are all right, but at the back of this pleasantness a brick wall is cleft by a giant jagged fissure the shape of a lightning streak.

It's long been obvious that the Almeida's short tenancy of the old Gainsborough Studios was going to provide some of the hottest tickets of the theatrical season. Any Almeida Shakespeare is an event, as the theatre's Hackney Hamlet proved: at Shoreditch, Jonathan Kent directs first Richard II and then Coriolanus . Any production with Ralph Fiennes will be sure of an audience, and he appears in both plays. The surprise factor is the building itself: the Gainsborough is its own drama.

Constructed 100 years ago to generate electricity, this lofty brick slab has been visited by glamour and neglect. In 1919 it was converted into film studios by the Famous Player-Laskys; it later became a base for Hitchcock, who made The Lodger there, starring Ivor Novello, and in 1938, The Lady Vanishes . It had a further life as a whisky-bottling plant and as a warehouse for oriental rugs. When the Almeida moves out, the building will be redeveloped as flats.

It is brilliant of the Almeida to have alighted on this space, and brilliant of them to have given it to the architectural firm of Haworth Tompkins to convert. This was the firm that refashioned the Royal Court, plaiting together contemporary and Victorian features. It is a firm that is helping to redefine the idea of what a theatre can look like, sheering away both from twentieth-century concrete blocks and the enduring nineteenth-century notion of a West End theatre, fantastic and imperial, with an interior like a ballgown, folded and looped and swagged with gold. The new idea is more intimate, more democratic.

In the Gainsborough, nothing is made to look perfect: you can see where the bones are buried, with the existing surfaces - bricks and timber and steel - being re-used, and rubble from demolition piled up for the rake of the seating. What could be better for a history play? The aim is to use the building's ecclesiastical qualities for Richard II and its industrial strength for Coriolanus .

There is a powerful sense of history in Kent's production of Richard II , very much helped by the space. It does not have the biting, dangerous quality which the play had recently at Stratford, with the crisply sardonic Sam West; there are too many blurred moments early on, and too much roaring, particularly from David Burke as John of Gaunt. But it does have its own coherence. Ralph Fiennes's Richard is always intelligent and always interesting. There's not an unthought moment, from his early appearances - awkwardly pleated like a playing-card king, all elbows, sceptre, crown and frown - to his later pets and rages and sudden introspections. He has the perfect foil in Linus Roache who is chillingly contained as Bolingbroke. He has perfectly judged support from Oliver Ford Davies. And the stage is ignited by the great and insufficiently praised actress Barbara Jefford, who makes a small part sing with a Shakespearean truth and makes you wish that Shakespeare had written Queen Lear .

Gary Mitchell is unlike any other Irish playwright. He's a Protestant. He writes thriller plots. And his settings are thoroughly urban. He has always written with verve and edge; and now he has produced his best play to date, a high-voltage, disputatious examination of the Royal Ulster Constabulary. The Force of Change sets the Theatre Upstairs alight. Simon Higlett's revealing design makes a traverse stage into a rat-run, with the audience banked on each side increasing the claustrophobia. Two interrogation cells in an RUC station are set at each end of a corridor: the officers pace between them as if caged up, and as if - which is indeed the case - each is compulsively rehearsing an argument.

At the centre of Mitchell's play is a charge of collusion between the RUC and the UDA. The moment in which this accusation comes out involves a clumsy plot-wobble with a mobile phone, but there's nothing clumsy about Mitchell's probing of the constabulary's psychology. Scrutinising a range of attitudes in the shape of four officers - one of them corrupt, one an embattled new female recruit - he shows a force bewildered and threatened by the political changes engendered by the peace process. He lays bare both reactionary and honourable traits. Mitchell is a dramatist, not a debater: his ideas are embodied in the action of the play. And they are given brilliant embodiment under Robert Delamere's direction. All these performances are first-rate. To see Gerard Jordan's juddering, slack-faced joy-rider, and Stephen Kennedy's taciturn, stealthy UDA suspect - who delivers a flick of the hand on a police file like a karate chop - is to be taken into a world behind the headlines. Stuart Graham's vicious and principled officer is a wonderful hard case. This is the play which makes the new Royal Court Upstairs look explosive.

There's something about a threesome that gets theatres buzzing. Two of the most successful plays of the last few years - Michael Frayn's Copenhagen and Yasmina Reza's Art - have featured not a triangular relationship in the pre dictable sexual sense, but a triangular argument. And now Joe Penhall has come up with a poised three-person play in the Cottesloe which, in a skilfully twisting production by Roger Michell, breaks with the National's recent record of dull new work. It sparkles.

Blue/Orange pits the theories of two psychiatrists against each other and over the head of their sectioned patient. In a finely judged performance, Bill Nighy as a senior consultant at first seems to offer himself - nonchalant, elegant and wry - as a cartoon disciple of R.D. Laing's: it's the human condition to be deranged; most patients should be discharged. Andrew Lincoln - persuasively earnest as a young doctor - is apparently all conscience and caring, arguing for further hospitalisation for the young black patient who thinks that oranges are blue, and Idi Amin is his father. Penhall's achievement is to lightly tweak these positions until they unravel: the consultant's stance has an economic and perhaps a racist aspect; the younger man's nurturing can look like oppression. What seems to be a debate about principles shades into an ambitious competition between the two professionals. Meanwhile, Chiwetel Ejiofor maintains a radiant presence, flashing from charm to alarm.

In the Olivier, things are less happy. The Villains' Opera is to The Beggar's Opera what the Millennium Dome is to St Paul's. Nick Dear's overblown updating of Gay's musical drama has drawn the sting out of the original and lost its charm. There's a glimpse of some good lines: in this neighbourhood, one navel-studded innocent is warned: 'Body piercing is something you do to someone else.' As Mrs Peachum, Beverley Klein is comically vibrant. But Stephen Warbeck's music straggles; the modernising references are lifestyle clichés - Chardonnay, cappuccino, the Groucho. These low-lifes caper to a band got up as as toffs in DJs and bow-ties. You could be back in a Victorian theatre.

webTitle: Failed 'bully' who pushed a teacher too far

fields.headline: Failed 'bully' who pushed a teacher too far
fields.standfirst: Staff at other schools have complained about inspector in suicide case, reports  Martin Bright reports
fields.trailText: The man at the centre of an inquiry into a school inspection that led to the suicide of a female teacher was a failed headmaster who had been struck off the list of registered inspectors.
fields.body:
The man at the centre of an inquiry into a school inspection that led to the suicide of a female teacher was a failed headmaster who had been struck off the list of registered inspectors.

The Observer has discovered that Piers Bilston had his registration withdrawn by the Office for Standards in Education (Ofsted) in June last year after a stream of complaints from schools.

Inquiries also revealed that Bilston became an inspector after a disastrous time as head of a Gloucestershire primary school, where he was forced out by governors after only eight months in the job.

Despite this, he was part of a team that inspected Middlefield Primary in St Neots, Cambridgeshire, in November 1999. A month later, 56-year-old teacher Pamela Relf killed herself and left a note blaming the pressure of work.

Teachers at the school said Bilston singled out Miss Relf for special attention during the inspection and reduced her to tears by saying her lessons 'lacked pace'. Westminster Education Consultants, the private contractor responsible for the inspection, said Bilston was no longer on their books. But last week he was still working as an inspector for other firms.

An Ofsted spokesman confirmed that Bilston was no longer a registered inspector and was not authorised to lead a team into a school. He explained, however, that those deregistered can still be junior members of a team of inspectors.

'Roles of registered inspectors and team inspectors are different. It is quite possible for a person who is not tal ented as a registered inspector to be talented as a team inspector,' he said.

Since the death of the Middlefield Primary School teacher, a stream of headteachers have complained about Bilston.

Ruth Dunkley, head of Crosshall Infants School, St Neots, complained about Bilston 's conduct even though her school was given such a glowing report from Bilston's team in October 1997 that it was lauded by Chief Inspector Chris Woodhead. According to Dunkley, the final report was littered with mistakes and had to be rewritten six times.

'It was professionally very bad. He was an extremely difficult person to work with. I was very surprised to hear he was allowed to continue inspecting after he had been quite rightly de-registered.'

At Corton Primary in Lowestoft, teachers were still suffering the effects of Bilston's visit when a counsellor visited the school a year after an inspection he led in December 1997.

'He picked on the older teachers and described them as past their sell-by date,' said headteacher Vicky Cunnane. She says that Bilston told them not to complain or they would face more inspections.

Last week, Bilston's time as head of Minchinhampton Primary in Gloucestershire in the mid-Nineties was described as 'short and unhappy' by Rod Harris, who succeeded him in April 1996. 'It is a part of our history that we would rather forget,' said Harris. Bilston left there in May 1995 after failing to complete a full year in the job.

Michael Chapman, director of Westminster Education Consultants last night said that his firm closely monitored all aspects of inspection and that Bilston was no longer working for them: 'We have decided not to use him for some time,' he said.

Teacher unions last night asked why it took so long to identify Bilston as a problem.

Peter Smith, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, of which Pamela Relf was a member, questioned the privatised Ofsted inspections system. 'Is it right that a major public service should work on a franchise system? This is effectively a fast food-style operation.'

He criticised the handling of the affair by Woodhead, who last week said there was no need to reform Ofsted in the light of the Relf case. 'I think his initial reaction from Ofsted appeared callous in the very least. His expressions of regret were too little, too late.'

Ofsted said Middlefield will receive the results of an inquiry into its inspection in the next few days. Bilston was last night unavailable for comment.

martin.bright@observer.co.uk
